Abu al-Rayhan Muhammad bin Ahmad al-Biruni. Abu al-Rayhan Muhammad bin Ahmad al-Biruni was one of the major scholars of the fourth and fifth Hijri centuries. He was born on the 2nd of Dhu al-Hijjah in the year 362 AH in a region called Birun, a dependency of Khwarazm [Khwarazm, Uzbekistan/Turkmenistan], hence he was nicknamed Al-Biruni. Neither his lineage, nor his father, nor his grandfather are known. He began receiving the sciences and knowledge circulating in his era thoroughly. What helped broaden the scope of his knowledge were his many travels and his overflowing yearning to acquire sciences, which began with him from a young age. From the beginning, he was interested in issues that were not customary or known among the educated in the Islamic Middle Ages. At the age of twenty, he left his homeland heading for the coasts of the Khazar Sea (Caspian Sea). He was patronized in Jurjan [Gorgan, Iran] by Qabus bin Wushmagir al-Ziyari, to whom he dedicated his first major work, 'The Remaining Signs' (Al-Athar al-Baqiyah). He also had correspondence with Ibn Sina, who was his contemporary. In the year 400 AH, he returned to his homeland, but soon sedition and tribulations stormed through it. When Mahmoud al-Ghaznawi came to occupy Khwarazm in the year 408 AH, he drove some of those therein as captives, including Al-Biruni. Thus, this scholar ended up in Ghazna [Ghazni, Afghanistan], the capital of Mahmoud in Afghanistan. However, Al-Biruni was not a man to rest or let calamities hinder him from his tasks; he began writing while he was on his way to captivity. Among what he wrote at this time was his book known as 'Verification of What is Said About India' (Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind). The name of Al-Biruni became famous in Arabic records in the field of geography and tourism, but what appears from his works is that he was not just a geographer; more accurately, he was an author of extremely vast knowledge, more than just being a geographical scholar. Indeed, the circle of his information was so wide that determining the number of sciences he did not know is easier than the sciences he concerned himself with. Most of his interests and scientific activities revolved around mathematics, astronomy, and related sciences; therefore, his interest in the field of geography was directed towards the mathematical and astronomical aspects of it. His Works: He has several compositions, including: 'Determination of the Coordinates of Positions for the Correction of Distances between Cities' (Tahdid al-Amakin), 'The Mas'udic Canon' (Al-Qanun al-Mas'udi), 'The Remaining Signs' (Al-Athar al-Baqiyah), 'Pharmacy in Medicine' (Al-Saydanah fi al-Tibb), 'Verification of What is Said About India' (Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind), and others.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: Preface. In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. When I began writing the introduction to this book, I thought the matter would be easy. But when I entered the world of Al-Biruni, I found him to be a genius and a raging, surging sea; you stand on its shore unable to perceive its extent, you dive into it unable to fathom its depths, and it enchants you so you cannot return. You seek help from the contradictions written about him in the dates of his news, and thus you become his captive. You will not know his news, attributes, and personality unless you read him and select what you wish from his works. This book, 'The History of India', or 'Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected', is considered a complete, fundamental reference for Indian civilization. He left nothing without writing about it. The orientalist Buhler says about this book: "He wrote it... viewing with the mind of a philosopher and mathematician familiar with the research methods of Aristotle, Plato, Ptolemy, and Galen..." Al-Biruni admits: "The entrances into it exhausted me, despite the eagerness that I uniquely possessed in my days." Al-Biruni intended the book 'History of India' to be for every Muslim wishing to debate with the Indians, so it would be a dialogue of equals. His Name, Title, and Birth: Al-Biruni was born on September 4, 973 AD, near Kath [Kath, Uzbekistan] (also called Kat). It is said that neither his lineage, nor his father, nor his grandfather is known. As for the Persian word 'Birun', it means 'the near one or the outsider'. Which...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...indicates that he was not from the members of a stable society. Perhaps that was due to his family's frequent traveling as merchants, or because they resided outside the city walls to avoid paying taxes. His Teacher: It was Al-Biruni's good fortune that his teacher was the famous astronomer Abu Nasr Mansur bin Ali bin Iraq (a student of Abu al-Wafa), who noticed his genius and trained him, and great affection and trust developed between them. His Life and Era: Al-Biruni grew up in Khwarazm [Khwarazm region]. We will mention a little about the history of this region and the characteristics of its people. When rule stabilized for the Umayyads, Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf in the year 704 (suggested to) the governor of Khurasan residing in Merv [Merv, Turkmenistan], the commander Qutayba bin Muslim, to cross the 'Amu Darya' river [Amu Darya] (Jayhun at the time) and conquer the lands beyond this river, where the armies of Uthman bin Affan had stopped. This river separated Persian-speaking nationalities from Turkic-speaking peoples (Turkmen). After magnificent operations lasting 8 years, Qutayba subjugated the northeastern regions (Bukhara [Bukhara, Uzbekistan], Tashkent [Tashkent, Uzbekistan], and Samarkand [Samarkand, Uzbekistan]) as well as the northwestern region (Khwarazm). Qutayba destroyed many idols and temples. This conquest brought praiseworthy consequences as it paved the way for the growth of great scientific and cultural centers that contributed to the progress of world civilization represented at that time by the Arabs. The reader may recall that geniuses before Al-Zamakhshari and Al-Khwarizmi were born in Khwarazm, and likewise Al-Biruni. Between the Sea of Khwarazm (Aral Sea) and the Caspian Sea to the west, Al-Biruni lived the first half of his life. Two cities were famous in Khwarazm at that time: Kath and Al-Jurjaniyah to the north; both of them...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...are on the Amu Darya river and are known today as Khiva [Khiva, Uzbekistan] and Urgench [Konye-Urgench, Turkmenistan], which are currently in Russia (Soviet Union context). Yaqut says about Khwarazm: Its people are scholars, jurists, intelligent, and wealthy. It is, by my life, a good land. They possess endurance and strength; tallness and bulkiness prevail among them, their heads are broad, and they have wide foreheads. They are accustomed to contentment with little (and the wealthy are like the poor), and we also deduce that they have a strong attachment to their homeland. Al-Maqrizi «1» also tells us: Al-Jurjaniyah is an amazing city, for all its people are soldiers, even the grocer, the butcher, the baker, and the weaver. Its people are people of precise crafts. The practice of theology (Kalam) prevails among them in the markets and alleys; they debate without fanaticism and denounce it from anyone, saying: (You have nothing but victory through argument/proof). Al-Biruni also lived in Jurjan [Gorgan, Iran] on the Caspian Sea, which is (a beautiful city on a great valley, with plains, mountains, sea, immense valleys, and high mountains; if the hunter goes out in the morning, he returns with what he desires). Al-Biruni spent a large period of his life in Ghazni [Ghazni, Afghanistan]. Al-Biruni's era was a dark era due to the sedition that ignited within it, yet it astounds with the scholars it gathered. Here is Ibn Yunus (died 1009), the genius of astronomy and trigonometry who invented the spherical pendulum and used it as a measure of time. And there is Ibn al-Haytham, the genius of mathematics and physics who developed the science of optics and lenses. And there is Ali bin Isa, the most famous surgeon and author in the field of vision and eyes. And let us not forget the philosopher-physician Ibn Sina. These are but a few of the scholars of the East. The historian Sarton, who evaluated the civilizations of nations and enumerated their achievements in his massive book 'Introduction to the History of Science', says that the first half of the eleventh century should...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...be named (The Age of Al-Biruni) because he filled his era and surpassed his contemporaries, soaring so high that no one could catch up with him. As for the political aspect of Al-Biruni's era, it was a stage of humiliation and dissolution for the Abbasid Caliphate. There is no doubt about his displacement and flight from the sedition that struck (Kath) when the governor of Al-Jurjaniyah, the second and large city in Khwarazm, invaded and besieged it, annexing Kath and its surroundings to his authority. Al-Biruni was supporting the governor of his town, so he fled. Al-Biruni says in his book 'The Remaining Signs of Past Centuries' (Al-Athar al-Baqiyah) that he took refuge in Rayy [Rayy/Tehran, Iran] and was in misery and abject poverty, which incited the mockery of an astrologer against him. However, they became friends after that, then the Buyid Prince Fakhr al-Dawla invited him, so he built a large sundial for him on a mountain overlooking Rayy and named it after the Prince. During this period, he worked in many regions around the Caspian Sea. When Muhammad bin Ma'mun, from whom Al-Biruni had fled, died and was succeeded by his son Ali, political conditions and personal animosities had calmed down. So Ali invited him to return to Khwarazm, and he returned due to what we know of Al-Biruni's attachment to his region and his acceptance of Ali's invitation, who attached him to the entourage of his brother, Prince Ibn al-Abbas Ma'mun. After Al-Biruni left Qabus, sedition stormed Jurjan and claimed Qabus's life within a few years. After Ali's death around the year 1009, he was succeeded by Abu al-Abbas, who increased Al-Biruni's burdens by appointing him as a resident political advisor in the palace and a respected ambassador due to the soundness of his mind, the eloquence of his tongue, and the strength of his arguments in persuasion. Al-Biruni speaks with complaint because his observations were affected and his work in the assembly of sciences diminished, saying in the book 'Tahdid...' (Determination...): 'And out of loyalty, I hated worldly states...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...for which the ignorant envied me... then I found little leisure in the days of the martyr Abu al-Abbas.' However, his preoccupations did not dissuade him from finishing what he started in the year 995 regarding measurements of the sun's altitude, especially since his benefactor granted him money to construct a device to observe the solar apogee. He performed this between June 7 and December 7 of the year 1016. In this prosperous period, he designed a 'hemisphere' with a diameter of 5 meters to be a device showing solutions via graphical lines for problems related to geodesy and measuring its properties, such as area, for example. But sedition refused but to sabotage his work; a sedition erupted in which Ma'mun fell victim, and as Al-Biruni says: 'Its consequences resulted in a security that did not allow for returning to the former state and occupying oneself with what represents the highest priority...' Thereupon, Mahmoud al-Ghaznawi took revenge for his covenant and occupied Khwarazm on July 3, 1017. He drove those in the court as captives, including Al-Biruni, in the spring of 1018. Thus, this scholar ended up in Ghazna [Ghazni, Afghanistan], the capital of Mahmoud in Afghanistan. But Al-Biruni was not a man to rest or let calamities hinder him from his tasks; he began writing while he was on his way to captivity. After Mahmoud's death in 1030, he was succeeded by his son Mas'ud, who overcame his brother. Al-Biruni's material conditions improved, and his freedom increased, so he was able to visit his country in the years 1032 and 1034. This period was distinguished by an abundance of authorship in various fields. His Works: In the year 1036, he finished a catalogue of his works up to that date, so it would not be confusing to anyone. He says in the language of one confident and certain of the importance of his works: 'You should know regarding what I have enumerated of my books, including what I did in my youth, and my knowledge of its art increased after that, yet I did not discard it or deem it base, for they are all my sons, and the most constitute the son and his enchanting poetry.' Then he lists the names of the books 'which happened for me to do by the year 427 AH, when my age reached 65 lunar years and 63 solar years.' You know that he wrote 180 works or more; we will summarize the discussion on some of them. 'The Book of the Determination of Coordinates of Positions for the Correction of Distances between Cities' (Kitab Tahdid al-Amakin...), he finished composing it on 28...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...August 1025. The book is a valuable volume for measuring longitude and latitude and the location of countries on the globe. 'The Mas'udic Canon' (Kitab al-Qanun al-Mas'udi) is a massive encyclopedia summarizing Al-Biruni's rules and innovations; within the encyclopedia is a large treasury of the history of nations and their calendars from the 'Day of Adam' to the day of Al-Biruni, so let whoever wishes consult it. His Death: In the year 1040, Mas'ud's commanders revolted and slaughtered the Prince. He was succeeded by his son (Mawdud), to whom he presented his last work, 'Pharmacy in Medicine' (Al-Saydanah fi al-Tibb). In this book, he mentions that he exceeded eighty years and his hearing and sight had weakened. His news diminishes after the year 1048, but what is certain from his words in the book 'Pharmacy in Medicine' is that he was alive that year, and perhaps he died around 1050. Some of His Feats: He possessed determination that made him perform calculations and solve equations that are not handled today except by electronic brains. He chose the most difficult problems and solved them; these geometric and mathematical problems are called 'Al-Biruni's problems'. He presented a simple method for drawing geometric shapes of third-dimension tools, like spherical bodies, on paper. Among his most important astronomical works is his invention of a special theory for estimating the 'approximate ratio' (Pi) necessary for calculating the areas and circumferences of circles. He managed to estimate the circumference of the Earth and its diameter. Al-Biruni found the value of the approximate ratio to be 3.14174, and the correct one is 3.14159. He is, therefore, the inventor of the rule known as Al-Biruni's Rule, which is a mathematical equation used to calculate the Earth's radius based on knowing its circumference. The equation is simple, like all great rules... Nallino says: '...Al-Biruni's equation for measuring the Earth's circumference is one of the glorious, transmitted scientific works.' He designed a simple device for measuring...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...the specific gravity (density) of some metals and gems, and his results testify for him: Gold 19.26, and this is what it is today. He says that gold was named so (Dhahab) 'because it is quick to leave (Dhahab) and slow to return to its owners!' He is the first to use the unit (ratio of one) for the known ratios in trigonometry, and this usage exists to this day. His works, with few exceptions, possess a clear style with no ambiguity or obscurity, even if not smooth. He loves brevity, so he says he writes '...for he who has knowledge and diligence, and loves science... and whoever is not of this description, I do not care if he understands or does not understand.' The West Resurrects Him: The orientalist Nicholas de Khanikoff was the first to alert Europe to Al-Biruni in 1866. Soon books flowed: 'Al-Biruni's Trigonometry', 'Al-Biruni's Geography'. Among the greatest editors was the German Sachau, who translated into German and English two massive books ('The Remaining Signs of Past Centuries' in 1879 and 'The History of India' in 1888). Sachau says: '...Al-Biruni is the greatest intellect that appeared in history...' After experts reviewed his books on India, one of them said: '...a unique attempt by a believing man studying with integrity and detachment a pagan civilization... from a historical perspective, this study became the greatest scientific phenomenon in the history of Islam... and everything written before is like children's games...' Therefore, the Indians became interested in Al-Biruni, and in 1913 a mission was established to collect his works, and likewise the Persians. As soon as the second half of the twentieth century entered, festivals abounded...

text: ...and books, and nations began to dispute the honor of affiliation with him, counting him among their sons. Russia names a university and a city after him and erects a statue for him at Moscow University. India, Iran, and Afghanistan honor him. Universities in America, Germany, and UNESCO issue a catalog of Arab feats, among which are his works. Even Turkey wants him, because they think that Al-Biruni is a descendant of the Turks who spread between the Aral and Caspian seas. Ali Safa.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: Author's Introduction. In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. The saying of the speaker, 'Hearsay is not like eye-witnessing,' is indeed true because eye-witnessing is the perception by the eye of the beholder of the beheld at the time of its existence and in the place of its occurrence. Were it not for the afflictions attached to reports, their virtue would surpass eye-witnessing and viewing due to the latter's limitation to existence which does not exceed the moments of time, while reports encompass that, what came before it of past times, and what comes after it of future times, such that the report covers both the existent and the nonexistent together. Writing is a type of it (reporting) that is almost nobler than others; for where would we get knowledge of the news of nations were it not for the enduring traces of the pen? Furthermore, the report about a possible existent thing, in customary practice, corresponds to truth and falsehood in a single form. Both are attached to it from the side of the reporters due to the disparity of intentions and the prevalence of conflict and dispute among nations. For there is a reporter of a false matter who intends thereby himself, aggrandizing his kind because it is under him; or he intends it to disparage the opposite of his kind because of his success in it through his will. It is known that both of these are from the motives of blameworthy desire and anger. And there is a reporter of falsehood regarding a class he loves out of gratitude, or hates out of resentment, and this is close to the first, for the motive for his action is from the motives of love and overcoming. And there is a reporter of it drawing near to a benefit due to baseness of nature, or...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...protecting against an evil out of cowardice and fear. And there is a reporter of it by nature, as if he is compelled to it, unable to do otherwise, and that is from the motives of wickedness and the evil of the hidden parts of nature. And there is a reporter of it out of ignorance; he is the imitator of reporters, even if they are many in total or sequential group after group. He is a delusion of intermediaries between the listener and the first intentional one. If they are dropped from the middle, that first one remains one of those we enumerated as fabricators. The one who avoids lying and adheres to truth is praised and commended even by the liar, let alone others. It has been said: 'Speak the truth even if against yourselves.' And the Messiah, peace be upon him, said in the Gospel what means this: 'Do not mind the assault of kings in speaking the truth before them, for they own nothing of you but the body, but as for the soul, they have no hand over it.' This from him is a command for true courage. For the character that the common people think is courage—when they see advancement into battles and recklessness in entering perils—is a type of it. But its highest genus over its types is the disdain for death, whether it be in speech or in action. And just as justice is pleasing in natures, loved for itself, desired for its beauty, likewise is truthfulness, except for one who has not tasted its sweetness or knew it but avoided it, like the one asked among those known for lying: 'Have you ever told the truth?' His answer: 'Were it not that I fear speaking the truth, I would have said no.' For he is the deviator from justice, the preferring of tyranny, false testimony, betrayal of trust, usurpation of properties by fraud and theft, and all else by which the corruption of the world and creation occurs. I had found the Master Abu Sahl Abd al-Mun'im bin Ali bin Nuh al-Tiflisi [Tbilisi, Georgia], may Allah support him, finding ugly the intent of the narrator in his book about the Mu'tazilites to disparage them in their saying: 'Allah the Almighty is Knowing by His Essence.' His expression about it in the narration was that they say 'Allah has no knowledge,' imagining to the commoners of his people that they attribute ignorance to Him—Exalted and Holy is He above that and above the attributes not befitting Him...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...so I informed him that this is a method from which he who intends to narrate about dissenters and adversaries is rarely free. Furthermore, it is more apparent regarding schools of thought that are united by one religion and creed due to their proximity and mixing, and more hidden regarding separate religions, especially those that do not share a root or branch, due to their distance and the obscurity of the path to knowing them. What is available to us of books on sects and what has been produced on opinions and religions contains nothing but the likes of this. Whoever does not know the reality of the matter regarding them scoops from them what does not benefit him with their people except shame if virtue shakes his shoulder, or persistence and obstinacy if vice slackens in him. Whoever knows the reality of the matter, his utmost affair is to treat them as evening tales and myths, listening to them for distraction and amusement, not for believing them and conviction. The example in the content of the speech fell upon the religions of India and their schools of thought. I pointed out that most of what is written in books is attributed falsely, and some of it is copied from others, gathered and mixed, not refined according to their opinion nor pruned. I did not find among the authors of books on sects anyone who intended bare narration without bias or sycophancy except Abu al-Abbas al-Iranshahri, if he was not involved in any of the religions but rather unique in an invention of his own to which he invited. He did well in narrating what the Jews and Christians are upon and what the Torah and Gospel contain, and he was thorough in mentioning Manichaeism and what is in their books regarding the news of extinct sects. But when he reached the sect of India and the Shamaniyya (Buddhists/Sramanas), his arrow missed the target, and he swerved at the end to the book of Zarqan, copying what was in it into his book. What he did not copy from it, it is as if it was heard from the commoners of these two groups. When the Master, may Allah support him, re-examined the books and found the matter in them as described, he was eager for the editing of what I knew from their side to be an aid for whoever wanted to refute them and a treasure for whoever sought to interact with them. He asked for that, so I did it, not slandering the adversary nor refraining from narrating his speech even if it diverged from the truth and its hearing was atrocious to its people (Muslims), for it is his belief and he is more insightful about it. The book is not a book of argumentation and debate such that I would use in it...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah (Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected)
text: By presenting the arguments of the opponents and contradicting those among them who deviate from the truth. Rather, it is a book of narration, so I have presented the speech of the Indians as it is, and I have added to it what the Greeks have of the like, to define the closeness between them. For their philosophers, even if they strove for verification, did not exit, in what connects to their common people, from the symbols of their creed and the postulates of their law. I do not mention with their speech the speech of others, unless it is for the Sufis or one of the sects of the Christians, due to the closeness of the matter between all of them regarding incarnation and union. I had translated into Arabic two books: one of them on the principles and the description of existing things, named "Sank" [Samkhya], and the other on the liberation of the soul from the fetters of the body, known as "Patanjal" [Patanjali/Yoga Sutras]. In them are most of the foundations upon which the orbit of their belief revolves, excluding the branches of their laws. I hope that this will substitute for them and for others in the reporting and lead to the encompassing of the objective, by the will of Allah.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: A - Mentioning the conditions of the Indians and establishing them before what we intend of narrating about them: We must visualize, before our objective, the conditions due to which it is difficult to see through the affairs of the Indians. Either the matter will become easy by knowing them, or the excuse for it will be paved. That is because separation hides what connection reveals, and for it, between us, there are causes: Among them is that the people differ from us in everything that nations share, and the first of it is the language. Even if nations differ by the like of it, when one seeks it to remove the difference, that is not easy because it is in itself long and wide, resembling Arabic. One thing in it is named by several names, original and derived, and one name applies to several named things, necessitating, in objectives, an increase of descriptions, as no one distinguishes between them except one with intelligence for the placement of speech and the analogy of meaning backwards and forwards. They take pride in that, just as others take pride in it, while in reality, it is a defect in the language. Then it is divided into a vulgar one from which no one benefits except the commoners, and a guarded eloquent one that relates to inflections, etymology, and the subtleties of grammar and rhetoric, to which no one returns except the skilled scholars. Then it is composed of letters, some of which do not match the letters of Arabic and Persian, nor do they resemble them. Rather, our tongues and uvulas hardly submit to producing them according to the reality of their outlets, nor do our ears hear them with distinction from their counterparts and likenesses, nor do our hands in writing [succeed] in imitating them. Thus, it becomes difficult to establish anything of their language in our script due to what we are compelled to of artifices to record it by changing points and signs and restricting it with diacritics that are either famous or devised. This is alongside the lack of care of the copyists for it and their lack of concern for correction and collation, until the effort is lost...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...and the book becomes corrupted in one transmission or two transmissions, becoming what contains a new language to which no one, inside or outside of both nations, can find guidance. It suffices you as a notification that we might pick up a name from their mouths and strive to authenticate it, then if we repeated it to them, they would hardly recognize it except with effort. In their language, as in other languages of the non-Arabs, two quiescent letters and three combine, which is what our companions call moving with a hidden vowel. It is difficult for us to utter most of their words and names because they begin with quiescent letters. Their books in the sciences, along with that, are arranged in types of meter according to their taste. They intended by that their preservation in their state and estimation, and the quick appearance of corruption in them when addition and deletion occur, so that memorization becomes easy, for their reliance is on it rather than the written. It is known that poetry is not free from a mixture of affectation to equalize the meters, correct the breakage, and mend the deficiency, and it necessitates the multiplication of phrases, which is one of the causes for the instability of names regarding their named objects. So this is one of the causes that make it difficult to understand what they have. Among them is that they differ from us in religion, a total difference. Nothing of acknowledgment of what they have occurs from us, nor [do they acknowledge] anything of what we have. Despite the lack of dispute in the majority of sects among them except for argumentation and speech without harming «1» the soul or body or condition, they are not on this path with those other than them. They call them "Malij" [Mleccha], which is the impure. They do not permit mixing with him in marriage and kinship, or sitting and eating and drinking, due to impurity. They deem impure what his water and fire have touched, and upon these two is the orbit of livelihood. Then there is no hope for correcting that by a trick, just as the impure is purified by moving to the state of purity, for it is not permitted for them to accept one who is not of them if he desires them or inclines to their religion. This is among what breaks every connection and necessitates the most severe separation. Among them is that they differ from us in customs and habits, until they almost frighten their children with us, our dress, and our appearances. They attribute devilry to us, and to it [they attribute] the opposite of what is obligatory, even though this attribution is absolute for us and common between us and indeed between nations in their entirety. My knowledge of some of them is that he resents us because one of their kings perished at the hands of an enemy...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...of his who sought him from our land and left a fetus. He became king after him and was named "Sabkar" «1». When he matured, he asked his mother about the condition of his father, so she told him the story. He became angry about it and went out from his land to the land of the enemy and exacted his share from the nations until he became weary of slaughter and inflicting damage. So he compelled the survivors to this dressing in our dress as a humiliation for them and a punishment. She thanked his deed when she heard it, as he did not brand us with becoming Indian and moving to their customs. What increased the aversion and difference is that the sect known as the Shamaniyya [Buddhists], despite the intensity of hatred from them towards the Brahmins, are closer to the Indians than others. Khurasan, Fars [Iran], Iraq [Iraq], and Mosul [Iraq] up to the borders of al-Sham [Syria] were in ancient times upon their religion until Zoroaster appeared from Azerbaijan [Azerbaijan] and called to Magianism [Zoroastrianism] in Balkh [Balkh, Afghanistan]. His call gained currency «2» with Gushtasp, and his son Isfandiyar undertook spreading it in the lands of the East and the West by force and by peace. He erected Fire Temples from China [China] to Rum [Byzantium]. Then the kings after him purified Fars and Iraq for their creed, so the "Shamaniyya" departed from it to the east of Balkh. The Magians remain until now in the land of India and are called there "Mag" [Maga Brahmins]. This was the beginning of the aversion from the side of Khurasan among them, until Islam came and the state of the Persians went. The raiding of their land increased their estrangement when Muhammad bin al-Qasim bin al-Munabbih entered the land of Sindh [Pakistan] from the regions of Sijistan [Sistan, Iran/Afghanistan] and conquered the city of "Bamhanwa" and named it "Mansura" [near Shahdadpur, Pakistan], and the city of "Mulistan" and named it "Ma'mura" [Multan, Pakistan]. He penetrated deep into the lands of India to the city of "Kannauj" [Kannauj, India] and trod the land of al-Qandahar [Gandhara, Pakistan/Afghanistan] and the borders of Kashmir [Kashmir, India/Pakistan], returning, fighting at times and making peace at others, and leaving the people upon their creed except for those who were satisfied with transfer «3» from it. This planted grudges in their hearts, even if no one of the raiders crossed the borders of Kabul [Kabul, Afghanistan] and the water of the Sindh [Indus River] after him until the days of the Turks, when they took possession in Ghazna [Ghazni, Afghanistan] in the days of the Samanids. The state fell to Nasir al-Din Subuktigin, so he preferred raiding and titled himself with it. He paved for those after him the paths in weakening the side of India, which Yamin al-Dawla Mahmud [of Ghazni], may Allah have mercy on them both, treaded for thirty odd years. He annihilated their greenery (prosperity) and performed wonders in...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...their lands by which they became scattered dust and a famous tale. Their scattered remnants «1» remained at the utmost aversion and distance from the Muslims. Rather, that was the cause of the erasure of their sciences from the conquered borders and their departure to where the hand does not reach yet, such as Kashmir [Kashmir, India/Pakistan] and Banarasi [Varanasi, India] and their likes, along with the strengthening of the separation in them from all foreigners by the requirement of politics and religion. After that, there are causes he mentioned like defamation of them, but they are evident «2» in their morals, not hidden. Foolishness is a disease that has no cure. That is because they believe regarding the earth that it is their earth, and regarding people that they are their race, and regarding kings that they are their leaders, and regarding religion that it is their creed, and regarding science that it is what they have. They become haughty, arrogant «3», and impressed with themselves, so they are ignorant. In their nature is stinginess with what they know and excessive guarding of it from those not worthy of it among them, so how about from others? Furthermore, they do not think that there are other than their countries on earth, or other than their inhabitants among people, or that creation has knowledge other than theirs. Such that if they were told of knowledge or a scholar in Khurasan and Fars [Iran], they would deem the informant ignorant and would not believe him due to the mentioned affliction. If they had traveled and mixed with others, they would have returned from their opinion. However, their ancients were not of this degree of negligence. Thus, "Barahmihir" [Varahamihira], one of their virtuous ones, when he commands the honoring of the Brahmins, says: "Indeed the Greeks, even if they are impure, when they graduated in the sciences and excelled «4» in them over others, honoring them became obligatory. So what might we say about the Brahmin if he gathers the honor of knowledge to his purity?" They used to acknowledge to the Greeks that what they were given of knowledge was weightier than their share of it. It suffices you as a proof of it from one who praises himself while he greets you: I used to stand before their astrologers in the position of the student to the master due to my foreignness among them and my falling short of what they are in of their conventions. When I was guided a little to them, I began to stop them on the causes and point to something of the proofs and hint to them the true methods in calculations. So they flocked to me...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...marveling and rushing to benefit, asking: "Whom have you seen of the Indians that you took from?" While I show them their measure and elevate myself above their side, disdaining. They almost attributed me to sorcery, and they did not describe me to their elders in their language except as the Sea [Bahr/Sagara], and water turns sour until vinegar becomes scarce «1». This is the picture of the situation. The entries into it have exhausted me, despite my eagerness in which I was unique in my days, and my spending of what was possible without being stingy on it in collecting their books from the presumed places, and summoning those who are guided to them from the hiding places. Who else «2» has the like of that, except one who is provided from the success of Allah what I was denied in ability for movements, in which I was incapacitated from «3» grasping and spreading in commanding and forbidding; its side was folded away from me. Thanks be to Allah for what sufficed of it. I say: Indeed the Greeks in the days of Ignorance (Jahiliyyah) before the appearance of Christianity were upon the like of what the Indians are upon of belief. Their elite in speculation is close to their elite, and their commoners in the worship of idols are like their commoners. For this reason, I cite the speech of some of them regarding others due to the agreement and the closeness of the two matters, not for correction, for what is other than the Truth is deviating, and disbelief is one creed because of the deviation from it. However, the Greeks were successful with the philosophers who were in their region, until they refined for them the special principles excluding the general ones, because the utmost of the elite is following research and speculation, and the utmost of the commoners is recklessness and stubbornness if they are free from fear and awe. Socrates indicates that when he opposed the general populace of his people in the worship of idols and deviated from naming the stars "gods" in his utterance. How the eleven judges of the people of Athens agreed on the verdict to kill him without the twelfth, until he fulfilled his vow (died) not returning from the truth. The Indians did not have the likes of them who refined the sciences. So you hardly find for them a special speech for that except in the utmost disorder and bad arrangement, and mixed at its end with the superstitions of the commoners of multiplying the number and extending the periods and of the postulates of the creed in which its people find opposition atrocious. For its sake, imitation (Taqlid) takes over them. Due to it, I say regarding what is my subject from them that I do not «4» liken what is in their books of...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...calculation and the type of mathematics except to shells mixed with pottery «1», or pearls mixed with dung, or crystal combined with pebbles. The two types are equal to them, as there is no example for them of the ascents of proof. I, in most of what I will present from their side, am a narrator, not a critic, except out of apparent necessity. I mention from the names and conventions in their language what must be mentioned once, necessitated by definition. Then if it is a derivative that can be transferred in Arabic to its meaning, I did not lean from it to another unless it is lighter in usage in Hindi, so we use it after the utmost authentication of it in writing. Or if it was original and very famous, then [we use it] after pointing to its meaning. And if it has a famous name with us, then the matter is easy in it. It is difficult in what we intended to follow the geometrical path in referring to the past and not the future, but mention of an unknown might come in some chapters, and its explanation is coming in that which follows it. And Allah is the Grantor of success.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
B - Mentioning their belief in Allah, Glory be to Him
The belief of the elite and the commoners differs in every nation only because the nature of the elite disputes the intelligible and intends verification in the principles, while the nature of the commoners stops at the sensed and is satisfied with the branches and does not desire precision, especially in what opinions have varied in and whims have not agreed upon. The belief of the Indians in Allah, Glory be to Him, is that He is the One, the Eternal, without beginning or end, the Chooser in His action, the Capable, the Wise, the Living, the Life-Giver, the Ruler, the Preserver, the Unique in His kingdom beyond opposites and peers, resembling nothing and nothing resembling Him. Let us present something of their books on that so that our narration is not like a mere heard thing. The questioner said in the book of "Patanjal" [Yoga Sutras]: "Who is this worshipped one, the worship of whom attains success?" The answerer said: "He is the One self-sufficient in His primacy «1» and His oneness from an action for a reward for it with a comfort hoped for and expected or a hardship feared and guarded against. And [He is] the Innocent of thoughts due to His transcendence above hated opposites and loved peers. And the Knowing in His essence eternally, since emergent knowledge is for what was not known. And ignorance is not applicable to Him at any time or condition." Then the questioner says after that: "So does He have attributes other than what you mentioned?" And the answerer says: "He has complete height in power, not place, for He is too great to be located. He is the Pure Complete Good which every existent yearns for. He is the Knowledge pure...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...from the filth of forgetfulness and ignorance." The questioner said: "Do you describe Him with speech or not?" The answerer said: "If He is knowing, He is inevitably speaking." The questioner said: "If He is speaking because of His knowledge, then what is the difference between Him and the wise scholars who spoke because of their sciences?" The answerer said: "The difference between them is time, for they learned in it and spoke after they were not knowing nor speaking, and they transferred their sciences by speech to others. So their speech and their benefiting are in time. Since divine matters have no connection with time, Allah, Glory be to Him, is Knowing, Speaking in eternity. He is the one who spoke to 'Brahm' [Brahma] and others of the ancients in various ways. Among them is one to whom He cast a book, and among them is one to whom He opened a door to a mediator, and among them is one to whom He revealed, so he attained by thought what He poured upon him." The questioner said: "So from where does He have this knowledge?" The answerer said: "His knowledge is in its state in eternity. Since He was never ignorant, His essence is knowing; He did not acquire knowledge He did not have." As He said in the "Bed" [Veda] which He revealed to Brahm: "Praise and extol Him who spoke the Veda and was before the Veda." The questioner said: "How do you worship One whom sensation does not perceive?" The answerer said: "His naming establishes His I-ness (existence), for news is only about a thing, and the name is only for a named. Even if He is absent from the senses so they did not perceive Him, the soul has intellect of Him and thought has encompassed His attributes. This is His pure worship, and by persisting in it, happiness is attained." This is their speech in this famous book. And in the book "Gita" [Bhagavad Gita], which is a part of the book "Bharat" [Mahabharata], in what transpired between "Basdiv" [Vasudeva/Krishna] «1» and "Arjun" [Arjuna]: "I am the All without a beginning by birth or «2» an end by death. I do not intend by my action a reward, nor am I particular to a class over another for friendship or enmity. I have given each of my creation his need in his action. So whoever knows me by this attribute and imitates me in distancing greed from work, his bond is untied and his salvation and liberation become easy." This is as was said in the definition of philosophy: It is imitating Allah as much as possible. He said in this book: "Greed in needs drives most people to Allah. If you verified the matter with them, you would find them in a place far distant from knowing Him...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...because Allah is not apparent to everyone such that he perceives Him with his senses; therefore they were ignorant of Him. Among them are those who did not go beyond the sensibles regarding Him. And among them are those who, when they went beyond them, stopped at the natural things. They did not know that above them is One who did not beget and was not begotten, and the knowledge of no one has encompassed other than «1» His I-ness, while He encompasses everything in knowledge." The speech of the Indians differs regarding the meaning of action. Whoever attributes it to Him, it is from the perspective of the more general cause, because since the subsistence of the agents is «2» by Him, He is the cause of their action, so it is His action through their mediation. And whoever attributes it to other than Him, it is from the perspective of the lower existence. In the book "Sank" [Samkhya], the ascetic said: "Is there a difference regarding the action and the agent or not?" The sage said: "A group has said that the Soul [Purusha] is not active and Matter is not living, so Allah the Self-Sufficient is the one who joins them and separates; so He is the Agent, and the action occurs from His side by moving them just as the capable living moves the incapable dead." Others said: "Their meeting is by nature, for thus the custom has run in every decaying growing thing." Others said: "The agent is the Soul because in the 'Bed' [Veda] is that every existent is from 'Purush' [Purusha]." Others said: "The agent is Time, for the world is tied to it like the tying of a sheep with a rope fastened to it, so that its movement is according to its attraction and relaxation." Others said: "Action is nothing but the reward for the preceding work." All these opinions are deviating from the correct. The truth in it is that all action belongs to Matter [Prakriti], because it is the one that binds, circulates in forms, and releases. So it is the Agent, and all that is beneath it are helpers to it in completing the action. Due to the Soul's emptiness of different powers, it is not active. This is the saying of their elite regarding Allah the Exalted, and they call Him "Ishfar" [Ishvara], meaning the Self-Sufficient Generous who gives and does not take, because they saw His unity as the pure one, and the unity of what is other than Him in any way is multiplied. They saw His existence as real because the subsistence of existents is by Him. It is not impossible to imagine 'is not' in them with 'is' [Ays/Being] «3» in Him, just as it is impossible to imagine 'is not' in Him with 'is' in them. Then if we go beyond the class of the elite of the Indians to their commoners, the sayings differ among them and might become ugly just as...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...the like of it is found in other sects, and indeed in Islam, of anthropomorphism and compulsion and forbidding speculation into anything and the likes of that which necessitates «1» refinement «1». An example is that some of their elite call Allah the Exalted a "Point" to absolve Him by it from the attributes of bodies. Then their commoner reads that and thinks that he magnified Him by dimunition, and his understanding does not reach with it to the verification of the point. So he crosses from the ugliness of anthropomorphism and limitation by magnification to his saying: He is twelve fingers long in a width of ten fingers—Exalted is He above limitation and numbering. And like what we narrated of His encompassing of the whole so that no hidden thing is hidden from Him, so their commoner thinks that encompassing is by sight, and sight is by the eye, and two eyes are better than one-eyedness, so he describes Him with a thousand eyes as an expression of the perfection of knowledge. The likes of these hideous superstitions exist among them, especially in the classes for whom engaging in knowledge is not permitted, as the mention of them will come in its place.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
C - Mentioning their belief in Intelligible and Sensible Beings
Indeed, the ancient Greeks, before the rise of wisdom among them by the seven named "Pillars of Wisdom"—and they are: A. "Solon" [Solon] of Athens, B. "Bios" [Bias] of Priene, C. "Faryandrus" [Periander] of Corinth, D. "Thales" [Thales] of Miletus, E. "Kilon" [Chilon] of Lacedaemon «1», "Fitiqus [Pittacus] of Lesbos" «2» F., and "Qilibulus [Cleobulus] of Lindos"—and [before] philosophy was refined among them by those who grew up after them, were upon the like of the doctrine of the Indians. There were among them those who held that all things are one thing. Then [there were] those who spoke in that of latency (Kumun), and those of potentiality (Quwwah), and that man, for example, is not superior to the stone and the inanimate object except by proximity to the First Cause in rank, otherwise he is it. And among them were those who saw real existence for the First Cause only, due to Its self-sufficiency in it and the need of other than It for It; and that whatever is in need of another for existence, its existence is like imagination, not real, and the Real is the First One only. This is the opinion of the Sufiyya [Sufis], and they are the sages (Hukama), for "Sof" in Greek is wisdom, and by it the philosopher is named "Pilasopa" [Philosophos], meaning lover of wisdom. When a group in Islam went to something close to their opinion, they were named by their name, but some did not know the title, so they attributed them for reliance (Tawakkul) to the "Suffah" (bench/ledge) and that they were its companions in the era of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. Then it was misspelled after that and made from "Suf" (wool) of goats. Abu al-Fath al-Busti turned away from that, the best turning away, in his saying:

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
People disputed about the Sufi and differed ... of old, and thought it derived from al-Suf (wool).
I do not attribute this name to other than a youth ... who is pure (Safi), so he is Sufi, until he was titled the Sufi.
Likewise, they went to the view that the Existent is one thing, and that the First Cause appears in it in different forms and Its power settles in parts of it in divergent states necessitating difference along with union. There were among them those who said: Indeed the one who turns completely to the First Cause, imitating It to the limit of his possibility, unites with It upon abandoning intermediaries and shedding attachments and hindrances. These are opinions the Sufis go to due to the similarity of the subject. They used to see in souls and spirits that they are subsisting by themselves before incarnation in bodies, numbered and marshaled, recognizing each other and denying each other; and that they acquire in bodies, by choice, what they attain by it, after separating from bodies, the power over the disposals of the world. Therefore, they called them "gods" (Alihah) and built temples in their names and offered sacrifices to them. As Galen says in the book "Exhortation to Learning the Arts": The virtuous among people only merited the honor they attained until they joined the deified ones (Mutallihin) because of the excellence of their treatment of the arts, not by athleticism, wrestling, and throwing the ball. Of that is that "Asqalibius" [Asclepius] and "Diyonusius" [Dionysus], whether they were in the past two humans then they became deified, or they were from the beginning of their affair deified, indeed they only merited the greatest honor because one of them taught people medicine and the other taught them the art of vineyards. Galen said in his commentary on the Covenants of Hippocrates: As for the sacrifices in the name of "Asqalibius," we have never heard that anyone offered a goat to him, because the spinning of its hair is not easy and increasing its meat causes epilepsy due to the badness of its chyme. Rather, they offer roosters as "Abuqrat" [Hippocrates] «1» offered them, for this divine man acquired for people the art of medicine, and it is better than what "Diyonusius" extracted, meaning wine, and "Dhimitar" [Demeter], meaning the grains from which bread is taken; therefore grains are named by the name of this «2» [goddess], and the vine tree by the name of this [god]. And he said...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...Plato in "Timaeus": "The gods whom the Hanifs (pagans) name 'gods' because they do not die, and they name Allah the 'First God', are the angels." Then he said: "Indeed Allah said to the gods, 'You are not in yourselves other than capable of corruption at all. Rather, you will not corrupt by death because you attained from My will, at the time of My originating you, the firmest knot'." And he said in it in another place: "Allah is by the singular number, not gods by the multiplied number." So according to them, based on what appears from their sayings, the name of gods applies from the perspective of generality to every majestic, noble thing. This is found likewise among many nations, until they cross «1» with it to mountains and seas and the likes. And it applies from the perspective of specificity to the First Cause, to the angels, to their souls «2», and to another type which Plato calls "al-Sakinat" (Sekina/Divine Presence?), and the expression of the translators did not reach a complete definition of it, so we received from it the name without the meaning. Yahya al-Nahwi [John Philoponus] said in his refutation of "Abruqlus" [Proclus]: "The Greeks used to apply the name of 'gods' to the sensed bodies in the sky, as do many of the non-Arabs. Then when they thought about the intelligible substances, they applied this name to them." So by necessity, it is known that the meaning of deification returns to what is held regarding the angels. That is in the explicit speech of Galen in that book: "If the matter is true that 'Asqalibius' was in the past a human, then Allah qualified him because He made him an angel of the angels, then what is other than that is delirium." And in another place in it, he says: "Indeed Allah said to 'Luvarghus' [Lycurgus] «3», 'I am at your door between two matters: between naming you a human and naming you an angel, and to this I incline regarding you'." However, among words are those which are ugly in one religion but not another, and allowed «4» by one language and refused «5» by another. Among them is the word of deification (Ta'alluh) in the religion of Islam, for if we consider it in the language of the Arabs, we find all names by which the Pure Truth is named applicable...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...to others in some way, except the name "Allah", for it is specific to Him, a specificity about which it was said that it is His Greatest Name. If we contemplate it in Hebrew and Syriac, the two [languages] in which are the books revealed before the Qur'an, we find "al-Rabb" (The Lord) in the Torah and what follows it of the books of the prophets counted in its whole parallel to "Allah" in Arabic, not applied to anyone by annexation like 'lord of the house' and 'lord of wealth'. And we find "al-Ilah" (The God) in them parallel to "al-Rabb" in Arabic. It was mentioned in them: Indeed the sons of "Elohim" came down to the daughters of men before the Flood and mixed with them. And it is mentioned in the book of "Ayyub al-Siddiq" [Job the Righteous]: Indeed Satan entered with the sons of "Elohim" to their gathering. And in the Torah of Musa [Moses], the saying of the Lord to him: "I have made you a god to Pharaoh." And in the eighty-second Psalm of the Psalms of Dawud [David]: "Indeed Allah stood in the congregation of the gods," meaning the angels. He named in the Torah the idols "strange gods." Were it not that the Torah prohibited the worship of everything other than Allah and the prostration to idols, indeed mentioning them at all and their crossing the mind, it would have been imaginable from this word that what is commanded is the rejection of the strange gods, excluding those that are not Hebrew «1». The nations that were around the land of Palestine are those who were upon the religion of the Greeks in the worship of idols. The Children of Israel did not cease disobeying Allah by worshiping the idol "Ba'ala" [Baal] and the idol "Astaruth" [Ashtoreth] which belongs to Venus. So deification in the sense of possession (kingship) according to those people applied to the angels, and to the souls that became powerful, and by metaphor to the images made in the names of their bodies, and by figure of speech to the kings and the great ones. Likewise is the name of "Fatherhood" and "Prophethood", for Islam does not allow them, as 'Walad' (child) and 'Ibn' (son) in Arabic are close in meaning, and what is beyond the child of parents and birth is negated from the meanings of Lordship. What is other than the language of the Arabs allows for that greatly, so that the address in it by 'Father' is close to the address by 'Master'. It is known what the Christians are upon regarding that, such that he who does not speak of the Father and the Son is outside the whole of their sect. The 'Son' returns to Isa [Jesus] in the sense of specificity and preference, and it is not limited to him but goes beyond him to others. For he is the one who orders his disciples...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...in supplication to say: "O our Father who is in heaven." And he informs them in announcing his death to them that he is going to his Father and their Father. He explains that by his saying in most of his speech about himself: that he is the Son of Man. The Christians are not alone on this, but the Jews share with them, for in the Book of Kings: Indeed Allah the Exalted consoled Dawud [David] regarding his son born to him from the wife of "Uriya" [Uriah] and promised him a son from her whom He would adopt. If it is permitted by adoption in Hebrew that Sulayman [Solomon] be a son, it is permitted that the adopter be a father. The "Mannaniyya" [Manichaeans] resemble the Christians among the People of the Book. Their leader "Mani" says in this meaning in the book "Kanz al-Ahya" (Treasure of the Living): Indeed the luminous hosts are called first-borns, virgins, fathers, mothers, sons, brothers, and sisters, according to what is customary in the book of the messengers. In the country of joy, there is neither male nor female, nor organs of copulation. All of them appear in living bodies and forms of divinity. They do not differ by weakness and strength, nor length and shortness, nor image and view, like lamps resembling each other lit from one lamp. The material of their food is one. The cause of that naming is only the mutual suffering «1» of the two kingdoms. When the lower dark one rose from its depth and the high luminous kingdom saw them as pairs, males and females, it formed its sons departing to war from the apparent in images like that, so it set up «2» every genus opposite its genus. The elite of the Indians refuse these descriptions, while their commoners and everyone in the branches of the creed are excessive in applying them. They transgress the mentioned measure to wife, son, daughter, pregnancy, giving birth, and other natural conditions, and they do not refrain from recklessness in mentioning them. There is no consideration for them. Their schools of thought, even if they are many, their pole is what the Brahmins are upon, and they have been candidates for its preservation and establishment. It is what we narrate. We say: They hold regarding the Existent that it is one thing, according to the like of what preceded. For "Basdiv" [Vasudeva] says in the book known as "Gita": "As for verification, all things are divine, because 'Bishn' [Vishnu] made himself earth for the animal to settle...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...upon, and made himself water to nourish them, and made himself fire and wind to grow them and raise them, and made himself a heart for every one of them. He granted remembrance and knowledge and their two opposites, as is mentioned in 'Bed' [Veda]." How similar is the saying of the author of the book "Balinas" [Apollonius] regarding the causes of things to this, as if it is taken from it: "Indeed in all people is a divine power by which things are intellectually perceived by the essence and by other than the essence." Just as he named in Persian "Khuda" [God/Self-Existent] as without essence and derived for man a name from that. As for those who turn away from symbols to verification, they name the Soul "Purush" [Purusha], and its meaning is the Man, because it is the Living in the Existent, and they do not see other than life in it. They describe it with the alternation of knowledge and ignorance upon it, and that it is ignorant in actuality and intelligent in potentiality, accepting knowledge by acquisition, and that its ignorance is the cause of the occurrence of action and its knowledge is the cause of its cessation. Following it is Absolute Matter, meaning the Abstract Hyle (Hayula), and they call it "Abyakt" [Avyakta], meaning a thing without form. It is a dead thing possessing three powers in potentiality not actuality; their names are "Sat" [Sattva], "Raj" [Rajas], and "Tam" [Tamas]. I heard that the term of "Buddhudan" regarding it for his people the Shamaniyya [Buddhists] is "Buddha Dharma «1» Sangha", as if they are Intellect, Religion, and Ignorance. The first «2» of them is rest and goodness, from which is being and growth. The second is fatigue and hardship, from which is stability and permanence. The third is languor and blindness, from which is corruption and annihilation. Therefore, the first «3» is attributed to the angels, the second to humans, and the third to beasts. These are things in which before, after, and then occur from the perspective of rank and the narrowing of expression, not from the perspective of time. As for Matter exiting to actuality by forms and the three first powers, they call it "Byakt" [Vyakta], meaning the Formed. They call the sum of the Abstract Hyle and the Formed Matter "Prakrit" [Prakriti]. There is no benefit in this name due to our dispensing with mentioning the Absolute, and Matter suffices us in expression, for neither of them is in existence without the other. Following it is Nature, and they call it "Ahankar" [Ahankara] «4», and its derivation is from overcoming, increase, and boasting, because Matter...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...when wearing forms, takes to growing the things originating from it. Growth is nothing but the transformation of the other and likening it to the growing thing. So it is as if Nature overcomes in that transformation and dominates the transformed. It is evident that every compound has simples from which composition begins and to which analysis returns. The universal existents in the world are the Elements, and they are, in their opinion: the Sky (Ether), Wind, Fire, Water, and Earth. They are called "Mahabhut" [Mahabhuta], meaning the Great Natures. They do not hold regarding fire what is held regarding the hot dry body at the concavity of the Ether; rather, they mean by it this existing one on the face of the earth from the burning of smoke. In "Baj Puran" [Vayu Purana?]: Indeed in ancient times there were Earth, Water, Wind, and Sky. Brahm saw a spark under the earth, so he extracted it and made it into thirds. The first is "Partib" [Parthiva], which is the familiar fire that needs wood and water extinguishes it. The second is "Divt" [Divya], which is the sun. The third is "Bidd" [Vidyut], which is lightning. The sun attracts water, and lightning flashes through water. In the animal, there is fire in the midst of humidities, feeding on them, and they do not extinguish it. These elements are compound, so they have simples preceding them called "Panj Matar" [Panca Tanmatra], meaning Five Mothers. They describe them as the Five Sensibles. So the simple of Sky is "Shabd" [Shabda], which is the Audible. The simple of Wind is "Spars" [Sparsha], which is the Tangible. The simple of Fire is "Rup" [Rupa], which is the Visible. The simple of Water is "Ras" [Rasa], which is the Tasted. The simple of Earth is "Gand" [Gandha], which is the Smelled. Each one of these simples has what is attributed to it and all that is attributed to what is above it. So Earth has the five qualities. Water decreases from them by smell. Fire decreases from them by it and by taste. Wind by them both and by color. Sky by them and by touch. I do not know what they mean by attributing sound to the Sky. I think it is similar to what "Omiros" [Homer], the poet of the Greeks, said: Indeed the possessors of the seven melodies speak and respond with a beautiful voice; and he meant the seven planets. As another of the poets said: Indeed the spheres of different melodies are seven, moving forever, glorifying the Creator because He holds them, encompassing them to the farthest end of the sphere without stars. "Furfurius" [Porphyry] said in his book on the opinions of the virtuous philosophers regarding the nature of the sphere: Indeed the heavenly bodies, when they move in their perfected shapes and forms and their chanting of wondrous sounds, as "Futhaghuras" [Pythagoras] and...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ..."Diyujanis" [Diogenes] said, indicated their Originator who has no like nor shape. It was said: Indeed Diogenes, due to the subtlety of his sense, was singled out to hear the sound of the movement of the sphere. All of these are symbols consistent in interpretation according to the straight law. Some of those who followed them among those falling short of verification mentioned: Indeed sight is watery, smell is fiery, taste is earthy, and touch is from the spirit benefiting the whole body by contact with it. I think he only attributed sight to water due to what he heard of the humors of the eye and its layers; and smell to fire due to vapors and smoke; and taste to earth due to his food which he swallows. The four elements were exhausted, so he returned in touch to the spirit. Then we say: The result of what the counting reached is the Animal. That is because plants, according to the Indians, are a type of it, just as Plato holds that plants have sense due to what is seen in plants of the power distinguishing between the suitable and the contrary. The animal is an animal by sense. The Senses are five, called "Indriyan" [Indriyani], and they are hearing by the ear «1», sight by the eye, smell by the nose, taste by the tongue, and touch by the skin. Then a Will disposing them in varieties of ways; its place in him is the heart, and they named it by it "Man" [Manas/Mind]. Animality is completed by five necessary actions they call "Karm Indriyan" [Karmendriyani], meaning the Senses in Actuality (Action Senses), for the result of the former is knowledge and cognition, and from these latter is work and craft. Let us call them "Necessities". They are: Vocalizing varieties of needs and desires, grasping with hands for drawing and avoiding, walking with feet for seeking and fleeing, and expelling the waste of foods by both outlets prepared for it. These are twenty-five: The Universal Soul, the Abstract Hyle, the Formed Matter, the Overcoming Nature, the Simple Mothers, the Principal Elements, the Perceiving Senses, the Disposing Will, and the Instrumental Necessities. The name of the sum is "Tattv" [Tattva]. Knowledges are restricted to them. Therefore, "Byas bin Barashar" [Vyasa son of Parashara] said: Know the twenty-five by detailing, defining, and dividing, a knowledge of proof and certainty, not study by tongue. Then adhere to whatever religion you wish, for your end is salvation.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
D - On the Cause of Action and the Connection of the Soul with Matter
The voluntary actions existing from the body of the animal do not issue from it except after the existence of life in it and the neighborliness of the Living (Soul) to it. They have claimed that the Soul in reality is ignorant of its essence and of what is beneath it of Matter, yearning to encompass what it does not know, thinking that it has no subsistence except with Matter. So it yearns for the Good, which is Permanence, and desires to view what is hidden from it, so it is stirred to unite with it. But the dense and the subtle, if they are at the extreme horizon of their two attributes, their proximity and mixing is impossible except by intermediaries that suit them, like the mediation of air between fire and water which are opposites in both qualities, for it suits each one of them in one of the qualities, so it enables it by it to mix with it. There is no divergence more distant than that between the Body and the Non-Body. Therefore, the Soul will never attain its desire as it is except by the likes of those intermediaries, which are spirits arising from the Simple Mothers in the worlds of "Bhurlok" [Bhurloka], "Bhubarlok" [Bhuvarloka], and "Svarlok" [Svarloka]. They named them, corresponding to the dense bodies existing from the elements, "Subtle Bodies" (Lingasharira). The Soul shines upon them, so they become vehicles for it. By that union, it is like the imprint of the image of the sun, which is one, in several mirrors set up facing it, or waters poured in vessels placed parallel to it. It is seen in every one of them equally, and its trace exists in it «1» by heat and light. So when the mixed different bodies are obtained and composed of the male and the female—as for from the male, what...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...is in them of bones, veins, and sperm; and as for from the female, what is in them of flesh, blood, and hair—and they are prepared to accept life, those spirits are coupled with them and become for them like palaces prepared for the varieties of interests of kings. The Five Winds enter them: by two of them is the drawing of breath and sending it; by the third is the mixing of foods in the stomach; by the fourth is the jumping of the body from one place to another; and by the fifth is the transfer of sensation from one end of the body to another. Spirits, according to them, are not different in substance, stamped upon equality. Their characters and traces only differ due to the difference of the bodies coupled with them because of the three powers (Gunas) that struggle in them and corrupt them with envy and rage. This is the Higher Cause in the stirring to action. As for the Lower Cause from the side of Matter, it is its seeking of perfection and its preference for the better, which is the exit from potentiality to actuality. And by what is in the root of Nature of boasting and love of overcoming, it displays what is in it of varieties of the possible to the one who learns. The Soul circulates in varieties of plants and types of animals. They likened it «1» to a dancer skilled in her art, knowing the effect of every join and separation in it, who attended a luxurious man intensely eager to witness what she has. So she began to display the types of her art «2» one after another, while the owner of the assembly watches her, until what she had was exhausted and the fondness of the viewer ceased. So she withdrew «3» abashed, as she had nothing other than repetition, and the repeated is undesired. So he dismissed her and the action was lifted. [This is] on the example of a caravan in a desert that was cut off (robbed) and its people fled, except for a blind man who was in it and a lame man who remained in the open, despairing of salvation. When they met and recognized each other, the lame man said to the blind man: "I am incapable of movement and capable of guidance, and your matter regarding them is the opposite of my matter. So enable me on your shoulder and carry me, so I may guide you to the road and we exit together from destruction." So he did, and the will was completed by their cooperation, and they separated upon exiting the wasteland. Then the expression differs among them regarding the Agent...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...as we mentioned. It was said in "Bishn Puran" [Vishnu Purana]: Matter is the root of the world, and its action in it is by nature on the example of the action of the seed for the tree by nature without intent and choice, and like the cooling of the wind for the water without intent other than blowing; indeed voluntary action belongs to Bishn [Vishnu]. This is an indication from him to the Living who is above Matter, and by whom Matter becomes active, striving for him the striving of a friend for his friend without greed. Mani built his saying upon it: The Disciples asked Isa [Jesus], peace be upon him, about the life of the dead. He said to them: Indeed the dead, if the Living mixing with it separates and becomes distinct on its own, returns dead, not living; and the Living who separated from it, being alive, does not die. As for in the book "Sank" [Samkhya], he attributes action to Matter because the forms that occur are different in their difference due to the three first powers and their dominance, singly and paired—meaning the Angelic, the Human, and the Bestial. These powers belong to it, not the Soul. The Soul, to know its actions, is in the position of the spectators, on the example of one of the travelers who sat in a village to rest. Each one of its people is striving in other than what the other strives in. So he looks at them and considers their states, disliking some of them and loving some of them, and learning by them. He is occupied without having a share in them nor a cause in stirring them up. Action is only attributed to the Soul despite its innocence «1» of it on the example of a man for whom accompaniment happened with a group he did not know. They were thieves returning from a village they had raided and ruined. He did not travel with them but a little until the pursuit caught up with them. The group was secured, and that innocent one was taken in their group and according to the likeness of their condition. What befell them befell him without sharing with them in their deed. They said: The example of the Soul is the example of rainwater descending from the sky in its state and one quality. When it gathers in vessels placed for it differing in substance, of gold, silver, glass, pottery, clay, and salt marsh, it differs by them in appearance, taste, and smell. Likewise, the Soul does not effect in Matter other than life by neighborliness. When Matter begins to act, what appears from it differs due to the dominant power among the three powers and the assistance of the other two...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...that are hidden by it in varieties of ways, [like] the cooperation of the wet oil, the dry wick, and the smoking fire on illumination. The Soul in Matter is like the rider of a chariot; the senses serve him in driving it according to his will, and the Intellect overflowing upon him from Allah, Glory be to Him, guides him. They have described it as that by which realities are looked at, leading to the knowledge of Allah the Exalted. And regarding actions, to every loved one to the whole, praised by all.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
E - On the State of Souls and their Circulation by Reincarnation in the World
Just as the testimony of the word of sincerity (Shahada) is the slogan of the faith of the Muslims, and the Trinity is the sign of Christianity, and the Sabbath is the sign of Judaism, likewise Reincarnation (Transmigration) is the science of the Indian creed. Whoever does not profess it is not of it and is not counted among its whole. For they said: Indeed the Soul, if it is not intelligent (knowing), does not encompass the objective with a complete encompassing at once without time. It needs the tracking of particulars and the induction of possibilities. Even if they are finite, their finite number is a multitude, and coming upon a multitude is compelled to a period possessing duration. Therefore, knowledge does not occur to the Soul except by witnessing persons and types and what alternates upon them of actions and conditions, until experience occurs to it in each one, and it benefits new knowledge by it. However, actions are different due to the powers (Gunas), and the world is not devoid of governance; rather, it is bridled and delegated to a purpose in it. So the remaining spirits circulate for that in the decaying bodies according to the variety of actions towards good and evil, so that the circulation in reward may be an alert to good, so it strives to increase it, and in punishment [an alert] to evil and the hated, so it exaggerates in distancing from it. The circulation becomes from the vilest to the best, not the reverse, because it bears both and requires difference of ranks in them due to the difference of actions by the divergence of mixtures and the measures of pairings in quantity and quality. This is Reincarnation, until there occurs from both sides of the Soul and Matter the perfection of the purpose. As for from the side of the Low (Matter), it is the annihilation of what is with Matter of form, except the repetition which is undesired. And as for from the side of the High (Soul), it is the departure of the Soul's yearning by its knowing what it did not know...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...and its certainty of the honor of its essence and its subsistence not by another, and its independence from Matter after its encompassing of its vileness and the lack of permanence in its forms and the yield in its sensible and the news in its pleasures.
