So it turns away from it, and the bond is untied, the connection is broken, separation and detachment occur, and the return to the mine [occurs], winning from the happiness of knowledge the like of what the sesame seed takes from preparation and fires (or numbers and lights?), so it does not separate from its oil after that. The knower and the known unite and become one. It is incumbent upon us to present from their books something of their explicit speech in this chapter and what resembles it from the speech of others in it. "Basdiv" [Vasudeva] said to "Arjun" [Arjuna], inciting him to fight while they were between the two ranks: "If you are a believer in the preceding decree, then know that they, and not we together, are dead or going a going with which there is no return. For souls are not dying nor changing. They only circulate in bodies according to the change of man from childhood to youth and middle age, then old age whose consequence is the death of the body, then the return." And he said to him: "How can one mention death and killing who knows that the Soul is of eternal existence, not from birth nor to destruction and non-existence? Rather it is firm, standing; no sword cuts it, no fire burns it, no water drowns it, and no wind dries it. But it transfers from its body when it becomes old towards another, not like that, just as the body exchanges clothes when they wear out. So why is your grief for a soul that does not perish? If it were perishing, then it is more appropriate that you do not grieve for a missing thing that is not found and does not return. If you are glancing at the body without it and panicking at its corruption, then every born thing is dead and every dead thing returns. You do not have anything of both matters. Our concern is only to Allah from whom are all matters and to whom they become." When "Arjun" said to him during his speech: "How did you fight Brahm in such-and-such [a time], while he is preceding the world, antecedent to mankind, and you are now among us known of birth and age?" He answered him and said: "As for the antiquity of the era, it encompassed me and you with him. How many times have we lived together! I have known their times and they were hidden from you. Whenever I intended coming for rectification, I put on a body, as there is no way to be with people except by becoming human." It was narrated about a king whose name I forgot that he ordered his people: to burn his corpse after his death in a place where no dead person had ever been burned. They sought a place like that, but it exhausted them until they found a rock protruding from the water of the sea. They thought they had succeeded in the desire. "Basdiv" said to them: "Indeed this king was burned on this rock many times, so do what you want."

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: For he only intended to inform you, and his need has been fulfilled. And 'Basudeva' [Vasudeva/Krishna] said: 'He who hopes for salvation and strives to reject the world, but whose heart does not comply with the desired goal, is rewarded for his action in the gatherings of the rewarded ones, but he does not attain what he wanted due to his deficiency. However, he returns to the world and is qualified for a body of a kind specialized in asceticism. The divine inspiration in the other body grants him success to gradually achieve what his will was in the first body, and his heart begins to obey him. He continues to be purified in the bodies until he attains salvation through the succession of births.' Basudeva also said: 'If the soul is stripped of matter, it is knowing; but if it is clothed in it, it is ignorant due to its turbidity, thinking that it is the doer and that the works of the world are prepared for its sake. So it clings to them, and the sensory things are imprinted in it. When it separates from the body, the traces of the sensory things remain in it, so it does not separate from them completely; it yearns for them and returns towards them. Its acceptance of the contrasting changes in those states compels upon it the necessities of the first three powers. So what can it do if it is not prepared, being clipped of wing?' He also said: 'The best of people is the perfect scholar, because he loves Allah and Allah loves him. How often death and birth have repeated upon him while he, in the spans of his life, was diligent in seeking perfection until he attained it.' In 'Vishnu Dharma', there is the saying of 'Markandeya' when mentioning the spiritual beings: 'Each of Brahma, Kartikeya son of Mahadeva, Lakshmi the extracting of happiness from the sea, Daksha whom Mahadeva struck, and Umadeva the wife of Mahadeva, are in the middle of this Kalpa, and they were like that many times.' And 'Varahamihira' said in 'The Judgments of the Comets': 'And what befalls people upon their appearance of calamities that force evacuation from homes, emaciated from wasting away, wailing from affliction, taking the hands of children, walking them, whispering to each other, "We have been seized for the sins of our kings," and answering each other, "Nay, this is the recompense of what we earned in the previous abode before these bodies."' Mani [Manichaeism] was exiled from Iranshahr [Iran], so he entered the land of India and transferred the concept of transmigration from them to his sect. He said in the 'Book of...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...Mysteries': 'When the disciples knew that souls do not die and that they are, in the repetition, turning into the likeness of every image they wear, and every creature they are molded into, and the likeness of every form poured into its hollow, they asked the Messiah [Jesus] about the fate of the souls that did not accept the truth and did not know the origin of their being. He said: "Any weak soul that did not accept its companions from the truth is perishing, having no rest." He meant by its perishing its punishment, not its annihilation. For he also said: "The Daisanites [Bardaisanites] thought that the ascension of the living soul and its purification is in the corpse of humans, and they did not know the enmity of the corpse toward the soul, its prevention of it from ascending, and that it is a prison and painful punishment for it. If this human form were true, its Creator would not have let it wear out and let harm occur in it, nor would He have necessitated reproduction by sperm in wombs."' As for the book of 'Patanjali', it is said: 'The likeness of the soul amidst the attachments of ignorance, which are the causes of bondage, is like rice within a husk. As long as it is with it, it is prepared for growth and harvest, wavering between being born and giving birth. But if the husk is removed from it, those accidents are cut off from it, and it remains in its state.' As for recompense, its existence is in the genera of beings in which the soul wavers according to the lifespan in length and shortness, and in the form of blessing in narrowness and abundance. The questioner said: 'What is the state of the spirit when it is caught between rewards and sins, then becomes entangled with the genus of beings for favor or vengeance?' The answerer said: 'It wavers according to what it sent forth and committed between ease and hardship, and fluctuates between pain and pleasure.' The questioner said: 'If a human earns what necessitates recompense in a mold (body) other than the mold of earning, the time between the two states is distant and the matter is forgotten?' The answerer said: 'Action is inherent to the spirit because it is its acquisition, and the body is a tool for it. There is no forgetfulness in psychic things, for they are outside of time which necessitates nearness and distance in duration. The action, by its adherence to the spirit, molds its character and nature to the likeness of the state to which...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...it transfers. So the soul, in its purity, knows that, remembering it, not forgetting. Its light is only covered by the turbidity of the body when it unites with it, like the example of a human remembering something he knew then forgot due to madness that befell him, or an illness that afflicted him, or intoxication that overcame his heart. Do you not see children and youths rejoicing at supplications for their long life and grieving at supplications for their speedy annihilation? What is it to them regarding these two, were it not that they tasted the sweetness of life and knew the bitterness of death in the past cycles in which they transmigrated for the existence of recompense?' The Greeks were in agreement with the Indians in this belief. Socrates said in the book 'Phaedo': 'We mention in the sayings of the ancients that souls go from here to Hades, then come also to what is here, and the living are from the dead, and things are from opposites; so those who died are among the living. Our souls in Hades are existing. The soul of every human rejoices and grieves for a thing and sees that thing as its own. This passivity binds it to the body, nails it to it, and makes it bodily in form. That which is not pure cannot go to Hades, but exits the body while full of it, such that it falls into another body quickly, as if it is deposited in it to remain. Therefore, it has no share in being with the one pure divine substance.' He said: 'If the soul is existing, then our learning is nothing but remembering what we learned in the past time, because our souls were in a place before becoming in this human form. When people see something they were accustomed to using in childhood, this passivity befalls them and they remember from the cymbal, for example, the boy who used to play it, whom they had forgotten. So forgetfulness is the departure of knowledge, and knowledge is the remembrance of what the soul knew before it came to the body.' Proclus said: 'Remembrance and forgetfulness are specific to the rational soul. It has become clear that it has always existed, so it must be that it has always been knowing and forgetting. Knowing when it separates from the body, and forgetting when it approaches the body. For in separation, it is from the domain of the intellect, so it is knowing; and in approaching, it descends from it, so forgetfulness befalls it due to the dominance of potentiality over it.' To this meaning...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...went those of the Sufis who said: 'The world is a sleeping soul and the Hereafter is an awake soul.' They allow the indwelling (Hulul) of the Truth (Allah) in places like the Heaven, the Throne, and the Footstool. Some of them allow it in the entire world, animals, trees, and inanimate objects, and express this as the 'Universal Manifestation.' Since they allowed that in Him, the indwelling of spirits through transmigration held no danger for them.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: VI. On the Gatherings and Places of Retribution of Paradise and Hell. The gathering is called 'Loka'. The world is divided primarily into upper, lower, and middle. The upper world is called 'Svarloka', which is Paradise. The lower world is 'Nagaloka', meaning the gathering of serpents, which is Hell; it is also called 'Naraloka', and perhaps they call it 'Patala', meaning the bottom of the earths. As for the middle one which we are in, it is called 'Madhyaloka' and 'Manushyaloka', meaning the gathering of humans. It is for earning, the upper is for reward, and the lower is for punishment. In them, the one who deserves them receives the full recompense of the deed for a set period according to the duration of the deed. Being in each of them is for the spirit alone, stripped of the body. For the one falling short of rising to Paradise or sinking to Hell, there is another Loka called 'Tiryagloka', which is plants and irrational animals. The spirit fluctuates in their individuals through transmigration until it transfers to humanity gradually from the lowest ranks of the growing (plants) to the highest ranks of the sensing (animals). Its being in it is for one of two reasons: either due to the deficiency of the amount of recompense for the two places of reward and punishment, or due to its return from Hell. For according to them, the one returning to the world is humanized in the beginning of his state, while the one returning to it from Hell fluctuates in plants and animals until he reaches the rank of a human. From the perspective of traditions, they multiply the number of hells, their descriptions, and names, and designate a place for every sin. It is said in 'Vishnu Purana': They are eighty-eight thousand.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: We recount from it what was mentioned therein. He said: The false claimant, the false witness, the helper of both, and the mocker of people go to 'Raurava' among the hells. The shedder of blood without right, the usurper of people's rights, the raider upon them, and the killer of cows go to 'Rodha'; the stranglers also go there. The killer of a Brahmin, the thief of gold, those who accompanied them, the princes who do not look after their subjects, and the one who commits adultery with the wife of his teacher or lies with his mother-in-law go to 'Saptakumbha' (or Sabat Kunb). He who overlooks the obscenity of his wife out of greed, he who commits incest with his daughter or son's wife, sells his child, or is stingy to himself with what he owns and does not spend it, go to 'Mahajwala'. He who rejects his teacher and is not pleased with him, despises people, commits bestiality, and he who disdains the Veda and Puranas or earns by them in the markets go to 'Shula' (or Shul). The thief, the fraudster, the violator of the straight path of people, he who hates his father and does not love Allah and people, and he who does not honor the gems that Allah has dignified and equates them with other stones go to 'Krimisa'. He who does not venerate the rights of fathers and grandfathers and does not make offerings to the angels, and he who makes arrows and arrowheads go to 'Lalahhaksha'. The maker of the sword and knife goes to 'Visasana'. He who hides what he owns out of greed for the gifts of rulers, and the Brahmin if he sells meat, oil, ghee, dye, or wine go to 'Adhomukha'. He who fattens chickens, cats, sheep, pigs, and birds goes to 'Rudhirandha'. The owners of entertainment places, reciters of poetry in markets, diggers of wells for drawing water (for profit?), he who has intercourse with his wife on the venerated days, he who throws fire at people's houses, and he who betrays his companion and kills him out of greed for his wealth go to 'Rudra'. He who gathers honey goes to 'Vaitarani'. The usurper of wealth and women through the intoxication of his youth goes to 'Krishna'. The cutter of trees goes to 'Asipatravana'. The hunter and maker of traps and snares goes to 'Vahnijwala'. The neglecter of customs and traditions and the nullifier of laws, who is the worst of them, goes to...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...'Sandamsa'. We have only listed this to make known the sins that are disliked among them regarding actions. Some of them view the intermediate state for earning as humanity, and the fluctuation in it with recompense falling short of (great) reward and punishment. Then they view Paradise as high above it for the bliss deserved for a duration due to good deeds, and the fluctuation in plants and animals as lower than it for the torment and punishment deserved for a duration due to bad deeds; they do not see Hell as anything other than this descent from humanity. All of this is because the seeking of liberation from bondage might not be on its straight path leading to certain knowledge, but rather on conjectured paths taken by imitation. The deed of a doer, which is the conclusion of his deeds after balancing the two types of earning, will not be lost, but the recompense will be according to the intended purpose, so he attains it in degrees: either in his mold (body) in which he is, or in the one he transfers to, or after his exit from his mold and before obtaining another. This is the place of their turning from theoretical inquiry to religious report regarding the nature of the two abodes of reward and punishment, and being in them without being embodied in a body, and the return after fully receiving the wage of the work to embodiment and humanity to prepare for what is for him. For this reason, the author of the book 'Samkhya' did not count the reward of Paradise as good due to its expiration and lack of eternity, and due to the similarity of the state in it to the state of the world regarding competition and envy because of the disparity of degrees and ranks, for resentment and regret do not disappear except with equality. The Sufis do not count it as good from another perspective, which is distraction by other than the Truth (Allah) and being occupied from the Pure Good by what is other than Him. We have said: They view the spirit in these two places as stripped of corporeality; but this is the opinion of their elite who conceive the soul as self-subsistent. As for those who fall below their rank and can hardly conceive its existence without a body, they hold different opinions on that. Among them is that the cause of death is the spirit waiting for a prepared mold, so it does not leave the body until the existence of an attachment resembling its action and earning from what nature has prepared as a fetus in wombs or a seed sprouting in the belly of the earth; then it leaves the body it is in. Among them are those who say, from the perspective of traditions, that it does not wait for that, but rather leaves its mold due to its frailty, and a body called 'Ativahika' has been prepared for it from the elements. Its interpretation is 'that which comes into being quickly,' because it does not obtain by way of birth. So it remains in it for a year...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...barren, in the utmost hardship, whether rewarded or punished. It is like the Isthmus (Barzakh) between earning and attaining the wage. Therefore, the heir of the deceased among them performs the rites of the year for the deceased, and they do not end until its expiration, because the spirit then goes to the place prepared for it. We mention here also from their books what declares these meanings. In 'Vishnu Purana': 'Maitreya' asked 'Parashara' about the purpose of Hell and punishment with it? He answered him that it is to distinguish good from evil, knowledge from ignorance, and to manifest justice. Not every sinner enters Hell, for some of them are saved by offering repentance and expiations, the greatest of which is adherence to the remembrance of 'Vishnu' in every action. And some of them fluctuate in plants, birds, and the vile and filthy creeping things like lice and worms until the duration of desert. In the book 'Samkhya': As for the one who deserves elevation and reward, he becomes like one of the angels, mixing with the spiritual gatherings, not veiled from acting in the heavens and being with their inhabitants, or like one of the eight genera of spiritual beings. As for the one who deserves lowness due to burdens and sins, he becomes an animal or a plant and fluctuates until he deserves a reward, so he escapes from hardship, or comprehends his essence, so he vacates his vehicle and becomes liberated. Some of the theologians (Mutakallimun) who inclined towards transmigration said: It is of four ranks: Naskh (Abrogation/Copying), which is reproduction among humans because it copies from one person to another; its opposite is Maskh (Transformation), and it is specific to humans being transformed into monkeys, pigs, and elephants; Raskh (Firmness), like plants, and it is more severe than Naskh because it is firmly rooted and remains over days and endures like mountains; and its opposite is Faskh (Dissolution), which is for plucked plants and slaughtered animals because they vanish and do not leave successors. Abu Yaqub al-Sijzi, the nicknamed, held the view in a book of his named 'Kashf al-Mahjub' (Unveiling the Veiled) that species are preserved and that transmigration in each of them does not cross into another species. This was the opinion of the Greeks, for John the Grammarian (Philoponus) relates from Plato...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...that he believed that rational souls become clothed in the bodies of beasts, and that he followed in that the myths of Pythagoras. Socrates said in the book 'Phaedo': 'The body is earthy, heavy, and weighty. The soul that loves it is transported and attracted to the place it looks at due to its anxiety over what has no form, and from "Hades", the gathering of souls. So it becomes polluted and wanders around graves and burial places. I have been shown in it souls that appeared in the form of shadow and imagination, from the souls that did not separate a pure separation, but rather contained a part of the object looked at.' Then he said: 'It is likely that these are not the souls of the good, but the souls of the people of gluttony. They wander in these things as a retribution they take from them due to the badness of their first sustenance. They remain so until they are bound again in a body by the lust of the bodily form that followed them. Their binding is in bodies of their character, like the characters they had in the world. For example, he who had nothing but eating and drinking enters the genera of donkeys and predatory beasts. And he who advanced injustice and domination, into the genera of wolves, falcons, and kites.' He said regarding the Gatherings: 'If I did not see myself going first to wise, master, good gods, then afterwards to humans who died better than those here, my leaving grief over death would be an injustice.' He said regarding the two places of Reward and Punishment: 'When a human dies, a "Daemon", who is one of the guards, goes with him to the gathering of judgment and carries him with those gathered there as an ordered guide to "Hades". Until he stays there what is appropriate of time, many and long cycles.' "Telephus" said: 'The road to Hades is simple.' He [Socrates] said: 'And I say if it were simple or single, the guide would not be needed on it. As for the soul that desires the body, or whose action was bad and unjust, and resembling the killer souls, it fled from there and took refuge in every species until times pass over it, so it is brought by necessity to the dwelling that resembles it. As for the pure one, it encounters companions and god-guides and inhabits the place that is appropriate.' He said: 'Whoever among the dead was of medium conduct, they ride upon mounts prepared...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...for them in "Acheron". When retribution is taken from them and they are purified of injustice, they wash and accept honors for the good deeds they did according to merit. As for those who committed major sins such as stealing from the offerings of the gods, usurping great wealth, or killing unjustly and deliberately contrary to the laws, they are cast into "Tartarus" and never exit it. As for those who regretted their sins during their lifetime, and their sins fell short of that degree, such as offenses against parents and overcoming them with anger, and accidental killing, they are cast into Tartarus for a full year being tormented. Then the wave throws them to a place from which they call out to their adversaries, asking them to limit themselves to retaliation so they may escape the evils. If they accept from them, (good), otherwise they are returned to Tartarus. This remains their habit in torment until their adversaries are satisfied with them. Those whose conduct was virtuous are delivered from these places of this earth, rest from the prisons, and inhabit the pure earth.' Tartarus is a great chasm and abyss into which rivers flow. Every human expresses the punishment of the Hereafter with the most terrible thing known to his people. The western region is plagued by eclipses and deluges, although he describes it with what indicates the flaming of fires in it, as if he means by it the sea or an ocean containing a whirlpool. There is no doubt that these are the expressions of the people of that time regarding their beliefs.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: VII. On the Manner of Liberation from the World and the Description of the Path Leading to it. Since the soul is bound in the world and its binding has a cause, its liberation from the bond is by the opposite of that cause. But we have related their doctrine that the cause of the bond is ignorance, so its liberation is then by knowledge, if it encompasses things with a comprehensive, distinguishing definition that dispenses with induction and negates doubts. Because if it details existents by definitions, it comprehends its essence and what it possesses of the honor of permanence, and what matter possesses of the baseness of change and annihilation in forms. So it dispenses with it and realizes that what it thought was good and pleasure is evil and hardship. Thus it obtains the reality of knowledge and turns away from clothing itself in matter, so the action is cut off, and they [soul and matter] are liberated by separation. The author of the book 'Patanjali' said: 'Singling out the thought on the Oneness of Allah occupies a person with perceiving something other than what he was occupied with. Whoever wants Allah wants good for all creation without excepting a single one for a cause. Whoever occupies himself with his soul to the exclusion of what is other than it, He does not make for it a drawn or sent breath. Whoever reaches this goal, his psychic power overcomes his bodily power, so he is granted power over eight things, by the attainment of which dispensing occurs. For it is impossible for anyone to dispense with what incapacitates him. One of those eight is the ability to make the body subtle until it is hidden from eyes. The second is the ability to make it light until treading on thorns, mud, and dust becomes equal to him. The third is the ability to make it great until he shows it in a...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...terrifying, amazing form. The fourth is the ability of wills (to attain wishes). The fifth is the ability to know what he seeks. The sixth is the ability to lead whatever group he seeks. The seventh is the submission of the led and their obedience. The eighth is the folding of distances between him and distant destinations.' Similar to this are the indications of the Sufis regarding the Knower (Gnostic) when he reaches the station of Knowledge (Ma'rifa); they claim that he obtains two spirits: an ancient one upon which change and difference do not pass, by which he knows the unseen and performs miracles, and another human one for change and coming into being. The sayings of the Christians are not far from the like of this. The Indians said: 'When he is capable of that, he dispenses with it and graduates to the objective in ranks. The first of them is knowing things by name and attribute and details that do not give definitions. The second is surpassing that to definitions which make the particulars of things universal, except that it is not devoid of detail therein. The third is the cessation of that detail and encompassing them united, but under time. The fourth is its stripping for him from time and his dispensing in it with names and titles which are tools of necessity; in it, the intellect, the intellecter, and the intellected unite until they become one thing.' This is what 'Patanjali' said regarding the knowledge that liberates the soul. They call its liberation in Indian 'Moksha', meaning the End/Consequence. They also call the complete clearing in solar and lunar eclipses by it, because it is the end of the eclipse and the occurrence of separation between the clinging ones. According to them, the senses and faculties were made for knowledge, and pleasure was placed in them as an incentive for research, just as the pleasure of eating and drinking was placed in taste to sustain the individual through nutrition, and the pleasure of sex to sustain the species through reproduction. Were it not for desire, the animal or human would not do them for these two purposes. In the book 'Gita': 'Man is created to know, and for the equality of knowledge, he was given tools equally. If he were created to work, the tools would have varied like the variation of works due to the variation of the first three powers. However, the bodily nature rushes to work because of its opposition to knowledge, so it seeks to cover it with pleasures which are in reality pains. Knowledge is what leaves this nature prostrate and clears the soul from darkness like the clearing of the sun from an eclipse or clouds.' This is like the saying of Socrates: 'When the soul is with the body and wants to investigate...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...something, it is deceived then by it. Through thought, something of the identities becomes clear to it. So its thought is in the time when nothing harms it of hearing, sight, pain, or pleasure; that is when it becomes by itself and leaves the body and sharing with it as much as possible. The soul of the philosopher specifically is the one that disdains the body and wants to separate from it. If we, in this life of ours, did not use the body and did not share with it except out of necessity, and did not acquire its nature but dissociated from it, we would approach knowledge by resting from its ignorance, and we would become pure by our knowledge of our essences until Allah releases us.' It is likely that this is the truth. Then we return to the context of the speech and say: Likewise, the rest of the faculties are for knowledge, and the Knower finds pleasure in deploying them in knowledges until they become his spies. Perception of things has different times. The senses that serve the heart (mind) perceive the present thing only. The heart reflects on the present and remembers the past. Nature takes over the present, claims it for itself in the past, and prepares to contend for it in the future. The intellect knows the quiddity of the thing, not attached to time or season, and the past and future are equal to it. The closest of its helpers to it are thought and nature, and the furthest are the five senses. Whenever they deliver to thought a partial piece of knowledge, it refines it from sensory fallacies, hands it over to the intellect, which makes it universal and informs the soul of it, so it becomes knowing by it. According to them, knowledge is obtained by the Knower in one of three ways: One is by inspiration and without time, but rather with birth and the cradle, like 'Kapila' the Sage, for he was born with knowledge and wisdom. The second is by inspiration after a time, like the sons of 'Brahma', for they were inspired when they reached their prime. The third is by learning and after a time, like the rest of people who learn when they mature. Arriving at salvation through knowledge only happens by abstaining from evil. Its branches, despite their multitude, return to Greed, Anger, and Ignorance; by cutting the roots, the branches wither. The pivot of that is upon the leadership of the powers of Lust and Anger, which are the most hostile enemy and most destructive to man; they deceive him with pleasure in foods and rest in revenge, while they are more deserving of leading to pains and sins. Through them...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...man resembles beasts and cattle, indeed devils and demons. And (it depends) upon preferring the rational logical power by which he resembles the proximate angels. And upon turning away from the works of the world; and he is not able to leave them except by rejecting their causes of greed and domination; by that, the second power of the first three is secluded. However, leaving work is of two ways: one is by laziness, delay, and ignorance according to the requirement of the third power; this is not the desired one, for its outcome is blameworthy. The second is by choice, insight, and preferring the better for betterment; this is the one of praiseworthy consequence. Leaving works is not complete except by seclusion and isolation from distractions to be able to withdraw the senses from external sensory objects so that he does not know that there is anything behind him, and quieting movements and breathing. For it is known that the greedy one is striving, the striver is tired, and the tired one is panting; so panting is then the result of greed. With its cessation, breathing becomes like the breathing of one who does not need air in the depth of water. Then the heart settles on one thing, which is seeking salvation and purity to the absolute Oneness. In the book 'Gita': 'How can one attain salvation who has scattered his heart and did not single it out for Allah, and did not make his work pure for His face? He who turns his thought from things to the One, the light of his heart becomes steady like the steadiness of the light of a lamp with pure oil in a shelter where no wind shakes it. That occupies him from sensing any pain of heat or cold, due to his knowledge that everything other than the One Truth is a false imagination.' In it also: 'Pain and pleasure do not affect the real scholar, just as the continued pouring of rivers into the sea does not affect its water.' And can anyone scale this mountain pass except one who has suppressed Lust and Anger and nullified them? For the sake of this which was mentioned, thought must be connected with a connection from which number disappears, because number applies to times (instances), and times do not exist without heedlessness intervening between them, separating them and preventing the union of the thought with the object of thought. This is not the desired goal; rather, it is the continuity of thought. One graduates to it either in a single body or in bodies by adhering to virtuous conduct and habituating the soul to it until it becomes a nature and an essential attribute for it. Virtuous conduct is what religion imposes. Its principles, after the multitude of branches, return according to them to several comprehensive points: that he does not kill, does not lie, does not steal, does not commit adultery, and does not hoard. Then he adheres to holiness...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...and purity, perpetuates fasting and asceticism, holds fast to the worship of Allah with glorification and praise, and perpetuates the passing of 'Om', which is the word of formation and creation, over his heart without speaking it. That is because leaving killing in animals is a type whose genus is refraining from harm and injury; usurping what belongs to others and lying enter into it, beyond what is in it of ugliness and baseness. In leaving hoarding is the shaking off of fatigue, safety from the seeker of surplus, and obtaining relief from the humiliation of slavery through the glory of freedom. In adhering to purity is an awareness of the filth of the body and a motive to hate it and love the pure soul. In punishing the soul with asceticism is its refinement, the quieting of its greed, and the sharpening of its senses. As 'Pythagoras' said to a man who cared for fattening his body and giving it desires: 'You are not falling short in constructing your prison and strengthening your bond and tightening it.' In holding fast to the remembrance of Allah Almighty and the angels is familiarity with them. In the book 'Samkhya': 'Everything a man thinks is his goal, he does not go beyond it.' In the book 'Gita': 'Everything a man perpetuates thinking about and remembering is imprinted in him such that he is guided by it without intent. And because the time of death is the time of remembering what he loves, if the spirit separates from the body, it unites with that thing and transforms into it.' Everything that has a going and a return, union with it is not pure salvation. Although it was said in this book: 'He who knows at his death that Allah is everything and from Him is everything is saved, even if his rank falls short of the ranks of the truthful.' In it also: 'Seek salvation from the world by leaving attachment to its ignorances, sincerity of intention in works, fire sacrifices to Allah without greed for reward and recompense, and withdrawal from people, the reality of which is that you do not prefer one for friendship over another for enmity. Contradict heedlessness in sleep at the time of their waking, and waking at the time of their sleep, for it is withdrawal from them while witnessing with them. Then guarding the soul from the soul (self), for it is the enemy if it desires, and an excellent ally if it abstains.' Socrates said upon his lack of concern for being killed and his joy at joining his Lord: 'My rank should not be lower with any of you than the rank of the "Cygnus" [Swan], which is said to be the bird of "Apollo the Sun", and that it knows the unseen for that reason, and that if...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...it senses its death, it increases its melodies in rapture and joy at going to its master. My joy at reaching my worshipped one should not be less than the joy of this bird.' For this reason, the Sufis said in defining Love (Ishq): 'It is being occupied with the creation (or distraction) from the Truth (Allah).' In the book 'Patanjali': We divide the path of salvation into three sections. One is practical, by habituation and management of withdrawing the senses from outside to inside until they are not occupied except by You. Sufficiency (moderate living) has been permitted for whoever seeks this. In the book 'Vishnu Dharma': 'Parikshit' the King, who is from the lineage of 'Puru', asked 'Shatanika', the head of a group of sages who attended him, about a meaning of the divine meanings? He answered him that he would not say anything about it except what he heard from 'Shaunaka', and he from 'Ushanas', and he from 'Brahma': 'Allah is He who has no beginning and no end, was not born from anything and did not beget anything, except that He who cannot be said to be "He" cannot be said to be "other than Him". How can I have the capacity to mention One who is pure Good in His satisfaction and pure Evil in His wrath? Is it possible to attain knowledge of Him so He is worshipped as He deserves except by being occupied with Him from the world entirely and perpetuating thought on Him?' It was said to him: 'Man is weak and his life is scant and slight. His soul hardly obeys him to leave the necessities in his livelihood, so that prevents him from the path of salvation. If it were in the first time when lifespans extended to thousands of years and the world was good due to the absence of evils, doing the duty would be hoped for. As for the end of time, what do you see for him in the rotating world so that he can cross the sea and escape drowning?' Brahma said: 'Man must have food, shelter, and clothing, so there is no harm in them. But rest is only in leaving what is other than them of superfluities and the troubles of works. So worship Allah purely, prostrate to Him, draw near to Him in the place of worship with gifts of perfume and flowers, glorify Him, bind Him to your hearts so they do not leave Him, give charity to Brahmins and others, vow to Him special vows like leaving meat and general ones like fasting. Animals belong to Him, so do not distinguish them from yourselves and kill them. Know that He is everything, so whatever you do, let it be for His sake. Even if you enjoy something of the ornaments of the world, do not forget Him in intention, and that your purpose in it is piety and empowerment...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...to worship Him. By this, you attain salvation, not by anything else.' It was said in 'Gita': 'Whoever kills his desire does not exceed the necessary needs, and whoever sticks to sufficiency is not disgraced nor deemed base.' It is also said in it: 'If man cannot dispense with what nature compels him to, of food to quell the fire of hunger, sleep to remove the aggression of tiring movements, and a seat to rest in, then its condition is cleanliness, softness, moderation in height from the face of the earth, sufficiency for the body to spread on it, and a place of moderate temperament not harmful with cold or heat, safe from the approach of vermin. For that aids in defining the heart for perpetuating the thought on Oneness. Because what is other than necessities in food and clothing are pleasures, and they are covered hardships; resting in them is interrupted, and [resting] in the hardest hardship is impossible. Pleasure is only for him who has killed the two enemies that cannot be tolerated, I mean Lust and Anger, in his life not his death, and rested from his inside not his outside, thus dispensing with his senses.' 'Basudeva' said to 'Arjuna': 'If you want pure Good, guard the nine gates of your body, know the one entering and exiting them, restrain your heart from spreading its thoughts, and quiet the soul by remembering the aperture of the fontanelle which closed and hardened after its softness so it was not needed. And do not view sensation except as a nature in the instruments of the senses so that you do not follow it.' The second section is Intellectual (by neglect/renunciation), by knowing the vileness of changing existents and perishing forms until the heart flees from them, greed is cut off from them, and supremacy is obtained over the first three powers which are the cause of actions and their difference. That is because the one who encompasses the conditions of the world knows that its good is evil and its rest is impossible in recompense to hardship, so he turns away from what confirms entanglement and generates remaining. In the book 'Gita': 'People have gone astray in commands and prohibitions and have not been guided to distinguish good from evil in actions; so leaving them and abandoning them is the Action.' In it also: 'The purity of knowledge exceeds the purity of all other things, because by knowledge is the eradication of ignorance and the exchange of certainty for doubt which is the substance of torment; for there is no rest for a doubter.' It is known from that that the first section is a tool for the second. Then the third section is more worthy to be a tool for both, which is Worship, so that Allah grants success for attaining salvation and qualifies for a mold in which graduation to happiness is attained. The author of Gita divided worship into...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...the body, the voice, and the heart. Upon the body are fasting, prayer, requirements of the law, serving the angels and Brahmin scholars, cleaning the body, dissociating from killing entirely and from looking at what belongs to others of women and others. Upon the voice are recitation, glorification, adhering to truth, being gentle with people, guiding them, and enjoining them to good. Upon the heart are rectifying the intention, leaving arrogance, adhering to patience, and gathering the senses with expansion of the chest (joy/peace). Then he followed it with a fourth legendary section called 'Rasayana' [Alchemy], which are managements with medicines that run the course of alchemy in obtaining impossible things by them. Mention of it will come, and it has no connection to this art except from the side of determination and correcting the intention by believing in it and striving to obtain it. They only went in liberation to Union because Allah is independent of hoping for reward or fearing opposition, free from thoughts due to His transcendence above hated opposites and loved peers, knowing by His essence not by knowledge occurring for what was not known to Him in some state. This is also the attribute of the liberated one according to them; he does not separate from Him in it except in the beginning (origin). For he was not like that in the pre-eternal past because he was before that in the place of entanglement, knowing the known, and his knowledge was like imagination acquired by effort, and his known was in the guarantee of covering. As for the place of salvation, the covers are lifted, the lids are removed, the obstacles are cut, and the essence is knowing, not eager to know a hidden thing, separated from the decaying sensory things, united with the permanent intelligible things. Therefore, the questioner asked at the end of the book 'Patanjali' about the nature of salvation? The answerer said: 'If you wish, say it is the suspension of the three powers and their return to the mine from which they issued. And if you wish, say it is the return of the soul, knowing, to its nature.' The two men disagreed about the one who obtained the rank of salvation. The hermit asked in the book 'Samkhya': 'Why does death not occur at the cessation of action?' The Sage said: 'Because the cause for separation is a psychic state, and the spirit is still in the body. Nothing separates them except a natural state that separates the union. Perhaps the effect remains after the disappearance of the cause for a period in which it slackens and retreats until...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...it vanishes, like the potter who spins his wheel with a stick until its spinning becomes intense, then he leaves it. It does not stop with the removal of the spinning stick from it, but its movement slackens little by little until it ceases. Likewise the body, after the lifting of the action, the trace remains in it until it is spent in hardship and ease towards the cessation of the natural force and the annihilation of the previous trace; so the perfection of salvation is at the falling down of the body.' As for the book 'Patanjali', what witnesses to the like of the foregoing is his saying regarding the one who withdrew his senses and feelings like the turtle withdraws its limbs upon fear: 'He is not trusted because he untied the knot, nor is he liberated because his body is with him.' That which contradicts it from his speech is his saying: 'Bodies are nets for spirits to fulfill recompense. The one who reaches the degree of salvation has fulfilled it in his mold regarding past action, then became suspended from earning for the future. So he unraveled from the net, dispensed with the mold, and moved in it without being entangled. He is capable of moving to wherever he likes and whenever he wants, not by way of death. For the dense, cohesive bodies are not hindering to his mold, so how about his body to his spirit?' The Sufis go to something close to this. It has been narrated in their books about some of them: 'A group of Sufis came to us and sat at a distance from us. One of them stood up to pray. When he finished, he turned and said to me: "O Sheikh, do you know a place here suitable for us to die in?" I thought he wanted to sleep, so I pointed to a place. He went and threw himself on his back and became still. I went to him and moved him, and lo, he had become cold.' And they said regarding the saying of Allah Almighty "Indeed, We established him upon the earth" [Quran 18:84]: 'That if he wishes, it is folded for him, and if he wishes, he walks on water and air; they support him in it, and mountains do not resist him in purpose.' As for those who lagged behind the rank of salvation despite their diligence, their degrees vary. It is said in 'Samkhya': 'He who advances towards the world with good conduct, generous with what he owns of it, is recompensed in the world by obtaining wishes and will, and fluctuating in it in happiness, envied in body, soul...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...and condition. For the reality of fortune is that it is a recompense for previous actions in that mold or another. The ascetic in the world without knowledge wins elevation and reward but is not liberated due to the lack of the instrument. The content, dispensed one, if he is empowered over the eight mentioned states and is deceived by them and succeeds and thinks they are salvation, remains at them.' A parable was struck for those differing in degrees of knowledge by a man who went out early in the dark with his students for a need. An upright figure obstructed them on the road; the darkness of the night prevented knowing its reality. The man turned to his students and asked them about it one after another. The first said: 'I do not know what it is.' The second said: 'I do not know it, and I have no power to know it.' The third said: 'There is no benefit in knowing it, for the rising of the day will reveal it. If it is a hidden thing, it will leave by morning, and if it is otherwise, its matter will become clear to us.' All three fell short of knowledge: the first by ignorance, the second by incapacity and a defect in the instrument, and the third by laxity and satisfaction with ignorance. As for the fourth, he did not find an answer before verification, so he aimed for it. When he approached it, he saw a pumpkin vine wrapped around it. He knew that a living, choosing human does not remain standing in his place until that wrapping occurs on him, and he verified that it was inanimate, erected. Then he did not feel safe that it might be a hiding place for a deceptive thing, so he approached it and kicked it with his foot until it fell, and the doubt about its matter was removed. He returned to his master with the certain news, having won knowledge from his own hands. As for the resemblance of the Greeks' speech to these meanings, 'Ammonius' narrated from Pythagoras his saying: 'Let your eagerness and diligence in this world be for connection with the First Cause which is the Cause of your cause, so that your remaining may be eternal and you escape corruption and extinction, and proceed to the world of true sense, true joy, and true glory in uninterrupted joy and pleasures.' Pythagoras said: 'How do you hope for dispensing while wearing bodies, and how do you attain emancipation while you are imprisoned in them?' 'Ammonius' said: 'As for Empedocles and those before him up to Heraclitus, they saw that filthy souls remain clinging to the world until they seek help from the Soul...'

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
Universal [Soul], so it humbles itself to the Intellect, and the Intellect to the Creator, so He pours His light upon it, and the Intellect pours from it upon the Universal Soul while it is in this world. It becomes illuminated by it until the Particular [Soul] sees the Universal [Soul] and connects with it, joining its world, except that this happens after many eons pass over it. Then it proceeds to where there is no place, no time, and nothing of what is in this world of fatigue or interrupted joy.
Socrates said: The soul by itself proceeds to the Holiness that is Ever-Living, eternally steadfast, due to what is in it of similarity upon abandoning spatial confinement. It becomes like it in permanence because it is affected by it in a manner resembling contact, and its affection is called Intellect. He also said: The soul is very similar to the Divine Substance which does not die and does not dissolve, and the One Intelligible steadfast in eternity, while the body «1» is contrary to it. When they join, nature commands the body to serve and the soul to rule. When they separate, the soul goes to other than the place of the body and becomes happy with what resembles it, resting from spatial confinement, foolishness, anxiety, passion, loneliness, and other human evils. That is if it was pure and hating the body. But if it became defiled by agreeing with the body, serving it, and loving it until the body subjugated it with desires and pleasures, it does not see anything more worthy than the corporeal type and touching it.
"Abruqlus" [Proclus] said: The body which the rational soul occupied before the spherical shape is like the ether «2» and its individuals. And that which the non-rational [soul] occupied before uprightness is like the human. And that which the non-rational [soul] occupied alone before uprightness with bending is like the non-rational animals. And that which was devoid of both and nothing existed in it other than the vegetative power before uprightness, and its bending was completed by inversion and its head was planted in the earth, is like the condition in plants. Since it became contrary to the human, the human is a heavenly tree whose root is towards its origin, which is the sky, just as the root of the plant became towards its origin, which is the earth.
The Indians went regarding nature to something similar to that. "Arjun" [Arjuna] said: What is the example of Brahm in the world? "Basdiv" [Vasudeva/Krishna] said: Imagine him as the "Ashvattha" «3» tree, which is known...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
...to them as one of the great and noble trees, inverted in position. Its roots are in the height and its branches are in the depth. Its nourishment became abundant until it thickened, and its branches spread «1» and clung to the earth and hung from it. Its branches and roots resembled each other in both directions so they became confused. Brahm is the upper roots of this tree, its trunk is "Bed" [Veda], its branches are opinions and doctrines, its leaves are explanations and interpretations, its nourishment is by the three powers, and its thickening and cohesion is by the senses. The wise person has nothing but cutting it with a sharp axe, which is asceticism in the world and its adornments. If he succeeds in cutting it, he seeks from its Originator the place of settlement in which return (rebirth) is nonexistent. If he attains it, he leaves the harm of heat and cold behind him and arrives from the light of the two luminaries and fires to the Divine Lights.
The Sufis went to the path of "Patanjal" [Patanjali] in occupation with the Truth. They said: As long as you point, you are not a monotheist until the Truth takes over your pointing by annihilating it from you, so neither a pointer nor a pointing remains. In their speech is what indicates the saying of Union (Ittihad), like the answer of one of them about the Truth: "How do I not verify He who is 'I' in I-ness and 'Not I' in where-ness? If I returned, then by return I separated; and if I neglected, then by negligence I lightened; and by Union, I joined." And like the saying of Abu Bakr al-Shibli: "Cast off the all, you reach us in totality, so you be and not be; your reporting is about us and your action is our action." And like the answer of Abu Yazid al-Bistami when he was asked, "By what did you attain what you attained?": "I shed myself as the snake sheds its skin, then I looked at my essence, and lo, I was He." They said regarding the saying of Allah the Exalted "So We said, strike him with part of it" «2»: The command to kill the dead to revive the dead is information that the heart does not live by the lights of knowledge except by killing the body through striving until it remains a trace with no reality, and your heart is a reality with no trace of the traces upon it. They said: Between the servant and Allah are a thousand stations of light and darkness. The striving of the people is only in cutting through the darkness to the light. When they reached the stations of light, they had no return.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
H - On the Genera of Creatures and their Names
This is a chapter difficult to obtain with verification because we view it from the outside, and those people do not refine it. Because of our need for it in what follows, we establish from it all that has been heard up to the time of writing these letters. We narrate first what is in the book "Sank" [Samkhya] of it. The Ascetic said: How many are the genera of living bodies and their types? The Sage said: Their genera are three: the Spirituals in the highest, Humans in the middle, and Animals in the lowest. As for their types, they are fourteen. Of them for the Spirituals are eight: Brahm [Brahma], Indra, Prajapat [Prajapati], Saumya «1», Gandharb [Gandharva], Yaksh [Yaksha], Rakshas [Rakshasa], and Pishach [Pishacha]. And of them for the Animals are five: cattle, wild beasts, birds, creeping things, and growing things, meaning trees. And Humans are one type. The author of this book enumerated them in another place in it with other names thus: Brahm, Indra, Prajapat, Gandharb, Yaksh, Rakshas, Pitr [Pitri], Pishach. These are a people who rarely observe order and guess greatly in enumeration, so names with them are many and the field is empty.
"Basdiv" [Vasudeva] said in "Gita" [Gita]: Indeed the first power of the three first [Gunas], if it dominates, is composed on intellect, purification of senses, and work for the angels; therefore, comfort becomes of its followers and salvation of its results. If the second dominates, it is composed on greed and leads «2» to fatigue and incites to the works...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
...of Yaksh and Rakshas, and the reward in it is according to the work. If the third dominates, it is composed on ignorance and deception by wishes until it generates sleeplessness, negligence, laziness, delaying of the obligatory, and constant slumber. If he works, it is for the genera of "Bhut" [Bhuta] and "Pishach" [Pishacha], the devils, and for "Pret" [Preta] carrying souls in the air, neither in Paradise nor in Hell; and its consequence is punishment and descent from the rank of humans to animals and plants. He said in another place in it: Faith and virtue are from the Spirituals in "Dev" [Deva]. Therefore, he who resembles them among humans becomes a believer in Allah, holding fast to Him, yearning for Him. Disbelief and vice are in the devils named "Asur" [Asura] and "Rakshas" [Rakshasa]. He who resembles them among humans becomes a disbeliever in Allah, not turning to His commands, stripping the world of Him, occupied with what harms in both abodes and does not benefit.
If these sayings are combined, the disorder appears from them in names and in order. As for what is famous among the public of the eight genera of Spirituals, it is "Dev" [Deva], and they are the angels; they have the direction of the North and their specialty is India. It has been said: "Zardusht" [Zoroaster] opposed the Shamaniyya [Buddhists] in naming the devils with the name of the most noble class among them, and that remained in Persian from the side of Magianism. Then "Daitya Danava", and they are the Jinn who are in the direction of the South; in their share is everyone who opposed the creed of India and was hostile to the cow. Despite the closeness of kinship between them and the angels, they claimed: Conflict does not cease between them nor do their wars calm down. Then "Gandharb" [Gandharva], the masters of melodies and songs before the angels; their harlots are called "Apsaras". Then "Yaksh" [Yaksha], the treasurers of the angels. Then "Rakshas" [Rakshasa], deformed devils. Then "Kinnar" [Kinnara], in the form of humans except their heads, for they are heads of horses, contrary to the Centaurs (Qantursat) of the Greeks, for the form of the horse is in the lower half of the body and the form of the human is in its upper «1» half, and of it is the image of Sagittarius. Then "Nag" [Naga], and they are in the form of serpents. Then "Vidyadhar" [Vidyadhara], and they are Jinn sorcerers whose magic does not last in currency. So the Angelic power is at the first end, devilry is at the lower end, and mixing is between the two ends.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
Their attributes only differed because they attained this rank by work, and works are different according to the three powers. Their duration was long due to their stripping from bodies. Obligation was removed from them, and they were capable of what humans were incapable of, so they served them in demands and drew near to them in needs. We should know from what we narrated from "Sank" that it is not verified. For "Brahm", "Indra", and "Prajapat" are not names for types. Rather, Brahm and Prajapat are close in meaning; their names differ by the difference of a certain attribute. And "Indra" is the chief of the worlds. Also, "Basdiv" counted "Yaksh" and "Rakshas" together in one class of devilry, and the "Puranas" speak regarding Yaksh: That they are treasurers and servants of treasurers.
We say after this: The mentioned Spirituals are a class that attained their rank by work at the time of being human and left bodies behind them, for they are weights removing ability and shortening duration. Their attributes and conditions differed according to the dominance of the three first powers over them. "Dev", meaning the angels without matter, were specialized with the first of them [Sattva], and comfort and happiness were obtained for them, and the conception of the intelligible outweighed in them, just as the conception of the sensible in matter outweighed in humans. "Pishach" and "Bhut" were specialized with the third [Tamas], and the ranks between them with the second [Rajas]. They said regarding the number of Dev: It is thirty-three Koti (Crore); of it for Mahadev is eleven. Therefore, this number became one of his titles and his name indicating it. The total of the mentioned number for the angels is [330,000,000]. Then they allowed for them the meaning of eating, drinking, intercourse, life, and death because they are in the realm of matter, even if they are from it in the subtler, simpler side, and because they attained that by work, not knowledge. In the book of "Patanjal": "Nandikeshvara" «1» increased sacrifices to Mahadev, so he transferred to Paradise in his corporeal mold. And "Indra" the Chief committed adultery with the wife of "Nahusha" the Brahmin, so he was transformed into a snake by way of punishment. Beneath them is the rank of "Pitrin" [Pitris], the dead fathers. Beneath these are "Bhut", humans who have connected with spirituality and mediated. As for those who passed the rank not stripped of the body, they are called "Rishi" and "Siddha" [?] and they differ...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
...in attributes and are distinct. Siddha is the one who attained by his work power over what he wills in the world and restricted himself to that and did not strive in the path of salvation. He has the ascent to the rank of "Rishi". To it the Brahmin graduates and is called "Brahmarshi". If a "Kshatriya" graduates to it, he is called "Rajarshi", and that is not for those below them. "Rishis" are the sages who, despite their humanness, are better than the angels due to knowledge; therefore, the angels benefit from them. There is none above them except Brahm. Below these are their classes existing among us, and for their mention is a separate chapter.
All of these are under Matter. As for the conception of what «1» is above it, we said «2»: The Hyle (Hayula) is an intermediary between Matter and what is above it of psychic and divine meanings. In it are the three first powers in potentiality. It is as if the Hyle, with what is in it, is a bridge from the high to the low. What flows in it upon the first power [Sattva] purely is called "Brahm" [Brahma] and "Prajapat" [Prajapati] and many other names from the perspective of law and reports. Its meaning returns to Nature in the prime of its action, because creation until the creation of the world is attributed to Brahm by them. What flows in it upon the second power [Rajas] is called "Narayan" [Narayana] in the reports. Its meaning returns to Nature at the end of its action reaching its limit, for it strives then in preservation, just like the striving of Narayan in rectifying the world so it remains. What flows in it upon the third power [Tamas] is called "Mahadev" and "Shankar" [Shankara], and his most famous name is "Rudra", and he is for corruption «3» and annihilation, like Nature in the ends of its action and the languor of its power. Their names only differ after the flowing in these ascents and steps to the low, so their actions differ. As for before that, the source is one. Therefore, they combine them in it and do not separate one of them from the other and call him "Bishn" [Vishnu]. This name is more appropriate for the middle power; rather, they do not distinguish between it and the First Cause. They go the way of the Christians in distinguishing the names of the Hypostases (Persons) by Father, Son, and Holy Spirit from each other and combining them in one substance. This is what appears from their speech upon consideration and acquisition. As for upon the face of report...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...and narration in which superstition abounds, its mention will come during the speech. One should not wonder «1» at their sayings regarding the class of "Dev" which we expressed as angels «2» and their allowing for them what minds do not allow of what the theologians of Islam cleared them from regarding its permissible, let alone its forbidden. For if you combine those sayings of theirs with the sayings of the Greeks in their creed, the strangeness disappears. We have presented that they used to call the angels "gods". So review what was narrated for them regarding "Zeus" so that you verify what we said. As for what proceeds in it from the resemblance of animality and humanity, it is their saying: That when he was born, his father wanted to eat him. His mother preceded by wrapping a stone in rags and fed it to him until he left. Galen mentioned that in the "Book of Miamir" in his saying: That "Philon" «3» spoke in riddles in describing the electuary of "Philonia" in his poetry and said: Take red hair «4» from the hair from which the scent of perfume wafts, which is the offering of the gods, and its blood; and weigh from it weights according to the minds of people. He meant by that saffron, five mithqals, because the senses are five. He mentioned the rest of the mixtures with their weights in types of symbols which Galen interpreted. Among them: And from the root lied against, which grew in the land in which "Zeus" was born. He said: This is the spikenard because it is lied against in its name; it was named "Sumbul" (Spike) but it is not a spike; rather it is a root. He ordered it to be "Cretan" because the people of proverbs say about "Zeus" that he was born on Mount "Dicte" in "Crete" where his mother used to hide him «5» from his father "Cronus" so he would not swallow him as he swallowed others. Then what is in the famous histories of his marrying known women one after another and impregnating some of them, usurped and unmarried. Among them is "Europa daughter of Phoenix" whom «6»...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ..."Asterius" King of "Crete" took from him, and she bore for him after that "Minos" and "Rhadamanthus" «1». That was far in time from the exit of the Children of Israel from the Wilderness to the land of Palestine. And what was mentioned that he died in Crete and was buried there in the time of "Samson" the Israelite, and he was seven hundred and eighty years old. And that he was named "Zeus" when his life became long after he used to be called "Dios". And that the first who named him by this name was "Cecrops" the first king in Athens. The situation between them in collusion was on what they inclined to of releasing the phallus right and left and easing the leadership of leadership on the resemblance of the situation of "Zoroaster" with "Gushtasp" in what they aimed for of strengthening the kingdom and politics. Historians have claimed that scandals among the people occurred from Cecrops and the kings who rose after him. They meant by that the likeness of what is in the accounts of Alexander, that "Nectanebo" King of Egypt, when he fled from "Artaxerxes" the Black (Ochus) and hid in the city of "Macedonia" «2» practicing astrology and divination, tricked "Olympias" the wife of "Philip" its king while he was absent, until he used to cover her deceptively and show himself in the form of "Amun" the god in the figure of a ram-horned serpent until she became pregnant with Alexander. "Philip" almost disowned him and exiled him upon his return, then he saw in a dream that he was the offspring of the god Amun, so he accepted him and said there is no opposition with the gods. The death of "Nectanebo" was at the hands of Alexander by way of hugging «3» (pushing into a pit) during astrology, and from that he knew that he was his father. The likes of this are many in their accounts, and we will bring «4» its counterparts in the marriages of the Indians. Then we say: As for what does not connect to humanity in the matter of "Zeus", it is their saying: That he is Jupiter, son of Saturn, because Saturn according to the owners of the "Canopy" (Stoics?), as Galen said in the "Book of Demonstration": Is eternal in existence alone, not generated. What is in the book of "Aratus" in "Phenomena" suffices, for he opens it with the glorification of Zeus: And that he is the one whom we, the assembly of people, do not leave nor dispense with; who filled the roads and the gatherings of people, and he is...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...compassionate to them, manifesting beloved things, rousing them to work, reminding of livelihood, informing of the chosen times for digging and plowing for healthy growth, and who set up signs and stars in the sphere. Therefore, we humble ourselves to him first and last. He praises «1» the Spirituals after him. When you compare between the two classes, these were the descriptions of Brahm. The commentator on the book "Phenomena" claimed that he differed from the poets in their beginning with the gods, that he decided to speak on the sphere. Then he looked also as Galen looked into the lineage of "Asclepius" and said: We would love to know which Zeus Aratus meant, the symbolic or the natural? Because "Crates" (?) the poet named the sphere "Zeus". Likewise "Homer" said: As pieces of snow are cut from Zeus. Aratus named the Ether «2» and the air Zeus in his saying: That the roads and gatherings are filled with him and that all of us need to inhale him. Therefore, he claimed that the opinion of the owners of the "Stoa" (Stoics) regarding Zeus is that he is the Spirit diffused in the appropriate Hyle for our souls, meaning Nature governing every natural body. He attributed compassion to him because he is the cause of good things. So rightly he claimed that he is not only the father of people but of the gods also.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
I - Mentioning the Classes they call Colors (Varnas) and what is below them
Every affair issuing from one naturally fond of politics, deserving by his virtue and strength of leadership, firm in opinion and resolve, aided by a state in the successors by their leaving opposition to the predecessors; indeed that affair becomes confirmed with the ordered one, a confirmation of the anchored mountains. It remains among them obeyed in the descendants over the recurrence of days and the passing of epochs. Then if that relied on a side of the sides of a creed, the two twins met, and the matter was completed by the meeting of Kingship and Religion, and there is no goal beyond perfection that is intended.
The ancient kings concerned with their craft used to direct most of their concern to classifying people into classes and ranks, guarding them from mixing and chaos, forbidding intermingling upon them because of it, binding every class to what is for it of work or craft and profession, not licensing anyone to exceed his rank, and punishing whoever was not satisfied with his class. The lives of the early Chosroes (Persian Kings) articulate that; they have strong traces in it which no approaching by service nor mediating by bribe could impugn. Until "Ardashir bin Babak", upon his renewal of the kingdom of Fars, renewed the classes. He made the knights and sons of kings in their first, the ascetics and servants of fires and lords of religion in their second, the physicians and astrologers and possessors of sciences in their third, and the farmers and craftsmen in their fourth. On ranks in each one distinguishing the types in their genera separately by themselves. Everything that was on this example became like lineage if its beginnings were mentioned, and a property «1» if...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...its causes and rules were forgotten. And forgetting is inevitably coupled with the prolongation of the period, the lapse of times, and the multiplication of centuries. The Indians in our days have the most ample shares of that, such that our differing from them and our equalizing among the whole except by piety is the greatest of barriers between them and Islam. They call their classes "Varna", meaning Colors, and they call them from the perspective of lineage "Jataka" [Jati], meaning Births. These classes in the beginning of the matter are four. Their highest is the "Brahmins". It has been mentioned in their books that their creation is from the head of "Brahm" [Brahma], and that this name is a metonymy for the power called "Nature". The head is the highest part of the animal, so the Brahmins are the choice of the genus, and therefore they became with them the best of mankind. The class that follows them is "Kshatriya". They were created, by their claim, from the shoulders of Brahm and his hands. Their rank is not very far from the rank of the Brahmins. Below them are "Vaishya". They were created from the legs of Brahm. These two last ranks are close. Despite their distinction, cities and villages bring them together; the four of them are mixed in dwellings and houses. Then the possessors «1» of professions below these are not counted in a class other than the craft, and they are called "Antyaja". They are eight types by crafts, and they intermingle with what resembles them of other crafts except the fuller, the shoemaker, and the weaver, for the rest of them do not descend to their craft. They are the fuller, the shoemaker, the juggler, the weaver of baskets and shields, the sailor, the fisherman, the hunter of wild beasts and birds, and the weaver. The four classes do not dwell with them in a town; rather, they shelter in dwellings near it and outside it. As for "Hadi", "Dom", "Chandala", and "Badhatau", they are not counted in anything. They are only occupied with the vilest of works of cleaning villages and serving them. All of them are one genus distinguished by work like the child of adultery. For it was mentioned that they return to a "Shudra" father and a "Brahmin" mother, having come out of them by fornication, so they are outcasts, degraded. Marks and titles attach to every one of the people of the classes according to his action and way. Like the Brahmin, for example; this is his mark absolutely if he keeps to his house in his work. If he keeps to serving one fire, he is titled "Ishti". If he serves three of the fires, he is "Agnihotri". If he offers to the fire along with that, he is "Dikshit". Likewise are these, except that "Hadi" is the most praiseworthy of them...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
...because he elevates himself above filth. Following him is the Dom because he plays the lute «1» and sings. After them, one becomes a candidate for killing and punishments as a craft and takes charge of it «2». The worst of them is "Badhatau" «3», for he does not restrict himself to eating the usual carrion but exceeds it to dogs and the likes of that. Each class of the four lines up in eating separately. A row does not include two individuals of different classes. If in a row of Brahmins, for example, there are two individuals among them who are mutually averse and their seats are close, a separation is made between the two seats by a board placed between them, or a cloth extended, or another thing; indeed, a line is drawn between them as a distinction. Because the leftover from food is forbidden, it necessitates being solitary with the eaten, because if one of the eaters takes from a single bowl, what remains by the taking of the other and the cessation of the eating of the first becomes a forbidden leftover.
This is the condition of the four classes. "Basdiv" [Vasudeva] said when "Arjun" «4» asked him about the natures of the four classes and what morals they must characterize themselves with: The "Brahmin" must be of ample intellect, calm heart, truthful tongue, apparent endurance, controlling the senses, preferring justice, of apparent cleanliness, approaching worship, his concern directed to religion. And the "Kshatriya" must be awesome in hearts, brave, aggrandizing, eloquent of tongue, generous of hand, indifferent to hardships, eager to ease difficulties. And the "Vaishya" must be occupied with agriculture, acquiring cattle, and trade. And the "Shudra" must be diligent in service and flattery, endearing himself to everyone by it. Everyone of these, if he remains firm on his custom and habit, attains the good in his will if he is not falling short in the worship of Allah, not forgetting His mention in most of his works. If he transfers from what is for him to what is for another class, even if it is nobler than him, it is a sin by transgression in the command. He also said to Arjun «5», encouraging him to fight the enemy: Do you not know, O...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...long of reach, that you are a "Kshatriya" and your genus is molded on bravery, daring, lack of concern for the calamities of days, and opposing the soul in its talk of anxiety? For reward is not attained except by that. If he wins, then to kingship and bliss; and if he perishes, then to Paradise and mercy. Beyond what you show of softness for the enemy and panic over the killing of this group is the spreading of your news of cowardice and failure, the departure of your reputation from among the tyrants and the strong brave ones, and your fall from their eyes and your name from their whole. I do not know a punishment more severe than this condition. So death is better than exposure to what bequeaths shame.
