If Allah commanded you and qualified your class for fighting and created you for it, then execute His command and implement His will with a resolve stripped of greeds so that your work is for Him. As for Salvation (Moksha), they differed regarding who is prepared for it among these classes. Some of them said: It is for none other than the "Brahmins" and "Kshatriya" what is not possible for them alone of learning the "Bed" [Veda]. The verifiers among them said: Salvation is common to the classes and to all the human type if intention is obtained for them perfectly. That is by the indication of the saying of "Byas" [Vyasa]: Know the twenty-five by way of verification, then profess whatever religion you wish, for you are saved inevitably. And by the indication of the coming of "Basdiv" [Vasudeva/Krishna] from the offspring of a "Shudra" (Vasudeva is usually Kshatriya/Yadava, text might imply something else or referring to a specific tradition) and his saying to Arjun «1»: Indeed Allah is capable of reward without injustice or favoritism. He counts evil as good if He is forgotten in it, and good as evil if He is mentioned in it and not forgotten, even if its doer is a "Vaishya" or a "Shudra" or a woman, let alone being a "Brahmin" or a "Kshatriya".

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
J - On the Source of Laws, Canons, Messengers, and the Abrogation of Laws
The Greek [civilization] used to take laws and canons from their sages who were delegated for that, attributed to divine support, such as "Solon", "Draco", "Pythagoras", "Minos", and their likes. Likewise, their kings used to do it. For "Minos", when he ruled over the islands of the sea and the "Cretans", and that was after the days of Moses by close to two hundred years, established laws for them claiming they were taken from "Zeus". In that time "Minos" established the laws. In the time of "Darius" the First, who was after "Cyrus", he sent messengers of the Romans to the people of "Athens", and they took the laws from them in twelve books, until "Numa Pompilius" ruled them and took charge of establishing the laws for them. He made the months of the year twelve after they had been ten for them. What indicates his compelling them is that he established their transactions with pottery and hides instead of silver, for that would be from rage at one who does not obey. In the first essay of the "Book of Laws" [The Laws] by Plato, the stranger from the people of Athens said: Who do you think was the cause of establishing laws for you? Is it some angel or some human? The "Knossian" (Clinias) said: It is some angel. As for in reality with us, it is Zeus. As for the people of "Lacedaemon", they claim that the establisher of laws for them is "Apollo". Then he said in this essay: It is obligatory on the establisher of laws, if he is from Allah, to make his purpose in establishing them the acquisition of the greatest virtues and the utmost justice. He described the laws of the people of "Crete" with this description, and that they complete the happiness of one who uses them...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
...correctly, because he acquires by them all human goods connected to divine goods. The "Athenian" said in the second essay of this book: When the gods had mercy on the race of humans because it is molded on fatigue, they prepared for them festivals for the gods and for the Sekinas (Muses?), and for Apollo the manager of the "Sekinas", and for Dionysus the granter of wine to humans as a medicine for the astringency of old age, so they return young by forgetting melancholy and the transfer of the soul's character from hardship to safety. He also said: Indeed they inspired them «1» with the measures of dance and rhythm of even weight as a reward for fatigues, and so they become accustomed with them in festivals and joys. Therefore, a type of types of music in the symbol for the prayers of the gods was named "Hymns".
This was the condition of these people. Upon the like of it is the matter of the Indians. For they see the Sharia and its laws issuing from the "Rishis", the sages, the bases of religion, not the Messenger who is "Narayan" [Narayana/Vishnu] imaged upon his coming in the forms of humans. He will not come except to cut off the material of evil looming «2» over the world or to remedy a reality. There is no substitution in anything of the matter of laws; rather, you work «3» by them as you find them. For this reason, dispensing with messengers occurred among them in the chapter of law and worship, even if the need for them occurred in the interests of creation. As for their abrogation, it seems it is not impossible for them, because they claim that many things were permissible before the coming of "Basdiv" [Vasudeva/Krishna] then were forbidden, among them the meat of cows. That is due to the change of the natures of people and their inability to bear duties. Among them is the matter of marriages and lineages. For lineage at that time was on one of three types: One of them from the loins of the father in the womb of the wedded mother, as it is now with us and with them. The second from the loins of the son-in-law in the womb of the daughter conducted [to him] if it was stipulated that the child belongs to her father; so the child of the daughter then belongs to the stipulating grandfather, not the sowing father. The third from the loins of the stranger in the womb of the wife, because the land belongs to the husband, so the children of the woman belong to her husband if the sowing was with consent...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...from him. On this mode, "Pandu" was attributed to the sonship of "Shantanu". That is because there presented to this king, by the curse of some ascetics upon him, what prevented him from approaching his women, along with the lack of a child. So he asked "Byas bin Parashar" [Vyasa son of Parashara] to raise for him from his women a child to succeed him. He sent one of them to him. She feared him when she entered upon him and trembled, so she conceived from him, according to that condition, a sickly yellow one (Pandu). Then he sent the second to him. She was shy of him and veiled herself with her veil, so she gave birth to "Dhritarashtra", blind and unfit. He sent the third and advised her to reject awe and shyness. She entered laughing and rejoicing, and conceived "Vidura" who surpassed people in jest and cleverness. The four children of "Pandu" had a common wife among them who stayed with each one for a month. Indeed, in their books: "Parashar" the ascetic rode a boat in which the boatman had a daughter. He fell in love with her and seduced her «1» until she yielded, except that there was no screen on the shore from eyes. A "Tamarisk" grew immediately to facilitate the matter. He lay with her behind the tamarisk and impregnated her with his son, this virtuous "Byas". All of that is now annulled and abrogated. For this reason, the permissibility of abrogation is imagined from their speech. As for these scandals in marriages, some of it exists now and in the pasts of Ignorance (Jahiliyyah). For the inhabitants of the mountains extending from the region of "Panjhir" to near "Kashmir" make obligatory the gathering on one woman if they are brothers. The marriage of the Arabs in their Jahiliyyah was on types. Among them is that one of them would prescribe to his wife to send to So-and-so and seek intercourse from him, then he would avoid her during the days of her pregnancy out of desire for the nobility of the child. This is the third division of the Indians. Among them is that he would say to the other: get down from your wife for me and I will get down for you from my wife; so they do it by exchange. Among them is that a group would cover her, and when she delivered, she would attach him to his father; if she did not know him, the physiognomists would know him. Among them is "Nikah al-Maqt" (Marriage of Abomination) with the wife of the father or the son; the name of the child from it is "Dayzan". It is not far from the Jews, for it was prescribed upon them that a man marry the wife of his brother if he died and did not leave offspring, and generate for his deceased brother a progeny attributed to him not to himself, so his mention does not perish from the world. They call the doer of that in Hebrew "Yabam". Likewise...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...the Magians. In the book of "Tansar the Herbad of Herbads" to "Padashwargarshah" «1» answering what he accused "Ardashir bin Babak" of: The matter of exchange (Ibdal) among the Persians, if a man dies and does not leave a child, is that they look; if he has a wife, they marry her to the nearest of his agnates in his name. If he has no wife, then the daughter of the deceased or one of his female relatives. If none is found, they propose on agnation from the wealth of the deceased. Whatever child there is belongs to him. Whoever neglects that and does not do it has killed uncounted souls because he cut off the progeny of the deceased and his mention until the end of time. I only narrated this so that the beauty of the Truth is known opposite it, and what differed from it increases in ugliness upon comparison «2».

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
K - On the Origin of Idol Worship and the Nature of the Setup Ones
It is known that the common nature inclines to the sensible and is averse to the intelligible which none intellects except the knowledgeable ones described in every time and place by scarcity. Due to its tranquility with the example, many of the people of creeds turned to imaging (representation) in books and temples, like the Jews and Christians «1», then the Manichaeans specifically. Sufficient witness to what I said is that if you showed the picture of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, or Mecca and the Kaaba to a commoner or a woman, you would find, from the result of joy in it, motives of kissing, dusting the cheeks, and rolling [in dust], as if he witnessed the imaged one and performed by that the rites of Hajj and Umrah. This is the cause motivating the creation of idols with the names of magnified persons from the prophets, scholars, and angels, reminding of their matter at absence and death, remaining as traces of their magnification in hearts upon loss, until the era became long for those who made them, and centuries and epochs revolved over them, and their causes and motives were forgotten, and they became a custom and a sunnah «2» used. Then the owners of laws entered them from their door since that was more imprinted in them, so they made them obligatory upon them. Thus the reports arrived regarding those who preceded the era of the Flood and those who came after it. Until it was said that the existence of people before the mission of messengers as one nation was on the worship of idols. As for the people of the Torah, they specified the beginning of this time with the days of "Serug" the grandfather of...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...the father of "Ibrahim" [Abraham]. As for the Romans, they claimed that "Romulus" and "Remus", the two brothers from the Franks, when they ruled, built "Rome". Then Romulus killed his brother. Earthquakes and wars followed successively after him until Romulus humbled himself, so he was shown in a dream that that would not calm down unless he seated his brother on the throne. So he made an image of gold and seated it with him. He used to say, "We commanded such-and-such." The custom of kings after him ran on this address, and the earthquakes calmed. He took a feast and a playground to distract possessors of grudges regarding the brother. He set up four statues for the sun on four horses: the green one for the earth, the sky-blue for water, the red for fire, and the white for air. They remain standing in Rome until now. Since we are in the narration of what the Indians «1» are upon, we narrate their superstitions in this chapter after informing that that is for their commoners. As for one who aimed for the path of salvation or studied the ways of argumentation and theology and desired verification which they call "Sara" [Sara/Essence] «2», he declares himself above worshipping anyone other than Allah the Exalted, let alone His made image. Among those stories is what "Shaunaka" told King "Parikshit". He said: There was in the past times a king named "Ambarisha" who attained his wish of the kingdom. He turned away from it and renounced the world and secluded himself for worship and glorification for a long time until the Worshipped One appeared to him in the form of "Indra" the chief of angels riding an elephant and said: Ask whatever appears to you so I may give it to you. He answered him: I am pleased to see you and grateful for what you offered of success and aid, but I do not ask from you but from Him who created you. "Indra" said: The purpose in worship is the good reward for it, so obtain the purpose from the one you found it from and do not critique saying 'not from you but from other than you'. The King said: As for the world, it has been obtained for me, and I have turned away from all that is in it. My intended purpose from worship is seeing the Lord, and it is not yours (in your power), so how can I ask my need from you? Indra said: All the world and whoever is in it are in my obedience, so who are you to oppose me? The King said: I am likewise hearing and obeying, except that I worship Him from whom you found this power...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...and He is the Lord of All who guarded you from the calamities of the two kings "Bali" and "Hiranyaksha". So leave me and what I preferred and return from me in peace. Indra said: Since you refuse but to oppose me, I am your killer and destroyer. The King said: It has been said that good is envied and evil has an opposite, and whoever secludes himself from the world, the angels envy him, so he is not free from their misleading him. I am among those who turned away from the world and turned to worship. I am not leaving it as long as I am alive. I do not know a sin for myself for which I deserve killing from you. If you are doing it without a crime from me, then [do] your affair and what you want. However, if my intention is pure for Allah and my certainty is not mixed with impurity, you will not be able to harm me. What you distracted me with from worship is enough for me. He returned to it. When he began it, the Lord appeared to him in the form of a human of the color of the dark blue water lily (Nilotpala), in yellow clothing, riding the bird named "Garuda". In one of his four hands was "Shankha", which is the conch shell blown on the backs of elephants. In the second was "Chakra" «1», which is the round sharp encompassing weapon which, if thrown, cuts what it hits. In the third was an amulet (Gada/Mace?). In the fourth was "Padma", which is the red water lily. When the King saw him, his skin shivered from awe, and he prostrated and glorified much. He comforted his loneliness and gave him glad tidings of winning his desire. The King said: I had attained a kingdom in which no one disputed me, and a condition which sadness or illness did not spoil for me. It was as if I attained the world in its entirety. Then I turned away from it when I verified that its good in the end is evil upon verification. I did not wish other than what I attained now. I do not want after it other than liberation from this bond. The Lord said: It is by abandoning the world in solitude «2» and holding fast to thought and withdrawing the senses to yourself. The King said: Suppose I was capable of that because of the honor I was qualified for, how can other than me «3» be capable of it? Man must have food and clothing, and they are connectors between him and the world, so is there other than that? He said to him: Use your kingdom and the world in the moderate and best way, and direct the intention to Me in what you do of constructing the world and protecting its people and in what you give in charity, nay in all movements. If the forgetfulness of humanity overcomes you...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: So make an image as you saw me, worship it with perfume and flowers, and make it a remembrance of me so that you do not forget me. If you suffer, [do so] with my mention; if you speak, [do so] with my name; and if you act, [do so] for my sake.' The King said: 'I have understood the generalities, so honor me with clarification and detail.' He said: 'I have done so and have inspired "Vasistha" your judge with everything needed, so rely on him for the issues.' Then the figure disappeared from his sight. The King returned to his seat and did what he was commanded. They said: From that time on, idols were made, some with four hands as we described, and some with two hands, according to the story and description and according to the owner of the image. They also reported that Brahma had a son named "Narada" who had no ambition other than seeing the Lord. It was his custom in his wanderings to hold a staff with him; when he threw it down, it would become a snake, and he would perform wonders with it, and it never left him. While he was contemplating his desire, he saw a light from afar. He headed towards it and was called from it: 'What you ask and wish for is impossible to exist, for you cannot see me except like this.' He looked, and behold, there was a luminous figure in the likeness of human figures. From that time on, idols were established with forms. Among the famous idols is the idol of "Multan" [Multan, Pakistan] in the name of the Sun, and for that reason, it was called "Aditya". It was made of wood covered with red Cordovan leather, and in its eyes were two red rubies. They claim that it was made in the earlier "Krita Yuga". Suppose it was at the end of that time, then from it to us is 216,432 years. When Muhammad bin Qasim bin al-Munabbih conquered Multan, he looked into the reason for its prosperity and the wealth gathered therein, and he found that idol, as it was a destination visited from every direction. He saw it prudent to leave it, after hanging cow meat on its neck in mockery of it, and he built a congregational mosque there. When the "Qarmatians" took over Multan, "Jalam ibn Shayban", the usurper, broke that idol, killed its custodians, and made its house, which was a palace built of baked brick on a high place, into a congregational mosque instead of the first mosque, which he closed out of hatred for what was built in the days of the Umayyads. When Prince Mahmud [of Ghazni], may Allah have mercy on him, removed their hands from those kingdoms, he restored the Friday prayer to the first mosque and neglected this second one, so now it is nothing but a threshing floor...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...for henna. If we drop the hundreds and what is below them due to the time of the appearance of the "Qarmatians" being earlier than our days—assuming that is around one hundred years—there remains 216,000 years, which is the time from the end of "Krita Yuga" to near the beginning of the Hijra. So how could the wood remain for that duration given the humidity of the air and the earth there! And Allah knows best. The city of "Taneshar" (Thanesar) [Thanesar, India] is venerated among them. Its idol was called "Chakrasvamin", meaning the owner of the Chakra, which is a weapon we have described. It is made of copper, close in size to the size of a human. It is now thrown in the hippodrome in Ghazna [Ghazni, Afghanistan] along with the head of "Somnath", which is a representation of the genitalia of "Mahadeva" (Shiva). This image is called "Linga". The news of Somnath will come in its place. As for Chakrasvamin, they said: It was made in the days of "Bharata" as a memorial of those wars. Inside "Kashmir" [Kashmir], a journey of two or three days from the capital towards the mountains of "Bolor" [Gilgit-Baltistan], there is a wooden idol house called "Sharada" which is venerated and visited. We mention the summaries of a chapter from the book "Samhita" regarding the making of idols, which aids in knowing what we are discussing. "Varahamihira" said: If the image made is for Rama son of Dasaratha or for Bali son of Virochana, make the height one hundred and twenty digits of the idol's digits. For others, reduce that by a tenth, meaning one hundred and eight. Make the hands of the idol of "Vishnu" eight, or four, or two. On his left side under the breast is the image of the woman "Sri" (Lakshmi). If you make him with eight hands, place in the right a sword, in the second a mace of gold or iron, in the third an arrow, and the fourth as if scooping water. In the left, a shield, a bow, a Chakra (discus), and a conch. If you make him with four, drop the bow and arrow. If you make him with two hands, let the right be scooping and in the left a conch. If the image is "Baladeva", the brother of "Narayana", put earrings in his ears and make his eyes intoxicated. If you make both images, join with them their sister "Bhagavati" (Ekanamsha), her left hand on her hip, turning away from...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...the side, and in her right is a lotus. If you make her with four hands, in the right is a rosary and a scooping palm, and in the left a book and a lotus. If you make her with eight, in the left is a "Kamandalu" which is a pot, a lotus, a bow, and a book; and in the right a rosary, a mirror, an arrow, and a scooping palm. If the image is for Samba son of Vishnu, place in his right hand a mace only. If it is for Pradyumna son of Vishnu, in his right hand is an arrow and in the left a bow. If you make their two wives, place in the right a sword and in the left a shield. The idol of "Brahma" has four faces in the four directions, on a lotus, and in his hand is a pot. The idol of "Skanda son of Mahadeva" is a boy riding a peacock; in his hand is a "Shakti", which is like a sword cutting on both sides and its handle is in its middle like the handle of a pestle. In the hand of the idol of "Indra" is a weapon called "Vajra" made of diamond, which is like the "Shakti" in the handle, but on each side of it are two swords meeting at the handle; place on his forehead a third eye and mount him on a white elephant with four tusks. Likewise, place in the forehead of the idol of "Mahadeva" a third eye standing vertically, on his head a crescent, and in his hand a weapon called "Shula" (Trident) resembling a mace with three branches, and a sword; his left hand holding his wife "Gauri daughter of Himavant", pressing her to his chest from his side. As for the idol of "Jina", who is the "Buddha", exaggerate in beautifying his face and limbs, and make the palms of his hands and the soles of his feet in the shape of a lotus, sitting on the like of it, with greyish hair, cheerful as if he is the father of creation. If you make "Arhant", which is the image of another body for the Buddha, make him a naked youth, beautiful of face, benevolent, his hands reaching his knees, and the image of the woman "Sri" under his left breast. The idol of "Revanta son of the Sun" is riding a horse like a hunter. The idol of "Yama", the Angel of Death, is on a male buffalo and in his hand is a mace. The idol of "Kubera" the Treasurer is crowned, large of body, wide of sides, riding a human. The idol of the Sun has a red face like the pith of the red lotus, shining like a gem, with prominent limbs...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...with earrings in the ears, the neck adorned with pearls hanging onto his chest, crowned with a crenelated crown, in his hands two lotuses, dressed in the clothing of the people of the North (Udichya), reaching down to his ankles. If you make the Seven Mothers, group them together. "Brahmani" has four faces in the four directions. "Kaumari" has six faces. "Vaishnavi" has four hands. "Varahi" has a head like a boar's head on a human body. "Indrani" has many eyes and a mace in her hand. "Bhagavati" is sitting as is customary. "Chamunda" is deformed, with protruding fangs and a shrunken belly. Then join to them the two sons of "Mahadeva": "Kshetrapala" with bristling hair, a grim face, and deformed appearance; and "Vinayaka" (Ganesha) whose head is the head of an elephant on a human body with four hands as previously mentioned. Near the group of these idols, sheep and buffaloes are killed with Kataras (daggers) so they may feed on their blood. All idols have measurements in their digits determined for their limbs, and perhaps there is disagreement in some of them. If the maker maintains them and does not add or subtract, he is far from sin and safe from the owner of the image causing him harm. If he makes the idol one cubit and with its throne two cubits, he attains safety and fertility. If he increases upon that, it is praiseworthy, provided he knows that excessive largeness of the idol, especially the idol of the Sun, is harmful to the ruler, and its smallness is harmful to its maker. Shrinking its belly brings continuous hunger to the region, and making it emaciated destroys wealth. If the hand of the maker slips so that he makes a mark on it like a blow, a blow will also occur on his body by which he will be killed. If he falls short in leveling so that one of its shoulders rises above the other, his wife will perish. If he turns its eye upwards, he will go blind in his life, or if downwards, his worries and anxieties will increase. When the sculpted idol is of one of the gems, it is better than wood, and wood is better than clay. For the benefits of the gem encompass the men of the kingdom and its women. Gold grants its owner strength, silver grants praise, copper grants increase in territory, and stone grants ownership of lands. The idol is honored by its owner (subject), not by its material...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...for we have mentioned that the idol of "Multan" was wooden. Likewise, the "Linga" that "Rama" set up upon finishing the battle with the demons was of sand he piled up with his hand, which petrified quickly because the chosen time for setting it up preceded the workers' finishing of the carving of the stone one he had ordered. As for building its house and the portico around it, cutting trees of specific kinds, choosing the time for setting it up, and establishing the rituals for it, it is a matter that is long and tedious. Then he ordered the establishment of servants and custodians for it from various sects. For the image of "Vishnu", the sect of "Bhagavata"; for the image of the Sun, the sect of "Maga", i.e., the Magians; for the image of "Mahadeva", the sect of "Uragara" (or similar ascetics), who are ascetics that grow their hair long, smear their skins with ash, hang the bones of the dead on themselves, and wander in the thickets. For the Eight Mothers, the "Brahmins". For Buddha, the "Shramanas". For "Arhant", the sect of "Nagna" (naked ones). In summary, for every idol, there are people who formed it, for they are more guided to its service. The purpose of recounting this nonsense was to know the image from its idol if seen, and to verify what we said that these idols are set up for the common people whose ranks are low and whose knowledge is short. For no idol was ever made in the name of One who is above matter, let alone Allah the Almighty. And to know how the low-minded are enslaved by delusions. Therefore, it is said in the book "Gita": 'Many people draw near to Me in their desires through other than Me, and seek means through charities, glorification, and prayer to other than Me; so I strengthen them upon it, grant them success in it, and bring them to their will because of My independence from them.' And in it also, "Basudeva" (Krishna) said to Arjuna: 'Do you not see that most of the hopeful ones address in sacrifices and service the genera of spiritual beings, the Sun, the Moon, and other luminaries? If Allah does not disappoint their hopes due to His independence from them, and increases upon their request and gives them that from the direction they intended, they turn to worshipping their intended ones due to the shortness of their knowledge of Him, while He is the one completing their matters in this mode of intermediation. There is no permanence for what is attained through greed...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...and intermediaries, as it is according to merit. Permanence is only for what is attained through Allah alone when one becomes weary of old age, death, and birth.' This is what is in the speech of Basudeva. These ignorant people, if they find success by chance or determination, and added to that is some trickery of the custodians by collusion, their veils (of ignorance) strengthen, not their insights, and they rush to those images, destroying their own forms before them by shedding their blood and mutilating themselves in front of them. The Greeks in ancient times used to place idols as intermediaries between themselves and the First Cause, and worshipped them with the names of the stars and the high substances, since they did not describe the First Cause with anything of affirmation, but rather by negating opposites to honor and exalt Him; so how could they intend Him for worship! When the Arabs transported idols from Sham (Syria) to their land, they worshipped them likewise to bring them closer to Allah. Here is Plato saying in the fourth treatise of the book "The Laws": 'It is obligatory upon he who gives complete honors to set up idols for the gods and the Shekinahs with a secret (mystery), and not to prioritize specific idols for the ancestral gods. Then the honors for parents if they are alive, for it is the greatest of duties according to ability.' He means by the 'secret' the 'mention' (Dhikr) in the special sense, which is a term frequently used among the "Harranian Sabians", the "Manichaean Dualists", and the theologians of India. Galen said in the book "Ethics of the Soul": 'In the time of "Commodus" one of the Caesars, which is close to five hundred and some years ago (from Galen's time), two men came to an idol seller in Alexandria and bargained with him for an idol of "Hermes". One of them wanted to set it up in a temple to be a memorial for Hermes, and the other wanted to set it up on a grave to remember the deceased by it. Neither trade was concluded, so they delayed his matter to the next day. The idol seller saw in his sleep that night as if the idol was speaking to him and saying: "O virtuous man! I am your creation. I have benefited from the work of your hands a form attributed to a star (planet), so the attribute of stoniness by which I was named before has departed from me, and I became known as Mercury. So the matter is up to you now in making me a memorial for something that does not corrupt or for something that has corrupted."' There is a letter by Aristotle in response to questions from the Brahmins sent to him by Alexander...

text: Chapter 12: On the Veda, the Puranas, and their Religious Books. "Veda" implies the knowledge of what is not known. It is speech they attributed to Allah the Almighty from the mouth of "Brahma". The "Brahmins" recite it as a recitation without understanding its meaning. They learn it likewise among themselves, one taking it from another. Then, only a few of them learn its interpretation, and fewer than that are those who engage in its meanings and interpretations by way of examination and debate. They teach it to the "Kshatriya", so he learns it without being permitted to teach it, even to a Brahmin. Then it is not lawful for a Vaisya or a Sudra to hear it, let alone pronounce it and read it. If that is proven against one of them, the Brahmins hand him over to the ruler, who punishes him by cutting off the tongue. The Veda contains commands, prohibitions, encouragement, and intimidation with specification, designation, reward, and punishment. Most of it is on hymns and fire sacrifices of types that can hardly be counted due to number and difficulty. They do not allow writing it down because it is read with melodies, so they refrain from the inability of the pen and its causing addition or subtraction in the written text. For this reason, it was lost to them several times. For they claim that in the addresses of Allah the Almighty with Brahma in the beginning, according to what "Shaunaka" narrated - transmitted by the planet Venus from him: 'You will forget the "Veda" at the time when the earth drowns, and it will go to its bottom. No one will be able to bring it out except the Fish, so send it so it hands it over to you; and send the Boar so it lifts the earth with its tusks and brings it out of the water.' They also claim that...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...the Veda was obliterated among what was obliterated of the customs of their religion and worldly life in the lower "Dvapara", which is a time we will mention in its chapter, until "Vyasa son of Parasara" renewed them. In "Vishnu Purana": It is renewed at the beginning of every time of the "Manvantara", the owner of a turn whose children own all the earth, and a chief who heads the world, and angels for whom people perform fire sacrifices, and the "Daughters of Na'sh" (Ursa Major/Seven Rishis) renew the perished Veda at the end of every turn. For that reason, near our time, "Vasukra" the Kashmiri, one of the eminent Brahmins, volunteered to interpret the Veda and preserve it in writing. He bore the burden of sin that others refrained from out of fear that it would be forgotten and lost from memories, and that was when he saw the corruption of people's intentions and their lack of desire for good, indeed for duty. Then they claim that there are places in it that are not read in settlements for fear of causing miscarriages in pregnant women and animals, so they go out to the desert to read them. No assigned text is free from such scaremongering. We had previously presented regarding their books that they are measured by meters like Rajaz poems, and most of them are in a meter called "Sloka" for the reason we presented. Galen approves of this and says in the book "De Compositione Medicamentorum" (On the Composition of Drugs): 'Single letters for the weights of medicines are corrupted by copying and are also corrupted by the obscuring of the envious. For this reason, "Democritus" deserved that his books on medicines be chosen, their matter publicized, and praised because they are written in measured poetry in Greek, for that would be beautiful.' This is because prose is more susceptible to corruption than verse. The "Veda" is not on that common meter, but on a meter other than it. Some of them say: It is miraculous; no one among them can compose the like of it. The verifying scholars among them claim that this is within their power, but they are prohibited from it out of respect for it. They said: "Vyasa" divided it into four parts: "Rigveda", "Yajurveda", "Samaveda", and "Atharvaveda". He had four "Shishyas", meaning students, and he taught each one one part or burdened him with it. They are, in the order of the mentioned parts: "Paila", "Vaisampayana", "Jaimini", "Sumantu". For each of the...

text: ...four parts, there is a method in reading. As for the first, the Rigveda, it is composed of verse called "Ric", segments of unequal measures. Rigveda was named by it as if it is the collection of Ric. It contains fire sacrifices. It is read with three types of reading: one is evenly like the custom in all readings; the second is by stopping at every single word; and the third, which is the best of them and promised abundant reward, is to read a small segment of it with known words, repeat it, add something from the unread to it, then repeat this added part alone, read it, and add another to it, and continue doing this so the recited text is repeated upon its completion. As for "Yajurveda", its verse is composed of "Kandali" (Kandika?), and its name is derived from it, meaning the collection of Kandali. The difference between it and the first is that this one can be read continuously, while it is not possible in the first. It contains what is in that one of fire works and sacrifices. I heard regarding the reason for the separation of "Rigveda" from continuity in reading that "Yajnavalkya" was with his teacher, and the teacher had a Brahmin companion who wanted to travel. He asked him to send someone to his house to establish the conditions for "Homa", meaning his fire, and preserve it from extinguishing during his absence. The teacher used to send his students there by turn. Yajnavalkya's turn came, and he was handsome in appearance, clean in dress. When he started what he was sent for in the presence of the absent man's wife, she disliked his adornment. Yajnavalkya sensed what she concealed. When he finished and took water in his hand to sprinkle it on the woman's head—for that stands in place of blowing (spitting lightly) after supplication, as blowing is disliked and impure among them—the woman said: 'Sprinkle it on that pillar.' He did so, and the pillar turned green immediately. The woman regretted her excess and came to the teacher the second day asking him to send the one sent yesterday. Yajnavalkya refused to go except in his turn. Persistence did not work on him, and he did not care about the teacher's anger, but he said to him: 'Take back from me what you taught me.' When he said that, he was made to forget what he knew. He went to the Sun and asked him to teach him the "Veda". The Sun said: 'How is that possible with my perpetual motion and your inability to do the like!' So Yajnavalkya clung to the wheel of the Sun and began learning the Veda from him, and was forced to break up the reading due to the disturbance in the movement of the wheel. As for "Samaveda"...

text: ...it contains sacrifices, commands, and prohibitions, and is read with a melody like singing, and it was named so because "Sama" is pleasant speech. The reason for its melodies is that "Narayana", when he came in the form of "Vamana" and came to King "Bali", made himself a "Brahmin" and began reading Samaveda with a melodious tune that enchanted him until his affair happened as it did. As for "Atharva", it is continuous, not from the first two verses, but from a third called "Bhara", and is read with a melody with nasalization. People's desire for it is less. It also contains fire sacrifices and commands regarding the dead and what must be done with them. As for the "Puranas", and the interpretation of "Purana" is the First Ancient, they are eighteen. Most of them are named after animals, humans, and angels because they contain their news or because the speech in them or the answer to questions is attributed to them. They are the work of the people called "Rishis". What I had of them taken from mouths by hearing are: "Adi Purana" meaning the First, "Matsya Purana" meaning the Fish, "Kurma Purana" meaning the Tortoise, "Varaha Purana" meaning the Boar, "Narasimha Purana" meaning the Human whose head is a lion's head, "Vamana Purana" meaning the man with contracted limbs due to smallness, "Vayu Purana" meaning the Wind, "Nanda Purana" who is a servant of Mahadeva, "Skanda Purana" who is the son of "Mahadeva", "Aditya Purana" and "Soma Purana" which are the two luminaries, "Samba Purana" who is the son of "Vishnu", "Brahmanda Purana" which is the heavens, "Markandeya Purana" who is a great "Rishi", "Tarkshya Purana" who is the Garuda, "Vishnu Purana" who is "Narayana", "Brahma Purana" who is the nature entrusted with the world, and "Bhavishya Purana" which is the mention of beings in the future. I have seen nothing of them except segments of "Matsya", "Aditya", and "Vayu". Then "Vishnu Purana" was read to me in another form, so I recorded it also as obligatory in what refers to reports, and they are: "Brahma", "Padma" meaning the Red Lotus, "Vishnu", "Siva" who is "Mahadeva", "Bhagavata" meaning "Basudeva", "Narada" who is the son of "Brahma", "Markandeya", "Agni" who is Fire, "Bhavishya" which is what will be, "Brahmavaivarta"...

Books in all arts are numerous, so who can gather them by their names, especially if he is a stranger to their people? They have a book whose status reaches such magnification among them...

text: ...that they decisively judge that whatever is found in others is inevitably found in it, and not everything in it is found in others. Its name is "Bharata" (Mahabharata), made by "Vyasa son of Parasara" during the days of the Great War between the children of "Pandu" and the children of "Kuru". Those days are also referred to by this name. The book is one hundred thousand "Slokas" in eighteen parts, each called "Parva". The first is "Sabha Parva", meaning the seat of the King. The second is "Aranya", which is going out to the desert by the departure of the children of "Pandu". The third is "Virata", which is the name of a king in whose kingdom they were during the time of hiding. The fourth is "Udyoga", which is preparation for fighting. The fifth is "Bhishma". The sixth is "Drona" the Brahmin. The seventh is "Karna son of the Sun". The eighth is "Shalya" brother of "Duryodhana". These are among the great brave ones who took charge of the fighting one after the killing of the other. The ninth is "Gada", which is the mace. The tenth is "Sauptika", which is the killing of the sleepers when "Ashvatthama son of Drona" attacked the city of "Panchala" at night and killed its people. The eleventh is "Jalapradanika", which is giving water in the name of the dead, scoop by scoop, and that is after washing from the impurity of handling and touching them. The twelfth is "Stri", which is the wailing of women. The thirteenth is "Shanti", twenty-four thousand "Slokas" on removing rancor from hearts, and it is four sections: "Rajadharma" on the reward of kings, "Danadharma" on the reward of charities, "Apaddharma" on the reward of the distressed and tested, and "Mokshadharma" on the reward of the one liberated from the world. The fourteenth is "Asvamedha", which is the sacrifice of the horse sent out with the army to roam the world, and it is proclaimed over it that it belongs to the King of the World, and whoever refuses that let him come forth, and the "Brahmins" follow it to establish fire sacrifices at its stopping places. The fifteenth is "Mausala", which is the mutual killing of "Yadu", the tribe of "Basudeva". The sixteenth is "Asramavasika", meaning leaving the homeland. The seventeenth is "Prasthana" (Mahaprasthanika), which is leaving the kingdom to seek salvation. The eighteenth is "Svargarohana", which is rising towards Paradise. Following these eighteen is one other part called "Harivamsa Parva", containing the news of "Basudeva". In this book, there are passages like riddles, bearing in the language...

text: Chapter 13: On Their Books on Grammar and Poetry. These two arts of sciences are tools for the rest of them. The foremost among them for them is the science of language called "Vyakarana", which is grammar that corrects their speech and etymologies that lead them to eloquence in writing and rhetoric in speech. We are not guided to anything of it because it is a branch of a root we lack, I mean the language itself. What I heard of the names of their books in this chapter is: The book "Aindra", attributed to "Indra" the head of the angels; the book "Candra", made by "Candra" who was one of the Red-Robed ones, the companions of Buddha; the book "Sakata" (Sakatayana) by the name of its author, and his tribe is also called by it "Sakatayana"; the book "Panini" by the name of its author; the book "Katantra" made by "Sarvavarman"; the book "Shisya-hita-vritti" made by "Ugrabhuti"; the book "Durgavritti"; and the book "Shishyahitavritti" made by "Ugrabhuti". It was told to me that this man was the tutor of the Shah in our time, "Anandapala son of Jayapala", and his instructor. When he made this book, he sent it to "Kashmir" [Kashmir], but its people did not pay attention to it due to their pride in that (field) and their arrogance. So the man complained about that to the Shah, who guaranteed him, by the right of discipleship, to achieve his desire. He ordered the dispatch of two hundred thousand dirhams and gifts resembling them to Kashmir to be distributed among those who engaged with his teacher's book. So they all rushed to it and copied other than it...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...by copying it, and they humbled themselves out of greed, and the book became famous and elevated. They said regarding the origin of this science: One of their kings, named "Samalvahana", and in eloquent speech "Satavahana", was one day in a pool playing with his wives. He said to one of them: "Ma udakam dehi", meaning 'Do not sprinkle water on me'. She thought he said: "Modakam dehi", meaning 'Bring sweets'. So she went and came with it. The King denied her action, and she was harsh in reply and rough in speech. The King became distressed by that and abstained from food as per their custom, and secluded himself until one of their scholars came to him and consoled him by promising to teach him grammar and the inflections of speech. That scholar went to "Mahadeva" praying, glorifying, fasting, and supplicating until he appeared to him and gave him simple rules, just as Abu al-Aswad al-Du'ali established in Arabic, and promised him support in what follows of the branches. The scholar returned to the King and taught him them, and that was the beginning of this science. Following it is "Chandas", which is the measure of poetry corresponding to the science of Prosody. They cannot dispense with it because their books are in verse, and their intent in that is to make memorization easy. They do not refer to the book in sciences except out of necessity. That is because the soul yearns for everything that has proportion and order and is disgusted by what has no order. For this reason, you see most Indians raving about their poetry and eager to read it even if they do not know its meaning, and they snap their fingers in joy with it and approval of it, and they do not desire prose even if its knowledge is easy. Most of their books are "Slokas". We are in trials from it in what I translate for the Indians from the book of "Euclid" and the "Almagest" and what I dictate on the craft of the Astrolabe to them, out of my eagerness to spread knowledge and that what they do not have falls to them. They busy themselves with making them into Slokas where the meaning is not understood because the verse necessitates affectation which becomes clear when we mention their numbers. Otherwise, I would confront them with writing it as it is in prose, and they would be alienated; may Allah grant me justice from them. The first to extract this art were "Pingala" and "Chalit" (?). The books made in this chapter are many. The most famous is the book "Gitam" (?) by the name of its author so that prosody is also nicknamed by it, and the book "Mrigalanchan", and the book "Pingala", and the book "Oliyand" (?). I have not seen any of them nor much of the treatise in "Brahmasiddhanta" regarding its calculation such that I can verify the laws of their prosody. Yet, I do not permit turning away from what I smell...

In counting letters, they depict something similar to what Al-Khalil bin Ahmad and the prosodists among us depicted for the quiescent and the moving (consonants/vowels), and they are these two forms: [Symbol]. The first, which is on the left because their writing is so, is called "Laghu" (Light) - |, and the second which is on the right is "Guru" (Heavy) - S. Its measure in estimation is that it is double the first; nothing fills its place except two of the Light. Among their letters are what is also called Long (Dirgha), and its measure is the measure of the Heavy. I think they are the ones whose quiescents (sukoon) are defective (vowels). Although I am until now not certain of the state of the Light and Heavy such that I can represent them in Arabic, the most likely opinion is that the first is not a quiescent (sukoon) and the second is not a moving (vowel), but rather the first is a moving only (short vowel) and the second is a combination of moving and quiescent (long vowel/closed syllable) like the 'Sabab' in our prosody. I only doubt the matter because of what I find of them gathering a large number of consecutive signs of Light, and the Arabs do not combine two quiescents, while that is possible in other languages. These are what the prosodists of Persian called moving letters of light movement, for exceeding three of them is difficult for the speaker, indeed pronouncing them is impossible, and they do not flow like the flow of combined moving letters in our saying: "Badanuka kamithli sifatika wa famuka bi-sa'ati shafatik" (Your body is like your description and your mouth is the width of your lip). Also, due to the difficulty of starting with a quiescent, most Indian names start with what is not quiescent, so it is from the hidden movements. If the beginning of the verse is like that, they drop that letter from the count because the condition of the Heavy is that its quiescent follows, not precedes. Then I say, just as our companions made form 'Fa-a-la' (Arabic meter roots) molds for the structures of poetry and numbers for the moving and quiescent among them to express the meter, likewise the Indians named what is composed of Light and Heavy by advancing and delaying and keeping the measure in estimation without counting the letters, titles by which they indicate the assumed meter. I mean by estimation that "Laghu" is one Matra, meaning measure, and "Guru" is two Matras. So attention is not paid to the count in writing without estimation, just as the stressed letter (Shaddah) is counted as a quiescent and a moving, and the Tanween (nunation) as a moving and a quiescent, even if each of them is one in writing. As for the two individually, the Light is called...

text: He defined by it the method of making combinations by induction and said: Place one of the two types purely in the first row. Then mix it with the second type; place one of it in the beginning of the second row and the remaining from the first type. Then place this mixed one in the middle of the third row, and place it at the end of the fourth row; you have finished the first half. Then place the second type also purely in the bottom row, and mix with the row above it one from the first type, placing it at its beginning, and in the middle of the one above it, and the end of the one above them. The other half is complete, and nothing remains of the ternary combinations. As for the composition, it is regular. However, the calculation he cited to know the ranks of the rows is not consistent with it. It is that he said: Place for each one of the letters of the row two as a base always, so it will be like this: 2 2 2. Multiply the left by the middle and the product by the right. If the multiplication is in the share of a Light, leave the total as it is. If it is in the share of a Heavy, subtract one from the total. He gave an example for the sixth row, which is: [Symbol], by multiplying two by two and subtracting one from the total, then multiplying the three by the remaining two, so six resulted. But that is not correct in most rows, and it seems a corruption occurred in the manuscript. As for the placement, if it is like this:

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: It is that the mixture of the right line is by alternating one from another, the mixture of the middle line is two of a type and two of another, and the mixture of the left is four of this and four of that, according to the pairs of the pair in the mixtures of the lines. Then it was added in the mentioned calculation that if the beginning of the row is with the share of a Heavy, subtract one from it before multiplication, and if the multiplication is in the share of a Heavy, subtract one from the sum, the desired number of the row's rank is obtained. Just as Arabic verses are divided into two halves by Arud and Darb, the verses of those people are divided into two parts, each called a "Pada" (Foot). The Greeks also call "Feet" what syllables are composed of words, and wars (beats?) by sound and its absence, length, shortness, and intermediacy. The verse is divided into three feet and four, which is the most common. Perhaps a fifth foot is added in the middle. It is not rhymed, but if the end of the first and second foot is a single letter like rhyme, and likewise the end of the third and fourth is also a single letter, this type is called "Orali" (?). It is permissible at the end of the foot for the Light to become Heavy, even if the construction of the genus is based on ending with Light. Their poetry, its branches, and divisions encompass very many meters. The one with five feet, the fifth is intermediate between the first two and the last two. According to the number of its letters, the titles differ in it, and according to what follows it also. For they do not like the verses of the poem to be all of one class, but they make them from many classes to be like embroidered brocade. As for the placement of the four feet in the one with four, it is in this form: [Diagram]. This is an example of a type of their meters called "Skandha", having four feet. It is two halves; in each of them are eight "Amshas". It is not permissible from their singulars in the first...

The twelfth is "Gana, Chalana, Paksha, Hastan «4»". The thirteenth is "Parvata...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...Kama, Kusuma, Madhy, Chalana". The fourteenth is "Hasta, Paksha, Parvata, Kusuma, Parvata, Loka, Kara". The fifteenth is "Pakshan «1», Parvata, Kusuma, Kaman «2», Kara". The sixteenth is "Paksha, Parvata, Kama, Kusuma, Paksha, Loka, Kara". The seventeenth is "Pakshan «1», Parvata, Gana, Chalana, Paksha, Kusuma". The eighteenth is "Pakshan «1», Parvata, Gana, Chalana, Kaman «2»: «3»". The nineteenth is "Kara, Pakshan «1», Parvata, Gana, Chalana, Kaman «2», Kara: «4»". The twentieth is four "Paksha, Chalana, Madhy, Paksha, Mana «5», Kara". The twenty-first is four "Paksha three, Chalana, Madhyan «5», Kara". The twenty-second is four "Paksha, Kusuma, Madhy, Chalana, Madhyan «5», Kara". The twenty-third is eight "Kara, ten Loka, Kama, Chalana, Loka, Kara". I only prolonged the narration even if...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...its benefit is scant, so that the combination of light [syllables] is witnessed, and it is known that they are moving [letters] not quiescent ones, and to encompass the manner of their templates and the scansion of their verses, and to know that Al-Khalil bin Ahmad was successful in the derivations, even if it is possible that he heard that the Indians have meters in poetry as some people thought of him. We burdened ourselves with that so that the condition of the "Shloka" [Sloka] is established by it, because the structures of books are upon it. So we say: It is of those possessing four feet, each one having eight letters. They are not similar in the feet. The ends of the four are of one genus, which is the Heavy [Guru]. One of its conditions is that the fifth letter in all its feet be light [Laghu] always, and the sixth in them be heavy, and the seventh in each of the second and fourth feet be light, and in the remaining two heavy. Then the rest of the letters are however they happened or were intended. In order that the manner of using calculation in it be known, we say, narrating from "Brahmagupta": Indeed the first of the genera of poetry is "Gayatri", and it possesses two feet. If we assume the number of letters of this genus to be twenty-four, and the minimum number of letters of the foot to be four, the two feet would be thus: 4:4 on the minimum possible. But the assumed for them is 24, so the remainder 16 we add to the right foot until they become 20:4. If it were possessing three feet, it would be 16:4:4, for the right foot is distinguished always, named by a name separately, and what is before it of the feet are combined as one sentence and named by a name separately. If it were possessing four feet, it would be 12:4:4:4. If we do not work on the four which is the minimum possible in the foot, and we wanted the pairings occurring in the one with two feet from the twenty-four letters, we add one to the left foot and subtract one from the right, and place the two results under them, each one in its side. One continues to do that until ending at the like of the two numbers which are in the beginning of the two lines, exchanged, on the example of this image: [Table/Image]. The number of these pairings is seventeen, like the difference between the first two numbers with one added to it. As for the one with three feet on the assumed number, its beginning placed on the minimum as we mentioned would be 16:4:4. So the right and middle [feet] stand in the place of the two feet of the one with two feet, and one works...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...with them what preceded of subtracting one in the right and adding it in the middle until the first two numbers are obtained exchanged. Nothing is done with the left other than repetition until thirteen pairings are obtained on this image: But by advancing and delaying, they become six times that, which is seventy-eight. I mean that the right be in its place and the remaining ones be exchanged so the left becomes middle and the middle left. Then the right is moved and placed between the remaining two, fixed in their state and exchanged. Then the right is moved to the outer side of the left with the fixity of the position of the remaining two and with their exchange. Because the difference in the numbers of the foot is like even of even, the number which is after the four in it is the eight. So it is allowed that the letters of the three feet be placed «1» thus: 8:8:8, except that the numerical properties...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...are for it according to another law. And the one with four [feet] is on the analogy of the one with three. I have only studied one leaf of the mentioned treatise, and it undoubtedly contains precious things of numerical principles. May Allah grant success and provide by His grace. The Greeks, according to what I infer from their books, used to follow their [Indians'] path regarding the feet of poetry. For Galen says in the book "Katagenes": Indeed the medicine made with the juices which "Menecrates" extracted, "Democrates" described it in measured poetry possessing three hemistichs.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
14 - Mentioning their Books in other Sciences
Sciences are many, and by the alternation of thoughts upon them, they are increasing whenever their time is in prosperity. Its sign is the desire of people for them and their honoring of them and of their people, and those most worthy of that are those who follow them. For its action empties the hearts occupied with the necessities of the world and shakes «1» the sides for increase of praise and satisfaction. For hearts are molded on the love of that and the hatred of its opposite. Our time is not of the mentioned description, but of its opposite, inevitably. So when will a science grow in it or a grower develop? What exists in it are only remnants and dregs from the times that were on that description. If a thing encompasses the earth, every sect on it takes its share, and the Indians are one of them. Their belief regarding the regression of days accords with what is found by viewing. The science of astronomy among them is more famous due to the connection of the matters of the religion with it. He who does not know the judgments (astrology) among them, the attribute of astronomy does not apply to him by mere calculation. What our companions know as "Sindhind" is "Siddhanta", meaning the Straight that does not become crooked nor change. This name applies to everything whose rank is high among them of the science of the calculation of stars, even if it is deficient with us compared to our Zijes (astronomical tables). It is five: One of them is "Surya Siddhanta" attributed to the Sun, undertaken by "Lata". The second is "Vasishtha Siddhanta" attributed to one of the stars of the Great Bear (Ursa Major), made by "Vishnuchandra". The third is "Paulisa Siddhanta" attributed to "Paulus" the Greek from the city of "Saintra" [?], and I think it is...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...Alexandria, made by "Paulus". The fourth is "Romaka Siddhanta" attributed to the Rum (Romans/Byzantines), made by "Srishena". The fifth is "Brahma Siddhanta" attributed to Brahm, made by "Brahmagupta bin Jishnu" in the city of "Bhillamala" [Bhinmal], which is between "Multan" and "Anhilvara" sixteen "Yojanas". All of them rely on the book of "Pitamaha" attributed to the First Father, who is Brahm. "Varahamihira" made a small-sized Zij named "Pancha Siddhantika". The name necessitates its containing what is in the five, but it is not so. Then it is not better than them so that it could be said it is the most correct of the five; rather the name establishes the five for their number. Then "Brahmagupta" says: Indeed the Siddhantas are many; among them is "Surya", and among them is "Indu", and among them is "Paulisa", and among them is "Romaka", and among them is "Vasishtha", and among them is "Yavana", meaning the Greek. Despite their multitude, they do not differ except in wording, not in meaning. Whoever contemplates them with true contemplation knows their agreement. I have not obtained until now a copy except that of Paulisa and that of Brahmagupta, without their translation having been completed for me yet. I mention the index of the chapters of "Brahma Siddhanta" for that is beneficial in knowledge: 1. On the conditions of the globe and the form of the heaven and the earth. 2. On the cycles of the planets and the manipulation of times and extracting the mean motions of the planets and making sines for arcs. 3. On the true positions of the planets. 4. On the three questions which are the shadow, the past of the day, and the ascendant, and extracting some of them from others. 5. On the appearance of the planets from the rays of the sun and their disappearance by it, and on the sighting of the crescent moon and the condition of its two horns. 7. On the eclipse of the moon. 8. On the eclipse of the sun. 9. On the shadow of the moon. 10. On the conjunction of planets and their association. 11. On the latitudes of the planets. 12. On the criticism of what is in the books and Zijes and distinguishing the correct from the incorrect. 13. On arithmetic and its manipulation in areas and other things. 14. On verifying the mean motions of the planets. 15. On verifying the true positions of the planets. 16. On verifying the three questions. 17. On the deviations of the eclipse. 18. On verifying the sighting of the crescent and its horns. 19. On "Kuttaka", which is pulverizing, in the sense of likening the exertion in seeking to the pounding of what oil is extracted from; and it is on algebra and comparison with unknown quantities and on other numerical demands. 20. On the matters of the shadow. 21. On the calculations of the meters of poetry and its prosody. 22. On circles and instruments...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...23. On times and the four measures, meaning the solar, the rising [sidereal?], the lunar, and the lunar mansion [measure]. 24. On the signs of numbers and numerals within the verses. So that is twenty-four chapters. He said: And the twenty-fifth is "Dhyanagraha" in which «1» demands are extracted «2» by thought without manipulating calculation. I did not mention it here because the causes are removed by calculation. I think that what he pointed to is the proofs of the operations, otherwise when is anything extracted from this art without calculation? Everything that falls below the rank of "Siddhanta" is called mostly either "Tantra" or "Karana". As for Tantra, its meaning is what is disposed under the hand of the worker. As for Karana, its meaning is the follower, meaning of the Siddhanta. Also, its workers are the "Acharyas", meaning the ascetic scholars, and they are followers of Brahm. Each of "Aryabhata" and "Balabhadra" has a known "Tantra". And "Bhanuyasas" has the book "Rasayana Tantra"; and Rasayana is explained in its chapter. As for "Karana", it is attributed to his name. For Brahmagupta is "Karana Khandakhadyaka". This is a name for a type of sweetmeat among them. I heard regarding the reason for naming it that, that "Sugriva the Buddhist" made a Zij he named "Dadhigrah" [Dadhigram?], meaning the Ocean of "Mast" (Yogurt). A student of his made a Zij he named "Kurubabya" [?], meaning a Mountain of Rice. Then he made "Lavanamushti", meaning a Handful of Salt. Therefore, "Brahmagupta" named his book Sweetmeat to complete the meal. What is in it is according to the opinion of "Aryabhata". Therefore, he followed it with a book he named "Uttara Khandakhadyaka", meaning its verification. Another book follows it; I do not verify if it is his or another's, called "Khandakhadyaka Tippa", containing the causes of the numbers used in it and what they are, although I strongly suspect it is by Balabhadra. For "Vijayananda" the Commentator in the city of "Varanasi" is a Zij known as "Karana Tilaka", meaning the Blaze of the Followers. And for "Viteshvara bin Mahadatta" from the city of "Nagarapura" is a Zij he named "Karana Sara", meaning the Extracted from the Followers. And for "Bhanuyasas" is the book "Karana Para Tilaka", by which, they claimed, the true positions of the planets are extracted from each other. And for "Utpala" the Kashmiri "Rahunrakarana" [?], meaning the Breaker of the Followers, and "Karana Pata", meaning the Killer of the Followers, and "Karana Chudamani"; and I do not know its author. Then other books with other names like "Manasa" the Great from...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...the work of "Manu" and the commentary of "Utpala". And like Manasa the Small, abridged by "Punjala" from the southern region. And like "Dasagitika" by Aryabhata, and "Aryashtasata" by him. And like "Lokananda" by the name of its author. And like the book of "Bhattila" the Brahmin by his name. And what can hardly be counted of this genus. As for their books in the judgments of the stars (Astrology), each of "Mandavya", "Parashara", "Garga", "Brahm", "Balabhadra", "Divyatat" [?], and "Varahamihira" has a book "Samhita". Its interpretation is: The Collection containing something of everything, like the travel memo on atmospheric events, affairs of states, and elections (Muhurtas), then physiognomy, dream interpretation, and augury. Their scholars believe in it. It became the custom of their astrologers to express the science of atmospheric and worldly events as Samhita. Each of "Parashara", "Satya", "Manittha", "Jivasharman", and "Mau" the Greek has a book "Jataka", meaning Nativities. Varahamihira has two of them, small and large; Balabhadra commented on them, and I translated the smaller of them into Arabic. In the chapter of Nativities is a large book of theirs called "Saravali", meaning the Chosen, resembling the "Bazidaj" (Persian astrological text?), made by "Kalyana Varman" the King, and he used to refer to a scholarly virtue. And a book larger than it, comprehensive in every chapter of judgments, known as "Yavana", meaning that of the Greeks. Varahamihira has small books, among them "Shatpanchasika", fifty-six chapters on Horary Astrology (Prashna), and the book "Hora Pancha Hotri" [?] on it also. On travels, the book "Yoga Yatra" and the book "Tikni Yatra" [Tiknikayatra?]. On wedding and marriage, the book Vivahapatal «1». On buildings, a book «2». Then «2» on what resembles augury and omens, the book "Sravadhava" [?], and it is in three copies: one of them attributed to "Mahadev", the owner of the second is "Vimalabuddha", and the owner of the third is "Bangala". And the book "Chudamani", meaning the Science of the Unseen, made by "Buddha", the master of the Red Shamaniyya (Red-robed Buddhists?). And the book "Prashna Chudamani", meaning Questions of the Science of the Unseen, made by "Utpala". Among their scholars whose name did not pass with a book: "Pradyumna", "Sangahila", "Divakara", "Preshvara", "Sarasvata", "Piruvan", "Devakirta", and...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ..."Prithuyasas Swami". The science of Medicine is with the science of Astronomy in conjunction, were it not for the entanglement of that one with the Creed. They have a book known by its author, who is "Charaka". They prioritize it over their books in medicine. They believe regarding him that he was a "Rishi" in the Lower "Dvapara" (Yuga) and his name was "Agnivesha", then he was named "Charaka", meaning the Intelligent, when he acquired medicine from the ancients, the children of "Sutra" [?], and they were Rishis. These took it from "Indra", and Indra took it from "Ashvin", one of the two physicians of "Dev", and this one took it from "Prajapati", who is Brahm the First Father. This book was translated for the Barmakids into Arabic. They have other arts of science, many, and books that can hardly be counted, but I have not encompassed them in knowledge. I wish I were able to translate the book "Panchatantra", which is known among us as the book of "Kalila wa Dimna". For it circulated between Persian and Hindi, then Arabic and Persian, on the tongues of people whose altering of it is not safe, like Abdullah bin al-Muqaffa' in his addition of the chapter of "Burzuyah" in it, intending to make the weak of belief doubt the religion and breaking them for the call to the doctrine of the "Manichaeans". If he is suspected in what he added, he is not free from the like of it in what he transferred.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
15 - Mentioning Knowledge of their Measurements so mentioning them becomes easy during the speech
Enumeration is imprinted in the human being. A thing becomes known in magnitude if it is added to what is named of its genus as 'one' by convention. By that, the difference between it and another that is of its genus becomes known. As for weight, by it the amount of heaviness is known from the perspective of transport when the column of the instrument is parallel to the horizon. The Indians rarely need a balance because their Dirhams are numerical (counted), and their fractions by Fuls (copper coins) are also counted. The dies of both are different such that they are attributed by them to their cities and borders. They only weigh gold with the balance, stamped or stamped non-minted. They use in it a measure they call "Suvarna". Three-quarters of it is called "Tola". Their usage of Tola is frequent, analogous to our usage of the Mithqal. According to what I knew of it from their side, it balances of our Dirhams by the weight of seven, three Dirhams (meaning 7 Tolas = 3 Dirhams? Or relation 7:3? Likely text corruption or specific context). So the Tola of our Mithqals is two Mithqals and a tenth of a Mithqal. The greatest parts of the Tola are twelve, and they are called "Mashas". For the Suvarna, it is sixteen Mashas. Each Masha of it is four "Andi", which is the seed of a tree called "Karu" [?]. Each Andi is four "Java" (Barleycorn). Each Java is six "Kala", and a quarter Kala «1». Each Kala is four "Pada". Each Pada is four "Mudri" [?]. So then in every Suvarna there are 16 Mashas, 64 Andis, 256 Javas, 1600 Kalas, 6400 Padas, 25600 Mudris. Every six of the Mashas is called "Drakshma" [Dramma/Drachma?]. If asked about its magnitude, they claimed that two «2» of it is a Mithqal, which is an error, for...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...the Mashas of the Mithqal are five and five-sevenths of a Masha. The ratio between Drakshma and the Mithqal is the ratio of twenty to twenty-one. So Drakshma is like the Mithqal and like a quarter of a fifth. It is as if the answerer intended the Mithqal due to approximation, so he expressed it as its double. After that approximation, and because the One is not One in reality in these things, but rather it is a quantity agreed upon for its unity, it accepts division in action and imagination. Its parts differ in places at one time, and in times at one place. Their names change in them upon the variation of the original languages and their accidental change. Some who lived near "Somnath" mentioned: That their Mithqal is our Mithqal, and it is divided into eight "Ruva" [?]. Each Ruva is "Palan «1»". Each Pala is sixteen "Java", meaning barleycorn. So the Mithqal then is eight Ruvas, sixteen Palas, and two hundred «2» and fifty-six «3» barleycorns. It is known from this that he erred in equalizing between the magnitudes of the two Mithqals, and that what they have is "Tola", and he provided another name for the Masha, which is Ruva. Whoever was arbitrary in this chapter, he claimed according to what "Varahamihira" mentioned in the estimation of the making of idols: That every ten dust particles «4», and its name is "Renu", is called "Raja". Every eight Rajas is «5» "Balagra", which is the tip of the hair. Eight of it is "Liksha" «6», which is the nit in the hair. Eight of it is "Yuka", which is the louse. Every eight lice is a Java, meaning a barleycorn. He goes from it there to the estimation of distance. As for in weights, he agrees with what preceded and says: Indeed every four barleycorns is "Andi". Every four Andis is "Masha". Every sixteen Mashas is "Suvarna", which is gold. Every four Suvarnas is "Pala". As for in dry things, every four "Pala" is "Kudava". Every four Kudavas is "Prastha". Every four Prasthas is "Adhaka". As for in wet things, every eight Palas is Kudava. Every eight Kudavas is Prastha. Every four Prasthas is Adhaka.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: Every four Adhakas is "Drona". In the book of "Charaka", among these weights is what I will narrate, transferring from the Arabic copy, not having picked it up from a tongue. I do not think it is anything but corrupt, like the corruption of the rest of the things I know. For this, in our script, is necessary, especially with the people of our time who do not care for correcting what they copy. He said: "Atreya" said that six atoms, meaning dust particles, are "Marichi". Six Marichis are a mustard seed. Eight mustard seeds are a red rice grain. Two red rice grains are a great bean (Masha?). Two beans are "Andi", which is an eighth of a Daniq, given that the Dirham is seven Daniqs. Four Andis are "Masha". Eight Mashas are "Shana". Two Shanas are "Karsha", which is "Suvarna", and it weighs two Dirhams. Four Suvarnas are Pala. Four Palas are Kudava. Four Kudavas are Prastha. Four Prasthas are Adhaka. Four Adhakas are Drona. Two Dronas are "Surpa" «1». Two Surpas «1» are "Goni". The magnitude of Pala is used in the transactions of India, except that it is different in commodities and in countries also. They say it is a third of a fifth of a "Mana". Then there is one who claims it is fourteen Mithqals, while the Mana is not two hundred and ten Mithqals. And one who says it is sixteen, while the Mana is not two hundred and forty Mithqals. And one who says it is fifteen Dirhams, while the "Mana" is not two hundred and twenty-five Dirhams, unless its number in the Mana or the number of the Mana from it is other than that. From the saying of Atreya: "Adhaka" would be sixty-four "Pala" and one hundred and twenty-eight Dirhams, and that balances the Ratl. But "Andi", when it is an eighth of a Daniq, the "Suvarna" contains sixty-four of it, so the share of the Dirham according to him is thirty-two. If they were eighths of Daniqs, they are four Daniqs, and its double is a Dirham and a third, falling short of two Dirhams. This is from the results of guessing in translation and mixing different opinions without knowledge. As for the first saying based on Suvarna being three Dirhams of our Dirhams, and they did not disagree that it is a quarter of a Pala, it would be twelve Dirhams. If it was a third of a fifth of the Mana, it would be one hundred and eighty Dirhams. This creates the illusion that Suvarna is three Mithqals of our Mithqals, not Dirhams. "Varahamihira" said in another place of "Samhita": Make a round vessel whose diameter is a cubit and its depth...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...is likewise. Place it for the rain until it stops. Measure «1» what collected in it of water with a measure holding two hundred Dirhams. Every four of it is Adhaka. This is said by approximation because Adhaka, according to what preceded of its definition, is seven hundred and sixty-eight, either Dirhams as they said, or Mithqals as «2» I inferred. "Sripala" narrated from Varahamihira: That fifty Palas are two hundred and fifty-six Dirhams, and that is Adhaka. He erred in the narration; these are not Dirhams, but rather the number of what is in Adhaka of Suvarna. What is in it of Pala is sixty-four, not fifty. As for the detailing of "Jivasharman" of these measures according to what I heard from him: Four "Pala" is "Kudava". Four Kudavas is "Prastha". Four Prasthas is "Adhaka". Four Adhakas is "Drona". Twenty Dronas is "Khari". Before this, it must be known that sixteen "Masha" is "Suvarna". If the weight is for wheat and barley, then four Suvarnas is Pala. If it is for water and oil, then eight Suvarnas is «3» Pala. The balances of India for commodities are "Steelyards" (Qarastunat) with fixed weights and moveable hangers on numbers and lines. The balance of them is called "Tula". The beginnings of the lines in them are for the units of weight up to five, then after the five it becomes ten, then twenty, stepping down ten by ten. They claim the reason for that is the saying of "Basdiv" [Vasudeva/Krishna]: I will not kill "Shishupala", the son of my maternal aunt, without a crime, and I will pardon «4» him up to ten, then I will punish him. We will mention his story later. "Al-Fazari" used in his Zij the name Pala in place of the minutes of days. I did not find a mention of it in the books of the people except that they name the modification (Equation) by it. They have a measure in weight called "Bhara". Its mention comes in the battles and conquests of "Sindh". It is obtained from two thousand Palas, because they say it is a hundred times twenty «5» Palas. It is as if it is the load of an ox.
