It applies in reality to the whole Ether from the perspective of its roundness and the shape of its movement, indeed to the whole world from the perspective of its division into the Upper and the Lower. When they count the heavens, they say: Indeed their totality is "Brahmanda". These are among those who lacked training in the science of astronomy (Hay'ah) and did not conceive it correctly, so they do not see for the heavens other than stillness, especially because they make them the settlement of the Sects. They think of them transfer and reliance towards the bottom when they describe the bliss of Paradise with the likeness of what is witnessed in the world on earth. In their informative symbols: Indeed water was before everything, and the place of the world was filled with it. Inevitably that was in the first day of the Soul and the beginning of formation and composition. They said: The water foamed by waving, so a white thing emerged from it. The Creator created from it the Egg of "Brahm". Some of them say: It split and Brahm came out of it. The heaven became from one of its halves and the earth from the other and the rains from the broken pieces between them. If they had said the mountains, it would have been more appropriate for it than rains and more similar. Some of them say indeed Allah the Exalted said to Brahm: I am creating an egg to make it for your dwelling in it. He created it from the foam of the mentioned water. When it dried and sank, He broke the egg then into two halves. The Greeks went to something close to it regarding "Asclepius" «1» the deviser of the art of medicine. For they, according to what "Galen" mentioned, when they picture him...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...they placed in his hand an egg to be a symbol of the sphericity of the world and an example of the whole, and that the whole world needs medicine. Asclepius is not of a lower rank than Brahma, for they mentioned regarding him that he is a divine power derived by this name from his action, which is the prevention of dryness, because death occurs when dryness and cold prevail. Although in natural lineage they say of him that he is the son of 'Apollo', and he is the son of 'Phlegyas', and he is the son of 'Coronis', which is the planet Saturn; all of that is due to the power of trigons. As for the precedence of water according to the Indians in creation, it is because by it is the cohesion of every mixture and the growth of every growing thing and the sustenance of life in every possessor of spirit. Thus, it is an instrument and tool for the Creator if He intends creation from matter. The Revelation (Quran) spoke likewise in the saying of Allah, Glorified and Exalted be He: 'And His Throne was upon the water', whether carried from the apparent wording upon a specific body named by this name commanded to be magnified, or carried upon interpretation as dominion and the like. The meaning is that at that time, after Allah, there was nothing but water and His Throne. Were it not that our book is restricted to the doctrines of a single sect, we would have cited from the doctrines of the sects that were in Babylon and around it in ancient times what resembles the story of this egg and exceeds it in absurdity. As for the Indians' reference to halving the egg, it is because the author of this speech was a commoner who did not know the encompassing of the heaven around the earth like the encompassing of the shell of 'Brahmanda' around its yolk. Rather, he conceived the earth as below and the heaven as above from one of its sides only. If he had verified the matter, he would not have needed to split the egg, but he aimed to spread half of it as earth and erect the other half over it as a dome. So he surpassed Ptolemy in flattening the sphere, but he did not excel him. Symbols have remained thus, interpreted by every taker according to what agrees with his belief. Plato said in the book 'Timaeus' something resembling the matter of Brahmanda: That...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...the Creator cut a straight line into two halves and bent from each of them a circle; they met at two points, and He divided one of them into seven sections. Thus he referred to the two motions and to the spheres of the planets by way of symbolism as is his custom. And 'Brahmagupta' said in the first treatise of 'Brahmasiddhanta' when he enumerated the heavens and placed the moon in the first of them and ascended with the planets to the seventh, placing Saturn in it: That the fixed stars are in the eighth, and that it was made round to endure, so the doer of good is rewarded in it and the evildoer punished, as there is nothing beyond it. He indicated in this chapter that the heavens are the spheres, and in their arrangement contrary to what is in their religious traditional books as we will recount in its place, and in rounding (circularity) to the slowness of being affected, and to what 'Aristotle' holds regarding the round and circular motion, and to the fact that there is no existing body beyond the spheres. If it is so, it is not hidden that 'Brahmanda' is the collection of spheres, I mean the Ether, indeed the Whole, because recompense according to them occurs in its interior as well. 'Paulisa' said in his 'Siddhanta': The totality of the world is the sum of earth, water, fire, wind, and heaven created beyond the darkness. The heaven appeared azure in color due to the falling short of the sun's rays from it so that it would be illuminated by it like the illumination of the non-luminous watery spheres, I mean by them the bodies of the planets and the moon, which if the sun's ray falls upon them and the earth's shadow does not reach them, their blackness goes away and their figures appear at night. So the Luminous One is one, and the rest are illuminated by it. He indicated in this chapter the perceived limit and called it heaven and placed it in darkness by mentioning its being in the place which the ray does not reach. The investigation into the visible greyish color would be very long. Brahmagupta said in the mentioned treatise: Multiply the cycles of the moon, which are 57,753,300,000, by the 'Yojanas' of its sphere, which are 324,000, and the sum is 18,712,069,200,000,000, and those are the Yojanas of the sphere of the Zodiac. As for the measure of a Yojana of distance, it is mentioned in its chapter. As for what...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...he mentioned, we took it on authority (Taqlid) since he did not mention anything necessitating it. As for 'Vasistha', he said: 'Brahmanda' encompasses the spheres, and these numbers are its measure because the sphere of the Zodiac is connected to it. As for 'Balabhadra' the commentator, he said: We do not make these numbers the measure of the heaven, for we cannot determine its greatness, but we make them for the limit of sight, for no perceptible object is higher than it, despite the disparity of other spheres in greatness and smallness. The followers of 'Aryabhata' said: Knowing the place reached by the ray suffices us, and we do not need what it does not reach even if it is great in itself, for what the ray does not reach, sensation does not perceive, and what is not sensed is not known. What results from the speech of these people: From the saying of Vasistha, it is that Brahmanda is a sphere encompassing the eighth sphere marked by the Zodiac signs containing the fixed stars, and they are touching. We were compelled to the eighth sphere. As for what is above it, there is nothing compelling the necessity of a ninth sphere. People differ regarding it; some necessitate it for the sake of the westward motion, moving by it, overpowering what it contains upon it; and some necessitate it for its sake while it is stationary. As for the first group, their purpose is known, but 'Aristotle' has shown that every mover is moved by a mover not within it. That ninth sphere must have an external mover, so what prevents it from moving the eight spheres without the mediation of the ninth? As for the second group, it is as if they heard what we recounted and that the First Mover is unmoving, so they made their ninth sphere stationary and the westward motion issuing from it. But Aristotle has also shown that He is not a body, so describing Him with sphericity, circularity, encompassing, and stillness necessitates His corporeality. Thus, the ninth sphere leads to the impossible. In this sense, 'Ptolemy' says in the preface of the book 'Almagest': The First Cause of the first motion of the whole, if we imagine motion singly, we see that it is a god, invisible and unmoving, and we named the class of inquiry about it divine. We conceive this action in the highest height of the world only, completely distinct from sensible substances. This is what Ptolemy says about the First Mover without pointing to the sphere narrated from him by John the Grammarian in his refutation of 'Proclus', and he mentioned that 'Plato' did not know the ninth sphere which has no stars, which is what Ptolemy understood, he claimed. As for the sayings of those accepting beyond the moving limit a stationary body or infinite void or negating void and fullness from it together...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...they are not connected to what we are discussing. As for 'Balabhadra', there is a scent from him of one who sees that the heaven or heavens is a solid body resisting weights, carrying them above the spheres. It is easy for him to prefer report over witnessing, just as it is difficult for us to prioritize ambiguity over proof. The truth is with the followers of 'Aryabhata', and it is as if they are truly the people of independent reasoning (Ijtihad). It has become clear that 'Brahmanda' is the Ether, including the created beings within it.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: XXI. On the Form of the Earth and Heaven According to the Religious Aspects Referring to Traditions and Reported Narrations. The people referred to in the chapter title have held regarding the earths that they are seven layers, one above the other, and regarding the division of the highest of them into a heptad (sevenfold division), not according to what astronomers among us hold regarding the Climes (regions), or the Persians regarding the 'Kishvars'. We want, after presenting the declaration of their sayings extracted from the side of the masters of their laws, to stand for fairness. If something appears to us in it or agreement with others, even if they are not correct in it together, we will establish it, not by way of defending them, but intending to sharpen the nature for those who study them. They did not differ in the number of earths nor in the number of divisions of the highest one, but they differed in their names and in the order of names. Perhaps I attribute that difference to the breadth of the language, for they name a single thing with very many names. An example is the sun; they named it with a thousand names as they mentioned, similar to the Arabs naming the lion with close to that. Some are improvised improvisation, and some are derived from the varying conditions in it or the issuing actions. They and those like them boast of that, while it is one of the greatest defects of language. For its subject is applying a name to each of the existents and their effects by agreement among a group, by which they know each other's purpose when expressing that name in speech. If the single name itself applies to several named things, it indicates the narrowness of the language and forces the listener to ask...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...the speaker what he means by his word. So that name falls, either by another like it that suffices, or by an explanation defining the meaning. If a single thing has many names, and the cause of that is not the monopolization of one of them by every tribe or every class, and there was sufficiency in one of them, the remaining are characterized as babble, nonsense, and prattle, and become a cause for obscuration and hiding, or bearing hardships to memorize the whole without benefit other than wasting life. Perhaps it occurred to my mind from the side of the masters of books and traditions that they turned away from the order and limited themselves to mentioning the names, or that the copyists were reckless, for those translating for me had power over the language and were not known for treachery without benefit. I will place in the table what I obtained of the names of the earths. The reliance among them is on what is transmitted from 'Aditya Purana', for it set a rule for them and placed each one of the earths and heavens on a limb of the sun's limbs. So the heavens were from the head to the belly, and the earths from the navel to the foot. Thus the order appeared and the confusion disappeared. 1 2 3 4 5

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: Following the earths are the seven layered heavens, called 'Lokas'. A Loka is a gathering and assembly. The Greeks were similar in making the heavens places for gatherings. John the Grammarian said in his refutation of 'Proclus': A group of theologians saw in the sphere called 'Galaxias', meaning milk, which is the Milky Way, that it is a dwelling and resting place for rational souls. The poet 'Homer' says: You made the pure heaven an eternal dwelling for the gods, not shaken by winds, nor wet by rains, nor damaged by snows, but in it is splendid clarity with no clouds covering it. 'Plato' said: God said to the seven wandering planets: You are gods of gods, and I am the father of works, making you with a making in which there is no undoing; for everything bound, even if dissolvable, corruption does not attach to what is well-ordered. 'Aristotle' said in a letter of his to Alexander: The world is the system of all creation. As for what is above it and surrounds it from its diameters, it is the place of the gods, and the heaven is full of their bodies which we call stars for expression. He says in another place in it: The earth is surrounded by water, water by air, air by fire, and fire by Ether. For this reason, the upper region became the place of the gods and the lower was estimated as the place of aquatic animals. In 'Vayu Purana' there is something similar: That the earth is held by water, water is held by pure fire, fire is held by wind, wind is held by heaven, and heaven is held by its Lord. He did not differ except in the order. Disagreement did not occur in the names of the 'Lokas' like it occurred in the earths. We also place their names in a table like the first: All of these are agreed upon except what happened to the commentator of the book 'Patanjali'. He heard that the 'Pitris', who are the fathers (ancestors), their gathering is in the sphere of the moon, which is speech based on the sayings of astrologers. So he made their gathering the first of the heavens. He should have placed it in the place of 'Bhu Loka', but he did not do so, but...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...dropped 'Svarloka' by that addition, which is the place of reward. Then he did something else: The seventh 'Satya Loka' was named in the 'Puranas' as 'Brahma Loka', so he placed it above it and made the one named with two names two things. It was obligatory for him to leave Brahma Loka aside and establish 'Pitri Loka' in place of the first and not drop 'Svarloka'. This is what is regarding the seven earths and seven heavens. Let us also mention the divisions of the face of the upper earth, then what must follow that. We say: 'Dvipa' in their language is the name for island. 'Simhaladvipa' is what we call 'Serendib' (Sri Lanka) because it is an island. And the Maldives (Dibajat) likewise, because they are many islands; some age, decompose, and flatten, so water rises over them and they disappear, and others appear new like a piece of sand that continues to increase...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...rise, and expand, so the inhabitants of the first move to them and inhabit them. What the Indians hold from the side of religious traditions is that the earth we are on is round, surrounded by a sea, and on the sea is land like a collar, and on that land is a sea also round like a collar. On this system until each of the number of dry collars called islands (Dvipas) is completed, and the number of seas is seven, on the condition that each one of a genus is double the one within it of its genus, I mean the one adjoining it so it surrounds it. Thus the magnitudes of each of them follow the progression of numbers of the power of two. If the middle earth is one, the total of the seven collar earths is 127. If the sea surrounding the middle earth is one, the total of the seven collar seas also is 127. The total of seas and earths together is 254. However, the commentator of the book 'Patanjali' assumed for the middle earth one hundred thousand 'Yojanas', so the total for the earths would be 12,700,000. He assumed for the sea surrounding the middle earth two hundred thousand, and for the one after it four hundred thousand, so the sum for the seas is 25,400,000. The total of that is 38,100,000. He did not mention the total so we could compare it with this, except that he mentioned in 'Vayu Purana': That the diameter of the total of Dvipas and islands is 37,900,000. This does not agree with the first; indeed, there is no way for it unless the seas are six and starting in doubling from four. As for the number of seas, it can be interpreted that he omitted mentioning the seventh because he intended dry land, and if he mentioned it, he would need to mention what surrounds it. As for starting with four in doubling, I do not see a way for it in the established law. Each of the Dvipas and seas has a name; we place what we have of it in a table so our excuse is accepted: 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: Reason has no entry in this, and I do not know a reason for the difference other than recklessness in enumerating however it happened. The most worthy of these sayings is what is in 'Matsya Purana' because it enumerated the islands and seas one after another according to the necessary order of surrounding sea such-and-such by island such-and-such, then surrounding island such-and-such by sea such-and-such, from the center to the margin. Let us recount now what resembles that and matches it, even if it is connected to places more worthy of it. That is that the commentator of the book 'Patanjali', when he wanted to define the world, started from its bottom and said: The magnitude of the darkness is one 'Koti' and eighty-five 'Lakh Yojanas', that is 18,500,000. Above it is 'Naraka', which is hells, thirteen Koti and twelve 'Lakh', that is 131,200,000. Then darkness of one Lakh, that is 100,000. Above it is the earth of 'Vajra' due to its hardness, which is diamond or the molten thunderbolt, 34,000. Then 'Garbha', which is the middle, 60,000. Above it is the Golden Earth, 30,000. Above it are the seven earths, each one ten thousand, so that is 70,000. The highest of them possesses the Dvipas and seas. Beyond the sea of fresh water is 'Lokaloka', meaning no-gathering, i.e., in which there is no habitation or sociable person. After it is the Earth of Gold, one Koti, that is 10,000,000. Above it is 'Pitri Loka' 6,134,000. The total of the seven Lokas whose sum is called 'Brahmanda' is fifteen Koti, that is 150,000,000. Above that is the darkness of 'Tamas' like the lower one, 18,500,000. We used to find mentioning the seven seas with the earths heavy until this man lightened it for us by adding lands beneath them. As for in 'Vishnu Purana' regarding the like of this art, he claimed: That under the seventh lower earth is a snake called 'Shesha' venerated by the spiritual beings, and also called 'Ananta', with a thousand heads, carrying...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...the earths without being burdened by their weight. That these earths, layered one upon another, possess bounties and grace, adorned with gems, shining with their own light without the two luminaries, for they do not rise in them. Therefore, their climates are moderate, and aromatic plants and the blossoms of trees and fruits are perpetual in them. Times are hidden from their inhabitants as they do not sense movements by counting them. Their magnitude is seventy thousand 'Yojanas', each one ten thousand. That 'Narada' the Rishi arrived at them for viewing and witnessing who inhabits them of the two genii 'Daityas' and 'Danavas', so he considered the bliss of Paradise meager beside their bliss and returned to the angels recounting that to them and making them marvel at their description. He said: And that beyond the Fresh Sea is the Earth of Gold, double all the Dvipas and seas, not inhabited by human or jinn. Beyond it is 'Lokaloka', a mountain whose height is ten thousand Yojanas and width the like of that. The total of that is 1,500,000,000 (?), meaning fifty 'Koti'. This whole aggregate is called in their language sometimes 'Dhatri', meaning holder of all things, and sometimes 'Vidhatri', meaning their releaser, and also called the resting place of every living thing. How similar is this to what those differing on the Void hold, the affirmers of it making it the cause of attracting bodies to it, and the deniers of it making it non-existence. Then he returned to the Lokas and said: Everything that a foot can tread or a ship can sail in is 'Bhu Loka', as if he referred by that to the face of the upper earth. He said: And what is between the earth and the sun of the air in which 'Siddhas', 'Munis', and 'Gandharvas', the companions of Paradise, frequent is 'Bhuvar Loka'. The sum of the three is called 'The Three Prithivis' (Earths), and what is above them is 'Vyasa Mandala', meaning the province of Vyasa. From the earth to the place of the sun is one hundred thousand 'Yojanas'. From the place of the sun to the place of the moon is the like of that. From the moon to Mercury is two Lakhs, meaning two hundred thousand. From it to Venus likewise. From it to Mars, then Jupiter, then Saturn are equal distances, each one two hundred thousand. From Saturn to the Seven Rishis (Ursa Major) is one hundred thousand. From the Seven Rishis to the Pole is one thousand Yojanas. Above that is 'Mahar Loka', twenty...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...million. Above it is 'Jana Loka', eighty million. Then 'Tapo Loka' (Tapoloka), four hundred and eighty million. Above it is 'Satya Loka'. This total is more than three times that which we recounted from the commentator of the book 'Patanjali'. This is the habit of copyists in every language, and I do not absolve the authors of the Puranas from it, for they are not among the people of verification.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: XXII. On the Pole and Its News. The Pole in their language is 'Dhruva' and the axis is 'Salaka'. You hardly hear from other than their astronomers except one pole, due to the previous mention of their belief in the dome of the heaven. In 'Vayu Purana': The heaven rotates on the Pole like the potter's wheel, and the Pole rotates on itself and does not move from its place, completing the rotation in thirty Muhurtas, i.e., in a day and night. I did not hear from them regarding the South Pole except that a king they had named 'Somadatta' deserved Paradise for his good deeds, but his heart was not pleased with removing his body from his soul upon his transfer. So he sought 'Vasistha' the Rishi and informed him that he loved his body and did not want to leave it. He made him despair of carrying the earthly body from the world to Paradise. He also presented his need to the sons of Vasistha, but they confronted him with their spit and mocked him, turning him into a Chandala with pierced ears in a new tunic. He came to 'Visvamitra' the Rishi in that state. He found it atrocious and asked him about it. He informed him and told him the whole story. He became angry out of indignation for him and summoned the Brahmins to make a great sacrifice, Vasistha's sons being among them. He said to them: I want to make another world and another Paradise for the sake of this righteous king where he attains his desire. He began making the Pole and the Great Bear (Seven Rishis) which are in...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...the south. 'Indra' the Chief and the spiritual beings feared him, so they came to him pleading, asking him to neglect what he had started on condition that they carry Somadatta with his body as it is to Paradise. They did that. So he left the making of the second world except what he had made of it up to that time. It is known that the North Pole is marked among us by the Great Bear (Banat Na'sh) and the South by Canopus (Suhail), except that some of those resembling the commoners among our companions claim that in the southern direction of the sky there is a Great Bear in the form of the northern one rotating around that pole. That is not impossible nor innovative if its report is obtained from someone deeply experienced in sea travels, trustworthy and reliable. Unknown stars may appear in the southern regions. 'Sripala' claimed that in summer in Multan a red star appears lower than the orbit of Canopus which they call 'Shula', which is the wood of crucifixion, and that the Indians take it as a bad omen. Therefore, if the Moon is in 'Purva Bhadrapada', they do not travel towards the south because it is in it. Al-Jayhani mentioned in the 'Book of Routes': That in the island of 'Langabalus' (Nicobar?) a huge star is seen known as 'Dhu al-Hamma' (The Venomous/Feverish?) in winter at the time of dawn from the direction of the sunrise at an altitude like the height of a mast. From the tail of the Little Bear and its rear and small stars there, an elongated shape is formed called 'Fas al-Raha' (The Mill Axle?). 'Brahmagupta' mentions it as the Fish. The Indians have haphazard reports regarding depicting it in the form of an aquatic animal with four legs called 'Sakvara' (?) and also called 'Sishumara'. I think this Sishumara is the large lizard (Dhab), for its name in Persian is 'Susmar' and there is a resemblance between them. There is an aquatic one like the crocodile and the skink. Among those myths is that 'Brahma', when he wanted to generate humans, divided himself into two halves. The name of the right is 'Viraj' and the name of the left is 'Manu', after whom the turn 'Manvantara' was named. Manu had two sons, one 'Priyavrata' and the other 'Uttanapada', the King with clubfeet (or lame).

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: He has a son named 'Dhruva' who was slighted by his father's wife, so he was given for that the power to turn all the stars as he wishes. His appearance was in 'Svayambhuva Manvantara', which is the first of the turns, and he remained in his place forever. In 'Vayu Purana': The wind moves the stars around the Pole, and they are tied to it by ties that people do not see, so they move like the example of the wood that is turned in the oil presses, for its base is like fixed and its end is rotating. In the book 'Vishnu Dharma': 'Vajra', who is one of the children of 'Balabhadra' brother of 'Narayana', asked 'Markandeya' the Rishi about the Pole. He answered him that 'Brahma', when he made the world, it was dark and desolate, so he made then the sphere of the sun luminous and the spheres of the stars watery, accepting its light from the face with which it faces them. He placed fourteen of them around the Pole in the form of 'Sishumara' (Porpoise/Dolphin) turning the rest of the stars around the Pole. Of them towards the North from the Pole on the upper jaw is 'Uttanapada', on the lower is 'Yajna', on the head is 'Dharma', on the chest is 'Narayana', on the hands towards the East the two stars 'Asvins' the physicians, on the feet 'Varuna' and 'Aryaman' towards the West, on the penis 'Samvatsara', on the anus 'Mitra', and on the tail 'Agni', 'Mahendra', 'Marichi', and 'Kasyapa'. He said: The Pole is 'Vishnu' the obeyed among the people of Paradise, and he is also Time which creates, grows, wears out, and destroys. Then he said: Whoever reads this and knows it with verification, Allah forgives him the sins of his day and adds fourteen years to his decreed lifespan. How safe (simple) are the hearts of the people! Among us are those who encompass a thousand and some twenty stars and no breath is taken from them nor is cut from their lifespan except for that. These stars are rotating however the placement of the Pole is from them. If I found among the Indians someone who could point to them with his finger, I would have been able to transfer them to what we know of the Greek and Arab constellations for the stars, or what approximates them if they are not of them.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: XXIII. On Mount Meru According to What the Authors of the Puranas and Others Believe About It. We begin with the description of this mountain as it is the center of the Dvipas and seas and the middle of 'Jambudvipa' among them. 'Brahmagupta' said: People's sayings have multiplied regarding the description of the earth and Mount 'Meru', especially from those who study the Puranas and religious books. Some of them describe this mountain as rising above the face of the earth excessively high, and that it is under the Pole and the stars rotate around its foot, so rising and setting occur from it. It was named Meru because of its power over that, and because the Head (Rahu) only eclipses the two luminaries by its power. The day of its inhabitants, the angels, is six months and their night is six months. He said: In the book of 'Jina', who is the 'Buddha': That Mount 'Meru' is square, not round. 'Balabhadra' the commentator said: Some people say: The earth is flat and Mount Meru is luminous and shining. He said: If it were as they claimed, the planets would not rotate around the horizon of those who inhabit Meru. And if it had rays, it would be seen due to its height as the Pole above it appears. Some of them say: It is of gold. Others say: It is of gem. 'Aryabhata' believes that it does not rise high, but rises one Yojana on a roundness not squareness. It is the kingdom of angels. It became invisible despite its rays because it is far from the lands, northern in all places in the cold regions in the middle of a desert called 'Nandana Vana'. If it were of great height...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...it would not happen at latitude sixty-six that the entire Tropic of Cancer appears, so the sun rotates in it visible not setting. Balabhadra is weak in speech and meaning, so I do not know how he volunteered for interpretation, although his interpretations are like that. As for his invalidation of the flatness of the earth by the rotation of stars around the horizon of Meru, it is closer to affirmation. Rather, if it were flat and statures were parallel to the column of the mountain, the horizon would not change and it would be the equator in all places. As for what he narrated from Aryabhata, let the sphere of the earth be AB on center E, and A a dwelling whose latitude is sixty-six degrees. We isolate arc AB equal to the maximum declination, so B is the place aligned by the Pole. We pass on point A line AC touching the sphere, so it is in the plane of the sensible horizon where sights pass around the earth. We join AE and extend EBG meeting AC at C, and drop perpendicular AT on EC. It is known that AT is the sine of the maximum declination and TB is its versine (sagitta) and TE is the cosine of the maximum declination. Because we address 'Aryabhata', we work the sines also by his Kardajas (units), so AT is 1397 and TE is 3140 and BT is 298. Due to the right angle EAC, the ratio of EC to EA is like the ratio of EA to ET. The square of EA is 11,819,844 (using Aryabhata's Radius R=3438) and its dividend by TE (3140) is 3764 (approx). The difference between it and TE (should be EC - EB?) ... (Mathematical reconstruction: EC = R^2 / TE = 3438^2 / 3140 ≈ 3764. BC = EC - EB = 3764 - 3438 = 326. The text says difference between it and TB is 324 which is BC). And its ratio to BE assuming it is the total sine which is 3438 is like the ratio of 'Yojana' BC to Yojana BE, which is according to Aryabhata eight hundred. Its product in the previous difference: 259,200 (using 324*800) and its dividend by the total sine: 75. That is the Yojana of BC, and it would be six hundred miles and two hundred parasangs. If the column of the mountain were two hundred parasangs, the one ascending it would be close to double it. Whenever 'Meru' is of this magnitude, nothing of it appears at latitude sixty-six and it does not hide anything of the Tropic of Cancer at all. If it is there under the horizon, then in dwellings whose latitudes are less than that latitude, it is lowered from the horizons. So grant that it is the sun in light, is it seen while it is under the earth absent? For this mountain...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...a model. The mountain is not hidden from us because of its distance in the cold highlands, but because of its being lower than the horizon due to the sphericity of the earth and the attraction of heavy things towards its center. Also, his inference of the mountain's low height by the appearance of the Tropic of Cancer in what equals in latitude the complement of the greatest declination is not necessary. Because we only knew the properties of the tropics and other things in those places by proof without viewing or transmission of a report, for those places are uninhabited and their paths are not traveled. If someone came to him from there informing him of the appearance of this tropic in that latitude, then someone has come to us informing us of the disappearance of part of it. There is no screen for that other than this mountain, and were it not for it, all of it would appear. So who made one of these two reports more worthy of acceptance? In the book of "Aryabhata" who is from "Kusumapura": Indeed Mount "Meru" is in "Himavant", which is the cold highlands, and does not exceed a "Yojana". It occurred in the translation: That it does not exceed Himavant by more than a Yojana. This man is not Aryabhata the Elder; rather, he is one of his followers, for he mentions him and follows him. I do not know which of the two namesakes "Balabhadra" means. In summary, the properties of the location of this mountain are known to us by proof, and the mountain itself according to them by reports, whether they made it a Yojana or more, and whether they made it square or octagonal. Let us mention now what the Rishis said about it. As for in "Matsya Purana", it was said: Indeed it is golden, luminous like fire purified from the murkiness of smoke, having four colors on its four sides. The color of the eastern one of them is white...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...like the color of the Brahmins, and the color of the northern is red like the color of "Kshatriya", and the color of the southern is yellow like the color of "Vaishya", and the color of the western is black like the color of "Shudra". Its height is 86,000 "Yojanas". What entered the earth from it is 16,000. Each side of its squares is 34,000. Sweet rivers flow in it. In it are pleasant golden dwellings inhabited by the spirituals "Dev" [Devas], their singers "Gandharva", and their harlots "Apsaras". In it also are of the genus "Asura", "Daitya", and "Rakshasa". Around it is the pond "Manasa". Around the pond in its four directions are "Lokapala", and they are the guardians of the world and its people. Mount "Meru" has seven nodes (ranges), which are great mountains, and their names are: "Mahendra, Malaya, Sahya, Shuktibam [Shuktimat?], Rikshabam [Riksha?], Vindhya, Pariyatra". As for the small mountains, they can hardly be counted in multitude, and they are the ones inhabited by people. As for the great ones around Meru, among them is "Himavant", covered by snow always, and in it are Rakshasa, "Pishacha", and "Yaksha". Among them is "Hemakuta", the golden, and in it are "Gandharva" and Apsaras. Among them is "Nishadha", inhabited by "Naga"—the serpents. The names of their seven chiefs are: "Ananta, Vasuki, Takshaka, Karkotaka, Mahapadma, Kambala «1», Ashvatara". Among them is "Nila", peacock-colored, many-colored, inhabited by "Siddha" and Brahmarshi ascetics. Among them is Mount "Shveta", inhabited by "Daitya" and "Danava". Among them is Mount "Shringavan", in which are "Pitrin", the fathers of Dev and their grandfathers. Near it from the direction of the North are passes filled with jewels and trees remaining for eras (Kalpas). In the middle of these mountains is "Ilavrita", and it is the highest of them. The total is called "Purusha Parvata". What is between the two mountains "Himavant" and "Shringavan" is called "Kailasa", the place of the playgrounds of "Rakshasa" and "Apsaras «2»". In "Vishnu Purana": Indeed the great mountains of the Middle Earth are "Sri Parvata, Malaya Parvata, Malyavat, Vindhya, Trikuta, Tripurantaka, Kailasa", and that its people drink the water of rivers and they are constantly joyful. It was mentioned in "Vayu Purana" regarding the magnitudes of its squares and its height the like of what...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...preceded. Then it was said: Indeed in every direction from it is a square mountain. The one to its east is "Malyavat", and the one to its north is "Nila", and to its west is "Gandhamadana", and to its south is "Nishadha". It was mentioned in "Aditya Purana" regarding its side what preceded, but I did not find its height in it. It was said: Indeed its eastern side is of gold, the western of silver, the southern of red ruby, and the northern of various jewels. These excessive magnitudes for the mountain do not persist except with the excessive magnitudes they mentioned for the earth. If guessing is not limited, the field of slander for the guesser is open, like the commentator of the book of "Patanjal", for he exceeded the square in it to elongation (oblongness) and made one of its squares fifteen "Koti Yojanas", which is 150,000,000, and the other five Koti, on a third of the first. He mentioned regarding its four sides that in its east are Mount "Malyavat" and the sea, and between them are kingdoms called "Bhadrasva". To its north are Mount "Nila", "Shveta", and "Shringavan" and the sea, and between them are kingdoms "Ramyaka «1»", "Hiranmaya", and "Kuru". To its west are Mount Gandhamadana and the sea, and between them the kingdom of "Ketumala". To its south are mountains "Malyavat" (Marabrat?), "Nishadha", "Hemakuta", and "Himagiri" and the sea, and between them are kingdoms "Bharata Varsha", "Kimpurusha", and "Harivarsha". This is what I found of the sayings of the Indians regarding it. Because I did not find a book for the Shamaniyya (Buddhists) nor anyone of them from whom I could see what they are upon, if I narrated from them, it is by the mediation of "Al-Iranshahri", even though I think his narration is not verified or from someone not verified. He mentioned about them regarding "Meru": That it is the middle of four worlds in the four directions, square at the bottom, round at the top. Its length is 80,000 "Yojanas", half of it going into the sky and half of it diving into the earth. Its southern side which is next to our world is of sky-blue ruby, and it is the cause of what is seen of the blueness of the sky. The remaining sides are of rubies red, yellow, and white. This is Mount Meru mediating the earth. As for "Qaf" which our common people name, it is according to the Indians "Lokaloka". They claim that the sun revolves from it towards Mount Meru and...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...does not illuminate from it other than its inner northern side only. The Magians of "Sogdia" went to the like of it, that Mount "Ardiya" is around the world and outside it is "Khum" resembling the pupil of the eye, in it is of every thing, and behind it is a void. In the middle of the world is Mount "Girnagar", it is between our clime and the six climes, the throne of the Kingdom. Between every two climes is burning sand on which no foot settles. The spheres revolve in the climes like a millstone, and in our clime inclined because it is above and in it are the people.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
24 - Mentioning the Seven Dvipas (Islands/Continents) in Detail from the Puranas
One should not pay attention to the difference of names and meanings which I cite. As for what is in the names, correcting it is easy due to the difference of languages. As for what is in the meanings, either something results from it that is desired to be understood and its subject matter, or the contradiction of everything that has no basis is known by it. We have mentioned the condition of the Middle Island where we mentioned what is around the mountain that is in its middle. It was named "Jambu Dvipa" «1» by the name of a tree in it whose branches extend a hundred "Yojanas". When mentioning the inhabited world and its division, its complete description will be. We will mention now the rest of the islands surrounding it, and we rely in the arrangement of names on what is in "Matsya Purana" for the reason we mentioned, after mentioning regarding the Middle one something that is in "Vayu Purana", which is that in "Madhyadesha" (Middle Land?) they claimed two genera. One of them is called "Kimpurusha"; their men are known by the color of gold and their women "Srinari" [?]. They live a long life, do not get sick for the duration of their life, do not commit a sin, and do not envy each other. Their food is what they squeeze from the fruit of a palm called "Madhu". The other genus is "Harivarsha", on the color of silver. They live eleven thousand years, do not grow beards, and their food is sugar cane. From the perspective of what was mentioned of the lack of beard and the color of gold and silver, the mind went to the Turks, but «2» from the perspective of feeding...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...on dates and cane, it deviated from them to the regions of the South. Where are these two colors found in its people except the color of boxwood? In the Zanj (Black Africans) is something of that, which is that they have no grief and no envy among them because they do not own anything by which that occurs. Life among them is inevitably longer than it is in our lands, but slightly, not reaching doubles. Even if the Zanj, due to their dullness, do not know a natural death but attribute it to poison only and follow it with accusations if the dead was not killed by a weapon. This is when «1» a consumptive spits it. So let us come now to "Shaka Dvipa" «2». In it, according to what is in "Matsya Purana", are seven great rivers; one of them is parallel in purity «3» to Ganges. In the first sea are seven mountains possessing jewels; some inhabited by "Dev" and some by devils. Among them is a towering golden one from which the cloud rises then comes to us and rains. Among them is one possessing all medicines, and from it "Indra" the Chief takes the rain. Among them is one called "Soma". Of its story: "Kashyapa" had two wives, one of them "Kadru" mother of the snakes, and the other "Vinata" mother of the birds. They were in the desert and in it was a gray horse. The mother of the snakes said: It is black. They bet on the enslavement of the liar and delayed the examination until the morrow. The mother of the snakes sent her black children by night until they twisted on it and covered its color. So the mother of the birds was enslaved for a time. She had two sons, one of them "Aruna" the guardian of the Rukh of the Sun drawn by horses, and the other "Garuda" «4». This one said to his mother: Ask the children of your co-wife by what your emancipation is possible. She did. They said to her: By the Amrita (Nectar) which is with "Dev". Then "Garuda" «5» flew to Dev and asked them for it. They answered him that Amrita is of their specialties, and if obtained by others, they would remain as long as they remain. He pleaded with them to enable him with it just until he frees his mother with it then returns it. They had mercy on him and gave it to him. He came to Mount "Soma" and they intended «6» it. He gave it to them and freed his mother, then said...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...to them: Do not approach the Amrita until you bathe in the river "Ganges". They went for that and left it in its place. Garuda «1» returned it to Dev and attained honor by that until he became the king of birds and became the vehicle of "Bishn" [Vishnu]. He said: The people of that land are righteous, long-lived, having dispensed with the policy of kings by abandoning envy and conflict. Their time is all "Treta Yuga", not changing. In them are the four colors, meaning the distinct classes; they do not intermarry and do not mix. They are always joyful, not grieving. In "Vishnu Purana": Indeed the names of the classes among them are "Aryaka" the highest of them, then "Kurura", then "Vivimsha", then "Bhavishya" [?]. And that they worship "Basdiv" [Vasudeva]. Then the third island "Kusha". In it, according to what is in "Matsya Purana", are seven mountains possessing jewels, fruits, lights, herbs, and crops. One of them is called "Drona"; in it are majestic medicines, especially "Vishalyakarani", which heals every wound immediately, and "Mritasanjivani", which revives the dead. Another mountain is called "Hari", like the black cloud. In it is a fire called "Mahisha" which came out of the water and inhabited it until the time of the annihilation of the world, and it is the one that burns it. In it are seven kingdoms and uncounted rivers flowing to the sea; "Indra" takes them for rain. Among the great ones is "Jumna" [?], purifier from sins. Nothing of its people was mentioned in it. In "Vishnu Purana": Indeed they are righteous, not sinning. Each one of them lives ten thousand «2» years. And they worship "Janardana" «3». The names of the classes among them are "Damin, Shushmin, Sneha, Mandeha". Then the fourth island "Krauncha Dvipa" «4». In it, according to what is in "Matsya Purana", are mountains possessing «5» jewels, and rivers which are branches of "Ganges", and kingdoms whose people are white in color, righteous, pure. In Vishnu Purana: Indeed the people in it are gathered in one place, not distinguished. Then it was said regarding the names of the classes: That they are...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...Pushkara, Pushkala, Dhanya, Tishya". They worship Janardana «1». Then the fifth island "Shalmala Dvipa" «1». In it, according to what is in Matsya Purana, are mountains and rivers. Its inhabitants are pure, long-lived, forbearing, not getting angry, not suffering drought «2». Food comes to them by their will without planting or toil. They obtain without reproduction. They do not get sick and do not grieve. They have dispensed with kings by rejecting competition in acquisition and became content, so they became safe. They chose beauty and loved good. The air does not change for them with heat or cold necessitating protection. They do not have rain; rather water springs for them from the earth and seeps from the mountains. Such is the condition of what is beyond it of the Dvipas. They are one genus not distinguished by classes. Each one of them lives three thousand «3» years. In Vishnu Purana: Indeed they are beautiful of face, worship "Bhagavat", and sacrifice to the fire. Each one lives ten thousand «3» years. The names of the classes among them are "Kapila, Aruna, Pita, Krishna". Then the sixth island "Gomedaka Dvipa" «4». In it, according to what is in "Matsya Purana", are two great mountains. One of them is called "Sumana", pitch black, surrounding most of the island. The other is "Kumuda", golden in color, very lofty, and in it are all medicines. In it also are two kingdoms. In Vishnu Purana: Indeed they are righteous, not sinning, and they worship "Bishn". The names of the classes among them are "Maga, Magadha, Manasa, Mandaga". Its pleasantness reaches such that the people of Paradise frequent it for goodness. Then the seventh island "Pushkara Dvipa" «4». In its east, according to what is in Matsya Purana, is Mount "Chitrasanu", meaning engraved of surface. It has horns of jewels. Its height is 34,000 "Yojanas" and its circumference 25,000. In its west is Mount "Manasa", luminous like the full moon. Its height is 3,500. It has a son who guards his father from the direction of the West. In its east are two kingdoms. Each of their people lives ten thousand «4» years. Their waters spring from the earth and seep from the mountains, so they do not have rain, nor does a river flow among them, nor do they have summer or winter. They are one genus not differing, nor suffering drought «5», nor aging...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...what they want comes to them. So they are in comfort and familiarity, knowing nothing but good. It is as if they are in the suburb of Paradise. They have been given beauty with longevity and the removal of preference. No service, no king, no sin, no envy, no conflict, no gossip, no toil in planting, nor effort in trade. In "Vishnu Purana": Indeed "Pushkara Dvipa" «1» was named by the name of a great tree in it called also "Nyagrodha" (Banyan). Under it is "Brahma Rupa", meaning his form. "Dev" and "Danava" prostrate to it. Its people are equal, not preferring one another, whether they are people or are with Dev. There is in it no other than one mountain called "Manasottama" circling on its circumference. The rest of the Dvipas are seen from its peak, for its height is 50,000 "Yojanas" and its width likewise.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
25 - On Mentioning the Rivers and their Sources and their Courses over the Sects
It was mentioned in "Vayu Purana": The rivers that flow from the famous great mountains which we mentioned are the nodes of Mount "Meru". We have placed them in a table for alleviation:
[Table Columns 1-5]

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: It was mentioned in "Matsya Purana" and "Vayu Purana" the rivers flowing in "Jambu Dvipa" «1» and that they exit from the mountains of "Himavant". We did not observe «2» order in them, but enumeration only. It must be conceived in the land of India that the mountains surround its borders. Those to its north are Himavant, possessing snows. The land of "Kashmir" is in its middle and connects to the land of the "Turks". Its cold continues to increase to the cut-off of habitation and to Mount "Meru". Because the extension of these mountains is in longitude, what exits from them towards the North flows in the land of the "Turks", "Tibet", "Khazars", and "Slavs" and falls into the Sea of "Jurjan" (Caspian) or the Lake of "Khwarazm" (Aral) or the Sea of "Pontus" (Black Sea) or the Northern Sea of the "Slavs" (Baltic?). What exited from them towards the South flows in the land of India and pours into the Great Ocean if it reaches it singly or paired. So the waters of the land of India are either from the cold Northern mountains, or from the Eastern mountains, and they are those same ones extending to the East and bending towards the South until they reached the Great Ocean and entered it piece after piece at the known Dam of "Rama". They are only separated by the heat in them and the cold. We have deposited the names of the rivers [in] this table:

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: There exits from the mountains bordering the kingdom of "Kayabish" [Kapisa], which is "Kabul", water nicknamed by its branches "Ghorwand". Added to it is the water of the pass of "Ghuzak" and the water of the gorge of "Panjhir" below the town of "Parwan" and the water of "Sharwat" and "Sawa" passing through the town of "Lanbaga", which is "Lamghan" [Laghman]. They meet at the fort of "Druta". The water of "Nur" and "Kirat" falls into it. So there becomes from them opposite the town of "Parshawar" [Peshawar] a great river known as the Crossing. It is the village of "Manhara" on its eastern bank. It falls into the water of Sindh [Indus] at the fort of "Bitur" below the city of "Al-Qandahar" [Gandhara], which is "Waihind". Then comes the water of "Biyatta" [Jhelum], known as Jhelum, to its west, and the water of "Chandrahaha" [Chenab]. They meet above "Jahrawar" by close to fifty miles and pass on the west of "Multan". The water of "Biyah" [Beas] passes on its east and falls into them. The water of "Irava" [Ravi] comes and the river "Kaj" [?], coming out from "Nagarkot" which is in the mountains of "Bhatal", falls into it. Then the water of "Shatladar" [Sutlej]. When they gather below Multan in a place called "Panjnad", meaning the Meeting of the Five Rivers, its magnitude becomes great. It reaches from its overflow...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...at the time of the flood that it spreads close to ten Farsakhs and drowns the trees of the deserts until the scum of the torrent is seen gathering on the tops of their branches like birds' nests. It is called among us, when it crosses united the town of "Aror" of the lands of "Sindh", the river "Mehran" [Indus]. It extends guiding, spread out, clear, surrounding places like islands until it reaches "Al-Mansura", which is between its branches. It pours into the sea in two places, one of them at the city of "Lohrani" and the other more inclined to the East in the borders of "Kutch". It is known as Sindhu Sagara, meaning the Sea of Sindh. Just as the meeting of the five rivers was named here, likewise the rivers flowing from the mentioned mountains towards the North, as when they gathered at Termez and the river of "Balkh" [Oxus/Amu Darya] came from them, were named the Meeting of the Seven Rivers. The Magians of Sogdia mixed both «1» matters and said: Indeed the sum of the seven rivers is "Sindh", and its highest is "Baridish" [?]. He who descends it sees the decline of the sun on his right if he faces the West, as we see it here on our left. As for the river "Sarsat" [Sarasvati], it falls into the sea east of "Somnath" by the amount of a bowshot. The water of "Jumna" [Yamuna] pours into the river "Ganges" below the city of "Kannauj", which is on its west. Then the two combined fall into the Great Ocean at "Gangasagara". Between the mouths of the rivers Sarsat and Ganges is the mouth of the river "Narmada". It comes from eastern mountains and extends on the South to the West and falls into the sea near the town of "Bharuch", which is east of Somnath by close to sixty Yojanas. Behind the water of Ganges is the water of "Rahab" and the water of "Kuhini" [?]. They gather to the water of "Saru" [Saryu] near the town of "Bari". Among the belief of the Indians regarding the river Ganges: That its course was in ancient times on the land of Paradise. The news of its descent to the earth will come. It was said in "Matsya Purana": Indeed Ganges, when it settled on the earth, divided into seven branches. The middle of them is its column known by this name. Three flowed towards the East and their names are: "Nalini, Hladini, Pavani". And three flowed towards the West and their names are: "Sita, Chakshu, Sindhu". As for the river Sita, when it exits from "Himavant"...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...it passes over the kingdoms of "Salila, Karstuba, China, Barbara, Yavana, Bhashkala, Kulata, Mangala, Kavara, Sangata", then falls into the Western Sea. South of it is the river "Chakshu". It waters the kingdoms of "China, Maru, Kalika, Dhulika, Tukhara, Barbara, Kacha, Palhava, Parada". As for the river "Sindhu", it penetrates the kingdoms of "Sindhu, Darada, Zandatanda, Gandhara, Rurasa, Karura, Sivapura, Indra, Maru, Sabat, Saindhava «1», Kubata, Bhimaruya, Maru, Maruna, Sukurda". The river "Ganges", which is the middle column, passes over "Gandharva—the singers—, Kinnara, Yaksha, Rakshasa, Vidyadhara, Uraga meaning the crawling on their chests and they are the snakes, Kalapa, Grama meaning the village of the virtuous, Kimpurusha, Khasa and they are the mountaineers, Kirata, Pulinda and they are hunters in the deserts thieves, Kuru, Bharata, Panchala, Kaushika, Matsya, Magadha, Brahmottara, Tamralipta". These are good and bad people Ganges passes over. It enters after that into the gorges of Mount "Vindhya", the mine of elephants and their origin «2», and falls after that into the Southern Sea. As for its eastern branches, the river "Hladini" passes over "Nishada, Upagana, Dhivara, Prishaka, Nilamukha, Kekara, Ushtrakarna meaning those whose lips are inverted like their ears, Kirata, Kalidara, Vivarna meaning those who have no color due to intense blackness, Kushika, Svargabhumu meaning like the land of Paradise", then falls into the Eastern Sea. As for the river "Pavani", it waters "Kupatha—those distancing from sins—, Indradyumna Saras meaning the ponds of King Indradyumna, Kharpatha, Vetrasankupatha". It penetrates the wilderness of "Ujjanamarura" and passes over "Kuthapravarana" «3» who wear the grass of the dancers of the Brahmins, then over "Indradvipa", and falls after that into the Salt Sea. As for the river "Nalini", it passes over "Tamra, Hamsamarga «4», Samuhaka, Purna". All of them are righteous...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...distancing themselves from evil. After that, it mediates mountains and passes over "Karnapravarana, meaning those whose ears fall on their shoulders, Ashvamukha, meaning those whose faces are like the faces of beasts, Parvatamaru—the deserts with mountains—, Rumi Mandala", then falls into the sea. As for in "Vishnu Purana", he mentioned that the large rivers of the Middle Earth pouring into the sea are: "Anutapta, Shikhi, Dipapa, Tridiva, Krama, Amrita, Sukrita".

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
26 - On the Form of the Heaven and the Earth according to their Astrologers
The matter of the Indians among themselves has run contrary to the condition among our people. That is because the Qur'an did not speak in this chapter, nor in any necessary thing, with what necessitates arbitrariness in interpretation to divert it to what is known by necessity, like the revealed books before it. Rather, it is in necessary things with them like the alignment of feather to feather (perfect match) and with precision without similarity. It also did not contain anything of what was disputed and despaired of reaching of what resembles histories. Even though Islam was plotted against in its beginnings by a group of its opponents who manifested it by pretense and narrated to those of sound hearts from their books what Allah did not create anything of in them, neither little nor much. So they believed them and wrote it from them, deceived by their hypocrisy, and left what they had of the True Book because the hearts of the common people are more inclined to superstitions, so the reports became confused because of that. Then another calamity came from the side of the heretics (Zanadiqah), the followers of "Mani", like Ibn al-Muqaffa' and like Abdul Karim ibn Abi al-Awja' and their likes. They made those of weak instincts doubt the First One from the perspective of justice and injustice, and inclined them to Dualism, and adorned for them the biography of Mani until they held fast to his rope. He is a man not restricted by his ignorances in his doctrine without speaking on the form of the world with what reveals his deceptions. That spread on tongues and was added to what preceded of Jewish plots, so it became an opinion attributed to Islam—Glory be to Allah from its like—and he who opposes it and holds fast to the Truth conforming to the Qur'an regarding it is branded with disbelief and atheism, his blood judged to be spilled, not permitted to have his speech heard. It is less than what...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...is heard from the speech of Pharaoh: "I am your Lord, the Most High" «1», "I did not know for you any god other than me" «2». The prolongation of partisanship might incline us with it from the ideal path for zealotry. May Allah make firm the foot of him who intends Him and intends the Truth in it. As for the Indians, their religious books and informative Puranas all speak on the form of the world with what contradicts the clear truth according to their astrologers. Except that the people, due to them, are compelled in establishing the laws and carrying the great majority on them to astrological calculations and judicial warnings. So they show inclination to them and speak of their virtue and seek blessing by meeting them and declare decisively that they are of the people of Paradise, none of them entering Hell. Their astrologers reward them with belief and conformity to what they are upon, even if most of it opposes the truth, and undertake for them what is needed from them. Therefore, the two opinions mixed over days, and the speech obtained with the astrologers became disordered, especially with those who imitate and take principles by reports and do not go in them the way of verification, and they are the majority of them. Let us narrate now what they are upon and say: Indeed the heaven and the world according to them are round, and the earth is spherical in shape. Its northern half is dry land and its southern half is submerged in water. Its magnitude with them is greater than what it is with the Greeks. Among what the moderns found and find, they have deviated in it from mentioning the seas and Dvipas and the many Yojanas estimated for it, and followed the owners of the creed in what is not impugning the art (astronomy) regarding Mount "Meru" being under the North Pole and the island of "Vadavamukha" under the South Pole. As for the Mountain, whether it is there or not, since what is needed from it is the properties of the millstone rotation, and they are, due to the zenith alignment, existing for the place on the surface of the earth and for what is at its zenith in the air. As for the Southern Island, it is likewise a harmless report. However, it is possible, indeed like the necessary, that two quarters of the quarters of the earth are dry land and the other two are submerged in water. They see the earth in the middle and weights gravitating towards it, so inevitably they see the heaven therefore as spherical...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...in shape. We narrate their sayings in that according to our translation. If the wordings oppose what is customary, let the meanings be considered by them, for they are the sought. "Paulisa" said in his "Siddhanta": Indeed Paul «1» the Greek mentioned in a place: That the earth is spherical in shape. And he said in another place: That it is planar (disk-like). He was truthful in both, because roundness is in its surface and straightness is in its diameter. He did not believe in it other than sphericity by many proofs from his speech and the consensus of scholars on that, such as "Varahamihira", "Aryabhata", "Deva", "Srishena", "Vishnuchandra" «2», and "Brahm". For if it were not round, the latitudes of places would not be marked, nor would day and night differ in summer and winter, nor would the conditions of planets and their orbits be found as they were found. As for its place, it is the center. Half of it is clay and half of it is water. Mount "Meru" is in its dry half, the dwelling of "Dev", the angels. Above it is the North Pole. In its half submerged in water under the South Pole is "Vadavamukha", and it is dry land like an island, inhabited by "Daitya" and "Naga", the relatives of the angels who are in Meru. Therefore, it was also named "Daityantara". The line separating the dry and wet halves of the earth is called "Niraksha", meaning that which has no latitude, and it is the Equator. In its four directions are four great cities. As for in the East, "Yamakoti". As for in the South, "Lanka" «3». In the West, "Romaka". And in the North, "Siddhapura". The earth is fastened by the two poles, and the axis holds it. If the sun rises on the line passing through "Meru" and "Lanka", that time is noon for "Yamakoti", midnight for Rum (Romaka), and evening for Siddhapura. Aryabhata says likewise. "Brahmagupta son of Jishnu" of Bhillamala said in "Brahma Siddhanta": Indeed the sayings of people have multiplied regarding the form of the earth, especially among those who study the Puranas and the religious books. Some of them see that it is like a mirror, flat. Some of them see that it is like a bowl, hollow. Some of them claim that it is level...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...like a mirror surrounded by a sea, then a land, then a sea to the last of them, round like collars. The magnitude of every sea of them or land is double that which is inside it, until the furthest land is sixty-four times like the middle land, and the furthest surrounding sea is sixty-four times the nearest surrounding sea. However, the difference of rising and setting, such that one in "Yamakoti" sees the single star at the single time on the horizon of the West, and one in Rum sees it then on the horizon of the East rising, is among what necessitates the shape of the sphere for the heaven and the earth. Likewise, the seeing of one in "Meru" of the single star at the single time on the horizon in the direction of "Lanka" «1», the homeland of the devils, and the seeing of one in "Lanka" «1» of it above their heads, indicates the like of it. Then calculations are not correct except with it. So by necessity we say: Indeed the heaven is a sphere because of our finding its properties in it, and indeed these properties are not correct in the world except with its being a sphere. So the invalidity of other sayings regarding it is not hidden then. "Aryabhata" investigates the world and says: It is earth, water, fire, and wind, and they are all round. Likewise "Vasishtha" and "Lata" say: Indeed the five elements, which are earth, water, fire, wind, and heaven, are round. "Varahamihira" says: Indeed the apparent sensed things testify to sphericity for it and negate other shapes from it. "Aryabhata", "Paulisa", "Vasishtha", and "Lata" have agreed that if it is noon in "Yamakoti" «2», it is then midnight in Rum, the beginning of the day in "Lanka" «2», and the beginning of the night in "Siddhapura". This is not possible except on circularity. Likewise, the times of eclipses are not consistent except on it. "Lata" said: Every place on the earth, only half the sphere of the heaven is seen in it. According to the latitude in the North, "Meru" and the Pole rise on the horizon as they descend according to the latitude in the South. In both of them, the Equator descends from the zenith according to the latitude. Everyone who is in a direction of the two directions, North and South, does not...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...see except the Pole which is in his direction, and the one which is in the opposite of his direction is hidden from him. These are their sayings regarding the sphericity of the heaven and the earth and what is between them, and the earth being in the center of the world with a very small magnitude compared to what is seen of the heaven. These are the principles of the science of astronomy which the first book of the Almagest contains, and what resembled it of other books, even if they are not with the verification and refinement that we follow. That is because the earth is heavier than water, and water is fluid like air. The spherical shape of the earth is necessary, natural, unless a divine command removes it from it. It is not possible that the earth moves aside towards the North and the water towards the South so that half the total is dry land and half of it is water except after hollowing out the dry land. As for us, our inductive finding necessitates dryness in one of its two Northern quarters, and for its sake we infer the like of that in the quarter diagonal to it. We allow the island of "Vadavamukha" but do not necessitate it because its matter and the matter of Meru is report-based. As for the Equator, it is not, in the quarter known to us, on the common separation between land and sea. For the land crowds the sea in places, so it enters it an entry by which it crosses the Equator, like the deserts of the "Sudan" (Blacks) of the West (Africa), because they butted the sea and entered it to places behind the Mountains of the Moon and the sources of the Nile. We did not verify them because from the land side they are a wilderness not traveled, and from the sea side behind Sofala of the Zanj likewise; no ship returned from there having risked itself so as to report what it witnessed. Likewise, there enters it from the land of India above the lands of Sindh a great piece in which it is imagined that it crosses the Equator to the South. Between that is the land of the Arabs and Yemen on this image without penetration into the sea crossing the Equator. Just as the land enters the sea, likewise the sea enters the land and pierces it in places and makes it gulfs and inlets «1», as it spread a tongue from the west of the land of the Arabs to near the middle of al-Sham (Syria) and tapered at al-Qulzum, so it was known by it. And another greater than it from the east of their land known as the Sea of "Fars" (Persian Gulf). It also bent between the lands of India and China, a bending to the North greatly. Thus the shape of the coast departed by that from sticking to the Equator or being at a distance...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...from it (the Equator) unchangeable. The discussion «1» on the four cities will come in its place. What was mentioned of the difference of times is from the consequences of the sphericity of the earth and its adhering to the middle of the world. If its inhabitants were mentioned with it—and cities must have civilized inhabitants—that would be from the consequences of the inclination of weights towards its center, which is the middle of the world. What is in "Vayu Purana" approximates it: That noon at "Amaravati" is sunrise at "Vibhavari" [?], midnight at "Sukha" [?], and sunset at "Samyamani" [?]. And what is in "Matsya Purana": That it mentioned in it that from Mount "Meru" towards the East is the city of "Amaravati Pura", which belongs to "Indra" the Chief, and in it is his wife. Towards the South is the city of "Samyamani Pura", in which is "Yama", son of the Sun; he punishes people there and rewards them. Towards the West is the city of "Sukha Pura", in which is "Varuna", meaning Water. Towards the North for the Moon is "Vibhavari Pura". The Sun and the planets revolve around Meru. If the Sun is at the noon of Amaravati Pura, it is the beginning of the day in Samyamani Pura, midnight in Sukha, and the beginning of the night in Vibhavari Pura. If it is at the noon of Samyamani Pura, it is rising on Sukha Pura, setting on Amaravati Pura, and at midnight of Vibhavari Pura. His saying: "Indeed the Sun revolves around Meru," means like a millstone for those on it. There is neither East nor West there due to the form of the movement, nor does the Sun rise in it from one specific place but from different places. He only pointed to the direction of a city and named it East, and to another direction and named it West. It is possible that these four cities are the ones their astrologers mentioned, but he did not clarify the distance between them and the Mountain. The rest of what we narrated from them is the truth which proof necessitates. But it is their custom not to mention the Pole unless this Mountain is mentioned with it in conjunction. They believe regarding the Low (Bottom) what we believe regarding it, that it is the center of the world, were it not that the expression for it is weak, especially since it is from the issues of the stalwarts which only great men undertake. "Brahmagupta" said: Indeed the scholars claimed that the sphere of the earth is in the middle of the heaven. From it is Mount "Meru", the dwelling of "Dev", and lower than it is "Vadavamukha", the dwelling of their opponents of...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ..."Daitya" and "Danava". They did not go from this Low except to rank (hierarchy), otherwise the condition of the earth from all its directions is one, and everyone on it stands upright towards the High. Heavy things fall to it naturally just as holding things and preserving them is in its nature, flowing is in the nature of water, burning is in the nature of fire, and moving is in the nature of wind. If a thing seeks lowliness from the earth, let it go down, for there is no low other than it. Seeds descend to it wherever they are thrown and do not ascend from it. "Varahamihira" said: Indeed the mountains, seas, rivers, trees, cities, people, and angels are all around the sphere of the earth. It is not possible to say regarding the opposition of "Yamakoti" and "Rum" (Rome/Romaka) that it is lowliness, as there is no low. How can it be said regarding one of them that it is low while its condition is like the condition of the other? Neither of them is more worthy of falling; rather, each one in itself and to itself says "I am the high one and the rest are low." All of them are around the sphere like the emergence of blossoms on the branches of the tree called "Kadamba", for they surround it. Each one in its place is like the example of the other; one of them does not hang down nor does another stand upright. The earth holds what is on it because it is low from all directions and the heaven is high in all directions. So the speech of the people in this chapter, as you see, issues from knowledge of correct laws, even if they compromised with the owners of reports and laws. For "Balabhadra" the Commentator says: Indeed the most correct of sayings, despite their multitude and difference, is that the earth and "Meru" and the zodiacal sphere are round. The "Apta Puranakara", meaning the Truthful Ones who follow the Purana, say: Indeed the earth is like the back of a tortoise; it has no roundness from below. He said: And they have spoken the truth, for the earth is in the middle of the water, and what appears of it is on the form of the back of a tortoise, and the sea surrounding it is not traveled. As for the roundness of the zodiacal sphere, it is witnessed by viewing. So look how he believed them in the roundness of the back and ignored their negation of roundness from the belly, and occupied himself with a talk unconnected to that. He said: Indeed the sight of man does not reach from the earth and its roundness five thousand «1» "Yojanas" except to a part of ninety-six parts of it, that is fifty-two...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...Yojanas. Therefore, he does not sense the roundness, and that is the cause of the difference of sayings regarding it. Those Truthful Ones did not deny the roundness of the back of the earth; rather, they established it by the example of the back of the tortoise. "Balabhadra" only denied it from their saying because he carried its meaning to the encompassing of water around it. What protrudes from the water is allowed to be spherical of face and [also] to be flat rising from the water like an inverted tambourine, meaning a segment of a round cylinder. As for roundness exiting from being sensed due to the smallness of man's stature, it is incorrect because even if the stature were like the column of the greatest mountain, then the contemplation was from one place on it without moving and using the method of measurement regarding what is found in it of the difference of conditions, its length would not benefit and one would not sense the roundness of the earth alone. But how does this speech connect to the doctrine of the people? If he had established roundness for the earth in the side opposite to roundness, meaning that which is below metaphorically, then mentioned what he mentioned to show it as intelligible benefited from sense, his saying would have had some face. As for his specifying the seen magnitude of the earth, let the sphere of the earth be for him: AB on center: E, and point: B of it the standing place of the viewer looking at what is around him, and the stature: BC, and CA comes out touching the earth. It is known that the seen is: BA. Let us assume it a part of ninety-six parts of the circumference, and that is three degrees and a half and a quarter of a degree if the circumference is three hundred and sixty. Like what preceded in the chapter of Mount "Meru", we divide the square of: TE (Hypotenuse/Secant?) which is 50625 by: 5 T (Cosine?) which is 3431, so TC comes out 1 «1» 4 45 (minutes?), and BC the stature is: «1» 7 45 (minutes?). That is on the basis that: EB the total Sine is: 3438. But the radius of the earth according to what was mentioned of its circumference: 795 27 16 (Yojanas?). If we convert: BC to it, it would be one Yojana «2» and six Krohs and one thousand and thirty-five «2» cubits. If we assumed: BC four cubits, its ratio to: AT by the magnitude of the Sine would be like the ratio of 57035 «3», which is the cubits of what came out for the stature, to: AT by the magnitude of the Sine which is 225. If...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...we extracted it, it would be 0 «1» 0 1 AC, and its arc likewise. But the share of one degree of the roundness of the earth as mentioned is thirteen Yojanas and seven Krohs and three hundred and thirty-three cubits and a third of a cubit. So the seen of the earth then is two hundred and ninety-one cubits and two-thirds of a cubit. The way from which "Balabhadra" was approached is what is in "Paulisa Siddhanta" when he cut the Sine for the quadrant of the circle into twenty-four Kardajas (segments). Then he said: If a questioner asks about the cause of that, let him know that one Kardaja of these is a part of ninety-six parts of the circumference, and its minutes are 225.
