When we extracted its sine, its minutes were 225. So we knew from that that sines equal their arcs in what is smaller than this Kardaja. Since the total Sine according to "Paulisa" and "Aryabhata" is on the ratio of the diameter to the circumference of three hundred and sixty, "Balabhadra" was deluded by this numerical equality and thought that the arc had become straight. Whatever does not have «1» a convexity, a protrusion preventing vision from passing, and did not become small, is perceived. This is the great error, for the arc never becomes straight nor...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...does the Sine, even if small, equal its arc. That is only in the parts assumed for use. As for in its parts, then 'so on' and 'drag along' (ad infinitum) to the farthest China. As for the saying of Paulisa regarding the earth: Indeed the axis holds it, he does not mean by it that a physical axis is there such that were it not for it the earth would fall. How could he say this when he sees the four cities around the earth inhabited, and those are necessitators of the descent of heavy things to the earth from all sides? But he meant by it that the movement of what is on the circumference is a cause for the stillness of what is in the center. Movement in the sphere is only on two poles, and the line connecting them seemingly is the axis. It is as if he says: Indeed the movement of the heaven is holding the earth in its place, making it natural for it, impossible to be in other than it. It is on the axis of movement, then on its middle, because the rest of the diameters of the sphere are possible to be imagined «1» as axes, for they are so potentially. If it were not in the middle, the existence of an axis away from it would be possible, so it is as if in the image it is supported by axes. As for the stillness of the earth, which is also one of the principles of astronomy where resolving the doubts occurring in it is difficult, they are also upon believing it. "Brahmagupta" said in "Brahma Siddhanta": Indeed some people claimed that the first movement is not in the meridian (Equator/Daily motion?), but rather it belongs to the earth. "Varahamihira" refuted them saying that that necessitates that a bird does not return to its nest whenever it flies from it towards the West. And it is as he said. Then Brahmagupta said in another place of it: Indeed the companions of "Aryabhata" say: Indeed the earth is moving and the heaven is resting. It was said in refuting them: Indeed if that were so, stones and trees would fall from it. Brahmagupta did not approve of that and said: Indeed it does not necessitate that for them. It is as if he meant by that from the perspective that heavy things are attracted to their center. He said: Rather, if that were so, the minutes of the heaven would not steal the "Prana" of times. Perhaps the confusion in this chapter is from the side of the translator. For the minutes of the heaven are: 21600 «2» and are called Pranas, meaning breaths, because they claim that every minute of the meridian...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...revolves in the time of a moderate breath of the breaths of people. Let us grant that that is correct and that the earth revolves the complete revolution towards the East in this number of breaths as the heaven revolves it according to him, then what is the hindrance in it from balancing and parallelism? Moreover, the movement of the earth rotationally does not impugn the science of astronomy in anything; rather, its matters are consistent with it equally. It is only impossible from other perspectives. Therefore, it became the most difficult of doubts in this chapter to analyze. The virtuous among the moderns after the ancients have spoken much on delving into it and refuting it. We think we have exceeded them in meaning, not speech, in the book "Miftah 'Ilm al-Hay'ah" (Key to Astronomy).

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
27 - On the Two First Movements according to their Astrologers and the Authors of the Puranas
As for according to the astrologers among them, the matter is as we hold in most things. We narrate first their sayings in it, even if what we found of that is very little. "Paulisa" said: The Wind turns the sphere of the fixed stars, and the two Poles hold it. Its movement which is to the West is seen by the inhabitants of Mount "Meru" from left to right, and the inhabitants of "Vadavamukha" see it from right to left. He said in another place: If a questioner asks about the direction of the movement of the stars despite what he sees of their rising from the East and their rotation towards the West until they set, let him know that the movement which we see for them towards the West differs in direction according to the perception of the people of the dwellings of it. So the inhabitants of Mount "Meru" see it from left to right, and the people of the island of "Vadavamukha" find it the opposite of that, from right to left. The inhabitants of the Equator [see it] towards the West only. Those who are between these places [see it] inclined according to the latitudes of the dwellings. It is in summary issuing from the Wind which turns the spheres so the stars and others adhere to rising from the East and setting in the West accidentally. As for essentially, their movements are towards the East. This movement is the one which is from "Ashvini" (Sheratan) towards "Bharani" (Butain), for Bharani is to the East of Sheratan. If the questioner does not know the Lunar Mansions and is unable to measure the Eastern movement upon them, let him contemplate the Moon itself in its distancing from the Sun first by first, then its approaching it likewise until it conjoins it, to conceive from that its second movement. "Brahmagupta" said: Indeed the Sphere was created moving on two poles with the fastest...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...movement possible so languor does not afflict it. The stars were created where there was no Belly of the Fish (Andromeda/Pisces?) nor Sheratan (Aries), meaning in the common separation between them, which is the Vernal Equinox. "Balabhadra" the Commentator said: Indeed the whole world is suspended by two poles and moving with a rotation starting «1» from "Kalpa" «2» and ending at Kalpa «2». So it is not permissible to say regarding the world, due to the continuity of its movement: That it has no beginning and no end. "Brahmagupta" said: The place which has no latitude, and it is the one divided into sixty Ghatis (Kahris), is a horizon for one in "Meru". East in it becomes West. Behind this place in the South is "Vadavamukha", and the sea surrounds it. If the spheres and stars rotate, the Equator becomes a common horizon for the angels and for Daitya; they see it together. The direction of movement differs between them. What the angels see of it as moving to the right, "Daitya" see as moving to the left, and vice versa, on the example of one who has something in his right hand; if he looks into water, he sees it in his left hand. The cause of this even movement which does not increase nor decrease is a Wind. It is not the wind witnessed among us, for this one calms down and agitates and varies, and that one does not calm down. He also said in another place: And the Wind turns all the fixed and wandering stars towards the West in one rotation. The wandering ones (planets) move towards the East a slight movement on the example of an ant moving on the potter's wheel in the opposite direction of the turning. For what is seen of its movement is the turning, and its essential movement is not sensed. This is a saying agreed upon by "Lata", "Aryabhata", and "Vasishtha", except a group who saw movement for the earth and stillness for the heaven. As for the movement which people consider from the East to the West, the angels see it from left to right and Daitya from right to left. This is what I studied of their books regarding it. As for the Wind which they point to in moving, I think it is only for approximation to understandings, for it is witnessed in moving winged instruments and vanes when it blows on them. Since the reference was to the Prime Mover, they returned to denying the resemblance of it to the natural wind which differs by the difference of...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...its causes. For even if it is a mover of things, it is not from its essence nor without contact, because it is a body and has stimuli from outside; its movement is according to their stimulating it. Their negation of stillness from it is an indication by them to the permanence of moving, not to the stillness and movement which belong to the body. Likewise, denying languor from it is an indication of its innocence of different conditions, for languor and fatigue only belong to the composite of opposites in quality. As for the preservation of the two poles for the sphere of fixed stars, its meaning is on order, not from falling. It was narrated about some of the ancient Greeks that he saw in the Milky Way that it was in some times a path for the Sun then it moved from it. This is the cessation of movements from the order which is possible to attribute to the preservation of the poles. As for the saying of "Balabhadra" regarding the finiteness of movement, its meaning is that what exits into existence falling under number is inevitably finite «1» from the perspective of its beginning, because number comes from the compositions of the One and its multiples, and it precedes them inevitably. And from the perspective of what exists of it in the 'Now' of time. That is a necessity. If the days and nights are increasing in number by the permanence of being, they have a first from which they began. If a denier denies their existence in the sphere and claims that day and night exist relative to the earth and its inhabitants, and that if they were lifted from the middle of the world, night and day would be lifted by their lifting, and enumeration would cease for the composites of their sums which are the days; Balabhadra turned away from inferring by the requirement of the first movement to the requirement of the second, which is the cycles of the planets, for they are relative to the sphere not the earth. He expressed it as Kalpa «2» because it is the collector of them and that which all of them begin from its start. As for the saying of "Brahmagupta" regarding the Equator: That it is the one divided into sixty, it is like the saying of a sayer if he were from our companions: That it is the one divided into twenty-four. That is because it is the measurer of times and the counter of them. Its rotation contains twenty-four hours as it contains according to the Indians sixty Ghatis (Kahris). Therefore, they calculated the ascensions of the Signs by Ghatis not by the times (degrees) of the Equator. As for his saying...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...regarding the Wind turning the fixed and wandering stars, then his specifying the wandering ones with the slight movement towards the East, it creates the illusion from him that he does not see a movement for the fixed ones. Otherwise, they also move a slight movement towards the East like the wandering ones; it does not differ from it except in magnitude and in the perplexity (retrograde) occurring to those in return. A group narrated about the ancients: That they did not realize their movements until long times guided them to them. What confirms that illusion is the emptiness of the cycles in his book of mentioning cycles for the fixed stars and his hanging their appearance and disappearance on degrees of the Sun that do not change. As for his negating right and left from the first movement for the one inhabiting the Equator, let it be known that the one dwelling under one of the poles, wherever he turns, faces the moving things. Because they are to one direction, they are necessarily taking from the alignment of one of his hands towards the direction of his face and from it to the alignment of the other hand. The matter is exchanged in the hands for the dwellers under both «1» poles due to their opposition, its exchange in water and the mirror. For sight, if reflected from them, becomes like another human opposite this viewer perceiving with his right his left and with his left his right. Likewise, the rest of the dwellings with Northern latitudes, their people face the moving things towards the South. And the Southern ones, their people face the moving things towards the North. So the matter of movement for them is on the analogy of the dwellers of "Meru" and "Vadavamukha". As for the one existing on the Equator, the moving things rotate over him approximately, so he does not face them in a direction. As for precisely, they distance from him a little. If he faced them in both directions in one form, the movement of the Northern ones over him would be from right to left, and the Southern ones contrary to that. So he combined the property of both poles together, and the exchange happened for him with himself not another. As for what rotated over his zenith, it is what "Brahmagupta" indicated of divisions. As for the sayings of the authors of the Puranas, they «2» made the heaven a dome over the earth, static, and the stars by themselves moving from East to West. So when would they have knowledge...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...of the second movement? And if it existed, when would the opponent allow them the moving of one thing to two different directions with two movements essentially? We mention what reached us «1» from their side not for benefit, for there is no benefit in it. It was said in "Matsya Purana": Indeed the Sun and the stars pass towards the South with the speed of an arrow, revolving around Meru. The rotation of the Sun is on the example of a wood with a flaming end if you speed up its rotation. It does not set in itself, but hides from some people excluding others of the four cities which are in the four directions of the Mountain. It revolves around it to the North of Mount "Lokaloka"; it does not cross it nor illuminate its Southern side. Its hiding at night is because of its distance. A human might see it from thousands of "Yojanas", then a small thing hides it from him if the thing is close to the eye. If the Sun aligns with "Pushkara Dvipa" «2», it moves in three-fifths of an hour a part of thirty of the earth. So for this duration is twenty-one «3» Lakhs and fifty «4» thousand Yojanas, and that is 2,150,000. Then it inclines to the North, so its travel becomes three times what it was; therefore the day lengthens. The rotation of the Sun in the Southern day is nine "Koti" and ten thousand «5» and forty-five «6» Yojanas. If it returns to the North and rotates over "Kshira", meaning the Milky Sea, its day is three Koti and twenty-one "Lakhs". Look at the disorder of these sayings in the subject. Because his saying regarding the passing of stars: That they speed like an arrow, even if it is by way of exaggeration in description for common understanding, the South is not specialized with it excluding the North. If they have in both directions two limits for fluctuation, and the time of their passing from the Southern limit to the Northern limit equals the time of their passing between them conversely, their passing to the North is also with the speed of an arrow. But that is proof of his belief regarding...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...the North Pole that it is the High, and the direction of the South is lowering from it, so the stars pass to it like boys on slides. If he means by this passing the second movement, while that is the first, then the stars by it do not pass around "Meru" but incline from its horizon close to half a sixth of a rotation (30 degrees). Then how far is his example in the movement of the Sun by the flaming wood. If we were seeing the moving Sun as a connected round collar, his example would be useful in informing us that it is not so. As for when we see the Sun as a piece in the sky like standing, his example is nonsense. If he means by that that it makes a round orbit, the flaming in his wood is filler, for a stone suspended from the head of a string makes an orbit like it if spun above the head. The rising of the Sun on people and its absence from others is true were it not for what we mentioned of his belief. Mount "Lokaloka" and the falling of the sun's ray on it from its inner side which he named North and the outer South testifies against him. The hiding of the Sun at night is not due to distance, but by a screen which is the Earth for us and Mount Meru for him, but he conceived the orbit around the Mountain and we are in a side from it, so the distances from us to it differed. What is after that of speech testifies that it is originally thus and its hiding at night is not for its distance. As for the numbers that were mentioned, I think they are corrupt, changed, and we have no work with them. But he made the travel of the Sun in the North three times its travel in the South and made that the cause of the length of the day and its shortness, while the sum of the day and its night is always in its state, and they in the North and South compensate each other. It must be that what was mentioned is said regarding the latitude whose summer day is forty-five Ghatis and winter [day] is fifteen. Along with that, the speeding of the Sun in the North needs presenting a cause for it, for its positions narrow the Northern orbits due to their proximity to the Pole and widen the Southern ones due to their proximity to the Tail (skirt/edge). If the Sun speeds in the smaller distance, its time becomes shorter than the time of the larger distance, and it has slowed in it also, and the matter is the reverse. Then his saying: That if it rotated on "Pushkara Dvipa" «1» is an expression for the orbit of the Winter Solstice, and he has made the day in it...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...greater in magnitude than other than it, whether it is the Summer Solstice or otherwise. So all the speech is unintelligible. Similar to it is what is in "Vayu Purana": That the day in the South is twelve "Muhurtas" and in the North eighteen, and it inclines between the North and South 17,221 "Yojanas" in 183 days, so the share of the day is 94 Yojanas. As for Muhurta, it is four-fifths of an hour. The proposition is said regarding a latitude whose longest day is fourteen hours and a fifth of an hour. What was mentioned of the number of Yojanas, the apparent matter requires that it be the share of double the declination of the sphere. The declination with them is twenty-four parts, so the Yojanas of the whole sphere then are 129,157 and a half Yojanas. The days in which the Sun cuts double the declination are half its year with the fraction forced (rounded), for it is close to five-eighths of a day. In Vayu Purana: That the Sun in the North slows by day and speeds by night, and in the South conversely. Therefore, the day lengthens in the North and reaches eighteen Muhurtas. This is the speech of one who does not know the Eastern movement at all and is not guided to estimate the arc of the day by viewing. In the book "Vishnu Dharma": That the orbit of the Great Bear is below the Pole, and below it is the orbit of Saturn, then Jupiter, then Mars, then the Sun, then Venus, then Mercury, then the Moon. They rotate towards the East like a millstone with a movement of equal magnitude in every planet, because among them are fast and slow. Death and life have repeated on them in ancient times thousands of times. This speech, if it is intended to be conducted on the paths of correctness, is disordered. Because if we went regarding the being below of the Great Bear from the Pole to [the idea] that the place of the Pole is the High, the Great Bear is lower than the zenith of the heads of the people of "Meru", and he spoke truth in it. Then he lied regarding the wandering planets, for 'below' in them is said regarding nearness and distance from the earth. It will never be consistent on that «1» unless Saturn is the greatest of planets in declination of course «2» from the Equator, then Jupiter, then the rest of them the first then the first, and with that fixed on that amount of declination. That is not so in existence. If we carried...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...all on one matter, it would be true, for the fixed stars are above the wandering ones, but the Pole does not rise above them. As for the millstone rotation, it is by the first movement towards the West, not the second which he pointed to. The planets with him are souls of persons who attained height by earning and returned to it at the completion of the period. I think he pointed to the number by thousands from one of two perspectives: either because of existence and exiting from potentiality to actuality, or because among them are what was liberated and in them are what will be liberated, so their number decreases, and everything accepting decrease is finite.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
28 - On Defining the Ten Directions
The extension of bodies in diameters is on three azimuths: one for length, the second for width, and the third for depth or thickness. The existing extension, not the imaginary, is finite in its azimuths. So the lines of these three azimuths, since they are finite, possess six ends, which are the directions. If an animal is imagined in their middle, meaning their intersection, his face to one of them, they become for him front and back, right and left, up and down. If they are added to the world, other names «1» obtain for them. Since rising and setting are in the horizon and the first movement appears by it, it is more appropriate for the directions to be defined in it. The four which are East, West, North, and South are famous. Those between every two of them are less famous. They with them become eight, and with Up and Down, which we do not occupy ourselves with mentioning, ten. As for the Greeks, they used to go in them to the risings of the Signs and their settings, then attribute them to the winds, so their number is sixteen. Likewise the Arabs attributed the four directions to the blowing places of the winds from them. What blew between two of them is "Nakba'" absolutely, and in special oddities named by special names. As for the Indians, they did not consider in them the blowing of a wind. They named the four directions first with names, then followed them with naming what is between every two directions of them, so they became eight in the horizon as in this image:
[Image/Table]

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: «1» Two remained for the poles of the horizon, they are Up and Down. The name of Up is "Upar" and the name of Down is "Adhas" and also "Tala". These and those of others are directions by position. Since the horizon is divided infinitely, the azimuths in it from the center are likewise. Every diameter, it is possible that its two ends be assumed either what is before and what is behind or their reverse, so the two ends of the diameter perpendicular to it are «2» right and left. Because they do not mention an intelligible or imagined thing except they establish a sensed person for it and hasten to marry him and hasten his wedding and conception and birth, in the book "Vishnu Dharma": Indeed "Atri", who is the star following the Daughters of the Bier (Ursa Major/Great Bear), married the Directions, which are one even if counted as eight, so the Moon was born to him from them. Another said: Indeed "Daksha", who is "Prajapati", married "Dharma", who is the Reward (Thawab?), to ten of his daughters, and they are the Directions. Among them is one called "Vasu", so he fathered from her many children called "Vasus"; one of them is the Moon. Inevitably...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
...our companions laugh at the birth of the Moon. I will increase for them from this commodity. They said: Indeed the Sun is the son of "Kashyapa" and its mother is "Aditi"; it was born in the sixth "Manvantara" at the mansion of "Vishakha". The Moon is the son of "Dharma"; it was born at the mansion of "Krittika". Mars is the son of "Prajapati «1»"; it was born at the mansion of "Purvashadha". Mercury is the son of the Moon; it was born at the mansion of "Dhanishta". Jupiter is the son of "Angira"; it was born at the mansion of "Purvaphalguni". Venus is the daughter of "Bhrigu «2»"; she was born at the mansion of «3» "Pushya «4»". Saturn is the son of the Sun; it was born at the mansion of "Revati". The Tailed One (Ketu) is the son of "Yama", the angel of death; it was born at the mansion of "Ashlesha". The Head (Rahu) was born at the mansion of Revati. They made lords for the eight directions in the horizon as is their custom. We placed them in a table:
[Table]

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: They have in the election for gambling by the eight directions a figure they call "Rahu Chakra «1»", meaning the Figure of the Head. It is this: [Figure]. The work with it is that you know the Lord of the Day you are in and his place from the image. Then you know the Eighth you are in of the eighths of the day. You count the eighths on the lines taking from the Lords of the Days in the sequence which is from East to South to West, so you end at the Lord of that Eighth. For example, if we wanted the owner of the fifth Eighth of Thursday, and the Lord of the Day is Jupiter in the South, and the line exiting from this direction ends at what is between West and North. So the owner of the first Eighth is Jupiter, and the owner of the second Eighth is Saturn, and the third...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...the Sun, and the fourth the Moon, and the fifth Mercury in the North. Based on this, the eighths extend to the completion of the day and enter into the following night continuously to the completion of the day (24 hours). If you know the direction of the Eighth you are in, know that it is attributed by them to the Head (Rahu). So make it, in sitting for play, behind your back, for you will win by their claim. You do not have to disdain the chosen of several playing grounds in one strike for the sake of this choice. It suffices you to entrust the matter of the dice (stones) to it.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
29 - On Defining the Inhabited Part of the Earth according to them
In the book "Bhuvana Kosha" [by] the Rishi: Indeed the inhabited earth is from "Himavant" towards the South and is called "Bharata Varsha". It was named by the name of a man, Bharata, who used to govern them and provision them. The people of this inhabited land are the ones upon whom reward and punishment fall, excluding others. This inhabited land is divided into nine divisions called "Nava Khanda Prathama", meaning the Nine First Pieces. Between every two of those pieces are seas in which one crosses from one to another. The width of the inhabited land from North to South is a thousand "Yojanas". His indication here to Himavant is to the mountains that are in the North at the cut-off of habitation due to cold; habitation is necessarily to its south. His indication to its people that they are the obligated ones is proof of the removal of obligation from others. Its removal is only by rising from humanity to the rank of angels who, by the simplicity of their substances and purity of their natures, do not disobey a command and do not weary of worship, or by descending from it to the rank of beasts that do not reason. So there is no one of mankind outside the inhabited land then. Bharata Varsha is not the land of India only, like the belief of the Indians regarding it that it is the World and they are the People only. No sea penetrates their land by which a piece in it is distinguished from a piece. One does not go in cutting to the Dvipas (Islands), for he declared that those seas are crossed in from side to side. It followed from his saying that the people of the earth all of them and the Indians are in the obligation of assignment one law. This division was named "Prathama", meaning First, only because they divide the land of India by it also alone, so it becomes...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...the division of the Inhabited World is the first, and this is the second. Their astrologers divide every kingdom by it, so it becomes a third division, and that is when they look into the locations of misfortunes and fortunes in it. In "Vayu Purana", there is something similar to what we have recounted, which is his saying: The middle of "Jambudvipa" is called "Bharatavarsha", meaning those who are devout and sustained. In it are the four Yugas, and reward and punishment are binding upon them. "Himavan" (Himalayas) is north of it. It is divided into nine divisions with navigable seas between them. Its length is nine thousand 'Yojanas' and its width is one thousand Yojanas. Because it is also called "Samanara", he who owns all of it is called by its name Samanara. The image of its nine divisions is like this: [Diagram/Table implied]. Then he begins describing the mountains in the middle piece between the East and North and the rivers flowing from them, a description he does not go beyond, giving the illusion that that piece is the Inhabited World. He contradicts himself by saying in another place: "Jambudvipa" is the middle in "Navakhanda Prathama" (The First Nine Sections?), and the rest of them are in the eight directions, containing angels, humans, animals, and plants. It is as if he is pointing to...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...the Dvipas here. If the width of the Inhabited World is one thousand 'Yojanas', its length must be approximately two thousand eight hundred Yojanas roughly. Then he mentioned the countries and regions in each direction. We will mention them in the tables along with what others mentioned, for that is easier in them. We have said previously: The piece containing habitation resembles a tortoise (Kurma) due to the roundness of its edges, its protrusion from the water, the water surrounding it, and the convexity of its spherical surface. It is possible that it is because their astrologers divide the directions among the Lunar Mansions (Nakshatras), so the countries are divided among them, and the shape becomes similar to a tortoise. Therefore, it was called "Kurma Chakra", meaning the Circle of the Tortoise or its shape. Thus it is in the book "Samhita" of Varahamihira:

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: Varahamihira called every section in "Navakhanda" a "Varga". He said: By it "Bharatavarsha", i.e., half of the world, is divided into nine sections. The first is the Middle, then the East, then it passes towards the South and circles the entire horizon. What indicates that he intended the land of India alone is his saying: Every Varga has a region whose king is killed if misfortunes befall it. For the first, which is the Middle, is the region of "Panchala". For the second "Magadha". For the third "Kalinga". For the fourth "Avanti", which is "Ujjain". For the fifth "Ananta". For the sixth Sindh and "Sauvira". For the seventh "Harahaura". For the eighth "Madra". For the ninth "Kulinda". All of these are regions of the land of India, not others. As for the names of the countries, most of them are different from what they are known by now. "Utpala" the Kashmiri commented on the book "Samhita" and said in this chapter: The names of countries change, especially in the Yugas. For "Multan" used to be called "Kasyapapura", then "Hamsapura", then "Bagapura", then "Sambhapura", then "Mulasthana", meaning the Original Place, for "Mula" is the root and "Sthana" is the place. The matter of the Yuga is of long duration, but names are quick to change when strangers of different language take over the place. Their tongues might falter in them, so they transfer them to their language like the custom of the Greeks, or take them by meaning, so the names vary. Do you not see that Shash (Tashkent) is taken from its name in Turkish which is "Tashkand", meaning the Village of Stone? Thus is its name in the book Geographia "The Tower of Stone". So they differ if they express them by their meanings or convert them to what is easy for them of letters and words, like the action of the Arabs in Arabizing names, so they become distorted, like "Pushang" in their books as "Fusanja", and like "Sagalakand" as "Farfaz" in their diwans. How far and grave the matter is! Rather, we find the single language itself in the single nation itself changing, so strange things appear in it that only the rare person understands, and that in a few years without anything happening to them to necessitate that. However, the Indians intend to multiply names and use derivation in them and boast of it. As for what is mentioned in "Vayu Purana" of the names of...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...the countries, it is in the four directions only. What is in "Samhita" is for the eight directions. The condition of all of them is the condition that preceded, and they are in these tables: 1 2 1 2 3 1 2 3 1 2 3 1 2 1 2 3

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: As for their astrologers, they have defined the longitude of the Inhabited World with Lanka in its middle on...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...the Equator, "Yamakoti" in its east, "Romaka" in its west, and "Siddhapura" opposite it. What they mentioned regarding the rising and setting in it indicated that between Yamakoti and Rum (Rome/Byzantium) is half a circle. It is as if they counted the lands of the Maghreb as part of Rum due to their opposition on the two coasts. Otherwise, the lands of Rum possess latitudes and penetrate deep into the North, and none of them has little latitude, let alone being on the Equator as they mentioned. We have finished mentioning "Lanka". As for Yamakoti, it is in the place where Yaqub and Al-Fazari mention that there is a city in the sea called "Tara". I did not find any trace of this name in Indian books at all. Because "Kot" is the name of the fortress and "Yama" is the Angel of Death, scents of "Kang-diz" waft from it, which the Persians mention that "Kay Ka'us" or "Jam" built in the furthest East beyond the sea, and that "Kay Khusraw" crossed to it following "Afrasiyab" the Turk, and went to it at the time of asceticism and leaving the kingdom. That is because "Diz" in Persian is the name of the fortress. Abu Ma'shar al-Balkhi based his Zij (astronomical table) on this place. As for Siddhapura, I do not know from where they extracted it. They do not disagree with us that beyond the inhabited half-circle are untraversed seas. As for latitude, no statement from them defining it has reached me. The saying that the longitude of the Inhabited World is half a circle is one of the common opinions among the people of the art (astronomers), but they differ in it regarding the starting point. The Indian opinion, if considered from the perspective of what is known to us, which is the city of "Ujjain", they placed it at the quarter from the eastern limit, and the limit of the completion of the second quarter is before the cessation of habitation in the direction of the West, as we will mention regarding the difference between the two longitudes. The opinion of the Westerners (Maghrebis/Muslim astronomers) is of two types. One is taken from the coast of the Surrounding Ocean (Atlantic), and the completion of the quarter from it would be around "Balkh". Therefore, when he gathered what cannot be gathered, he made Al-Shaburqan and Ujjain on one meridian. Far from it is what cannot be verified.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: The other opinion is from the Fortunate Isles (Canary Islands), and the completion of the quarter from it would be around "Jurjan" (Gorgan) and "Nishapur". Both types are far from the Indian opinion. That will become clear later. If Allah delays the term (prolongs life), I will devote a treatise investigating that for the longitude of "Nishapur".

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: XXX. On the Mention of "Lanka", Which is Known as the Cupola of the Earth (Arin). The middle of the habitation in longitude on the Equator is known to astronomers as the Cupola of the Earth. The great circle going out to it from the alignment of the Pole is called the Meridian of the Cupola. Whenever the earth is in its natural shape, no place deserves the name Cupola more than another, except by way of analogy due to the equality of distance of the two ends of habitation from it in the directions of East and West, like the equality of distances of the tent skirts from the head of the tent or the cupola. However, the Indians do not use a word for it that implies the meaning of Cupola in our language. They claim that Lanka is between the two ends of the Inhabited World, having no latitude. It is the one in which "Ravana" the Demon fortified himself when he abducted the wife of "Rama son of Dasaratha". His twisted fortress is called "Trikuta" (Three Peaks?), which is called in our lands "Javankot" (?), and perhaps attributed to "Rome". I mean by it this whose image is: [Diagram]. And that "Rama" crossed the sea to it by damming it for one hundred "Yojanas" with a mountain in a place called "Setubandha", meaning the Bridge of the Sea, which is east of "Serendib" (Sri Lanka). He fought him and killed him, and his brother killed his brother, as described in the story of "Rama" and "Ramayana". Then he cut the dam by shooting arrows in ten places.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: They claim that "Lanka" is the fortress of the demons. Its height from the earth is thirty Yojanas, that is eighty parasangs. Its length from East to West is one hundred "Yojanas", and its width from North to South is like its height. Because of it and the island of "Baravamukha" (Mare-faced fire/Vadavamukha?), they take the direction of the South as ominous. They do not do any good deeds in it, nor do they take a step towards it; rather, they assign it for evil deeds. On the line on which astronomical calculations are based, between "Lanka" and "Meru" on the straight path, is the city of "Ujjain" in the borders of "Malwa",

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: and the fort of "Rohitaka" (Rohtak) near the borders of Multan, which is now ruined. It passes through "Kurukshetra", which is the plain of "Thanesar" in the middle of their kingdoms, and over the river "Yamuna" on which is the city of "Mathura", and over "Himavant" (Himalayas), the mountains where snows persist and their rivers originate. Beyond that is Mount Meru. The city of Ujjain is the one mentioned in the tables of countries as "Arin" on the sea (likely confusion with Uzain/Ujjain as zero meridian but Arin is erroneous transcription of Ujjain). However, between it and the coast is close to a hundred Yojanas. It is also not as assumed by those of our astronomers who do not distinguish, that it is on the meridian of Al-Shaburqan which is one of the districts of Guzgan; rather, it is east of this district by many time degrees of the Equator. Its matter is confused only for those who mix different opinions regarding the origins of the longitude of the Inhabited World in the directions of East and West and are not guided to distinguish them. No one who roamed the sea around the place indicated for this fortress and traveled on its path informed us of news of it matching their reports or resembling them so that it becomes closer to possibility by hearing. Rather, I imagine from the name of "Lanka" something else, which is that Cloves are called "Lavanga" because they are imported from a land called "Lanka". It is agreed upon among sailors that ships are prepared for it, then what is prepared for it of old western Dinars and goods like towels (cloths) and salt and what is customary is carried in boats. It is poured on the coast on leather mats with the names of their owners written on them, and they move away from them towards the ships. When it is like the next day, cloves are found on the mats instead of the prices according to its abundance with them by quantity and its scarcity by lack. It is said: This trading is with the Jinn, and it is said with wild people. The Indians near those regions believe regarding Smallpox that it is a wind that is agitated from the island of Lanka towards the lands to snatch souls. It is recounted that some of them foresee its agitation before it happens, then time its reaching region after region. If Smallpox appears, they know by signs its quality, whether it is safe or fatal, and they use stratagems for the fatal one so it corrupts a single limb instead of the soul. They treat it with cloves given as a drink...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...with gold filings, and tying male cloves resembling date pits on the necks, such that not one in ten of them comes out (recovers?) except one (perhaps meaning only one dies?). It crosses the mind that Lanka which the Indians mention, even if not with their descriptions, is there. Then it is not traveled to, for it is said: If any merchant stays behind in this island, no trace of him is found after that. What strengthens the conjecture is that it is mentioned in the book of "Rama and Ramayana" that beyond the mentioned sea are a people who eat men. Furthermore, it is known among the people of the sea that the cause of the savagery of the people of the island of "Langabalus" (Nicobar?) is their eating of men.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: XXXI. On the Difference Between Kingdoms Which We Call "The Difference Between Two Longitudes". He who hovers around verification in this chapter intends what is between the meridians of the two towns. As for our companions (astronomers), they take times (degrees) which are from the Equator, and what resembles them between the mentioned two circles from the parallel of one of the towns, and they call it "The Difference Between Two Longitudes" because they take the longitude of every town as its distance in its parallel from the great circle passing through the pole of the Equator chosen at the limit of habitation. The choice of them is in the West. Whether these times are taken assuming the circle is three hundred and sixty, or taken as sixty to be minutes of days, or taken as parasangs or Yojanas according to what is for the whole circle. The Indians have operations for that; what we have of them has not settled on one matter but differed. Despite their difference, it is apparent from their state that they deviate from correctness. Just as we preserve for every town its longitude, they preserve for it the Yojana distance from the meridian of the city of "Ujjain", western deserving addition or eastern deserving subtraction. They call it "Desantara", meaning the difference between kingdoms. They multiply it by the motion of the planet in the mean for a day and divide the amount by 4800. The result is what pertains to those Yojanas from the motion of the planet, I mean what must be added to its mean derived for the noon of Ujjain or its night so it transfers from it to the intended town. As for the number they divide by, it is the Yojanas of the circumference of the earth, because the ratio of the distance between the meridians of the two towns to the distance of the circumference of the whole earth is like the ratio of what the planet travels between the two towns...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...in the mean to what it travels in the entire daily rotation around the earth. When the circumference is 4800, the diameter is close to 1527, although according to "Paulisa" it is 1600, and according to "Brahmagupta" 1581 in Yojanas, meaning each of them is eight miles. In the Zij of Arkand it is 1050, but this number in the accounts of Ibn Tariq is for the radius of the earth, and the whole diameter is 2100 assuming one of them is four miles, and its circumference is 6596 and nine twenty-fifths. As for Brahmagupta, he used the number 4800 in the Zij "Khandakhadyaka". As for in his correction, he used the rectified circumference of the earth instead, agreeing with Paulisa. Its rectification is to multiply the Yojanas of the earth's circumference by the sine of the complement of the town's latitude (cosine latitude) and divide the amount by the total sine. The result is the rectified circumference of the earth, which is the Yojanas of the parallel of the town, and perhaps it is called "The Collar of the Parallel". Because of this, it might occur to the imagination that 4800 is the rectified circumference of the earth for the city of "Ujjain", but if we test it, its latitude comes out as sixteen degrees and a quarter degree, and the latitude of Ujjain is not so; it is twenty-four degrees. The author of the Zij "Karanatilaka" went in this rectification to multiplying the diameter of the earth by twelve and dividing the total by the equinoctial shadow in the town. The ratio of the gnomon to this shadow is like the ratio of the radius of the town's parallel to the sine of the town's latitude, not to the total sine. The author of this operation only went to the equivalence of ratio which the Indians call "Vyastatrairasika", meaning positions by reversion (Inverse Rule of Three). Their example in it is that if the wage of a harlot when she is fifteen years old, for example, is ten dirhams, how much will it be when she becomes forty? His method is to multiply the first by the second and divide the result by the third; the fourth comes out, her wage at middle age, three dirhams and a half and a quarter. Likewise, when he found the equinoctial shadow increasing with the increase of latitudes and the diameter of the parallel decreasing, he thought there was a proportionality between this increase and decrease. Therefore, he set the decrease of the diameter of the parallel from the diameter of the earth according to the increase of the equinoctial shadow. Then he extracted the rectified circumference from the rectified diameter. If he extracted what is between the two towns in longitude...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...by observing a lunar eclipse and knowing the difference between its time in the two towns in minutes of days, "Paulisa" multiplied it by the circumference of the earth and divided the amount by sixty, which is the minutes of the daily rotation. The Yojanas between the two towns come out, which is correct, but what comes out is what is on the great circle on which "Lanka" is. "Brahmagupta" does likewise, multiplying by 4800, and its mention has preceded. Their intent and purposes have been known up to this point, whether their work in it is correct or flawed. As for extracting "Desantara" from the latitudes of the two towns, Al-Fazari mentioned it in his Zij. It is to sum the squares of the sines of the latitudes of the two towns and take the square root of the sum, which is the Share (Hissah). Then the difference between these two sines is squared and added to the Share, and the total is multiplied by eight and the result divided by 377. The Grand Distance between them comes out. Then the difference between the two latitudes is multiplied by the Yojanas of the earth's circumference, and the amount is divided by three hundred and sixty. It is known that this is the conversion of what is between the latitudes from the amount of degrees and minutes to the amount of Yojanas. He said: The square of what comes out is subtracted from the square of the Grand Distance, and the square root of the remainder is taken; it will be the Straight Yojanas. It is apparent that it is what is between the meridians of the two towns on the parallel. It is known from it that the Grand is the distance between the two towns. This operation is found in the Indian Zijes agreeing with what we narrated except in one thing, which is that the mentioned Share is the square root of the difference between the squares of the sines of the two latitudes, not their sum. However the work was, it deviates from correctness. We have fulfilled it in several books of ours restricted to this meaning. It is known from them that by the two latitudes alone, neither the distance between the two towns nor the longitude between them is known, unless one of these two is known, so the other is known from it and the two latitudes. An example of this operation was found unattributed to its author: that if the Yojanas between the two kingdoms are multiplied by nine and the amount is divided by the difference between one (and?) the square root of the difference between its square and the square of the difference between the two latitudes, and divided by six, the minutes of days between the two longitudes come out. It is known that in the first he takes the distance and converts it to...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...the revolution of the circle. However, if we reversed it and converted the degrees of the great circle by his operation to Yojanas, 3200 came out, which is less than what we recounted from the Arkand by one hundred Yojanas. But its double, which is 6400, is close to what Ibn Tariq mentioned, falling short of it by only nearly two hundred Yojanas. Let us now say according to what is correct with us regarding the latitudes of some places... It is agreed upon in their Zijes (astronomical tables) that the line connecting "Lanka" and Mount "Meru" bisects the habitation in longitude and passes through the city of "Ujjain", the fortress of "Rohitaka", the river "Yamuna", the plain of "Thanesar", and the cold mountains. From this line, the distances of cities in longitude are taken. I did not find any disagreement among them regarding it except what is in the book of "Aryabhata" of Kashmir, and this is his wording: People say that "Kurukshetra", meaning the plain of Thanesar, is on the line passing from Lanka to Meru through the city of Ujjain, and they attribute it to "Paulisa". He is too excellent for that to be hidden from him, for the times of the eclipse belie that. "Prithusvami" claims that the difference between the two longitudes contains one hundred and twenty Yojanas. This is what Aryabhata said. As for Yaqub bin Tariq, he said in "Tarkib al-Aflak" (Composition of the Spheres): The latitude of Ujjain is four degrees and three-fifths. He did not mention to us whether it is in the North or the South. Then he narrated in it from the Arkand that it is four degrees and two-fifths of a degree. As for us, we found it in the Arkand in an example of what is between Ujjain and Al-Mansura, and he expressed it as Brahmanabad, which is "Bahmanwa". As for the latitude of Ujjain, it is twenty-two degrees and twenty-nine minutes. As for the latitude of Al-Mansura, it is twenty-four degrees and one minute. He mentioned for "Lohaniyya", which is "Lohrani" (?), that the equinoctial shadow is five digits and three-fifths of a digit. It is agreed upon in the Zijes regarding the latitude of Ujjain that it is twenty-four degrees, the sun aligns with it at the summer solstice. "Balabhadra" the commentator mentioned that the latitude of "Kannauj" is 26:35...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...and the latitude of "Thanesar" is 30:12. The scholar Abu Ahmad bin Jilaghtakin measured the latitude of the city of "Karli" (?) and found it 28. The latitude of Thanesar is 27, and between them on latitude is three stages. I do not know the reason for the disagreement. In the Zij "Karanasara": The latitude of "Kashmir" is 34:9, and the equinoctial shadow there is 8:7. I have found the latitude of the fortress of "Lahore" 34:10. From it to the capital of Kashmir is fifty-six miles, half of it rugged and half of it plain. What I was able to observe of latitudes: "Ghazna" 33:35, "Kabul" 33:47, "Kandi" the Ribat of the Emir 33:55, "Dunpur" 34:20, "Lamghan" 34:43, "Purushavar" (Peshawar) 34:44, "Waihind" 34:30, "Jhelum" 33:20, the fortress of "Nandana" 32:0. Between it and "Multan" is close to two hundred miles. "Sialkot" 32:58, "Mandakkakor" (?) 31:50, and "Multan" 29:40. When latitudes are known and distances between them estimated, it is possible to reach the longitude between them according to what is in the books we referred to. We did not go beyond these mentioned places in their land, nor did we come across longitudes and latitudes from their books. Allah is the Helper in achieving goals!

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: XXXII. On the Mention of Duration and Time in Absolute Terms, and the Creation of the World and Its Annihilation. Muhammad bin Zakariya (Al-Razi) narrated from the early Greeks the eternity of five things: The Creator, Glory be to Him, then the Universal Soul, then the Primal Matter (Hyle), then absolute Place, then absolute Time. He built upon that his doctrine which originated from him. He differentiated between Time (Zaman) and Duration (Muddah) by the application of number to one of them and not the other, due to what attaches to number of finiteness, just as philosophers made Time a duration for what has a beginning and an end, and Eternity (Dahr) a duration for what has no beginning and no end. He mentioned that the five in this existing existence are necessary. For what is sensed in it is Matter formed by composition, and it occupies space, so there must be a Place. The variation of states upon it is among the necessities of Time, for some of them are prior and some posterior, and by Time precedence and event, and the older and newer, and simultaneity are known, so there must be it. In existence there are living beings, so there must be a Soul. And among them are rational beings, and the Artifice is of utmost perfection, so there must be the Wise, Knowing, Perfecting, Rectifying Creator to the utmost possible extent, pouring forth the power of intellect for salvation. Among the people of speculation are those who made the meaning of Eternity and Time one, and applied finiteness to the motion that counts it. And among them are those who assigned Eternity (Sarmad) to circular motion, so it adhered to the moving object by it inevitably, and it possessed the honor of permanent subsistence. Then he ascended from the moving object to its mover, and from the moved mover to the First Mover who does not...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...move. This is a very subtle and obscure inquiry. Were it not so, those differing in it would not have become extremely divergent, to the point that some said: There is no Time at all; and some said: It is a substance self-subsistent. Alexander of Aphrodisias says: "Aristotle" demonstrated in the book "Physics" (Al-Sama' al-Tabi'i) that every moving object is moved by a mover. "Galen" says in his face (countering him): He did not explain it, let alone demonstrate it. As for the Indians, their speech in this chapter is scant and unverified. "Varahamihira" said at the beginning of the book "Samhita" when mentioning what has pre-eternity: It has been said in the ancient books that the first thing and the oldest is Darkness, which is not blackness but rather non-existence like the state of a sleeper. Then Allah created this world for the sake of "Brahma" as a dome for him, and made it two parts, upper and lower, and ran the sun and moon in it. "Kapila" said: Allah and the world with Him, with its substances and bodies, have always existed, but He is a cause for the world and is superior by His subtlety over its density. "Kumbhaka" (?) said: The Eternal is "Mahabhuta", meaning the sum of the five elements. Others said pre-eternity belongs to Time. Some said to Nature. Others claimed that the Governor is "Karma", meaning Action. In the book "Vishnu Dharma", "Vajra" said to Markandeya: Clarify the times for me. He answered him that Duration is "Atman Purusha", meaning his spirit, and Purusha is the Owner of the Whole. Then he began clarifying for him the partial times and their lords as we presented each one in its chapter. The Indians divided Duration into two times: a movement that estimated Time, and a rest that could be estimated by imagination parallel to the First Moving Estimator. The Eternity of the Creator became for them estimated but not counted due to the negation of finiteness from it, although imagining an estimated uncounted thing is very difficult and far-fetched. We will mention from their sayings in this chapter according to our knowledge what suffices. As for what circulates among them of the mention of Creation, it is common (popular/vulgar), because we have recounted their opinion on the eternity of Matter. So they do not mean by creation origination from nothing, but they mean by it the artifice in the clay (matter) and the bringing about of compositions in it, forms, and managements leading to intended purposes and goals in it. Therefore, they attribute creation to angels and Jinn, even humans, either fulfilling the right of a benefactor or out of satisfaction...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...due to envy and competition, like their saying: "Visvamitra" the Rishi created buffaloes so people could expand with their benefits. This is like the saying of "Plato" in "Timaeus": The gods who undertook the creation of man, when their father commanded them, took a non-mortal soul and made it a beginning, then turned a mortal body over it. Here is a duration our companions call "Years of the World" according to the doctrine of the Indians. It is thought from it that Creation and Annihilation are at its two ends by way of origination (from nothing). The subject of the people is not that, but rather it is the Day of "Brahma", followed by a Night like it for him, because Brahma is entrusted with bringing into being (growth). Growing is a movement in the growing thing from another, and its most apparent causes are the upper movers, I mean the planets. They will not be influential in what is beneath them with moderate influences except with their movement and the changing of their positions in every direction. That is restricted to the Day of Brahma because the planets according to them are traveling in it and their spheres rotating according to the system destined for them, and growth is therefore continuous on the face of the earth. In the Night of Brahma, the spheres rest from their movements, and all planets settle in one place with their apogees and nodes. The earthly conditions therefore become a single state that does not vary. So growth ceases by the rest of the Grower and the suspension of action and passivity. The elements rest from transformations and mixtures, their rest now in... and they prepare by their purity for the resumed existences in the future Day. The matter revolves on that for the duration of the life of "Brahma" as we will recount in its place. So Creation and its Annihilation according to them occur from this perspective on the face of the earth without obtaining by creation in existents the existence of clay (matter) that was not, nor at annihilation the non-existence of clay that was. How could they have origination when they have spoken of the eternity...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...of Matter. They expressed for their commoners the two mentioned durations as the Waking of Brahma and his Sleeping. Their phrasing is not denounced for applying to what has a beginning and an end in its duration. The sum of Brahma's life, with the alternation of movement and rest in the world during it, counts for existence, not non-existence, due to the presence of clay in it, indeed the Form also with it. Brahma's entire life is a Day not followed by (Night? or not elevated?), so when he dies, compounds dissolve in his Night, and what Nature was entrusted to preserve is suspended due to its vanishing. That is the rest of "Purusha" and his vehicles. Their commoners followed the Night of Purusha with the Night of Brahma in description. And because Purusha is the name of Man, they attached sleep and waking to him, and established for annihilation from his sleep a snoring by which every connected thing breaks, and sweat of the forehead in which every standing thing drowns, and such things that minds reject and ears spit out. Therefore, their elite did not share with them in it, knowing the reality of sleep and that the body composed of opposing humors needs it for rest and the return of every needy thing to its natural place, like its need due to constant dissolution for eating to restore what dissolved, and due to its mortality for intercourse to perpetuate the species by replacement, and other evils we are compelled to, which simple substances dispense with, and He who is above them, there is nothing like unto Him. They also claimed regarding Annihilation and the corruption of the world that it is by the gathering of the twelve suns that alternate now in the months, and their insistence on the earth with burning and calcination, drying up moistures and desiccation. Then the gathering of the four types of rains that alternate now in the seasons until the calcined is attracted by the driving to itself and dissolves by it. Then the disappearance of light and the dominance of darkness and non-existence until it becomes dust and scatters. In "Matsya Purana": The fire burning the world came out of the water and inhabited Mount "Mahisha" (?) in "Kusa Dvipa" until that time and was named after that mountain. In "Vishnu Purana": That "Mahar Loka" is above the Pole and that the duration of staying in it is a "Kalpa", because if the three Lokas burn, the heat and smoke harm those in it, so they rise and move to "Jana Loka", and in it are the sons of Brahma preceding...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...creation, and they are "Sanaka, Sananda, Sanatana, Asuri, Kapila, Vodhu, and Panchasikha". It is known from the content of these stories that this annihilation is at the end of a Kalpa. Abu Ma'shar's opinion on the Flood at the conjunction of planets is adapted from them, because this configuration for them exists at the end of every "Chaturyuga" and at the beginning of every "Kaliyuga", even if it is not at the utmost perfection. Thus, there is no doubt that the Flood is also not for complete extermination and destruction. Whenever we delve deeper into the chapters, these meanings increase in openness and these names and terms in clarity and exposition. Al-Iranshahri narrated from the Shamaniyya (Buddhists) what resembles these myths: That in the directions of Mount "Meru" are four worlds alternated by habitation and ruin. Its ruin is by the dominance of fire over it upon the rising of a sun after a sun until the completion of seven; the water of springs dries up and the blazing fire is enabled to enter it. Its habitation is by its exit from it to another. When the powers of the wind exit in it and carry the clouds and rain on it until it becomes a sea, shells are generated from its foam, to which spirits attach, and humans come from them when the water recedes. Some of them believe that a human from the other world falls into that world and becomes lonely in it from his solitude, and a mate is formed for him from his thought, and offspring begin from them.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: XXXIII. On the Types of the Day, Its Daytime and Its Night. The "Day" in custom and habit among us, the Indians, and others is the duration between the sun's leaving of a great half-circle (meridian) until its return by the motion of the whole to that very half of it. The Day is divided for eyesight into "Daytime", which is the duration of the sun being visible to the people of an assumed dwelling on earth, and into "Night", which is the duration of its being absent from them. Visibility and absence are only relative to the horizon. It is known that the horizon of the Equator, which the Indians call "The Kingdom that has no latitude", cuts the parallels parallel to the Equator into two halves; therefore, daytime and night are always equal in it. And that the horizons which intersect the parallels without passing through their pole divide the smaller ones into two unequal parts, so the daytime differs for that reason from its night in their dwellings, except at the times of the two Equinoxes. For they encompass all the earth except "Meru" and "Vadavamukha" in the equality of daytime in it with its night, so that its dwellings then share with the dwellings of the Equator, then differ from them in other times. The beginning of the daytime is the rising of the sun from the horizon, and the beginning of the night is its setting in it. The daytime according to the Indians precedes its night, which is what follows it. For this reason, they called it "Savana", meaning a rising day, and also called it "Manushya Ahoratra", meaning the day of humans, because their majority know no other. When this day is known, we made it a basis for what is other than it and a standard in estimating others. We said: That which follows the day of humans is "Pitrya Ahoratra", meaning the day of the ancient Fathers (Ancestors), due to their belief regarding their spirits that they are in the sphere of the moon. This is a day whose...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...daytime and night are obtained by light and darkness, not by visibility and absence which are according to horizons. That is that if the light of the moon is in its upper parts towards them, that is daytime for them, and if the light is in its lower parts, it is night for them. It is apparent that their noon is the time of Conjunction (New Moon) and their midnight is the Opposition (Full Moon). Their day then is the entire lunar month. The beginning of the daytime in it is the halving of light in its body increasing, and the beginning of the night is the halving of light in its body decreasing. That is by way of necessity regarding the two halves of daytime and night, and by way of analogy, for the halving of light in the moon is similar to the rising of half the sun's disk from the horizon and the setting of half of it in it. So the daytime of the Fathers then is from the last quarter in the month to the first quarter in the month that follows it, and their night is from the first quarter to the second quarter (last quarter?) in the single month itself, and their sum is their day. Thus the author of "Vishnu Dharma" mentioned it in summary, detail, and definition. Then he returned with lack of verification and made the daytime of the Fathers the dark half of the month, which is from Opposition to Conjunction, and the other white half their night. The correct view in the subject is what preceded. Even in their subject is giving charity to the Fathers on the day of Conjunction, and they stated that noon is the time of lunch, and for that reason charity reaches them at the time of their nutrition. Following the day of the Fathers is "Daiva Ahoratra", which is the day of the Angels (Gods). It is known that the horizon of the extreme latitudes, which is ninety degrees when the Pole is at the zenith, is the Equator approximately because it is slightly lower than the sensible horizon for the place of Mount "Meru" on earth. As for its smallness and what is between it and its foot, it is possible that it is the Equator itself and the sensible horizon is lower than it. It is apparent that the Zodiac belt is halved by its intersection with the Equator, so half of it falls above the horizon and half below it. As long as the sun is in the signs of northern declination, it rotates a mill-like rotation because the daily paths are parallel to the horizon like almucantars. As for the one under the North Pole, its visible part is above the horizon, and therefore it is daytime for him. As for the one under the South Pole, it is hidden below the horizon...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...and therefore it is night for him. When the sun moves to the southern signs, it rotates mill-like below the horizon, so it is night for the one under the North Pole and daytime for the one under the South Pole. Under both Poles are the dwellings of "Daivika", meaning the spiritual beings, so the day was attributed to them. "Aryabhata" of Kashmir said: The "Devas" see half the solar year and the "Danavas" see its other half, and the "Pitris" see half the lunar month and humans see the other half. Thus the cycle of the sun in the sphere of the Zodiac comprised a daytime and a night for each of the Devas and Danavas, and their sum is a day. So our year then is a day of the "Deva". Its daytime is not equal to its night because the sun slows down in the northern half of the declination around its apogee, so the daytime is more abundant in magnitude. The difference between the sensible horizon and the true horizon does not compensate for it, for it is imperceptible in the sphere of the sun. Also, the inhabitants of that place according to them are elevated above the face of the earth because they are in Mount "Meru". The believer in this opinion believes regarding the height of this mountain what is mentioned in its place. That height necessitates for the horizon an amount of depression by which the increase of daytime over night is doubled. Were it not a religious report and disagreed upon besides, we would have busied ourselves with extracting that amount in which there is no benefit. Among the common Indians are those who heard the mention of daytime for this day in the North and night in the South, along with their use of the two divisions of the year by the two halves of the Zodiac belt: the ascending from the winter solstice attributed to the North, and the descending from the summer solstice attributed to the South. So they made the daytime of this day in the ascending half and its night in the descending half and immortalized it in books. Like the author of "Vishnu Dharma", for he said: The half whose beginning is Capricorn is the daytime of the "Asuras", who are the "Danavas", and the beginning of their night is the sign of Cancer, after saying: The half which is from the beginning of Aries is the daytime of the "Devas". He did not notice because nothing occurs at the Poles except the exchange. However, the verification of the one knowing the story, learned in astronomy, is far from this issue. Following is the day "Divya Brahma Ahoratra", which is the day of Brahma...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...it is not taken from light and darkness nor from appearance and concealment, but rather it is from the requirement of nature in created beings by movement and rest in daytime and night. The magnitude of Brahma's day in our years is 8,640,000,000. Half of it is daytime in which the Ether with what is in it is moving, the earth is inhabited, and the fluctuations of generation and corruption on its face are continuous. Half of it is night in which the matter is contrary to what is in the daytime, and the earth is unchanging due to the stillness of the changers and the suspension of the movers, like the rest of the created being at night and in winter and its gathering prepared for new existence in the daytime and in summer. Each of Brahma's daytime and his night is a "Kalpa", which our companions call "Years of Sindhind". After this day is "Purusha Ahoratra", meaning the day of the Universal Soul, and it is called "Mahakalpa", meaning the Greatest Kalpa. As for them, they do not establish it except as an estimation of duration standing in place of time without detailing it into daytime or night. It is imagined from it that its daytime is the duration of the soul's attachment to matter, and its night is the duration of their separation and the rest of the spirits, and that the state necessitating attachment and connection for them returns at the completion of this day. In the book "Vishnu Dharma": The life of "Brahma" is the daytime of "Purusha" and the like of it is his night. They have agreed on the life of "Brahma" as one hundred years of his years. The composition of years according to them is from multiples of three hundred and sixty. The magnitude of Brahma's day has preceded; so his year in our years is 3,110,400,000,000, and one hundred years for him in our years is like that with the addition of two zeros so its total is ten zeros (digits?). That is the daytime of "Purusha", and his day is double that, which is 6,220,800,000,000,000. In "Paulisa Siddhanta": The life of Brahma is the daytime of Purusha, but he mentioned that the daytime of Purusha is "Parardha Kalpa". They also said: Parardha Kalpa is the daytime of "Ka" (Kha?), meaning the Point, they meant by it the First Cause high above all existents. That is a "Kalpa" placed in the eighteenth order of the calculation orders, for this is...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...its name and its interpretation is half of the heaven. So double what is in it is all the heaven, and it is the whole Day. The day of Ka then is 864 after twenty-four zeros to the right to be in our years. It is more worthy to be for timing rather than composition of number because it is inevitably taken from composition and analysis, and bringing into existence and annihilation.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: XXXIV. On What Falls Short of the Day of Its Diminishing Parts. These parts, because they are arbitrary in refining them, differ among them endlessly. You hardly study them from two books or hear them from two people in one state. Among them is that the day is divided into sixty minutes, each called "Ghati". It is mentioned in the book "Sarodhaya" by Utpala the Kashmiri: That if a piece of wood is hollowed out cylindrically, the diameter of its round hollow being twelve fingers and its height six fingers, holding three Manas of water; if a hole is pierced in its bottom accommodating six hairs twisted from the hair of a young woman, not an old woman nor a child, the three Manas of water exit from it in the duration of one "Ghati". Then every minute of the day is divided into sixty seconds, each called "Cashaka" or "Cakaka" (Vighati/Pala), and also called "Vigahatika". Each of these seconds is divided into six parts, each called "Prana", meaning breath. In the mentioned book "Sarodhaya" regarding its definition: It is the breath of a sleeper who has slept in a moderate state, neither sick, nor retaining urine, nor hungry, nor full, nor occupied in thought with worry or fear. That is because psychological symptoms from desire or fear and physical ones from emptiness or fullness or a symptom corrupting the praised temperament change the breath of the sleeper. Whether the magnitude of Prana is taken as we mentioned, or taken in every Ghati three hundred...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...and sixty, or taken in every degree of the sphere sixty. Up to this point they do not differ in meaning even if they differ in names. For "Brahmagupta" called the seconds which are Cashaka "Vinadi", and "Aryabhata" of Kashmir called them likewise, but he also called the minutes of the day "Vinadi". Both did not descend below Prana which corresponds to the minutes of the sphere. For "Paulisa" says: The minutes of the sphere which are 21600 are similar to the breaths of humans which are average at the times of the two Equinoxes and in the state of health. So a minute of the sphere rotates and a duration of a breath of time passes. Some of them mediated between minutes and seconds an amount they called "Kshana", which is a quarter of a minute. They made each one of it fifteen parts, calling each "Kala", which is one-sixteenth of the minute which is "Casha", except that he named it Kala. At the bottom of this division are three names they did not differ in ordering. The highest is "Nimesha", which is the duration of the opening of the eye naturally between two blinks. The middle is "Lava". The lowest is "Truti", which is the snapping of the index finger from the inside of the thumb when they admire something and approve of it. As for the ratio between them, it varies greatly, because many of them claim that every two Truti is a Lava and every two Lava is a Nimesha. Then regarding the number of Nimesha which we make a species for what is above it, they differ. Some make it fifteen, some make it thirty, and some make the numbers of these three names each eight. Thus it is in "Sarodhaya", and to it went "Sammya" (?), who is one of their verifying astrologers. He increased in precision claiming that below Truti is another name which is "Anu", and every eight of it is one Truti. As for above Nimesha, it is "Kashta" and "Kala". As for Kala, we have said: Some of them named Casha by it and made it thirty Kashta, and every Kashta fifteen Nimesha, and every Nimesha two Lava, and every Lava two Truti. Some of them...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...made "Kala" one part out of sixteen of the minute of the day, and every one of it thirty "Kashta", and every Kashta thirty "Nimesha" and what is below it as we said. Some made every "Casha" six Nimesha and every Nimesha three "Lava", and his speech ended. In "Vayu Purana": Every "Muhurta" is thirty "Kala", and every Kala thirty Kashta, and every Kashta fifteen Nimesha; and he did not descend to what is below it. There is no way to verify this meaning. The best is to take in it what "Utpala" and "Sammya" went to regarding the division of what is below "Prana" by eights. So in every Prana there are eight Nimesha, in every Nimesha eight Lava, in every Lava eight "Truti", and in every Truti eight "Anu", as in this table: The day is also divided a common division into eight "Prahara", meaning turns in guarding.
