In some of their towns are water clocks (clepsydras) adjusted to the Ghati by which the times of the eight turns are monitored. When a turn passes and its Ghatis are seven and a half, they beat the drum or blow the twisted conch which...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...they call "Sankha" and in Persian "Spid Muhra". I saw that in the town of "Purushavar" (Peshawar). For them and those in charge of them are times and rations. The day is also divided into thirty Muhurtas, and their matter is confusing. Sometimes it is thought that they are equal in estimation when they relate them to the Ghati and say: Every two Ghatis is a "Muhurta", or to the turns and say: Every "turn" is three Muhurtas and three quarters. By that, their matter runs the course of equal hours (constant hours). But the number of these hours differs in the daytime of every parallel with declination and its night. Therefore, it is thought of Muhurta that its magnitude in daytime is different from its magnitude at night. Then if they enumerate their lords, the thought is reversed, for they make them fifteen in each of the daytime and night. By that, their matter runs the course of crooked temporal hours (seasonal hours). This is confirmed by an operation of theirs in knowing the Muhurta from the fingers of the person's shadow at the time, if the fingers of the shadow of noon are subtracted from it and the remainder is entered into the middle table which we copied from their poetry. Indeed, the commentator of "Paulisa Siddhanta" declares this last opinion and denounces whoever generalizes the statement on the magnitude of "Muhurta": That it is two Ghatis, claiming that the number of "Ghatis" of the daytime differs in the year while the number of Muhurtas does not differ. Even though he belies himself in explaining the magnitude of Muhurta, that he only made it seven hundred and twenty Pranas because breath is composed of "Apana" which is inhaling air and "Prana" which is sending it out. They are also called "Niswasa" and "Ucchwasa". But if one of them is mentioned, it implies the other like nights in the mention of days if mentioned. So it is...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...three hundred and sixty inhalations and the like exhalations. Therefore, he limited the magnitude of Ghati to one of the two types, making it three hundred and sixty breaths absolutely. When Muhurta is estimated by breaths, it is on the standards of Ghati and equal hours. But he refuses that and disputes his opponents who claim that Muhurta is only fifteen for the daytime if the one counting them is on the Equator or at the times of the two Equinoxes not on the Equator, by (arguing that) "Abhijit" falls on noon and the beginning of the other half; if the number of Muhurtas in the daytime were different, their number for the mentioned name for noon would be different. "Vyasa" said regarding the birth of "Yudhishthira": That it was in the white half (waxing moon), at noon, in the eighth Muhurta. If the opponent thinks from that that it was the day of the Equinox, "Markandeya" said regarding it: That it was at the fullness of the full moon of the month "Jyaishtha", and this is far from the time of the Equinox. Vyasa also said regarding the birth of "Basudeva" (Krishna) that it was in "Abhijit" at the passing of the youth of the night and its middle on the eighth of the black half (waning moon) of the month "Bhadrapada". That is also far from the time of the Equinox. "Vasistha" said: In Abhijit, "Basudeva" killed "Shishupala", the son of the sister of "Kamsa". They claimed in his story that he was born with four hands, and his mother was called from above "His killer is the one who, if he touches him, his extra hands fall off." So they began placing him in the lap of everyone who attended. When Basudeva touched him, his hands fell off as was said. The aunt said to him: You are undoubtedly the killer of my son. Basudeva, while among the boys, said: I will not do that unless he deserves it by a crime he intends, and I will not punish him until he exceeds ten sins. After a time, "Yudhishthira" was performing a fire sacrifice, and every notable attended. He consulted "Vyasa" on the ranking of the attendees and who the foremost among them deserved of offering water and flowers in a basin to him. He advised putting Basudeva forward. His cousin was present, so he started quarreling and that he was more entitled to honor than Basudeva. He exceeded boasting to...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...attacking Basudeva's father. He called people to witness his bad manners and left him until the matter dragged on and the number exceeded ten. Then he took the basin and threw it at him in the manner of their throwing the Chakra weapon, and severed his head. This is the story of the mentioned. The one arguing with what we described is not successful in his argument unless he verifies that Abhijit falls on noon and also falls on the middle of the eighth "Muhurta" equally. For if he does not do so, Muhurta has a width in duration, and with the little difference of days and nights in the land of India, it is possible that noon in times far from the Equinoxes is on one side of the eighth "Muhurta" and is within it. Evidence of the poor acquisition of the arguer is that he narrated among his arguments from "Garga" his saying: That the shadow disappears in "Abhijit" of the Equator line, while that does not happen in it except on the two days of the Equinoxes only; indeed, even if it were so always, what does he have in what he is in of that. As for the lords of Muhurtas, they are in this table: The Indians do not use hours except their astrologers in the lords of the hours which is the cause of the lords of the days. The lord of the day is the lord of the night also; they do not separate the daytime from it nor mention the night at all. Then they arrange the lords in the equal hours. The name of the hour is "Hora", so this name opens the usage of crooked hours. That is that the halves of the signs which we know as Nim-Bahra, they also call Hora. That was because the ascendants of each of the daytime and night are six signs always. If the hour is marked by the name of half the sign, the hours in each of the daytime and night are twelve. So they are then in the lords of hours crooked as used in our lands and marked on astrolabes for them. This is confirmed by the saying of "Vijayanandi" in "Karanatilaka", meaning the Blaze of Zijes, when he mentioned knowing the lord of the year and month: As for "Horapati", meaning the lord of the hour, make what rose since the morning to the degree of the ascendant minutes all of it and divide it by nine hundred. What comes out is a count from the lord of the day on...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...the order of the spheres to the bottom, so you end at the lord of the hour. He should have said: So what comes out, add one to it, then count from the lord of the day. If he said: Take what rose of the times (degrees), the matter would have reverted to equal hours. Also, the crooked hours have names among them which we have placed in this table, and we think they are from "Sarodhaya": It was mentioned in the book "Vishnu Dharma" among the Nagas, which are snakes, a snake called "Naga Kulika". It has known inauspicious divisions in the hours of the planets; what is eaten in them harms...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...and does not benefit. Those treating themselves in them with poisons do not succeed but die and perish. The charm of the charmer does not benefit in them against biting, for charms are by the mention of "Garuda", and in those ill-omened times, the stork itself does not benefit, let alone its mention. These are those times, assuming the hour is divided into one hundred and fifty parts:

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
35 - On the Varieties of Months and Years
The "Natural Month" is from conjunction to conjunction. It became natural only due to the similarity of its conditions to the conditions of natural things, which are not devoid of a beginning for them as if from non-existence, and of increase and rise in origination and growth, and something like pausing at the peak, then a decline following it towards decay and extinction, and a decrease in origination and growth until it returns to that non-existence. Likewise, the light of the moon in its body is on this path when it appears from the waning crescent (Mahaq) as a crescent, then a moon, then a full moon, and retreats from it likewise to the concealment (Sarar) which is like non-existence relative to sensation. As for the stay in the waning crescent, it is known to all. As for in fullness, it might be confusing to some of the elite, until when the smallness of the moon's body and the greatness of the sun are known, it is known that the illuminated piece of it exceeds the dark one, and that is what necessitates a duration of stay at fullness as a full moon by necessity. Also, from the perspective of its influence on moistures and the apparent affection of them by it so that the matters of increase in tide and ebb and decrease in them revolve with it, that is not hidden from the inhabitants of the coasts and passengers of the sea. Just as its influence on the humors of the sick and the turning of their crises with it is not hidden from physicians. And on the naturalists, the attachment of the affairs of animals and plants to it. And on the experimentalists, its effect on marrows, brains, eggs, and the dregs of wine in its jars and vats, and what it excites in the heads of sleepers in its moonlight, and what it brings to linen clothes placed in its light. And on the farmers, what it shows in cucumber fields, melon fields, and cotton fields and the likes of that, until they go beyond them to knowing the times of sowing...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...and planting and grafting and pollination and reproduction and things similar to that. And on the astrologers from the events of the atmosphere by its aspects in its movements. This is the month, and twelve «1» of it is a year by convention called "Lunar". As for the "Natural Year", it is the duration of the return of the sun in the zodiacal sphere, because it includes «2» the beings of tillage and offspring circulating in the four seasons. By it, the rays of the sun return from the spheres «3» and the shadows of gnomons exactly to their magnitudes, positions, and directions in which or from which they take. This is the year, and it is called "Solar" for the sake of the Lunar. Just as the lunar month was half a sixth of its year, likewise the part of twelve of the sun's year is a month for it by convention if the taking is from its mean motion. If it is from its true motion, its month is the duration of its being in a Sign. These are the two famous months and years. The Indians call the Conjunction "Amavasya" and the Opposition "Purnima" and the two Quartiles "Atuh" [?]. Some of them use in the lunar year its lunar months and days. Some of them use the solar months by the heads of the Signs, and the transition in them is called "Sankranti". That is by way of approximation, because if it continued with them, they would have used the year of the sun itself and its months, and dispensed by that with intercalating the year with months. Of the users of the moon's months, some of them begin them with the Conjunction, and it is the approved school. Some of them begin them with the Opposition. I heard that "Varahamihira" does that, but I have not verified it from his books yet. That is forbidden, and it seems ancient, for in the "Veda": Indeed people say the full moon is complete and the month is complete by its completion. That is from their ignorance of me and my interpretation, for the Creator of the world began it from the white half, not the black. It may be permissible that this narrated is from the saying of people. Then «4» the month, from the perspective that the number after Conjunction begins with the name "Pratipada" from the lunar days (Tithis), is like its beginning with it after Opposition. Every...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...two days whose distances from them are one, their name is also one. In them, light and darkness in the body of the moon are equal, and the hours of rising in one of them and setting in the other are equal. They have a calculation for it, which is to multiply the past lunar days of the month if they are less than fifteen, or their excess over fifteen if they are more than it, by the number of "Ghatis" of that night, and add two to the product always, and divide the sum by fifteen. So Ghatis and what follows them come out for what is between the beginning of the night and the setting of the moon in the white days or between its rising in the black days. This is because the difference of this duration in nights is by two degrees (minutes?), and the magnitudes of nights hover around thirty degrees (minutes?). If thirty degrees «1» is taken for each day and the product is divided by its half, two degrees come out for each one. Except that he adjusted for the difference of nights, so he multiplied by the magnitude of the night. It would have been more precise to multiply by half the sum of this night and the first of the month. There is no benefit in adding the two degrees, for it is the station of the sighting of the crescent. If the month were taken from it, it would have moved by them to the Conjunction. Because months are composed of days, the types of months are according to the types of their days. Each one of them is thirty «2». As for by the civil days (Savana), which are the standard, the lunar month according to the cycles of the two luminaries in a "Kalpa" with them is twenty-nine days and 189,005 of 356,222 of a day. It is what results from dividing the days of a Kalpa by the months of the moon in it. The months of the moon in it are the difference between the cycles of the two luminaries in it, and that is 53,433,300,000. As for the month by the days of the moon (Tithis), it is thirty because this is the number assigned for the month just as the number assigned for the year is three hundred and sixty. The solar month by its days is thirty, and by civil days is thirty days and 1,362,987 of 3,110,400. The month of the Fathers (Pitris) is thirty months of our months, and its civil days are 885 and 163,410 of 178,111. The month of the Angels (Devas) is thirty years, and its civil days are 10,957 and 241 of 320. The month of "Brahm" is sixty Kalpas, and its civil days are...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...94,674,987,000,000. The month of "Purusha" is two thousand thousand and one hundred and sixty thousand "Kalpas", and that in civil days after nine zeros on the right is 3,408,299,532. The civil days of the month of "Ka" [Prajpati?] after twenty-three zeros on the right is 94,674,987. If we multiply each one of these months by twelve, the days of its year gather. As for the lunar year, it obtains in civil days three hundred and fifty-four days and 65,364 of 178,111. As for the solar year, its days obtain three hundred and sixty-five days and 827 «1» of 3,200. As for the year of the Fathers, it is three hundred and sixty lunar months, and its civil days are 10,631 and 1,699 of 178,111. As for the year of the Angels, it is of our years three hundred and sixty, and its civil days are 131,493 and 3 «2» of 80. As for the year of "Brahm", it is seven hundred and twenty Kalpas, and its civil days after six zeros on the right is 1,136,099,844. As for the year of "Purusha", it is 25,920,000 Kalpas, and its civil days after nine zeros is 40,899,594,384. As for the year of Ka, its civil days after twenty-three zeros is 1,136,099,844. Although it was mentioned in their books that nothing is composed of the day of Purusha because He is the First and the Last who has no first for His primality nor last for His eternity. The rest of the days from which months and years are composed belong to those below Him of those limited in duration. This from them is by way of transcendence «3» for what is above the Soul, for they do not distinguish between Him and it except in order. They mention Him with the likeness of the sayings of the Sufis that He «4» is not the first and there is not «4» other than Him. However, the duration, if you estimate it from the existing 'now' to each one of its two sides, meaning the lost past and the potential future, the imagination does not refuse it. If some of it bears estimation by the day, the imagination is not prevented in its multiples from the attribute of the month and the year. Their purpose is only that we attribute their years to...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...ages for them beginning with being and ending with corruption and death. The Creator, Glory be to Him, is exalted above both, and likewise the simple substances. Therefore, we restrict ourselves to His day and do not exceed it. Then we say: That which is not necessary, difference and conventional branching has a path to it, so sayings multiply in it. Among them is what happens to have a system and a law, and among them is what does not have that. Of that is speech which fell to me, and I have forgotten its source. He said: Indeed thirty «1» -three thousand years of the years of people become a year for the Great Bear (Banat Na'sh), and thirty «2» -six thousand years of the years of people become a year for Brahm, and ninety «3» -nine thousand years of the years of people become a year for the Pole. As for the year of "Brahm", "Basdiv" [Vasudeva] said to Arjun «4» in the battle between the ranks that the day of Brahm is two Kalpas. In "Brahma Siddhanta", a narration from "Vyasa son of Parashara" and from the book "Smriti": That "Kalpa" is a day for Daivika, who is Brahm, and the like of it is a night for him. So then this saying is apparently invalid. The thirty-six thousand years is only the duration of the rotation of the fixed stars in the zodiacal sphere one rotation if their traversing is every degree in a hundred years. The Great Bear is of them, except that they, from the perspective of reports, distinguish it from them and assign to it a distance from the earth different from their distance; therefore it is specialized with states other than their states. If he meant by its year a rotation for it, how fast it is and how false to existence. The Pole does not have a rotation to make a year for it. I only imagine from that that its sayer was very far from the sciences and leading in the group of the foolish (Nuka), and that he attributed these years to those he mentioned by way of magnification. So he had to increase the number to be more effective in aggrandizement.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
36 - On the Four Measures called "Mana"
"Mana" and "Pramana" is the measure. These four are those mentioned by Ya'qub bin Tariq in "The Composition of the Spheres" without verifying them and with misspelling «1» of their names, if that did not occur in the copies. They are "Saura Mana", meaning the Solar measure, "Savana Mana", meaning the Civil (Rising), "Chandra «2» Mana", meaning the Lunar, and "Nakshatra Mana", meaning the Mansion (Sidereal). From each one of them is a day which is it separately. If measured to another, its magnitude differs. The number three hundred and sixty encompasses them. The Civil days are a basis for considering others by them and estimating them. As for Saura Mana, it has become known that the solar year in civil days is three hundred and sixty-five days and 827 «3» of 3,200. If it is divided by three hundred and sixty or multiplied by ten seconds «4» (base 60?), one civil day and 5,609 of 384,000 «5» comes out, which is the magnitude of the solar day. In the book "Vishnu Dharma", it is the traversing of the sun of its Bhukti (daily motion). As for "Savana Mana", it is the one placed as one day to measure others by it. As for "Chandra «6» Mana", the lunar day...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...is called "Tithi". If its year is divided by three hundred and sixty or its month by thirty, the magnitude of the lunar day comes out as 10,519,443 «1» of 10,686,660 «1» of a civil day. In the book Vishnu Dharma: It is the magnitude in which the moon is seen if it distances from the sun. As for "Nakshatra Mana", it is the duration of the moon traversing its twenty-seven mansions, and it is twenty-seven days and 11,259 of 35,002, meaning the quotient of the days of "Kalpa" by the rotations of the moon in it. If this duration is divided by twenty-seven, the duration of cutting one mansion comes out as one civil day and 417 of 35,002. If that duration is multiplied twelve times as was done with the month of the moon, three hundred and twenty-seven days and 15,051 of 17,501 in civil days result from that. If the duration of the moon cutting its mansions is divided by thirty, 318,771 of 350,020 of a civil day comes out. That is the magnitude of the Mansion day, although the author of Vishnu Dharma claimed that the Nakshatra month is twenty-seven days and the months of the other Manas are thirty days. If a year is composed from it, it would be three hundred and twenty-seven days and 15,051 of 17,501. As for "Saura Mana", it is used in the years by which "Kalpa" and the four Yugas in "Chaturyuga" are estimated, and in the years of nativities, and in the two equinoxes and two solstices, and in the sixths of the year, and in the difference between day and night in the day. For all these things are estimated by solar years, months, and days. As for "Chandra «2» Mana", it is used in the eleven Karanas «3» and in knowing the intercalary month and what gathers of the days of decrease (Una Ratra), and in Conjunction and Opposition for the two eclipses. For all these are by lunar years, months, and days called "Tithi". As for "Savana Mana", upon it "Vara", which is the days of the week, and "Ahargana", meaning the days of dates (chronology), and the days of planting and fasting and "Sutaka", which are the days of puerperium of women and the impurity of the houses of the dead and their vessels, and "Chikitsa", which is in medicine what is prescribed...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...for medicines of months and years, and "Prayashchitta", which are the days of expiations which the Brahmins impose on one burdened with sin, times he pays in fasting and anointing with ghee and dung, are calculated. For all these are by civil years, months, and days. Nothing runs on the fourth Mansion measure, and it is included in the Lunar. Every magnitude of time which a group has agreed upon naming a day is from the whole of the Manas. The mention of some of them has preceded, except that the four absolutely are what we restricted this chapter to.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
37 - On the Parts of the Month and Year
Because the year is a return in the zodiacal sphere, it is divided by its divisions. The zodiacal sphere is divided into two halves at the points of the two solstices. The year is also divided opposite them into two parts, each one called "Ayana" «1». When the sun separates from the point of the winter solstice, it starts advancing towards the North Pole. Therefore, this part of the year, which is close to half of it, is attributed to the North, so it was said "Uttarayana". It includes the duration of the sun cutting six signs, the first of which is Capricorn. Therefore, it was said for this half of the zodiacal sphere "Makara-adi", meaning that whose beginning is Capricorn. When the sun separates from the point of the summer solstice, it starts advancing towards the South Pole. Therefore, the other half of the year was attributed to the South, so it was said "Dakshinayana". It includes the duration of the sun cutting six signs, the first of which is Cancer. Therefore, it was said for it "Karkata-adi", meaning that whose beginning is Cancer. The common people only used these two halves due to the appearance of the matter of the solstices to them visibly. The zodiacal sphere is also divided into two halves according to the direction of declination from the equator, a more specific division, meaning that the common people do not know it with their first knowledge because this one is based on measurement and theory. Each one of its two halves is called "Kula" [Gola]. The one whose declination is northern is called "Uttara Kula" [Uttara Gola] and is also called "Mesha-adi", meaning that whose beginning is Aries. And that...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...whose declination is southern is called "Dakshina Kula" [Dakshina Gola] and is also called "Tula-adi", meaning that whose beginning is Libra. The zodiacal sphere divided by both divisions into quarters called the durations of the sun cutting them "Seasons of the Year", which are Spring, Summer, Autumn, and Winter. Their Signs opposite them are attributed to them. However, the Indians went in the partitioning of the year to the sixth-division instead of the quarter-division and named its sixths "Ritu". Each one of Ritu includes two solar months, which are the duration of the sun being in two consecutive Signs. Their names and lords are established in this table according to the common opinion. I heard that in the borders of the land of "Somnath" they use thirds of the year, each one four months. The first of them is "Varshakala" and its beginning is from the month of "Ashadha". The second is "Sitakala", meaning Winter. The third is "Ushnakala", meaning Summer: «1» I think that they divided the zodiacal sphere by the opening of the hexagon (radius/60 degrees), which is half the diameter from the two points of the solstices, so they used its sixths. If it is so, we have divided it from the points of the solstices once and from the points of the equinoxes another time and used the halves of the sixths in...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
...its quarters. As for the months, they are parted by the halves which are between the Conjunctions and Oppositions. For the halves of the months are lords mentioned in the book "Vishnu Dharma" which we have placed in this table:
[Table]

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
38 - On what is composed from the Day to the completion of the life of "Brahm"
The Day (daytime) is called "Divasa" and eloquently "Diva". The Night is "Ratri". The Day which combines them is "Ahoratra". The Month is called "Masa", and its half is "Paksha". The first of the two halves is described by whiteness, so it is said "Shukla Paksha" because the beginnings of its nights are moonlit in the times when people do not sleep, and the light of the moon in its body is towards increase and the blackness towards decrease. The other half by blackness, so it is said "Krishna Paksha" because the beginnings of its nights are dark even if illuminated from them the times of people's sleep, and the light of the moon in its body is towards decrease and the blackness towards increase. The sum of two months is "Ritu", and that is said by approximation, for the month containing two of "Paksha" is lunar, and that whose double is Ritu is solar. Six Ritu is a year for people, solar, and it is called "Varsha", "Barkh", and "Barsh", for these three letters might interchange in their language. Three hundred and sixty years of the years of people is a year for the Angels and is called "Divya Varsha". Twelve «1» thousand years of the years of the Angels is "Chaturyuga". There is no disagreement in it; rather, the disagreement is in its four parts and in its multiples from which "Manvantara" and "Kalpa" are completed. That is described in their place. Two Kalpas is a day for Brahm. Whether we said two Kalpas or we said twenty-eight...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...Manvantaras, the three hundred and sixty «1» multiples of them are a year for Brahm. It is either seven hundred and twenty Kalpas or ten thousand and eighty Manvantaras «2». Then they said regarding his lifespan: That it is a hundred years of his years. So it is either seventy-two thousand Kalpas or a thousand thousand and eight thousand Manvantaras. This is what we made an end in this chapter. In the book "Vishnu Dharma", a narration from "Markandeya" and his questioner "Vajra": That "Kalpa" is a daytime for "Brahm" and the like of it is a night for him. So every seven hundred and twenty Kalpas is a year for him, and his lifespan from it is a hundred years. This hundred is a daytime for Purusha and the like of it is a night for him. As for how many "Brahms" preceded him, no one knows that except one who is able to count the sand of "Ganges «3»" or enumerate the drops of rains.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
39 - On what exceeds the lifespan of Brahm
Everything that lacks order or contradicts preceding speech, nature shuns it and hearing is bored by it. These are a people who mention many names applicable, by their claim, to the First One or to one below Him pointed to. When they come to the like of this chapter, they repeat those names for many and estimate lifespans for them and lengthen the numbers. This is their purpose, and the field is empty, and number does not stop except by action and stopping. Then they do not agree in them also on one thing so that we may deal with them in it however they dealt. But they differ in them like their difference in the parts of the day descending from breaths. In the book "Sravadhava" by Utpala: That "Manvantara" is the lifespan of "Indra" the Chief. Twenty-eight Manvantaras is a day for Pitamaha, who is Brahm. His lifespan is a hundred years, which is a day for Keshava. His lifespan is a hundred years, which is a day for Mahadev. His lifespan is a hundred years, which is a day for Ishvara the Near. His lifespan is a hundred years, which is a day for Sadashiva. His lifespan is a hundred years, which is a day for Viranjana, the Eternal, the Everlasting, remaining with the annihilation of these five. It has preceded that the lifespan of "Brahm" is 72,000 Kalpas. All that we mention now of numbers are "Kalpas". If this lifespan is a day for Keshava «1», his year, given that the year «1» is three hundred and sixty days, is 25,920,000 «2», and his lifespan with the addition of two zeros...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...and that is a day of "Mahadev". So his lifespan then on this analogy after nine zeros is 93,312. And that is a day of "Ishvara", and his lifespan after twelve zeros is 3,359,232. And that is a day of "Sadashiva", and his lifespan after fifteen zeros is 120,932,352. And that is a day of "Viranjana «1»". "Parardha Kalpa" has become a small part of it compared to it. However the matter was, it is somewhat orderly due to its foundation on the day and on the hundred years from its beginning to its end. But others build in it on the diminishing parts of the day which we mentioned. So they differ in the composite as they differ in the divided. We mention one of them for those who went to [the view] that a "Ghati" is sixteen "Kala", and a Kala is thirty «2» "Kashta «3»", and a Kashta «3» is thirty «3» "Nimesha", and a Nimesha is two «4» of "Lava", and a Lava is two «4» of "Truti". They claimed that the reason for this division is the composition of the day of "Shiva" from what resembles them. That is that the lifespan of Brahm is a Ghati for Hari, who is "Vasudeva". His lifespan is a hundred years, which is a Kala for Rudra, who is Mahadev. His lifespan is a hundred years, which is a Kashta «5» for Ishvara. His lifespan is a hundred years, which is a Nimesha for Sadashiva. His lifespan is a hundred years, which is a "Lava" for Sakti. His lifespan is a hundred years, which is a "Truti" for Shiva. If the lifespan of "Brahm" is 72,000 Kalpas, then the lifespan of "Narayan" is 155,520,000,000. The lifespan of "Rudra" after eleven zeros is 53,747,712. The lifespan of "Ishvara" after sixteen zeros is 557,256,278,016. The lifespan of "Sadashiva" after twenty-two zeros is 17,332,899,271,409,664. The lifespan of "Sakti" after twenty-eight zeros is 10,782,449,978,758,523,781. That is a Truti. If the day is composed from it according to this subject, it would be after thirty-one zeros 37,264,147,126,589,458,187 «5». That is the day of "Shiva". They described him as...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...the Eternal, Innocent of birth and begetting and of qualities and descriptions applicable to creatures. The ranks (digits) of this number are fifty-six. Even if these describers manipulated its calculation, they would not have exceeded in increasing. And Allah is their reckoner.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
40 - On "Sandhi", which is the Common Separation between Times
The original Sandhi is that which is between the day and the night, which is the Dawn (Fajr) in the mornings, and they call it "Sandhi Udaya", meaning that of Rising; and the Twilight (Shafaq) in the evenings, and they call it "Sandhi Astamana", meaning that of Setting. The need for them is religious for the washing of the Brahmins in them, and in the noon between them for food, so that he who has no knowledge of that thought it is a third Sandhi. As for others, they do not exceed the two. In the Puranas, from the story of "Hiranyakashipu", the king who was of the genus of "Daitya": That he prolonged worship until he deserved answering. He asked for permanence, but was answered to its length because permanence is of the attributes of the Creator, Glory be to Him. When he did not attain it, he asked for his death that it not be at the hands of a human or angel or jinn, and not be on the earth or the sky, and not be in night or day. All of that was a trick to escape from death which is inevitable. He was answered to his request. This is like the asking of Iblis for respite until the Day of Resurrection because it is a day of resurrection from death. Therefore he was not answered except to the day of the known time, about which it was said: That it is the last of the days of obligation. He had a son named "Prahlada". He handed him to the teacher when he grew up. He summoned him one day to know what he was in. He recited poetry to him whose meaning was: That there is nothing but "Bishn" [Vishnu] only, and what is other than him is false. That was contrary to the desire of the father, for he hated Bishn. So he ordered the changing of his teacher and that he be taught who is the ally and who is the enemy. He stayed for a while then he asked him. He said: I learned what you commanded, but I do not need it, for all are equal to me in alliance; I do not hate anyone. So the father became angry and ordered poisoning him...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...with poisons. He took them in the name of Allah and mentioned Bishn, so it did not harm him. He said: Do you know magic and incantations? He said: No, but Allah who created you and gave to you protects me. His rage increased and he ordered throwing him into the abyss of the sea. It spat him out and he returned to his place. He threw him before him in a great raging fire, but it did not burn him. He began debating him while in its flames regarding Allah and His power. It ran on his tongue: That Bishn is in every place. His father said: Is he in this pillar of the portico? He said: Yes. The father leaped to it and struck it. "Narasimha" came out of it, like the head of a lion on the body of a human, not in the form of a human nor angel or jinn. He and his companions began defending against him, and he repelled because the time was day, until evening came and they got into the "Sandhi" of twilight, neither in day nor in night. Then he took him and lifted him to the air and killed him in it, neither on earth nor in sky. He took his son out of the fire and made him king in his place. The astrologers among them need these two times for the strength of some Signs in them as will be reported in its place. So they use them on the apparent matter and make the time of each one of them a "Muhurta", meaning two Ghatis, and that is four-fifths of an hour. As for "Varahamihira", due to his virtue in the art, he did not know other than day and night and did not allow himself to follow the common opinion regarding Sandhi. He explained it with what is the truth and claimed that it is the time of the being of the center of the sun's body on the reality of the circle of the horizon, and he made it the time of strength of those Signs. After that, the astrologers and others exceeded the two Sandhis of the natural day to others by what is by convention, not nature or sense. They made for each of "Ayana", meaning the two halves of the year in which the sun ascends and descends, a Sandhi which is seven days before the arrival of its beginning. Something possible not far-fetched is imagined by me in it, which is that this is innovated, not ancient, and said near the year one thousand three hundred of Alexander (approx 1000 AD) upon their stumbling on the precession of the solstice [relative to] their calculation. For "Punjala", the author of the small "Manasa" book, says: That in 854 of "Shaka Kala" (932 AD) the solstice preceded his calculation by six degrees and fifty minutes, and that will be in the future increasing every year by a minute. This is speech issuing from a precise observer or one considering many ancient observations with him, from which he cut the amount of the difference every year. There is no doubt that others also noticed it or what is close to it from...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...the side of measuring noon shadows. Therefore, "Utpala" the Kashmiri accepted it from him and believed him in it. What confirms this conjecture is their running the "Sandhi" of the two solstices in each one of the sixths of the year (Ritus) until their beginnings became from the twenty-third degrees of the Signs which are before their Signs. They placed also between the Yugas a Sandhi, as they placed the like of it between the Manvantaras. Just as these principles are conventional, likewise their branches are conventional. Mention of them will come in their places which will be sufficient.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
41 - On Clarifying "Kalpa" and "Chaturyuga" and Defining One by the Other
Indeed the year of "Deva" (Divya Varsha), its magnitude has become clear. Twelve «1» thousand years of it is a Chaturyuga. A thousand Chaturyuga is a Kalpa. text: ...this day is a 'Kalpa', nothing else. He also said: That one thousand 'Chaturyugas' are a daytime for 'Daivika' (Devas), meaning Brahma, and the like is a night for him. So the day is two thousand 'Chaturyugas'. Similarly, "Vyasa son of Parasara" says: That he who believes that one thousand Chaturyugas are a daytime and the like are a night, he is the one who knows Brahma. Within a Kalpa, every seventy-one Chaturyugas is a 'Manu', meaning 'Manvantara', which is the turn of a Manu. And fourteen Manus also constitute a Kalpa. If seventy-one is multiplied by fourteen, the total Chaturyugas for the Manvantaras is nine hundred and ninety-four. The remainder to complete a Kalpa is six of them. However, if they are divided by fifteen, because what borders consecutive things on their two sides is greater than their number by one, the result is two-fifths. So if we start from the beginning of the Manvantaras and place before it two-fifths of a Chaturyuga, and likewise between every two Manvantaras, the fifths will be exhausted following its exhaustion (?), and two-fifths will result at the end of it, just as we placed at its beginning. It is a 'Sandhi' between them, I mean a common interval (Sandhi/Twilight). By it, a Kalpa of one thousand Chaturyugas is completed as was said. The conditions of a Kalpa are consistent, witnessing for each other. For its beginning opens with the vernal equinox, on Sunday, with the conjunction of planets, their apogees, and their nodes, such that there is no 'Revati' nor 'Ashvini', meaning between them, and with the beginning of the month 'Chaitra', and rising over 'Lanka'. Whenever one of these conditions is changed, the others are disturbed and dissolved. We have mentioned the days of a 'Kalpa' and its years. It is known that the days of a 'Chaturyuga', having set a tenth of a tenth of a tenth of a Kalpa (1/1000), are 1,577,916,450, and its years are 4,320,000. So the ratio between a Kalpa and a Chaturyuga is known, and the magnitude of one is known by knowing the other. All of this is according to the opinion of "Brahmagupta" and his citations for his position. As for the great "Aryabhata" and "Paulisa", they composed 'Manvantara' from seventy-two Chaturyugas and composed a Kalpa from fourteen Manvantaras of them, a composition not interspersed with any 'Sandhi'. It is known that the number of Chaturyugas of a Kalpa according to them is 1008, and the years of a Kalpa in 'Deva' years are 12,096,000, and in human years 4,354,560,000. text: XLII. On the Division of Chaturyuga by the Four Yugas and Mention of the Difference therein. The author of the book "Vishnu Dharma" said: That one thousand two hundred years of 'Deva Yuga' years is named 'Tisya' (Kali), and its double is 'Dvapara', and its triple is 'Treta', and its quadruple is 'Krita'. The total is twelve thousand years, and that is a Chaturyuga, meaning the four Yugas, and its meaning is the Totality. He said: Seventy-one Chaturyugas is a 'Manvantara', and fourteen Manvantaras with a 'Sandhi' between every two of them whose duration equals the duration of 'Krita Yuga' constitute a Kalpa. Two Kalpas are a day for Brahma. His life from it is one hundred years, and it is a day of 'Purusha', the First Man for whom no beginning or end is known. He said: This is what 'Varuna', the master of water, informed 'Rama son of Dasaratha' in the first time, as he knew it truly. Likewise, 'Bhargava', who is 'Markandeya', informed of it; he reached such knowledge of times that no one from the numbers (?) opposed him. They had a likeness of the Angel of Death annihilating them with the throne he had, which is 'Apradhrishya' (Invincible?). "Brahmagupta" said: The book "Smriti" states that four thousand years of 'Daivika' (divine) years is Krita Yuga, and four hundred years with it is Sandhi (twilight) and four hundred 'Sandhyamsa' (portion of twilight). text: ...laws for numbers, some approved and some disliked. For the law of Yugas, he set forty-eight as a base and subtracted from it its quarter, so thirty-six remained. text: XLIII. On the Properties of the Four Yugas and Mention of What is Expected at the End of the Fourth. The Greeks used to believe regarding the name of the earth—and let the example be one of them—that the calamities that befall it from above and below differ in quality and quantity, and that perhaps what exceeds in one of them or both covers it, so no trick is useful against it, nor escape and caution from it. So it comes upon it. That is like the drowning floods and the destructive earthquakes by swallowing or drowning and burning by what gushes from them of waters or is thrown of heated rocks and ash, then thunderbolts, tremors, and storms, then epidemics, diseases, and death, and the like. When a wide region becomes empty of its nation, then revives after its destruction upon the lifting of that calamity from it, a scattered people gather to it like wild beasts who were fortifying themselves before that in hiding places and mountain tops. They become civilized, helping each other against the adversary whether from predatory beasts or humans, and assisting each other in passing life in safety and joy until they multiply. Then competition fluttering over them with the wings of anger and envy disturbs the goodness of their life. Perhaps a group of those groups traces its lineage to one who was the first to attend among them or distinguished by a state distinguishing him from them, so they do not know over the passage of days other than him. text: ..."Bharadvaja son of Atri" until he ascended the mountain and supplicated, so Allah taught him the science of Medicine. What we narrated from the Greeks is similar to that. It has been said that she was in the first time with people in the domain of women, not visible to men. Her name among them is "Justice" (Dike). She used to gather the elders and leaders in assemblies and streets and urge them with a loud voice to the truth, bestow countless wealth, and give rights. The earth then was called "Golden". None of its people knew destructive dispute in deed or word, nor was there among them a blameworthy sect. Rather, they lived a neglected life (simple/carefree). The sea was rejected, not ridden by ships. Cows used to bring provisions. When the Golden Race became extinct and the Silver Race came, she associated with them not expansively and hid in the mountains not mixing with women as she was before. Then she used to come to the great cities, warn their people, reproach them for bad deeds, and blame them for corrupting the race left by the Golden fathers. She informed them of the coming of a race worse than them and the existence of wars, blood, and great calamities. When she finished, she disappeared from them to the mountains until the Silver ones became extinct and people became of a Bronze race. They extracted the sword, the doer of evil, and tasted the meat of cows, and they were the first to do that. Justice hated their neighborhood and flew to the sphere. The commentator of his book said: This Virgin is the daughter of "Zeus". She used to inform people in assemblies of the common laws. text: XLIV. On the Mention of the Manvantaras. Just as seventy-two thousand Kalpas are estimated for the life of "Brahma", likewise "Manvantara", which means the turn of "Manu", is estimated for the life of "Indra". His presidency ends with its expiration, and he would have reached his rank at the end of the "Paurus" (Human/Soul?) of the world in the new Manvantara. "Brahmagupta" said: Whoever claimed that there is no Sandhi between every two Manvantaras and calculated each one of them as seventy-one Chaturyugas, a "Kalpa" decreased according to him by six Chaturyugas. The decrease in it from the thousand is like the increase upon it in the contradiction of both to the book "Smriti". Then he said: That "Aryabhata" mentioned in two books of his, one named "Dasagitika" and the other "Aryastasata", that every "Manvantara" is seventy-two Chaturyugas. So a Kalpa according to his saying is one thousand and eight Chaturyugas. In the book "Vishnu Dharma" from the answers of "Markandeya" to Vajra: As for "Purusha", he is the Owner of the Whole. As for Kalpa, its owner is Brahma who is the Owner of the World. As for Manvantara, its owner is "Manu". They are fourteen, and the kings of the earth in its beginning are their children. We have placed their names in the table. What occurred in the names of the future Manvantaras, which are below the seventh, I think is only from the side of what preceded of its like in the Dvipas, of the people's intent for names without order. 1 2 3 4 5

text: XLV. On the Mention of the Daughters of Na'sh (Ursa Major/Seven Rishis). The Daughters of Na'sh are called in their language "Saptarshayah", meaning the Seven Rishis. They mention that they were ascetics who sought their sustenance from the lawful. With them was a righteous woman, "Al-Suha" (Arundhati). They avoided the stalks of lotus from the ponds to feed on them. Religion came and hid her from them. Each one of them was ashamed of the other, so he swore oaths that Religion approved of, and He raised them to the place they are seen in as an honor to them. We had reported that the books of the Indians are composed in poetry, and accordingly they are fond of similes and praises that are novel to them. In "Samhita" of Varahamihira is a description of the Daughters of Na'sh before judging by them. That is, according to our translation: The direction of the North is adorned with these stars like the adornment of a beautiful woman with a necklace of strung pearls and a collar of arranged white lotus. Rather, they are in it like dancing maidens rotating around the Pole as he orders them. I say, narrating from "Garga" the ancient old man, that the stars of the Daughters of Na'sh were in "Magha", the tenth of the Lunar Mansions, when "Yudhishthira" ruled the earth. The "Shakakala" was after that by two thousand five hundred and twenty-six years. They stay in every Mansion for six hundred years. Their rising is between the East and North. The one adjacent to the East then of them is "Marichi", and towards...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...the West of it is "Vasistha", then "Angiras", then "Atri", then "Pulastya", then "Pulaha", then "Kratu". Near Vasistha is a chaste woman called "Arundhati". These names might be confused, so we define them by what is known in the constellation of the Great Bear: Marichi is the twenty-seventh of it (Eta Ursae Majoris), Vasistha is the twenty-sixth (Zeta), Angiras is the twenty-fifth (Epsilon), Atri is the eighteenth (Delta), Kratu is the sixteenth (Alpha), Pulaha is the seventeenth (Beta), and Pulastya is the nineteenth (Gamma). These stars take in our time, and the Shakakala in it is 952, from eight and a third degrees of Leo to thirteen and a half degrees of Virgo. According to the motion we find for the fixed stars, they were in the time of Yudhishthira from eight degrees and two-thirds of Gemini to twenty degrees and five-sixths of Cancer. According to the motion the ancients and "Ptolemy" worked on, they were then from twenty-six and a half degrees of Gemini to eight degrees and two-thirds of Leo. The mentioned Mansion (Magha) takes from the beginning of Leo to the completion of eight hundred minutes of it. This time (our time) is more worthy for the Daughters of Na'sh to be attributed to "Magha" than the time of "Yudhishthira". If they went in it to the star Heart of the Lion (Regulus), it was then in the beginning of Cancer. There is no basis at all for what "Garga" mentioned; rather, it indicates his lack of guidance to what is needed in associating stars by observation or instruments to the degrees of the signs. I saw in the notebooks of the calendar brought from Kashmir calculated for the year 951 of the "Shakakala" that the Daughters of Na'sh have been in the Mansion of "Anuradha" for seventy-seven years. This Mansion takes from three and a third degrees of Scorpio to the completion of sixteen degrees and two-thirds of it. The Daughters of Na'sh precede it by close to...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...a sign and twenty degrees. Who can verify their differing sayings on the back of the unseen from them! Let us grant first that Garga is truthful, even if he did not clarify the position from Magha, so we posit it as its beginning, which is the beginning of Leo. From the time of Yudhishthira to our year which is 1340 of Alexander is 3479. We also believe "Varahamihira" in the stay of the Daughters of Na'sh in every Mansion for six hundred years. So its position for our year would be in Libra six degrees and seventeen minutes, and that is in the Mansion of "Svati", ten degrees and thirty-eight minutes. If we assume what we posited in the middle of "Magha", we end up at three degrees and fifty-eight minutes of "Visakha". If we assume it at the end of Magha, we end up at ten degrees and thirty-eight minutes of Visakha. What is mentioned in the Kashmiri calendar does not agree with what is in "Samhita". Likewise, if we made the position what is in the calendar and went back from it with this motion to the past, we would not end up at Magha at all. We used to consider the speed of the fixed stars in our time great and their slowness in the past and seek reasons for it in the configuration of the sphere. Their motion according to us is a degree in every sixty-six solar years. So the matter of "Varahamihira" became more amazing because it implies their motion is a degree in forty-five years, and his time precedes our time by close to five hundred and twenty-five years. In the Zij "Karanasara" for the motion of the Daughters of Na'sh and knowing its position, its author ordered to subtract 821 from "Shakakala". The Origin remains, which is what exceeds the completion of four thousand years from the beginning of "Kali Yuga". Then the Origin is multiplied by 47 and 68000 is added to the sum. The sum is divided by ten thousand. Signs and what follows them come out, and that is the position of the Daughters of Na'sh. As for the addition, it is necessarily the position of the Daughters of Na'sh for the beginning of the Origin multiplied by ten thousand. If the addition is divided by it, six signs and twenty-four degrees come out. It is known that we divided the ten thousand by the forty-seven, the duration of the motion of one sign came out as two hundred and twelve years and nine...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...months and six solar days. So the motion of a degree is in seven years, a month, and three days, and the Mansion in ninety-four years, six months, and twenty days. What a difference between "Varahamihira" and "Vatesvara" if there is no error in the transmission. If we follow this operation for our year, it comes out in "Anuradha" nine degrees and seventeen minutes. The people of "Kashmir" used to believe regarding the motion of the Daughters of Na'sh that it is one hundred years for the Mansion. It was in the mentioned calendar that the remainder for it to complete the hundred is twenty-three years. All of this is due to lack of exercise in the conditions of astronomy and mixing it with religious reports. Their authors among them believe regarding the Daughters of Na'sh that they are higher than the positions of the fixed stars. They claim that in every "Manvantara", a "Manu" is renewed, so his children own the earth, and the presidency is renewed for Indra, as well as the groups of angels and the Daughters of Na'sh. As for the need for angels, it is for people to make sacrifices for them and deliver their shares to the fire. As for the need for the Daughters of Na'sh, it is to renew the "Veda", for it perishes at the end of every Manvantara. This chapter is from "Vishnu Purana", and from it we copied what we placed in the table of the names of the Daughters of Na'sh in every Manvantara:

Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
46 - On "Narayan" [Narayana], His Coming at Times, and His Names
Narayan, according to them, is a power from the High Powers, not intending reform with the best nor corruption with corruption. Rather, it is repelling corruption and evil with what is possible. Reform, according to it, precedes corruption. If it is not consistent and not possible, then with the corruption that is inevitable. Like a rider who has entered the middle of a crop; if he reviews himself and feels guilty and wants to exit from the badness of his deed, he is unable to achieve his goal except by turning the beast backward and exiting from where he entered. In his exiting there is [harm] like what was in his entering and more, and there is no way for remedy other than that. They do not distinguish between it and the First Cause. It may have an incarnation in the world resembling its people in having a body and color, since other than that is not possible. Among the times of his coming is at the expiration of the first "Manvantara" to snatch the leadership of the worlds from "Bali" [?] who aspired to it and wanted to take it. He came and handed it to "Shatakratu" [Indra] who completes a hundred sacrifices, and made him Indra. Among them is his coming at the expiration of the sixth Manvantara in which he destroyed the King "Bali son of Virochana" who took Venus as a vizier and possessed the world. When he heard from his mother the superiority of his father's days over his days, as it was closer to the beginning of "Krita Yuga" «1» and people were more drowned in comfort and farther from fatigue, his ambition shook him to compete in that. He began acts of righteousness, spreading gifts, distributing wealth, and offering...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...sacrifices, for which one deserves, upon completing a hundred of them, the leadership of Paradise and the world. When he approached completion or almost finished ninety-nine of them, the Spirituals feared for their position and knew that what they have from people would be cut off if they dispensed with them. They gathered to "Narayan" calling him for help. He answered their request and descended to the earth in the form of "Vamana" [Dwarf], which is the human whose hands and legs fall short of the magnitude of his body so his appearance becomes ugly because of that. He came to "Bali" the King while he was in the act of sacrifice, and the Brahmins were with him around the fires, and Venus his vizier was before him. The treasuries had been opened and jewels poured «1» in heaps for gifts, grants, and charities. Vamana began, like the Brahmins, reciting the "Veda" from the place called now "Sama Veda" with a sad «2» enchanting melody that shook the King to generosity towards him regarding what he wanted and proposed. Venus whispered to him that this is Narayan who has come to steal your kingdom, but he did not heed his saying due to the intensity of his joy. He asked him what he wanted. He said: An amount of four steps from your kingdom to live in. He said: Choose what you want and how you want. He asked for water to pour on his hand to execute by that what he ordered, and it is a custom for them. Venus entered the jug due to his intense love for the King and blocked its spout so it would not let out «3» water, blocking the hole of the spout with the grass of the ring finger's ring. He (Vamana) poked the eye of Venus and removed him, so the water flowed. Vamana stepped one step to the East and another to the West and a third upwards reaching "Svarloka". No place remained of the world for the fourth, so he enslaved him by it and placed his foot between his shoulders as a mark of enslavement and sank him into the earth until he sank to "Patala", the lowest of the low. He took the worlds from him and handed the leadership to "Purandara" [Indra]. In "Vishnu Purana": That "Maitreya" the King asked "Parashara" about the Yugas. He answered him: That they are for "Bishn" [Vishnu] to occupy himself in them. He comes in "Krita Yuga" in the form of "Kapila" purely for knowledge. In "Treta Yuga" in the form of "Rama" purely for courage and subduing the wicked and preserving the three Lokas by power and victory...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
...and benevolence to them. In "Dvapara" in the form of "Vyasa" to make the "Veda" into four parts and branch it out. In the end of Dvapara in the form of "Basdiv" [Vasudeva/Krishna] to annihilate the tyrants. In "Kali Yuga" in the form of "Kalki son of Jishnu" the Brahmin to kill all and repeat the cycle in "Yuga". This is his occupation. In another place of this book: That Bishn, and this is an expression for "Narayan" also, comes at the end of every Dvapara to divide the Veda into four due to the weakness of people and their inability to observe all of it. He is in his comings in the form of Vyasa, even if his names differ. He listed them in the past Chaturyugas of this seventh Manvantara. We placed them in a table:
[Table]

text: «1» «2» And "Krishna Dvaipayana" is "Vyasa son of «3» Parashara". The twenty-ninth is future, not yet happened. In the book "Vishnu Dharma": That the names of "Hari", who is "Narayan", differ in the Yugas. So they are: "Vasudeva, Sankarshana, Pradyumna, Aniruddha". I think that he did not observe «3» the order in them, for in the last of the four Yugas he was "Basdiv" [Vasudeva]. In it also: That his colors differ in them. He is white in "Krita Yuga", red in "Treta Yuga", yellow in "Dvapara", and it is the beginning of his embodiment in the form of a human, and black in "Kali Yuga". These colors are like the colors of the three first Powers (Gunas), for they claim that "Sattva" is white transparent, "Rajas" is red, and "Tamas" is black. We mention after this the condition of his last coming.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
47 - On Mentioning "Basdiv" [Vasudeva/Krishna] and the Wars of "Bharata"
The world is populated by tillage and offspring. Both «1» are increasing over days, and increase is unlimited while the world is limited. If increase and its mode were left in one type of plant and animal, and each of them does not exist nor corrupt once but generates its like, indeed its likes, many times, the type of one tree or the type of one animal would take over the earth as long as it found a place for spreading and propagation. The farmer selects his crop, leaving in it what he needs and uprooting other than it. The keeper leaves of the branches what he knows nobility in and prunes what is other than it. Indeed, the bee kills from its kind the one who eats and does not work in its hive. Nature does likewise, but it does not distinguish because its action is one. So it destroys the leaves and fruit of the tree and prevents it from the action prepared for it, so it removes it. Likewise the world, if it is corrupted by multitude or almost is, and it has a Manager and His care totally in every part of it exists, He sends to it one who reduces the multitude and cuts off the materials of evil. Of that, according to what the Indians claim, is "Basdiv". For he arrived in the last time in the form of a human named Basdiv when the tyrants multiplied in the earth and it was filled with injustice until it was swaying from the multitude and trembling from the intensity of the tread. Basdiv was born in the town of "Mathura" to the sister of "Kamsa" its ruler then. They were of the genus of "Jat" [Yadava?], owners of cattle, and his status was "Shudra" (This contradicts the usual Kshatriya lineage of Krishna/Yadavas). Kamsa knew that his destruction was from his side by a call he heard at the time of his sister's wedding. So he entrusted with her someone who would carry to him...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...her loads when she delivered. He used to kill her male and female until "Balabhadra" [Balarama] was born to her. "Yasoda", wife of "Nanda" «1» the cowherd, took him and raised him and used a trick to hide his matter from the entrusted ones. Then "Basdiv" [Krishna] was born to her after him in the eighth womb on a rainy night which was the eighth of the black half of "Bhadrapada" while the Moon was in the mansion of "Rohini" in the Ascendant. The guards were oblivious with a sleep that heavily weighed on them. His father stole him and carried him to "Nandagokula", meaning the place of the cow-shed belonging to Nanda the husband of "Yasoda", which is near "Mathura" with the river "Jumna" between them. He exchanged him with a daughter of Nanda whose birth happened at the time of Basdiv's reaching them. He carried the daughter to the guards instead of the son. "Kamsa" the ruler wanted to kill her, so she flew into the air and went. Basdiv was raised in the hand of Yasoda the wet nurse without her knowing that he was the exchange of her daughter. Kamsa became aware of his matter, so he plotted against him with every plot and deceit, all of which returned upon him, until he demanded him from his parents for wrestling before him. He excelled in his deed over everyone after he did on the road what enraged the maternal aunt (Kamsa?), from subduing a snake entrusted with guarding the "Nilofar" (lotus) of his pond and bridling it in its nostrils, and from killing his fuller when he refused to lend him clothes for wrestling, and from robbing the sandalwood from its owner entrusted with anointing the wrestlers with it. Then he killed the rutting elephant prepared to kill him at his gate. The action of rage reached such an extent in Kamsa that his gall bladder split and he perished instantly. Basdiv, his sister's son, ruled in his place. He has a name in every month; his followers open them with the month of "Margashirsha" and with the eleventh day of all of them, for his emergence was on it. Then the father-in-law of the deceased became angry at that and advanced to "Mathura" and seized the kingdom of "Basdiv" and expelled him to the sea. The golden fort of "Baroi" (Dwarka) appeared to him near the coast, so he inhabited it. The children of "Kuru" (Kauravas) were against the cousins (Pandavas). They hosted them and gambled with them, winning from them all they owned until the matter reached that they stipulated on them exile from the homeland for over ten years and hiding in the last of them such that no one would know them. And that if they did not fulfill, the return of the like of those years would be obligatory on them. They did...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...«1» until the time of their emergence came. Each of the two parties began mobilizing and striving in seeking help until there gathered in the plain of "Thanesar" (Kurukshetra) multitudes that can hardly be counted. They were eighteen "Akshauhini". Each of the two parties sought the help of Basdiv. He offered himself alone or his brother "Balabhadra" with the army. The children of "Pandu" chose him. They are five: "Yudhishthira" their chief, "Arjuna" the bravest of them, "Sahadeva", "Bhimasena", and "Nakula" «2». With them were seven Akshauhini and their opponents were stronger, were it not for the tricks of Basdiv and his teaching them what obtains victory for them, until those multitudes were annihilated and none remained except the five brothers. Then Basdiv departed to his center. He and his tribe known as Yadava and the five brothers died before the completion of the year and the passing of the hawl (year) from the finish of those wars. As for Basdiv...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...he made between him and Arjun the twitching of the left upper arm and eye a sign for the occurrence of an event to him. In that time there was a Rishi ascetic named "Durvasas". The brothers of Basdiv and his tribe were scoundrels, jesters. One of them hid under his clothes an iron frying pan and asked the ascetic about his pregnancy, mocking him. He said: In your belly is what is the cause of your destruction and the destruction of all your family. "Basdiv" heard that and grieved for it due to his knowledge of the truth of his saying. He ordered that that frying pan be filed with a file and thrown into the water. That was done. A remnant remained which the one in charge of that deemed insignificant and threw as it was. A fish swallowed it and was caught; the fisherman found it in its belly and fashioned it for his arrow as a point. When the destined time came, Basdiv was on the coast sleeping under the shade of a tree, one of his legs over the other. The hunter thought him a gazelle and shot him, hitting his right foot. The wound was the cause of his death. Arjun's left twitched, then his upper arm. His brother "Sahadeva" advised him not to enable him (Basdiv) to embrace him lest he take away his strength. He came to him, and due to what was in him, he did not «1» enable him to embrace him. He asked for his bow and handed it to him, so he tested his strength with it. He advised him regarding his body and the bodies of his tribe for burning, and regarding his women to carry them from the fort, and he died. As for the filings, they grew reeds (sedge). "Yadava" came to it and tied bundles from it for sitting and drank. A brawl occurred between them; they fought in it with the bundles of reeds and killed each other. All that was near the mouth of the river "Sarasvati" in the sea at the place of "Somnath". Arjun did «2» all that he was ordered. He carried his women, but thieves intercepted them. Arjun was not able to string his bow, so he realized the departure of his strength. He began circling the bow above his head; what was under it survived, and what went out of it the thieves captured. He and his brothers knew that there was no benefit for them in life, so they went to the direction of the North and entered the mountains whose snows do not melt. The cold killed them one after another until "Yudhishthira" remained. He was received with the honor of Paradise after crossing over Hell because of one lie he told at the request of his brothers and "Basdiv"...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...that from him. It is his saying in the hearing of "Drona" the Brahmin: "Ashvatthama" the Elephant died, and his pausing between the two words so he deluded Drona that he meant his son. Yudhishthira said to the angels: If that is inevitable, then let my intercession be accepted for the people of Hell and let them be freed from it. He was answered to that and was taken to Paradise.
