text:
48 - On Clarifying the Magnitude of "Akshauhini"
Every Akshauhini contains ten "Anikini". Every Anikini contains three "Camu". Every Camu three "Pritana". Every Pritana three "Vahini". Every Vahini three "Gana". Every Gana three "Gulma". Every Gulma three "Senamukha" «1». Every Senamukha «1» three "Patti". In every Patti is one "Ratha", which is named in Chess a Rook (Rukh/Chariot). The Greeks used to call them "Chariots of War". The first to innovate them among them was "Manqalus" [?] in the city of "Athens". Its people claim that they are the first who rode them. Before that, "Aphrodisias" the Indian had invented them in Egypt when he ruled it, and that was after the Flood by close to nine hundred years. He made it with two horses running it. From the myths of the Greeks: That "Hephaestus" loved "Athena" and seduced her, but she repelled him to preserve virginity. He hid for her in the lands of "Athens" and wanted to seize her, but she stabbed him with a spear until he left her. He sent the sperm on the earth, so from it was "Erichthonius". Indeed he came on a chariot like the Rukh of the Sun, and with him was a holder of the reins, riding. What is in the hippodrome in our time of the customs of galloping and running in Rukhs (Chariots) is a resemblance to it. There is also in it one elephant, three horsemen, and five foot-soldiers. These arrangements are for the sake of mobilization, camping, and marching. Whatever gathers of...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...Rukhs 21,870, and of elephants the like of it, and of horsemen 65,610, and of foot-soldiers 109,350, it is an "Akshauhini". But in every Rukh are four horses, its groom, the chief of the chariot the Archer, his two allies the Spearmen, the guard of the chief from behind him, and the one entrusted with repairing the chariot. On every elephant is its leader, his deputy from behind him, his driver behind the seat, the chief in it the Archer, his two allies the Spearmen, and his playmate "Huhu" who runs before him. So there is an increase in people from the side of Rukhs and Elephants of 284,323 (error in calculation or text?) «1», and in horses 87,480. So the total elephants in an Akshauhini is 21,870, and the like of it of chariots, and animals 153,090 «2», and people 459,283. The count of all animals in an Akshauhini of elephants, beasts, and people is 634,243 «3». In the total of eighteen Akshauhinis is 11,416,374; of it elephants 393,660, beasts 2,755,620, and people 8,267,094. This «4» is the detailing of Akshauhini and its explanation.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
49 - On Eras (Dates) in Summary
By Eras, the times pointed to in time become known. The Indians, even if they did not find the multitude of number heavy but rather rejoiced in it, they are compelled in usage to reduce it. Among their eras is the beginning of the being of "Brahm". Among them is the beginning of the day of his day now, which is the beginning of "Kalpa". Among them is the beginning of the seventh "Manvantara" which we are in. Among them is the beginning of the twenty-eighth "Chaturyuga" which is the one we are in. Among them is the beginning of the fourth Yuga of it, called "Kalikala", meaning the time of "Kali", for the Yuga is known by it even if its time is in its end, but they mean by it the beginning of "Kali Yuga". Among them is "Pandava Kala", which is the time of the wars of "Bharata" and its days. All these eras are ancient; their years have exceeded hundreds to thousands and beyond. Astrologers, let alone others, found them heavy. We, to define them, make the first example the Indian year most of which falls in the year four hundred of Yazdegerd (400 Y.E. / 1031 AD). For its hundreds are stripped of units and tens, so it was specialized by that and distinguished from other years. Then it became famous by the collapse of the most impregnable pillars and the passing of the like of Sultan Mahmud, Lion of the World and Rarity of Time, Allah's mercy upon him, less than a year before it. As for the Indian year, its Nowruz (New Year) precedes by twelve days and follows the mentioned obituary by ten complete Persian months. If what we assumed is known, we drive the years to this Conjunction which is the opener of the Indian year, for it completes at it, and the mentioned Nowruz is close to it and follows it. In the book "Vishnu Dharma": That "Vajra" asked "Markandeya" about what has passed of the lifespan...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...of "Brahm". He answered him that the past of it is eight «1» years, five months, four days, six "Manvantaras", seven "Sandhis", twenty-seven Chaturyugas, three "Yugas" of the twenty-eighth, and ten years of the years of "Deva" to the time of "Ashvamedha" which you performed. He said: And whoever encompasses the detail of that and conceives it with true conception is a Knower ('Arif). The Knower is the one who serves the One Lord and seeks the neighborhood of His place called "Brahma Pura" (Padam?). If what he mentioned is known—and we have indicated the magnitudes of these things with a sufficient indication from which it becomes clear that the past of the life of "Brahm" to the time we assumed for the example in our years is 26,215,732,948,132 «2». And from his day which is the "Kalpa" of the Day 1,972,948,132. And from the seventh Manvantara 120,532,132. It is also the date of the imprisonment of King "Bali" because it was in the first "Chaturyuga" of the seventh Manvantara. Everything we mentioned and mention in dates is their complete years, as there is no custom for them to use the broken year in them. In the book "Vishnu Dharma": "Markandeya" said in answer to "Vajra": Six Kalpas have passed over me, and from the seventh six Manvantaras, and from the seventh twenty-three "Treta Yugas". In the twenty-fourth "Rama" killed "Ravana", and it was said "Lakshmana" brother «3» of Rama [killed] "Kumbhakarna" brother «3» of Ravana, and they conquered all "Rakshasas". At that time "Valmiki" «4» the Rishi made the story of "Rama and Ramayana" and immortalized it in books. And I narrated it to "Yudhishthira son of Pandu" in the grove of "Kamyakavana". As for his counting "Treta Yuga", it is because the mentioned conditions were in it. Also, counting by one is better than one that expresses four. The end of Treta Yuga is more worthy of those conditions than its beginning due to its proximity to evil. There is no doubt that the date of "Rama and Ramayana" is known to them, but it did not fall to us. The years of twenty-three Chaturyugas are 99,360,000. And to the end of Treta Yuga is 102,384,000. If...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...we subtract it from the date of "Manvantara" for our year, 18,148,132 remains, which is the date of Rama according to conjecture until a trustworthy hearing supports it. And from the twenty-eighth "Chaturyuga" 3,892,132. All of this is on the estimations of "Brahmagupta". He and "Paulisa" agree that the "Kalpas" of the life of "Brahm" before our Kalpa are 6,068. The dispersal «1» is only in their Chaturyugas. For with Paulisa they are 6,116,544, and with Brahmagupta with a decrease of 48,544. If we work according to the school of Paulisa that a Manvantara is 72 Chaturyugas without "Sandhi" and a Kalpa is 1008 Chaturyugas and every "Yuga" is a quarter of it, the past of the life of Brahm to the time of our example would be 26,425,456,200,000. And from Kalpa 1,986,124,132. And from Manvantara 119,884,132. And from Chaturyuga 3,244,132. As for what is after "Kali Yuga", there is no disagreement in its complete years. So it is according to both of them from Kali Yuga 4,132, which is "Kalikala". And from the wars of "Bharata", which is "Pandava Kala", 3,479. They have an era called "Kala Yavana". I did not verify it, except that they claimed it was in the end of the Lower "Dvapara". The mentioned Yavana was dominant over their land, corrupting their religion. All these eras are large in number, distant in beginning. Therefore, they turned away from them and came to the eras of "Sri Harsha", "Vikramaditya", "Shaka", "Vallabha", and "Gupta". As for Sri Harsha, they believe regarding him that he used to contemplate the earth and see what is in its belly to the seventh [earth] of hoarded treasures and stored burials, extract them, and dispense by them from burdening his subjects. His era is used in Mathura and the regions of "Kannauj". From him to Vikramaditya is four hundred years according to what some people of that region mentioned. I saw it in the Kashmiri Almanac later than Vikramaditya by 664. So I obtained doubt and certainty has not cleared it yet. The users of the era of Vikramaditya in the southern and western countries in the land of India place 342 and multiply it by three always, so 1026 gathers. Then they add to it the past of "Shadabda" (Samvatsara?), which is the Sexagenary Cycle, so that is the era of Vikramaditya. I found his name in the book "Sravadhava"...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...by Mahadev "Chandrabija" [?]. In what they do is affectation firstly. If they had placed in the beginning of the matter 1026 as they placed 342 without a necessitating cause, it would have been sufficient. Suppose it was consistent in one "Samvatsara", what is the way in it if it doubled? As for the era of Shaka, which is "Shakakala", it is later than Vikramaditya by 135. The mentioned Shaka was dominant over what is between the river Sindh and the sea of their land. He had made his residence "Aryavarta" in the middle. He prohibited them from attributing to other than the Shaka era. Some of them claimed that he was a Shudra from the city of Al-Mansura. Some of them claimed that he was not Indian but came to them from the direction of the West. They were in severe affliction from him until succor came to them from the regions of the East by "Vikramaditya" intending him, until he defeated him and killed him in the region of "Karur" which is between "Multan" and the fort of "Loni". The time became famous according to the joy at his killing and was dated by, especially by the astrologers among them. They attached "Sri" to the name of Vikramaditya out of reverence for him. Due to the extension of the period between «1» the date we attributed to him and the killing of "Shaka", I think he is not the killer but his namesake. As for the era of "Vallabha", who is the owner of the city of "Vallabhi" which is south of the city of "Anhilvara" by close to thirty "Yojanas", its beginning is later than the era of Shaka by two hundred «2» and forty-one years. Its users place "Shakakala" and subtract from it the sum of the cube of six and the square of five, so the era of Vallabha remains. Its news will come in its place. As for "Gupta Kala", they were, as was said, a wicked powerful people. When they became extinct, they were dated by. It is as if Vallabha was the last of them, for the beginning of their era is also later than Shakakala by 241. The era of the Astrologers is later than Shakakala by 587. Upon it is built the Zij "Khandakhadyaka" by Brahmagupta, which is known among us as Al-Arkand. So then the years of the era of "Sri Harsha" for our year represented «3» by it is 1488. And the era of Vikramaditya 1088. And Shakakala 953. And the era of Vallabha which is also Gupta Kala 712. And the date of the Zij Khandakhadyaka 366. And the date of "Pancha Siddhantika"...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...by Varahamihira 526. And the date of "Karana Sara" 132. And the date of "Karana Tilaka" 65. These eras attributed to the Zijes are the ones their authors deemed suitable for driving calculation from. It is possible they were in their times, just as it is possible they precede them. The commoners of India count years hundred by hundred and call it "Samvatsara" of the Hundred. Whenever a hundred expires, they leave it and start counting a hundred after it. They called it "Laukika Kala", meaning the Era of the Public. They differed in reports about that, a difference with which verification of it disappeared from me. To the extent of their difference in it, they differed in the principle of the year and its opening. I present of it what I heard specifically until the matter in it reveals a law. I say that he who uses the era of "Shaka", and they are the Astrologers, opens the year with the month of "Chaitra". It was said that the people of "Kanir" [Kanauj? / Kunar?] bordering Kashmir open it from the month of "Bhadrapada", and their date for our year is 84. And that those living between "Bardari" and "Marigala" open it from the month of "Kartika", and their date for our year is 110. He claimed in the Kashmiri that it is six of the New Hundred, which is the school of the people of "Kashmir". And that those living in "Nirahar" behind Marigala to the last borders of "Takishar" and "Lohawar" open it from "Margashirsha", and their date for our year is 108. The people of "Lanbaga", meaning "Lamghan", follow them in that. I heard the people of "Multan" say that this was the opinion of Sindh and the people of "Kannauj", and that they used to open the year from the conjunction of Margashirsha, and that the people of Multan left that since a few years and moved to the opinion of the people of Kashmir and agreed with them on opening it with the conjunction of Chaitra. I have presented the excuse in this chapter, and that its dates are not verified because of what is in them of the addition to the hundred. Although I witnessed them in the year of the uprooting of "Somnath", which is four hundred and sixteen of the Hijra, and "Shakakala" in it is 947. If they intended it, they placed 242 and under it 606 99. Then they sum them, so it is Shakakala. It was imagined by me that 242 is the years of the delay of their beginning with the Hundred, and that they began in that from "Gupta Kala". And that 606 is the Samvatsaras of the complete Hundred, and it necessitates that each one be 101. As for 99, they are the past years of the incomplete. It is so, and a leaf I found from a Zij made by "Durlabha" the Multani verifies it. He says in it: Place 848 and add to it "Laukika Kala", meaning the era...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...of the Group, so Shakakala gathers. If we place Shakakala for our year which is 953 and subtract 848 from it, "Laukika Kala" remains 105. It would be for the year of the uprooting of "Somnath" 98. He said: And the principle is from "Margashirsha", and with the astrologers of Multan from "Chaitra". They had kings in Kabul, Turks, said in their origin that they were from Tibet. The first of them came, "Barhatakin", and entered a cave in Kabul which cannot be entered except lying down crawling «1», and in it is water. He placed food there for days. This cave is now known there called "Baqar" [?]. He who seeks blessing by it enters it and exits with some of that water with effort. At its door were groups of farmers working. The likes of these things are not possible nor circulate «2» except by collusion with someone. The one who colluded with him made the people persist in work night and day by shifts so the place would not be empty of people. Upon the passing of days since his entry, one exits from the cave while people are gathered, and they see him as born from the mother, wearing the dress of the Turks of tunic, cap, boots, and weapon. So he was honored with the honor of a being invented and for the kingdom created. He took over those places styling himself the Shah of "Kabul". The kingdom remained in his children for generations numbering around sixty. Were it not that the Indians are negligent in the matter of order and heedless of the system of the dates of kings in succession and resorting to guessing at confusion and necessity, we would have presented what a group of them mentioned. Although I heard that that lineage is on brocade found in the fort of "Nagarkot". I was eager to examine it, but the matter was prevented for reasons. Among their whole was "Kanak" [Kanishka], and he is the one to whom the Vihara in Peshawar is attributed, so it is said "Kanak Chaitya". They claimed that the "Rai of Kannauj" gifted him among what he gifted a fine wondrous robe. He wanted to cut clothes for himself, but the tailor refrained from working on it and said: Here is the image of a human foot, and however I strive, it does not come except between the shoulders. In that is what we mentioned in the story of "Bali". So Kanak knew that the owner of Kannauj intended humiliating him and making light of him. He rode immediately with...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...his armies galloping towards him. The Rai heard that and became confused, for he had no power against him. He consulted his vizier. The vizier said: You have stirred a still one and done what is not obligatory. So cut off my nose and lips now and mutilate me so I may find a way to plot, for there is no face for open confrontation. The Rai did to him what he said and left him and went to the far ends of the kingdom. When the army stumbled upon the vizier and knew him, they brought him to Kanak. He asked him about his condition. The vizier said: I was forbidding him from opposition and calling him to obedience and advising him. He accused me and mutilated me. He passed on his face to a place to which taking the main road is long, and it is easy from the side of traversing a desert between us and him if carrying water for such-and-such days is possible. "Kanak" said: This is easy. He carried water as he said and asked him to guide the direction. He preceded him and entered him into a wilderness with no limit to its ends. When the days expired and the road did not end, he asked the vizier about the condition. He said: There is no blame on me in protecting my master and destroying his enemy. The nearest exit from this desert is what you entered from. So do with me what you want, for there is no escape for anyone from it. Kanak rode and galloped his horse around a low place. Then he planted his spear in its center, and water gushed forth, a gushing that sufficed the army for drink and provision! The vizier said: I did not intend by the trick the capable angels, but I intended by it the incapable humans. Since the matter is so, accept my intercession for my benefactor and forgive him. Kanak said: I am returning from this place to the back. I have answered your request. What was obligatory has been executed in your master. He departed. The vizier went to his master "Rai" and found him having lost his hands and legs on the day Kanak planted the spear in the earth. The last of them was "Lagaturman" and his vizier from the Brahmins was "Kallar". Time helped him, so he found by chance buried treasures by which he became strong and powerful. According to that, the state turned away from his master due to the antiquity of its era with the people of his house «1». So the manners of Lagaturman became bad and his actions ugly until complaints multiplied to his vizier. He fettered him and imprisoned him for discipline, then found sweet the seclusion with the kingdom, having with him the instrument of that from wealth, so he took over it. The Brahmins ruled after him: "Samanta", then "Kamalu", then "Bhim", then "Jaipal", then...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ..."Anandapala", then "Trilochanapala". It was said in the year four hundred and twelve of the Hijra (1021 AD), and his son "Bhimapala" after him for five years. The Hindu Shahi dynasty ended, and there remained of the people of that house no blower of fire (no one). They were, despite power, fond of noble deeds and good covenant and favor. I admired Anandapala's correspondence to Emir Mahmud, while the situation between them was at the utmost roughness: That I heard of the emergence of the Turks against you and their spread in Khurasan. If you wish, I come to you with five thousand «1» horsemen and double that foot-soldiers and a hundred elephants. And if you wish, I send you my son with double that. There is not in «2» that a consideration for the position of that with you. Rather, I am your broken one (vanquished), so I do not want anyone other than me to defeat you. This one was intense in hatred for the Muslims since the capture of his son, but his son Trilochanapala was the opposite of him.

text:
50 - On the Cycles of the Planets in each of "Kalpa" and "Chaturyuga"
Indeed, among the conditions of Kalpa is that the wandering planets be gathered in it at the beginning of the Sign of Aries, meaning the point of the Vernal Equinox, with their apogees and nodes. So there are for each one of them in the days of Kalpa complete cycles inevitably. In the Zij of Al-Fazari and Ya'qub bin Tariq, those cycles are benefited from the Indian man who was in the group of the delegation of Sindh to Al-Mansur in the year one hundred and fifty-four of the Hijra (771 AD). If we compare between them and what the Indians are upon, we find differences between them whose cause I do not know. Is it from the transmission of the two men? Or is it from the dictation of the Indian? Or is it from the correction of "Brahmagupta" or another of them? Inevitably, he who is vigilant, what he sees in the planets of the disorder of calculation concerns him, so he strives to correct it, like Muhammad bin Ishaq al-Sarakhsi. For he found a lagging in the calculation of Saturn and continued considering until he became certain that it was not from the side of the equation. Then he began adding a cycle to its cycles and inducing until the calculation from them agreed with his witnessing. So he established them thus in his Zij. Brahmagupta narrated from "Aryabhata" regarding the cycles of the apogee of the Moon and its node a difference we mention as he narrated, since we did not study that except imitating him. In this table is all of that to be encompassed if Allah the Exalted wills. These cycles are by mean motions. Because "Chaturyuga" is a tenth of a tenth of a tenth (1/1000) of "Kalpa" according to "Brahmagupta", if we take from each one of these cycles a part of a thousand parts of it, it is the movement in Chaturyuga. Just as if we take instead of this part a part...

text: LI. On Establishing the Matter of "Adhimasa", "Unaratra", and the "Aharganas" of Different Days. Because the months of the Indians are lunar in solar years, necessarily the beginning of their year advances in its position from the solar year in every year by the difference between the two lunar and solar years. When one month is completed from that advancement, they do with it what the Jews do in making the leap year thirteen months by repeating "Adar", and like the action of the Arabs in the Jahiliyya with the year of Nasi' (intercalation) by delaying the beginning of the year so that the one preceding it becomes thirteen months. The Indians call the year in which a month is repeated, in common usage, "Malamasa". "Mala" is the wick of dirt on the palm (when rubbed), for it is thrown away just as this month is thrown from the calculation so the number of months of the years remains twelve-fold. In books, it is called "Adhimasa". The one repeated of the months is the one in which the calculation of the month is completed. If it is completed in its beginning before its entry and before anything of it passes, that month is repeated and not another, for even if it has not entered it, the completion is also not in the month before it. If the month is repeated, the first of them is named by its name, and "Dwi" (Double/Second?) is attached to the second from its beginning to distinguish between it and the first. As if, for example, the month of "Ashadha" is repeated, so the name of the first of them is Ashadha and the second "Dwi Ashadha". The first is the discarded one, which is considered ominous and in which nothing is performed of what is performed in the other months. Its most unlucky time is the day of the completion of its calculation. The author of the book "Vishnu Dharma" said: That the decrease of "Chandra" (Lunar) from "Savana" (Civil), meaning the decrease of the lunar magnitude from the rising (civil) one, is six days...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...and it is "Unaratra". The meaning of "Una" is decrease. And that the increase of "Saura" (Solar) over Chandra is eleven days, so from it gathers in two years and seven months the intercalary month "Adhimasa". All of this month is inauspicious; nothing should be done in it. This is speech in gross terms. Its verification is that the year of the moon in its days is three hundred and sixty, and the year of the sun in them is three hundred and seventy-one days and thirty-one parts out of four hundred and eighty parts of a day (likely referring to tithis/lunar days). According to the difference between them, thirty days for Adhimasa gather in 976 and 4156 out of 47799 lunar days. That is thirty-two months, meaning two years, eight months, and sixteen days, then the fraction we mentioned, which is approximately five minutes and thirteen seconds. As for the religious command necessitating that, what was read to us from "Veda" has this meaning: If the day of Conjunction (Amavasya), which is the first of the lunar days of the month, passes devoid of the sun's transition (Sankranti) from one sign to another, then there is a transition in the day following it, the month before it is dropped from the calculation. This is not correct, and the matter was from the reader/translator. That is because the month in lunar days is thirty days, and half of a sixth of the solar year in these days is thirty days and 5311 out of 5760. That in minutes of days is 55 19 22 30 (55 days?). If we assume for example the Conjunction in the beginning of a sign, and we start adding these fractions to the time of that Conjunction time after time, the times of the sun's transitions in the signs after it appear. Because the difference between the months of the two luminaries is a fraction less than a day, it is impossible for a day in the month to be devoid of a transition; rather, perhaps two consecutive transitions gather in a single day of it. That is when the earlier of them happens in the day in less than 4 40 37 30 (?), for the next one happens necessarily in the like of that mentioned fraction which does not suffice to complete a day. So then the narration from "Veda" is incorrect. What I guess is correct is thus: If a month passes and the sun does not have a transition in it from one sign to another, then that month is dropped from the calculation. That is because if the transition happens from the twenty-ninth day in not less than 4 40 37 30, the transition precedes the month after it, so it is devoid of transition...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...because the second transition falls on the first day of the third month. If I induced the consecutive transitions which I composed on the example Conjunction, I found the one in the thirty-third month at 30 20 of the twenty-ninth day, and the one following it at 25 39 22 30 of the first day of the thirty-fifth month. It is known with that the reason for taking this annulled month as ominous, because it is stripped of the time designated for earning reward. As for "Adhimasa", if the derivation of the name is from the first month because "Adi" is the beginning, this name appears in the books of Yaqub bin Tariq and Al-Fazari as "Padamasa", and "Pada" is the end, so it is possible the Indians name it with both, although the two men are prone to misreading and their narration is not relied upon. I only mentioned this because "Paulisa" declared regarding the latter of the two namesake months that it is the intercalary one. As for the month from Conjunction to its like, it is a return of the moon obtained distancing from the sun following the signs to it, and it is the difference between their motions because they are towards one direction. The returns of the sun in a "Kalpa", I mean its cycles, if subtracted from the returns of the moon in it, the lunar months in a Kalpa remain inevitably. Whatever is in every Kalpa, let us call it Universal for ease, and what is in part of it, Partial. The months of solar years are twelve solar. The months of the moon likewise, either in its own year it exhausts them. As for in the sun's year, due to the excess between the two years, the months of the year in "Adhimasa" become thirteen. It is known that the difference between the Universal months of the two luminaries are those extra months by which the year becomes thirteen months. So they are then the Universal Adhimasa months. As for the Universal Solar months, they are 51,840,000,000. As for the Universal Lunar months, they are 53,433,300,000. The difference between them, which is Adhimasa months, is 1,593,300,000. If each of that is multiplied by thirty, it becomes days. As for the days of the Sun, they are 1,555,200,000,000.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: And the days of the Moon are 1,602,999,000,000. And the days of Adhimasa months are 47,799,000,000. If we want to reduce the numbers, we divide them by the common number between them, which is 9,000,000. So each of the months of the Sun becomes from its days 172,800, and each of the months of the Moon and its days 178,111, and each of the months of "Adhimasa" and its days 5,311. If one of the Solar, Civil (Savana), and Lunar days universally is divided by the Universal Adhimasa months, what comes out is the number of days in which this month is completed by the days of that genus. As for Solar, it will be 976. As for Lunar, it will be 1006, and each of them is followed by a fraction which is 464 out of 5311. As for Civil, it will be 990 and 3663 out of 10622. All of this is according to the magnitudes seen by "Brahmagupta" in "Kalpa" and the cycles in it. As for what "Paulisa" is upon in "Chaturyuga", the Solar months are 51,840,000, and the Lunar months are 53,433,336, and Adhimasa months are 1,593,336. The days of Solar months are 1,555,200,000, and days of Lunar months are 1,603,000,080, and days of Adhimasa months are 47,800,080. If we want to reduce these numbers, the commonality of these months is by twenty-four, so Solar months become 2,160,000, Lunar months 2,226,389, and Adhimasa months 66,389. As for their days, they all share by seven hundred and twenty, so Solar days become 2,160,000, Lunar days 2,226,389, and days of Adhimasa months 66,389. If we follow the previous method in them, it comes out for the completion of Adhimasa from Solar days 976, and from Lunar 1006, and each is followed by a fraction which is 4336 out of 66389, and from Civil days 990 and 21465 out of 66389. These are principles in Adhimasa prepared for what follows. As for the need for the days of Decrease (Unaratra), it is that if a year or years are assumed and twelve months are taken for each of them, the count is Solar months...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...in it, and their product by thirty is its Solar days. It is known that the Lunar, I mean months or days, are in it like this count with an addition from which the month of "Adhimasa" and its months are obtained. If what pertains to the assumed years of Adhimasa is composed from those additions by the ratio of Universal Solar months to Universal Adhimasa months, and added - if it is months to the months of the years, and if days to their days - the Partial Lunar Days, I mean those corresponding to the given years, are obtained. But they are not the desired, because it is their Civil (rising) days, and they are less than the Lunar in number because the unit of one is greater than the unit of the Lunar. So a number needs to be subtracted from them to obtain the desired. This decrease is the one called "Unaratra". What pertains to the Partial Lunar Days from it is according to the ratio of the decrease of Universal Civil Days from Universal Lunar Days to Universal Lunar Days. Universal Lunar Days are 1,602,999,000,000, and their excess over Universal Civil Days is 25,082,550,000, which is the Universal Decrease. We count them together by 450,000, so they are reduced by it, and Universal Lunar Days become 3,562,220 and Universal Decrease Days 55,739. As for in "Chaturyuga" according to the opinion of "Paulisa", the Lunar Days are 1,603,000,080 and Decrease Days in it are 25,082,280. The common number between them for reduction is 360. By it, Lunar Days become 4,452,778 and Decrease Days 69,673. These are principles for knowing the Decrease needed in what follows of the calculation of "Ahargana". Its interpretation is the sum of days, for "Ahar" is days and "Gana" is sum. Yaqub ibn Tariq erred in deriving Solar Days and claimed that obtaining them is by subtracting the cycles of the Sun in a "Kalpa" from its Civil Days, I mean the Universal. It is not so. Rather, he multiplies its cycles by twelve to become months, then thirty to become days, or multiplies the cycles by three hundred and sixty. He stuck to correctness in Lunar Days, multiplying its months by thirty, then returned to error in deriving Decrease Days, claiming they are obtained by subtracting Solar Days from Lunar Days. The correct way is to subtract Civil Days from Lunar Days.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: LII. On the Calculation of "Ahargana" in General, I Mean Analysis of Years and Months into Days and Vice Versa by Synthesizing Them into Years. The general operation in analysis is to multiply the complete years by twelve, add to them the past months of the broken year, and add to them the past days of the broken month. What gathers is "Saura Ahargana", meaning the sum of Solar Days, which are the Partial. It is placed in two places. One of them is multiplied by 5311, which is the number representing Universal Adhimasa days, and the amount is divided by 172800, which is the number representing Universal Solar Days. What comes out of whole days is added to the other place, so "Chandra Ahargana", meaning the sum of Partial Lunar Days, gathers. Let it be placed in two places. One of them is multiplied by 55739, which is the number representing Universal Decrease days, and the sum is divided by 3562220, which represents Universal Lunar Days. What comes out of whole days is subtracted from the other place, so "Savana Ahargana", meaning the sum of required Civil Days, remains. However, it must be known that this calculation is driven from a time in which "Adhimasa" and Decrease days are completed together and there is no fraction for them in it. If the given years are starting from the beginning of a "Kalpa" or beginning of a "Chaturyuga" or beginning of a "Kali Yuga", this operation is correct...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...in them. If the given years start from another time, it is possible that the operation is correct in them by coincidence, and it is possible that it indicates the presence of Adhimasa then it is not, or the reverse, unless the position of the years from these three is known, so a special operation is singled out for it as examples of it will come later. We give an example of this operation for the beginning of the Indian year and "Shakakala" 953, which is what we made an example for our operations. There remained until the month of "Adhimasa" is completed thirty days, which is five of the Ghatis, and that is two hours. So the year is "Intercalary" (Kabisah) and the month repeated in it is Chaitra. This work is what is in the Zij Al-Arkand by a corrupt transmission...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...which is: If you want to know the Arkand, meaning "Ahargana", take ninety and multiply it by six and add to it eight and the years of the kingdom of Sindh, which is to Safar of year one hundred and seventeen, which is Chaitra, one hundred and nine years. Cast from it 587, so the years of "Al-Shakh" remain. Easier than that: Take the complete years of Yazdegerd and cast from them 33 always, so the years of Al-Shakh remain. Or take the origin of the years of Al-Arkand, the ninety, multiply it by six and add to it fourteen, then add to it the years of Yazdegerd and cast from it 587, so the years of Al-Shakh remain. I do not think this Shakh is anything but "Shaka". However, what results from the date is not its date, but rather the date of "Gupta Kala" which is analyzed into days. If he were to place this ninety multiplied by six with eight added to it, which is 548, unchanging with the increase of years, the matter would be the same and far from affectation. Safar which he pointed to corresponds first to the eighth day of "Dai Mah" year 103 of Yazdegerd. For this reason, he suspended the matter of "Chaitra" on the crescent occurring in Dai Mah. But the months of the Persians have advanced since then due to neglecting «1» the quarter day in them. The subject necessitates the advance of the date of the kingdom of Sindh which he mentioned over the date of "Yazdegerd" by seven years. So its years for the time of our example would be 405. With the years of Al-Arkand which is its origin, meaning 548, it is 953, which is "Shakakala". With the subtraction he ordered from it, it becomes "Gupta Kala". What remains of the work in analysis is according to what we narrated from "Khandakhadyaka". Perhaps division by a thousand instead of division by 976 is found in some of its copies; that is an error in copying, not that it is a method. We follow this with the work of "Vijayananda" in his Zij known as Karana Tilaka, which is this: Place Shakakala and subtract from it 888. Multiply the remainder by twelve and add to what gathered what passed of the year of complete months. Place the sum in two places. Multiply one of them by 900 and add to what gathered 661. Then divide the sum by 29,282. So the months of "Adhimasa" come out. Add them to the other place and multiply what reached by thirty and add to the sum what passed of the days of the month. So their total becomes the lunar days. Place them in two places.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: Multiply one of them by 3,300 and add to it 64,106. Divide the sum by 210,902. So the days of Decrease come out and "Avama" remains. Then subtract the days of Decrease from the lunar days. So "Ahargana" remains calculated from midnight. An example of it for our example is that we subtracted from "Shakakala" 888, so 56 remained. Its months are 710. We placed them in two places. We multiplied one of them by 900 and added to it 661 and divided the sum by 29,282. So the months of "Adhimasa" came out as twenty-three, and 29,175 «1» of 29,282 remained. As for the number multiplied by, it is thirty to make the months days, but it is also multiplied by thirty. As for the divisor, it is the multiple of 976 with a fraction following it by thirty so they are of one genus. We multiplied one of them by 3,300, so 79,398,000 gathered. We added to it 64,106, so it became 79,462,104. We divided it by 210,902, so the days of Decrease came out 376 and Avama remained 162,952 «2» of 210,902. That which is in "Pancha Siddhantika" by Varahamihira is this: Place Shakakala and subtract from it 427. What remains, make it months by multiplying by twelve. Place them in two places. Multiply one of them by 7 and divide what reached by 228. So the months of "Adhimasa" come out. Add them to the other place and multiply the sum by thirty and add to it the past of the broken month. Place what reached in two places. Multiply the lower of them by eleven and add to it 514 and divide the sum by 703. Subtract what comes out from the other place, so the civil days remain. This, he claimed, is the method of the "Siddhanta" of the Rum (Romaka). Its example for the time of our example is that we subtracted from "Shakakala" 427, so 526 remained, and its months 6,312. What comes out of the months of Adhimasa is 193 and 15 remains of...

text: ...19 (Text says 228, result 193 and remainder 180/228 = 15/19). As for the months, they are with the months 6,505, and their days, which are lunar, are 195,150 «1». This work would be correct if the months of the seventy-two years were lunar, but they are solar, necessitating from intercalation close to twenty-seven months in excess of 864. text: ...thirty. He placed them with the past days of the month in two places. He multiplied the lower by eleven and added to it 686. He placed the sum below it. This work has preceded universally. When the man assumed it for a time, he added additions in it and the rest remained as it was. So the share of the year came out 11 3 52 50, and the share of the month from it 0 55 19 24 10. text:
54 - On Extracting the Mean Motions of the Planets
If the cycles in "Kalpa" or "Chaturyuga" «1» are known and the past in it is known, the ratio of all the days in it to all the cycles is like the ratio of the past days of it to their share of the cycles. So the general work in them is to multiply the past days of Kalpa or Chaturyuga «1» by the cycles of the planet or the apogee or the node in it, and divide the sum by all the days of Kalpa or Chaturyuga «1», whichever the work was by. So what is complete of its cycles comes out. There is no need for them, so they are discarded. Then the remainder is multiplied by twelve «2» and what reached is divided by all the days which you divided by. So Signs (Burj) come out. What remained is multiplied by thirty and we divide it by what you divided by. So Degrees come out. The remainder is multiplied by sixty and we divide it by what you divided by. So Minutes come out. Likewise to what is desired of what follows them. That is the position of that planet by mean course or that apogee or node. This is what "Paulisa" also mentioned on another method, which is that when the complete cycles came out «3» for him, he divided what remained of them by 131,493,150. So the Signs of the mean came out. He divided the remainder by 4,383,150. So Degrees came out. He divided four times what remains by 292,207 (possibly 292,210). So Minutes came out. After that, he multiplied the remainders by sixty and divided...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...the sums by this last number. So Seconds «1» came out and what follows them to where he wanted. That is the sought Mean. This is because he needed in the remainder of the cycles to multiply it by twelve «2» and divide the sum by the days of "Chaturyuga" «3» because his work is on it. So he divided instead «4» of that by the quotient of the days of Chaturyuga «4» by twelve, which is the first number of the three numbers. He needed in the remainder of the Signs to multiply it by thirty and divide the sum by what he divided by. So he divided instead of that by the quotient of the first number by thirty, which is the second number. On this analogy, he wanted to divide the remainder of the Degrees by the quotient of the second number by sixty. But when he divided it by it, 73,051 came out and three quarters remained. So he multiplied the total by four to force the fraction. Therefore, he also used four times the remainder. When the numbers did not work out for him as indicated first, he returned to multiplying by sixty. If we wanted to follow this method in "Kalpa" according to the school of "Brahmagupta", the first number by which the remainder of the cycles is divided would be 131,493,037,500. The second by which the remainder of the Signs is divided 4,383,101,250. The third would be 37,051,687 «5» and a half remains necessitating doubling, until it becomes 146,103,375 and double the remainder is divided by it. "Brahmagupta" has turned away from "Kalpa" and "Chaturyuga" «6» due to the multitude of their days to "Kaliyuga" for alleviation. So when his date is worked with by what preceded of analysis according to his school and its days are multiplied by the cycles of the planet in Kalpa, and its origin is added to it, which is the remainder of cycles that were for it at the beginning of Kaliyuga «7», and the sum is divided by the civil days of Kaliyuga «7» which are 157,791,645, its discarded complete cycles come out. Then he works...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...with what remains as preceded, so its mean comes out. As for these origins, they are for Mars 4,308,768,000, for Mercury 4,288,896,000, for Jupiter 4,313,520,000, for Venus 4,304,444,800 (error in text?), for Saturn 4,305,312,000, for the apogee of the Sun 933,120,000, for the apogee of the Moon 1,505,952,000, and for the Head (Node) 1,838,592,000. As for the Sun and Moon, they were in the middle of their course at the beginning of Aries, and there was no separation for Adhimasa nor for the days of Decrease. As for in the Zijes which we mentioned, "Ahargana", meaning the days of the date, is multiplied for every planet by an assumed number, and you divide it by another assumed one. So the complete cycles and what followed them of the mean come out. Perhaps it is completed from them; and perhaps its completion is by returning to the days of the date and dividing them either as they are or after multiplication by a number by another number, and appending what comes out to the first. Perhaps numbers are assumed like the origin to be added or subtracted so the mean at the beginning of the date is driven from the beginning of the wholes. This is the method of "Khandakhadyaka" and "Karana Tilaka". As for in "Karana Sara", he extracts the means for the Vernal Equinox and Ahargana is from his side. Because those are partial methods not stopping from multiplication, narrating them lengthens without benefit. Then what is after that of the Equation and the rest of the works does not have connection with what we are in.

text:
55 - On the Order of the Planets, their Distances and Sizes
A narration from "Vishnu Purana" and from the commentary of "Patanjal" preceded in the mention of the Lokas necessitating the lowness of the Sun below the Moon in the order of the spheres. That is their religious opinion. Especially, it was said in "Matsya Purana": That the distance of the heaven from the earth is by the magnitude of half the diameter of the earth. The Sun is lower than all. The Moon is above it. The Mansions and their stars are above the Moon. Above them is Mercury, then Venus, then Mars, then Jupiter, then Saturn, then the Great Bear, then the Pole above it. The Pole is connected to the heaven. It is impossible that the stars fall under the counting of a human. Whoever defended this opinion claimed that the Moon is hidden by conjunction from the Sun as the lamp is hidden in its light, then appears by distancing from it. We mention now some of what is in the books of this opinion of the descriptions of the two luminaries and the planets, then we follow it with the astronomical opinion, even if only a little of it fell to us. It was said in "Vayu Purana": That the Sun is spherical in shape, fiery in nature, having a thousand rays by which it takes water. Four hundred of them are for rain, three hundred for snow, and three hundred for the air. It was said in another place of it: That some of them are for the coexistence of "Dev" in happiness, and some for the coexistence of people in amenities, and some for the Fathers. He also divided it in another place over the sixths of the year. He said: It illuminates the earth in the third which is from the beginning of Pisces with three hundred rays, and rains in the third following it with four hundred rays, and cools and snows in the remaining third with three hundred. In it also: That the ray of the Sun and the wind lift water from the sea to the Sun. If it dripped from...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...it, it would be hot. But it pushes it to the Moon to drip from it cold, reviving the world by it. In it also: That the heat of the Sun and its light are a quarter of the heat of the fire and its light. It falls into the water at night in the North, therefore it reddens. In it also: That there was in ancient times earth, water, wind, and heaven. "Brahm" saw a spark under the earth, so he extracted it and made it into thirds. A third of it is the familiar fire needing wood, extinguished by water. A third is the Sun and a third is Lightning. In the animal also is fire, and this is not extinguished by water. For the Sun attracts water, and Lightning flashes through rain, and that which is in the animal is among moistures and feeds on them. It is as if they went in this to the nutrition of the celestial bodies by vapors as Aristotle narrated that from a group. That is because the author of "Vishnu Dharma" declared that the Sun feeds the Moon and the stars. If there were no Sun, there would be no star, no angel, and no human. Their belief regarding the bodies of all stars is that they are spherical in shape, watery in substance, not luminous; and the Sun among them is fiery in substance, luminous by essence, illuminating others accidentally if it faces them. In the totality of stars by vision is what is not stars in reality, but rather lights of rewarded people whose seats are in the high heaven on chairs of crystal. It was said in Vishnu Dharma: That the stars are watery and the ray of the Sun illuminates them at night. Whoever obtains by his good work a place in the high sits in it on his throne. If he shines, he is counted among the stars. He named all of them "Tara", which is a name derived from "Tarana", which is the crossing (Passage). The meaning: As for these, it is as if they crossed the evil of the world and settled in bliss. As for the stars, because they cross the heaven by rotation. The name "Nakshatra" is restricted to the stars of the Mansions. Because all of them are characterized as fixed stars, the name Nakshatra applies to all of them also, for its meaning is that it does not increase nor decrease. As for me, I think that this increase and decrease applies to number and the distances between them, but the author of the book diverted it to light. He said: As the moon increases and decreases. Then he said, and the speech belongs to Markandeya: The stars which do not perish before the completion of "Kalpa" are in the rank of "Nikharva", meaning 100,000,000,000. Those falling before the completion of Kalpa are of unknown number; hardly anyone knows it...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...except one who stayed in the high for the duration of a Kalpa. "Vajra" said: O "Markandeya", you have remained six Kalpas, and this is your seventh, why do you not know them? He said: If they were fixed in their state not changing to their duration, I would not be ignorant of them. But He continues to ascend one of the virtuous and bring down another; therefore I do not record them. As for the diameters of the two luminaries and the Shadow, it was said in "Matsya Purana": That the diameter of the body of the Sun is nine thousand «1» "Yojanas" and the diameter of the Moon is double that, and the Head (Rahu/Node) is like their sum. Likewise it is in "Vayu Purana", except that it was said regarding the Head: That if it is with the Sun it is like it, and if it is with the Moon it is like it. Another said regarding the Head: That it is fifty thousand "Yojanas". As for the diameters of the wandering planets, it was said in "Matsya Purana": That the circumference of Venus is a part of sixteen parts of the circumference of the Moon. The circumference of Jupiter is three quarters of the circumference of Venus. The circumference of each of Saturn and Mars is three quarters of the circumference of Jupiter. The circumference of Mercury is three quarters of the circumference of Mars. Likewise it is in "Vayu Purana". As for the fixed stars, in both of them is that the circumference of the great fixed stars is equal to the circumference of Mercury. That which is smaller than that is five hundred Yojanas. Then they decrease by a hundred until they reach two hundred; there is not among them smaller than a hundred and fifty. This is what is in Vayu Purana. As for in Matsya Purana, it was said: Then they decrease by a hundred until they reach the hundred, and there is not among them less than half a Yojana. I suspect this from the side of the copy. The author of "Vishnu Dharma" said, narrating from "Markandeya": That "Abhijit", Vega, and "Ardra", Sirius, and "Rohini", Aldebaran, and "Punarvasu", the heads of Gemini, and "Pushya", and "Revati", and "Agastya" «2», which is Canopus, and the Great Bear, and the owner of "Vayu" (Svati?), and the owner of "Ahirbudhnya" (Uttara Bhadrapada?), and the owner of "Vasishtha" (Mizar?): each one is five Yojanas. The rest are each one four Yojanas. I do not know what is not counted after them; they are from below four Yojanas to two Krohs, meaning two miles. What falls short of two Krohs people do not see; rather "Dev" sees it. I found...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...an opinion for them on the magnitudes of the planets not attributed to a known human, which is: That each of the diameters of the two luminaries is sixty-seven Yojanas, the Head a hundred, Venus ten, Jupiter nine, Saturn eight, Mars seven, and Mercury six. This is what we found of their confusions in this chapter. Let us turn away from them to the opinions of the astrologers among them. There is no disagreement between us and them in the order of the planets, that the Sun is their middle, Saturn and the Moon their ends, and the fixed stars their highest. A part of it has passed during the preceding narrations. "Varahamihira" said in the book "Samhita" «1»: The Moon is always below the Sun. It «2» casts its ray upon it and illuminates half its body, and the other half remains dark possessing a shadow, like the jar if you set it up to the eye of the sun, until it illuminates its half facing the sun and the half which does not face it remains dark. The Moon is watery in origin; therefore it reflects the ray falling on it as water and the mirror reflect it to the wall. If the Moon is with the Sun, the whiteness is from it to it, and the blackness to us. Then the whiteness descends towards us little by little according to the distance of the Moon from the Sun. Everyone who has an outcome from the owners of their reports, let alone the astrologers, sees that the Moon is below the Sun, indeed below all planets. What fell to us of their reports about the distances of the planets is what Ya'qub bin Tariq mentioned in his book on "The Composition of the Spheres": He benefited them from the Indian in the year one hundred and sixty-one of the Hijra (777/778 AD). He codified a principle in it which is: That the finger (digit) is six barleycorns arranged in width, the cubit twenty-four fingers, and the Farsakh sixteen thousand cubits. But the Indians do not know the Farsakh; this magnitude as we presented is half a "Yojana". Then he mentioned: That the Farsakhs of the diameter of the earth are 2,100 and its circumference 6,596 «3» and 9 of 25. Upon it he calculated the distances as we established in the table. What he mentioned of the magnitude of the earth is not agreed upon by the Indians, for its diameter according to "Paulisa" in Yojanas is 1,600 and its circumference...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...5026 and 14 out of 25. According to "Brahmagupta" it is 1581 and its circumference is 5000. If these numbers are doubled, they should equal what Yaqub mentioned, but they do not equal it. However, the cubit and mile are agreed upon between us and the Indians. The miles of its radius according to our finding are 3284. If we take for every three miles, as is customary in our lands, a parasang, it would be 6728. If we take for every sixteen thousand cubits a parasang as Yaqub mentioned, it would be 5046. If we take for every thirty-two thousand cubits a Yojana, it would be 2523. In this table is what is in the book of Yaqub: [Table] 1 2 3 4 5 1 2 3 4

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: This is an opinion contrary to what "Ptolemy" based the matter of distances on in "The Book of Hypotheses" (Planetary Hypotheses), and the ancients and moderns followed him in it. For their principle in them is that the furthest distance (apogee) of every planet is the nearest distance (perigee) of the one above it, and there is no place between their two spheres idle from action. In this opinion (of the Indians), there would be between the two spheres a place empty of them containing a holder like an axis upon which rotation occurs. It is as if they believed in the Ether some heaviness so that a holder was needed for the inner sphere to hold it in the middle of the outer one. Among what is known among the people of the art (astronomers) is that there is no way to distinguish the higher of two planets from the lower except by way of Occultation or by way of the increase of Parallax. As for Occultation, it happens rarely. As for Parallax, it is imperceptible in other than the Moon. However, the Indians went in that to the equality of motions and difference of distances. So the cause of the slowness of the higher became the wideness of its sphere and the speed of the lower the narrowness of its sphere. Thus, a minute in the sphere of Saturn is two hundred and sixty-two times a minute in the sphere of the Moon. Therefore, the time of traversing them differed despite the equality of the two motions. Then I did not see any speech in this chapter except what comes amidst the books mentioning corrupt numbers in them, like the answer of "Paulisa" to one who objects to him for making the circumference of the sphere of every planet twenty-one thousand and six hundred and its radius three thousand four hundred and thirty-eight, while "Varahamihira" says regarding the distance of the sun that it is 2,598,900 and regarding the distance of the fixed stars that it is 321,362,683. That the first is in minutes and the latter in Yojanas, along with his saying that the distance of the fixed stars is sixty times the distance of the sun. It should have been that the distance of the fixed stars is 155,934,000. As for the method we pointed to from their side, it is built on a principle unknown to me according to what I knew until Allah facilitates the translation of their books. That principle is that the area of a minute in the sphere of the Moon is fifteen Yojanas.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: However "Balabhadra" explained it, its reality did not become clear. That is because he said: The time of the moon's passing over the horizon, I mean from the shining of the beginning of its body to the rising of all of it, or from the beginning of its setting to the completion of its disappearance, was observed and found to be in thirty-two minutes of the rotation of the sphere (daily rotation), although observing degrees is difficult let alone minutes. So the "Yojana" of the diameter of its body was observed and found to be 480. It was divided by the minutes of its body, and the share of a minute came out as fifteen Yojanas. That was multiplied by the minutes of the circle (360 degrees x 60), and 324,000 gathered. This is the area (circumference) of the sphere of the Moon in Yojanas which it traverses in every cycle. If it is multiplied by its cycles in a "Kalpa" or "Chaturyuga", what it traverses of it in it gathers. That according to "Brahmagupta" in the duration of a Kalpa is 18,712,069,200,000,000. He calls it "Yojanas of the sphere of the Zodiac". It is known that if they are divided by the cycles of every planet in a Kalpa, the Yojanas of one cycle come out. But the motion of the planets according to them, as we said, is one in distance. So the output is the area (circumference) of the sphere of that planet. And because the ratio of the diameter to the circumference according to him is approximately the ratio of 12,959 to 40,980, if the area (circumference) of the planet's sphere is multiplied by 12,959 and the amount divided by 81,960 (should be 40980?), the radius comes out, which is its distance from the center of the earth. text: Just as the existing minutes of the Moon's diameter related to 21600, which are the minutes of the Circle, according to the ratio of its share of "Yojanas", which is 480, to the Yojanas of the whole cycle of its sphere, likewise it was done for the existing minutes of the Sun's diameter. Its Yojanas according to "Brahmagupta" were 6522 and according to "Paulisa" 6480. When Paulisa obtained the minutes of the Moon's body as 32, which is an even number (power of 2), he divided it for the planets by halving down to one. It is as if he admired the order, otherwise the diameter of Venus is not half the diameter of the Moon in vision, nor Mars a quarter of its eighth. As for the calculation of the two bodies of the luminaries at every time according to their distance from the earth, which is the Modified Diameter obtained in the two operations of their rectification (equation): Let AB be the diameter of the Sun's body, GD the diameter of the Earth, and GDH the shadow cone, with its axis HL. These two numbers are the product of the "Yojanas" of the diameters of the two luminaries by 3438, which are the minutes of the Total Sine. Likewise "Brahmagupta" said: Multiply the Yojanas of the Luminary by 3416, which are the minutes of the Total Sine, and divide what results by the Yojanas of the radius of its sphere. text: LVI. On the Lunar Mansions (Nakshatras). The derivation of the Mansions according to them is in reality like the derivation of the Zodiac Signs in dividing the Zodiac belt by them into twenty-seven equal parts, like its division in the Signs into twelve equal parts. The share of each Mansion in degrees is thirteen and a third, and in minutes eight hundred. The planetary stars enter them and exit from them and oscillate in latitude to their north and south. Each Mansion is specialized from the side of the art of astrology with what the Signs are specialized with of description, nature, indication, and property. The derivation of this number is that the Moon traverses the entire belt in twenty-seven days and a third of a day deserving cancellation. Just as the derivation of the number with the Arabs is from the first western visibility (New Moon) to the last eastern visibility. Its method is to add the motion of the Sun in the lunar month to the cycle, and subtract from the total the motion of the Moon for the two days specific to the waning (darkness), and divide the remainder by the motion of the Moon for a day. Twenty-seven comes out, and a fraction more than thirty (meaning 27 and a fraction), which deserves rounding. But the Arabs are an illiterate people who do not write or calculate. They rely only on counting and eyesight, as they know nothing but visibility and do not define the Mansions except by the stars that are in them of the fixed ones. When the Indians sought the like of that definition, they agreed with the Arabs in some stars and differed with them in some. Although the Arabs do not stray far from...

text: ...the paths of the Moon and do not use of the fixed stars except what the Moon conjoins or approaches. The Indians do not adhere to this condition, but they consider alignment and opposition (zenith/nadir?) in it. Then they include the Falling Vulture (Vega/Abhijit) in the total, so the number becomes twenty-eight with it. For this reason, our astronomers and authors of books on 'Anwa' (weather stars) were deluded in this meaning and mentioned that the Mansions according to the Indians are twenty-eight and that they dropped one which is always hidden by the rays of the Sun. As if they heard the Indians naming the Mansion in which the Sun is "Burnt" (Combust), and the one it left "Separated after embrace", and the one before it "Smoking". Some of our companions stated the dropping of Al-Zubana (Libra scales), then explained it by the matter of the Burnt Path (Via Combusta) in the end of Libra and beginning of Scorpio. All of that from them is a conjecture that the Mansions according to the Indians are twenty-eight then dropping attaches to them. It is not so; rather, they are twenty-seven then addition attaches to them. "Brahmagupta" narrated that in the book "Veda" from those who inhabit Mount "Meru", that they see two suns and two moons and the Mansions are fifty-four, and the days also double for them. Then he started contradicting it by saying that we do not see the fish of the Pole rotating twice a day but once. As for me, tricks exhausted me in directing a face for this false proposition. As for knowing the position of a planet or an assumed degree from the Mansions, it is: To make its distance from the beginning of Aries all minutes and divide by eight hundred. Complete Mansions preceding the one it is in come out. The remainder is what it traversed of the broken Mansion. Either relate it to the eight hundred as they are, or folded (simplified) by agreement, or raise the minutes to degrees, or multiply by sixty and divide the sum by eight hundred to get what it traversed of it assuming the Mansion is one divided by sixty. All of these cover the Moon and planets and others. Then the Moon is specialized by dividing the product of the remainder by sixty by its Bhukti (daily motion), so what passed of the Mansion Day comes out. The Indians in the matter of fixed stars are of little yield. I did not find among them anyone who knows the stars of the Mansions by sight and points to them with fingers. I strove the utmost striving in acquiring most of that by measurements...

As for the Indians' lack of guidance to the motion of the fixed stars, a sufficient witness to it is the saying of "Varahamihira" in "Samhita": That it was mentioned in the books of the ancients that the summer solstice was in the half of "Ashlesha" and the winter one in the beginning of "Dhanishta". That was correct at that time. As for now, the summer one of the solstices is in the beginning of Cancer and the winter one in the beginning of Capricorn. If anyone doubts that and claims it is as the ancients mentioned not what we mentioned, let him go out to a level place where he guesses the approach of the summer solstice. Let him draw a circle in it and set up at its center a gnomon standing perpendicular to the horizon. Let him mark the tip of its shadow until it meets the circumference of the circle on one of the eastern and western sides. Let him return the next day around the like of that yesterday's time and observe like he observed first. If he finds the tip of the shadow in the line deviating from the first mark towards the south, let him know that the sun has moved towards the north and has not turned yet. If he finds it deviating towards the north, he knows that the sun has moved towards the south and has turned. If he observes that constantly and determines the day of the solstice, he will verify what we mentioned. This is proof from "Varahamihira" that he did not know that the fixed stars have a motion towards the east. So he made them (fixed) like their name and moved the solstice towards the west. Because of this imagination, he mixed the two matters in the Mansions. Let us distinguish between them so the doubt is removed and the speech refined. That is that the Zodiac Signs, if started from half of the sixth of the belt which is from the intersection towards the north following the second motion, the summer solstice is always at the head of the fourth Sign, and the winter one at the head of the tenth Sign. In the Mansions, if started with a third of a ninth of the belt which is from the beginning of the first Sign, the summer solstice is at three quarters of the seventh Mansion always and the winter one at a quarter of the twenty-first Mansion. That does not change throughout the duration of the world. However, if the Mansions are marked by stars and named with names following the stars, they must transfer with them. The stars of the Signs and Mansions were in the divisions before them in past times, then transferred to these...

text: LVII. On the Appearance of Stars from under the Rays and Mention of Their Laws and Customs Regarding It. As for their operation regarding the visibility of planets and the crescent, it is what the Zijes of Sindhind among us contain. They call the degrees assumed for the necessity of visibility "Kalamsa". According to what the author of "Ghurrat al-Zijat" mentioned: As for Canopus, Sirius, Vega, Capella, the two Simaks (Arcturus and Spica), and Antares, it is thirteen degrees. But for Botein, Heka, Praesepe, "Ashlesha", "Shatabhisha", and "Revati", it is twenty degrees. For the rest, fourteen degrees. Thus the matter regarding them is divided into three limits. It occurs to the imagination from them that the first limit is restricted to the stars counted by the Greeks in the first and second magnitude; the middle limit to those counted in the third and fourth magnitude; and the last limit to those counted in the fifth and sixth magnitude. This detailing was more worthy of Brahmagupta in his correction "Khandakhadyaka", but he did not do it. Rather, he generalized and made the degrees of visibility for all Mansions fourteen degrees. "Vijayanandi" said: There are stars which the rays do not hide nor does the sun strike them, and they are Capella, Arcturus, the two Vultures (Vega and Altair), "Dhanishta", and "Uttara Bhadrapada". That is due to their great latitude in the north along with the great latitude of the lands (high geographic latitude). For in what is more penetrating (further north), they are seen at both ends of the single night itself and do not...
