text: ...disappear. They have methods regarding the rising of "Agastya", I mean Canopus. They see it when the sun enters the Mansion of "Hasta" and its setting when it enters the Mansion of "Rohini". "Paulisa" said: Double the sun's apogee; when the sun's true longitude equals it, it is the time of its disappearance. The sun's apogee according to him is two Signs and two-thirds of a Sign (80 degrees). Its double falls in the third of Virgo, which is the beginning of the Mansion Hasta. Half the apogee is in the third of Taurus, which is the beginning of the Mansion Rohini. As for "Brahmagupta", he claimed in the correction of Khandakhadyaka that the position of Canopus is in twenty-seven degrees of Gemini and its latitude in the south is seventy-one degrees, and its degrees of visibility are twelve. The position of "Mrigavyadha", which is Sirius, is in twenty-six degrees of Gemini and its latitude in the south is forty degrees, and its degrees of visibility are thirteen. If you want the time of their rising, assume the sun is in the position of the star, and the past of the day is its degrees of visibility. Set up the Ascendant on that. When the sun obtains the degree of this Ascendant, the star is seen at its first visibility. To know the time of its setting, add six Signs to the degree of the star, subtract from the sum its degrees of visibility, and set up the Ascendant on what remains. If the sun enters its degree, it is the time of its setting. In "Samhita", there is mention of sacrifices and customs performed at the rising of some stars. We recount them according to our translation fulfilling the condition of exhausting the stories in their manner. "Varahamihira" said: When the sun rose in the past and aligned with the lofty Mount "Vindhya" in its passage, it resented its height, and pride incited it to rise towards it to prevent it from its intent and hold back its wheel from passing over it. So it rose until it neared Paradise and the dwellings of the "Vidyadhara" spirits. They rushed to it for its pleasantness and the beauty of its gardens and meadows and settled it joyfully, their women frequenting it and their children playing. Until when the wind blew on the garments of their white daughters, they moved like fluttering flags. Beasts and lions are seen in its ravines, black in color from the abundance of the animal called "Bhramara" (Large Black Bee) and its gathering upon them longing for what their bodies were stained with upon rubbing with the stained claws, intoxicating the rutting elephants that engaged them. You see monkeys and bears ascending its peaks and high folds as if intending the sky in...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...their feeding. And you see ascetics in its thickets limiting themselves to feeding on its fruits, with glories belonging to it that escape counting. When "Agastya son of Varuna", that is Canopus son of Water, saw that action of the mountain, he offered it companionship in what it aimed for and asked it to stay and wait until he returns to it, thus diverting it by that from what it was intent on. He turned to the sea swallowing its water until it receded and the foothills of Mount Vindhya appeared. "Makara" (sea monsters) and water animals clung to it scratching it until they notched it with pits and pierced it with furrows in which gems and pearls remained. So it was adorned by them and by the trees protruding on its skirts and snakes moving twistingly on its face. By Canopus wronging it, it was compensated with what it gained of adornment from which the angels benefited for the examples of their crowns and wreaths. Just as the sea was compensated by the drying of its water with the beauty of the shining of fish when they move in it, the appearance of gems in its bottom, and the movement of snakes and elephants in its remaining water. If fish, conch, and shell rise on it, you would think it ponds whose water surface is covered by white lotus in the sixth of "Sharad", the Autumn season. You could hardly distinguish between it and the sky due to the adornment of the sea with gems like the adornment of the sky with stars, the resemblance of the multi-headed snakes to the threads of rays emanating from the sun, and the likeness of the crystal in it to the body of the moon and the white vapor which the clouds of the sky surmount. How can I not praise him who did this great deed, alerted the angels to the beauty of crowns, and made the sea and Mount "Vindhya" a treasury for them! That is Canopus by whom the water is purified from the earthy dirts mixing with it, like the purification of the heart of the righteous man from what overcame it in the company of the wicked. Whenever he rose and water decreased in rivers and valleys in his time, you saw rivers offering to the moon what is on the water surface of types of white and red lotus and blue lotus, and types of ducks and flamingos swimming in it as an offering to him, like the young girl offers flowers and gifts upon her entry. The standing of pairs of red flamingos on the two banks and the movement of white ducks in the middle making noise was likened only to the lips of a beautiful woman whose teeth appeared in a laugh of joy. Indeed, the indigo blue lotus between its white and the rushing of...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ..."Bhramara" upon it out of eagerness for its fragrant scent was likened only to the black of her pupil between the white of the eye moving with coquetry and dalliance, surrounded by the hair of the eyebrow. If you saw the ponds then, the moonlight shining upon them illuminating their stagnant water, and what had closed upon Bhramara of their white lotus opening, you would think them the face of a beautiful woman looking with a black eye from a white eyeball. If the flood coming from the torrents of "Varsha-kala" (Rainy Season) had flowed to them with snakes, poisons, and filth, the rising of Canopus upon them purifies them from impurity and saves them from harm. If the thought of mentioning Canopus at the door of a human is erasing of his sins necessitating punishment, then the loosening of the tongue in praising him is more effective in removing burdens and earning reward! The early Rishis mentioned what offering is obligatory at the rising of Canopus. I present the kings with its story and make it an offering to him. I say: His rising is at the time when some light of the sun appears from the East and the darkness of the night gathers in the West. His first appearance is difficult to perceive; not every observer is guided to it. Ask the astrologer at that time about the direction of his rising. Present the offering called "Arghya" to that direction. Spread on the ground what agrees of fragrant flowers and aromatic plants according to that spot. Throw upon it what appears to you of gold, clothes, and sea gems. Present incense, saffron, sandalwood, musk, and camphor with a bull, a cow, much food, and sweets. Know that whoever does that for seven consecutive years with good intention, strong belief, and trust will possess after that all the earth and the sea surrounding it from the four directions if he is a "Kshatriya". If he is a "Brahmin", he attains his desire, learns the "Veda", possesses a beautiful wife, and is blessed with noble children from her. If he is a "Vaisya", he obtains many lands and acquires a great chieftainship. If he is a "Sudra", he obtains wealth. Then health, security, disappearance of afflictions, and attainment of reward encompass all of them. This is what was mentioned of the offering of Canopus. As for the judgments of "Rohini", "Varahamihira" said in it that "Garga", "Vasistha", "Kasyapa", and "Parashara" told their students that Mount "Meru" is built of plates of gold. It has appeared...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...from between them trees of many blossoms and lights, pleasant scents. "Bhramara" circles them always with a hum pleasant to hear. The harlots of "Deva" frequent it with enchanting songs, distracting amusements, and constant joy. This mountain is in the wilderness of "Nandana Vana", which is the garden of Paradise. They said: Jupiter was in it once, so "Narada" the Rishi asked him about the judgments of "Rohini" until he explained them to him. I recount them as is their duty. Look in the black days of the month "Ashadha" until the moon reaches Rohini. Seek in the direction of the North from the town or in its East a high place. The Brahmin entrusted with the houses of kings should go to it. He lights a fire in it and depicts the planets and Mansions around it with their colors. He performs the duty of reading what is for each one of them, giving it its share of flowers, barley, and oil, and pleasing it by throwing them into the fire. Let there be around it in the four directions what is possible of gems and jars filled with the sweetest waters, and what exists at that time of fruits, medicines, tree branches, and plant roots. Grass cut with a sickle is spread there for sleeping. Then he gathers types of seeds and grains, washes them with water, places gold in their middle, deposits them in a jar, and puts it aside. He performs "Homa", which is throwing barley and oil into the fire while reading passages from "Veda" attributed to directions, which are "Varuna Mantra", "Vayavya Mantra", and "Saumya Mantra". He sets up a "Danda", which is a long high spear, hanging from its head two streamers, one equal to the spear and the second like three times its double. Let him do all of that before the moon reaches "Rohini" so that when it reaches it, he is free to estimate the times of the wind blowing and the directions of its blowing. That is known from the streamers of the spear. If the wind blows on that day from the hearts of the four directions, its matter is praised. If it blows from between them, it is blamed. Its steadiness on one direction with strength without variation is also praised. The time of its blowing is estimated by eighths of the day, and for each...

text: ...eighth, half a month is assigned. Then when the moon exits the Mansion of Rohini, he looks at the seeds placed aside. Whatever of them sprouts is what thrives in that year. He looks into the day of its approaching Rohini. If the sky is clear and no corruption befalls it, and the wind is pure not stirring up dust that harms, and the origins of beasts and birds are good, it is praised. He contemplates the cloud. If it ripples like the branches of the Banyan (?) and the flash of lightning appears from it to the eye, and it opens like the opening of the white lotus and surrounds it like the sun's rays, and is colored the color of Kohl or "Bhramara" or saffron, or the sky is covered with clouds and lightning flashes through them like gold, and a rainbow circles colored like the redness of twilight and colors like the bride's clothes, and the thunder rumbles like the crying peacock or the bird that cannot drink water except from the falling rain so it cries out of joy for it as frogs rejoice at the fullness of pools so they increase in croaking, and you saw the disturbance of the sky like the disturbance of elephants and buffaloes in the thicket if fire ignites in its edges, and the clouds moved like the movement of the elephant's limbs and glistened like the glistening of pearls, conch, and snow, indeed the moonlight as if it lent them brilliance and luster, that indicates the abundance of rain and relief by fertility. He said: It is disliked at the time the Brahmin is sitting amidst the water jars the falling of stars (shooting stars), the flashing of lightning and thunderbolts, redness in the atmosphere, tremor, earthquake, falling of hail, and the crying of beasts. If water decreases from a jar in the direction of the North either by itself or by a hole or leakage, rain is lacking in the month of "Sravana". If it decreases from a jar in the direction of the East, it is lacking in "Bhadrapada". From a southern jar in "Asvayuja". From a western one in "Kartika". If nothing decreases from them, the summer rain is complete. Likewise, evidence is taken from the jars regarding the castes. The North jar is for Brahmins, the East jar for Kshatriyas, the South jar for Vaisyas, and the West jar for Sudras. If names of people and conditions are written on the jars, evidence is taken regarding them by what happens in them of breakage and decrease. As for the judgments of "Svati" and "Ashadha", they are like the example of the judgments of "Rohini". In the white days...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...of the month "Ashadha", if the moon is in one of the two Ashadhas, I mean "Purva" and "Uttara", choose a place as you chose for Rohini and take a balance of gold, which is best. If it is of silver, it is medium. If not, make it of wood they call "Khadira", and it seems like teak(?), or from an iron arrowhead with which a human was killed. The smallest amount in the length of its beam is a span. Whatever increases upon it is better, and what decreases from it is not praised. Its strings are four, each one ten fingers. Its two pans are of linen with the magnitude of six fingers. Its weights are of gold. Weigh with them equal amounts of each of well water, pond water, river water, elephant tusks, beast hair, pieces of gold with names of kings on them, and pieces of wax with names of other people, animals, years, days, directions, or kingdoms on them. Face the East in weighing. Place the weight in the right pan and the weighed items in the left. While you recite over them and say to the balance: You are the straight one, you are "Deva" and the wife of Deva, and you are "Sarasvati daughter of Brahma" manifesting truth and honesty. You are more correct than straightness itself. You are like the sun and stars in their passage from East to West on one mode. By you the order of the world is straightened, and in you is gathered what all angels and Brahmins have of honesty and correctness. You are the daughter of Brahma and your household is "Kasyapa". Let this weighing be in the evening. Then put them aside and repeat their weighing in the morning. Whatever increased in weight is thriving and fortunate in that year, and what decreased is bad and unfortunate. Do not limit yourself with this weighing without doing it in "Rohini" and in "Svati". If the year is "Adhimasa" and the weighing happens in the repeated month, repeat the operation in it. If their judgments agree, then so be it; otherwise, take what Rohini requires, for it is predominant.

text: LVIII. On the Tides Occurring Successively on the Waters of the Sea. As for the reason for the sea water remaining as it is, it is said in "Matsya Purana": That sixteen mountains in ancient times had wings with which they flew and rose. The rays of "Indra" the Chief burned them until they fell around the sea clipped of wings, four in every direction. The Eastern ones: "Rishabha, Valahaka, Chakra, Mainaka". The Northern ones: "Chandra, Kanka, Drona, Suma". The Western ones: "Vakra, Vadhra, Narada, Parvata". The Southern ones: "Jimuta, Dravina, Mainaka, Mahasaila". Between the third and fourth of the Eastern mountains is the fire "Samvartaka" which drinks the sea water. Were it not for that, it would have filled up due to the constant pouring of rivers into it. They said: It is the fire of a king they had named "Aurva". It is that he inherited the kingdom from his father who was killed while he was a fetus. When he was born and grew up and heard the news of his father, he became angry at the angels and drew his sword to kill them because of their neglect in preserving the world despite people worshipping them and drawing near to him (them?). They pleaded with him and placated him until he refrained. He said to them: So what should I do with the fire of my anger? They advised him to throw it into the sea, and it is the one that drinks its water. They also said: The water of rivers does not increase in the seas because Indra the Chief takes them with the cloud and sends them as rains. It is also said in Matsya Purana: That the dark spot called "Shashalakshana", meaning the image of the hare, is the reflection of the images of the sixteen mentioned mountains by the moon's light onto its body. In the book "Vishnu Dharma": The moon is called "Shashalakshana" because the sphere of its body is watery accepting the image of the earth as a mirror accepts it. In the earth are mountains and trees...

text: ...of varying shapes, from which the image of a hare is formed in it. It is also called "Mrigalanchana", meaning the mark of the deer, because a group likened the dark spot in its face to the image of a deer. They said regarding the Lunar Mansions that they are the daughters of "Prajapati" and that the moon married them. Then he became fond of Rohini among them and preferred her over them. Jealousy drove her sisters to complain about him to their father. He strove with him to treat them equally and admonished him, but it did not work on him. Then he cursed him until his face became leprous. The moon regretted his deed and came to him repenting for his sin. Prajapati said to him: My word is one, there is no return in it. But I will cover your disgrace for half of every month. The moon said: So the past sin, how will its trace be erased from me? He said: By setting up the image of "Linga Mahadeva" as an object of service for you. He did so. It is the stone of "Somnath". "Soma" is the moon and "Natha" is the master, so it is "The Master of the Moon". Prince Mahmud (of Ghazni), may Allah be pleased with him, uprooted it in the year four hundred and sixteen Hijri. He broke its top and carried it with its gold covering encrusted and crowned with gems to his residence in Ghazni. Part of it is thrown in its hippodrome with "Chakrasvamin", the copper idol carried from "Thanesar", and part of it is at the door of its congregational mosque for feet to wipe dust and wetness on it. As for Linga, it is the image of the penis of Mahadeva. I heard regarding its cause: That a Rishi saw him with his wife and thought ill of him and prayed against him to lose his penis. It separated from him and fell off immediately. Then he established signs of his innocence with that Rishi and verified them with proofs, until what he harbored in his heart was removed. He said: I will compensate you by making the image of the organ that separated from you verified among people, used as a means and approached. "Varahamihira" mentioned regarding its making: After choosing the stone for it free from defects, the length intended to be made for it is taken. It is divided into thirds. The bottom third of it is squared as if it is a cube or square cylinder. The middle third is octagonalized by removing its four corners. The top third is rounded and its head rounded off until it becomes like the glans. In setting it up, the square third of it is placed in the belly of the earth. For the octagonal third, a cover called "Pinda" is made, square on its outside matching the squareness of what entered the earth from it, and the octagon of the inside fits the middle third protruding from the earth. The round part remains outside the cover. Then...

text: ...he said making this round part small or thin corrupts the land and manifests evil in the people of the regions who made it. A little depression in it or protrusion from it sickens them. If it is hit during manufacture by a peg, the chief and his household perish. If it is bumped on the way of carrying it and the bump leaves a mark on it, its maker perishes and corruption and diseases spread in that land. In the southwestern lands from the lands of Sindh, this image abounds in the houses designated for their worship. However, "Somnath" was the most venerated of them. A jar of Ganges water and a basket of Kashmir flowers were carried to it every day. Their belief in it is that it heals chronic illnesses and cures every incurable disease that has no medicine. It became famous because it is a harbor for travelers in the sea and a station for those going back and forth between Sofala of the Zanj and China. As for the matter of tides in this sea: Tide in their language is "Bharana" and Ebb is "Uhara". They believe, as for their commoners, that in the sea is a fire named "Vadavanala" constantly breathing. The tide is from its inhaling breath and swelling with wind, and the ebb is from its exhaling breath and the disappearance of swelling from it. Like what "Mani" believed when he heard from them that there is a demon in the sea whose breathing in and out causes the tide and ebb. As for their elite, they know them in the day by the rising and setting of the moon and in the month by the increase and decrease of its light, even if they are not guided to the natural cause in them. They attached the name of the moon to "Somnath" because this stone was set up on the coast west of the mouth of the river "Saraswati" in the sea by less than a third of a mile and east of the place of the golden fortress "Baroi" (?) which appeared to Basudeva until he inhabited it, and near his killing place and the killing places of his tribe and the place of their burning. Whenever the moon rose and set, the sea water rose by the tide and drowned it (the Linga). When it reached the meridian of noon and night, it receded by the ebb and revealed it. So it was as if the moon was diligent in serving and washing it. Therefore, it was attributed to it. As for the fortress built around it and around its treasures, it is not ancient but was made nearly a hundred years ago. It is mentioned in "Vishnu Purana": That the maximum...

text: ...height of the tide water is one thousand five hundred fingers. That is much, for if the depth and middle of the water rise by sixty-some cubits, it covers the shore and the feet from it more than what is observed. Yet it is not so far from existence that it enters into impossibility. As for the appearance of the fortress from the water, it is not strange in that sea. That is because the Maldives islands on this example originate and protrude from the water like a gathered sand dune, and increase in height and expanse and remain for a time. Then old age afflicts them, so they dissolve from cohesion and spread in the water like a melting thing and disappear. The people of those islands move from the old island whose corruption appeared to the young fresh one whose time of appearance is near. They move coconut palms to it and inhabit and dwell in it. The attribution of the fortress also to gold is possible to be a conventional name, and possible to be a true description, for the islands of the Zanj are called "The Land of Gold" because much gold settles in the washing of little soil from it.

text: LIX. On the Mention of the Solar and Lunar Eclipses. As for the fact that the eclipsing agent of the moon is the earth's shadow and the eclipsing agent of the sun is the moon, their astrologers have verified it and built their calculations in the Zijes and others upon it. "Varahamihira" said in the book "Samhita": That some scholars claimed that the Head (Rahu) was among the "Daityas" and his mother was "Simhika". That the angels when they extracted Amrita from the sea asked "Vishnu" to distribute it among them. He did so. The Head came resembling the angels in form and entered among them. When Vishnu handed him the share of Amrita, he took it and drank it. Vishnu knew his matter, so he struck him with the round Chakra and severed his head. The head remained alive because of the Amrita in the mouth, and the body died as it had not reached it nor had its power spread in it. The Head pleaded saying: For what sin was this done to me? So he was compensated by being raised to the sky and made one of its inhabitants. Some of them said that the Head has a body like the two luminaries except that it is black and dark, so it is not seen in the sky. "Brahma", the First Father, ordered him not to appear in the sky at all except at the time of the eclipse. Some said that it has a head like a snake's head and a tail like its tail. Others said that it has no body other than this blackness that is seen. When "Varahamihira" finished recounting the myths, he said: If the Head had a body, its action would be by contact, yet we find it eclipsing at a distance when there are six Signs between it and the moon. It does not...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...increase its motion or decrease so that that (contact) could be imagined from its self reaching the place of the moon's eclipse. If a goer goes to that by committing (an error), let him inform why cycles were made for its motion and why they were correct with its uniformity. If a snake with a head and tail is imagined in it, why does it not eclipse in what is less than six Signs or more? And its body is there present between its head and tail and they are connected by it. So it does not eclipse anything of the two luminaries nor of the stars of the Mansions unless they are two heads opposite eclipsing. If it were so, then the moon rose eclipsed by one of them, the sun must set eclipsed by the other. Likewise, if the moon set eclipsed, the sun rose eclipsed. None of that exists as such. So the lunar eclipse, according to what the scholars supported by Allah mentioned, is its entry into the shadow, and the solar eclipse is the moon covering it from us. For this reason, the beginning of the eclipse in the moon is not from the west side nor in the sun from the east side. An elongated shadow may extend from the earth like the extension of a tree's shadow, for example. If the moon's latitude is little while it is in the seventh Sign from the sun and its magnitude in north or south is not much, it enters the earth's shadow and is eclipsed by it. The first contact is from the east side. As for the sun, the moon comes to it from the west side and covers it like a piece of cloud covers it. The amount of covering differs in locations. Because the coverer of the moon is large, its light vanishes when half of it is eclipsed, and the coverer of the sun is not large, therefore it has strong rays with the eclipse. The entity of the Head has no entry in the eclipse itself. On this is the agreement of scholars in their books. When "Varahamihira" finished describing the quiddity of the two eclipses according to his knowledge, he was pained by those ignorant of them and said: But the common people multiply riot in attributing the eclipse to the Head and say were it not for the appearance of the Head and its undertaking of the eclipse, the Brahmins would not perform a mandatory washing then. Varahamihira said: The reason for that is that the Head, when it pleaded at the cutting, "Brahma" allotted him a share of the Brahmins' offering to the fire at the time of the eclipse. So he approaches the place of...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...the eclipse seeking his share. Therefore, people's mention of him abounds then, and they attribute the eclipse to him, while he has nothing to do with it from his side; rather, it is from the alignment of the moon's path or its deviation. This from Varahamihira, along with the preceding evidences of his verification of the configuration of the world, is denounced, were it not that he humors the Brahmins sometimes, for he is one of them and must be of their group. Then he is not blamed given the firmness of his foot on the truth and his declaration of it, like what we recounted about him also regarding the nature of "Sandhi". Would that all virtuous men imitate him! But look at "Brahmagupta", and he is the best of this class among them. Since he was of the Brahmins who read from their Puranas the lowness of the sun below the moon, they need a Head to bite the sun to eclipse it. He rejected the truth and supported falsehood, even if it is possible that he was mocking or compelled like one fainting from death due to intense indignation with them. This is his speech in the first treatise of "Brahmasiddhanta": That some people view that the eclipse is not from the Head. That is an impossible opinion, for he is the eclipsing one, and the majority of the people of the world say that the Head is the one who eclipses. In "Veda", which is the word of Allah from the mouth of "Brahma", that the Head eclipses. Likewise it is in the book "Smriti" which "Manu" made, and in "Samhita" which "Garga son of Brahma" made. As for "Varahamihira", "Srishena", "Aryabhata", and "Vishnuchandra", they claim that the eclipse is not from the Head but is from the moon and the earth's shadow. This from them is opposition to the majority and hostility to the mentioned speech. For if the Head were not the eclipsing one, what the Brahmins do of anointing with heated oil and other rituals of worship prescribed for the time of the eclipse would be waste with no reward for it. In invalidating that is a departure from consensus, which is not permissible. Manu said in Smriti: If the Head takes one of the luminaries by eclipse, all water on earth becomes pure and becomes like the water of "Ganges" in purity. In Veda: That the Head is the son of a woman from the daughters of "Daitya" named "Simhika". For this reason, what is done of acts of righteousness is done. So it is obligatory on these to leave stubbornness against the majority because all that is in "Veda", "Smriti", and "Samhita" is correct. Since "Brahmagupta" in this place is among those about whom Allah Almighty said: "And they rejected them, while their...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...souls were convinced thereof, out of injustice and haughtiness," we do not argue with him with anything except that we whisper in his ear: If leaving hostility to religious books was obligatory on the people, why did you command people to righteousness and forget yourself? And you began after this speech extracting the magnitude of the moon's diameter to eclipse the sun with it, and the magnitude of the shadow's diameter to eclipse the moon with it? And you calculated their eclipse according to the requirement of the opinion of these opponents, not the opinion of those you saw fit to agree with? Even if the Brahmins are commanded to establish worship or something else at the existence of the eclipse, the eclipse is a time for it, not that the action is for its sake. Just as we were commanded to prayers and forbidden from them at states of the sun and its light made as signs for their times, without the sun having any entry in our worship. Then his saying that the majority are on that, if he means by it the totality of the inhabitants of the Inhabited World, how far he is from tracking it by knowledge or report. The land of India compared to its totality is small and little, and those who differ with the Indians in opinion and religion are more than those who agree with them. If he means by it the majority of Indians, their commoners are more than their elite, and the majority in our revealed books is blameworthy and described with ignorance, doubt, and lack of gratitude. I do not think anything led Brahmagupta to what he said except a branch of Socratic tribulation he was afflicted with despite the abundance of his knowledge and sharpness of his mind with his young age and youthfulness. For he made "Brahmasiddhanta" while he was thirty years old. If this is his excuse, we have accepted it, and peace. As for the mentioned people who should not be opposed, when do they submit to the subject of astronomers regarding the moon eclipsing the sun when they have placed it in their Puranas above the sun, and the higher does not cover the lower from who is lower than both. So they needed a grabber of the two luminaries like the fish grabbing the loaf and shaping it with the shape of the eclipsed one of them. No nation is devoid of ignorant people and leaders for them who are more ignorant 'bearing their burdens and burdens with their burdens' and increasing their minds in rust to their rust. Then among the wonders is what "Varahamihira" narrated from the ancients...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...whose pardon is obligatory if differing from them is not obligatory, that they used to infer the occurrence of the eclipse by pouring a small amount of water with the like of it of oil in a wide flat-bottomed vessel on the eighth day of the lunar days, and observing the places of the oil's gathering and separation. They used to attribute the beginning of the eclipse to the gathered and its end to the place of separation. He narrated from some that they thought the cause of the eclipse was the conjunction of the wandering planets, and that some of them used to infer its occurrence from the occurrences of misfortunes which are meteors, shooting stars, halo, darkness, storms, tremors, and earthquakes. He said: These things do not always happen with the eclipse nor are they the cause of its occurrence, but they share with it in the nature of misfortune. The path of reason is far from these myths. The man, with his achievement over the nature of his people in mixing mung bean with soup (?) and pearls with dung, said without quoting anyone: If a strong wind blows at the time of the eclipse, the eclipse following it will be after it by six months. If a star shoots (meteor), the eclipse following it will be after twelve months. If the atmosphere becomes dusty, then after eighteen months. If the earth quakes, then after twenty-four months. If the air darkens, then after thirty months. If hail falls, then after thirty-six months. I see silence about this as an answer. However, I say that what is in the Zij of Al-Khwarizmi regarding the colors of the eclipse, even if organized in speech, is contrary to witnessing. What the Indians hold of it is more correct and right, which is that the eclipse falling short of half the moon's body is smoke-colored. If it completes half, its color becomes jet black. If it exceeds half, redness mixes with its jet-blackness until if it is complete, it is after that yellow with blondness.

text: LX. On the Mention of "Parva". The limits in which the eclipse is possible and the months between them are fulfilled by demonstration in the sixth treatise of the Almagest. The Indians call the duration between the lunar eclipses that are on the edge of these limits "Parva". This is what is from it in "Samhita". "Varahamihira" said: In every six months is a Parva in which eclipse is possible. Their cycle is on seven, and each one of them has a lord and a judgment which is in this table: [Table]

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: The extraction of the "Parva" you are in according to what is in the Zij "Khandakhadyaka": Place the "Ahargana" made from this Zij in two places. Multiply one of them by fifty and divide the sum by 1296 and round up its fraction if it does not fall short of half. Add 1063 to the result and the sum to the other place. Then divide the amount by 180. What comes out of integers is the complete Parvas. Cast away sevens; what remains is not more, so count from their first which is for Brahma. What remains of the division less than 180 is the past of the "Parva" you are in. Subtract it from one hundred and eighty. If less than fifteen remains, a lunar eclipse is possible then necessary. If more remains, it is impossible. On this basis, the past should be considered by its like. It was found in another place: Take "Kalpa Ahargana", I mean what passed of Kalpa days, and subtract from them 96031. Place what remains in two places. Subtract from the lower of them 84 and divide what remains by 561. What comes out subtract it from the upper and divide the remainder by 173. What comes out cast it away, and what remains divide it by seven. The Parva comes out, and their first is "Brahma". There is no agreement between the two operations. It seems something fell from the second operation or was changed by copying. What "Varahamihira" mentioned of the judgments of Parva contradicts what he had of good achievement. That is that he said: If there is no eclipse in the assumed Parva then it occurs in the other cycle, rains are lacking and hunger and killing rise. This, if no oversight occurred from the translator in it, covers every preceding Parva in which there is an eclipse. More amazing than this is his saying: If vision precedes in the eclipse and calculation delays, rain decreases and the sword is drawn. If vision delays and calculation precedes, there is epidemic, death, and corruption in crops, fruits, and aromatic plants. He said: This is among what I found in the books of the ancients so I transmitted it. As for him who masters calculation and perfects it, precedence or delay does not occur in what he calculates. If the sun is eclipsed outside a Parva and becomes dark, know that a king named "Tvashtar" has eclipsed it. This resembles his saying in another place: Whenever...

text: ...the Solstice to the North is before the sun enters Capricorn, the directions of South and West are corrupted. If the Solstice to the South is before its entering the head of Cancer, the directions of East and North are corrupted. If the Solstice coincides with its entering the beginning of these two Signs or is after it, safety encompasses the four directions and righteousness increases in them. The appearances of these sayings resemble the speech of the insane if there are no subtleties behind them we do not know. It is appropriate that we mention after this the lords of times because they are likewise cycles that rotate, and we mention with them what resembles that.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: LXI. On the Lords of Times in Religion and Astrology and What Follows That of Their Likes. Absolute Duration is attributed to the Creator, Glory be to Him, because it is His eternity which is not limited by two ends, and by it is His pre-eternity. Perhaps they represented it with the soul called "Purusha". As for Time counted by movements, its parts are attributed to created beings below the Creator, Glory be to Him, and below the soul. They attributed "Kalpa" to "Brahma" because it is his day or his night and his life is measured by it. Every "Manvantara" has a lord called "Manu", known by a specific description mentioned in its chapter. I did not hear for Chaturyugas nor for Yugas anything resembling that. "Varahamihira" said in the "Great Book of Nativities": That "Abda", which is the Year, belongs to Saturn; "Ayana", its half, to the Sun; "Ritu", its sixth, to Mercury; the "Month" to Jupiter; "Paksha", meaning its half, to Venus; "Vasara", which is the Day, to Mars; and "Muhurta" to the Moon. He mentioned in this book for the sixths of the year: That the first of them from the Winter Solstice is for Saturn, the second for Venus, the third for Mars, the fourth for the Moon, the fifth for Mercury, and the sixth for Jupiter. We have described the lords of hours, Muhurtas, and half lunar days, all of them in its white and black halves, and the lords of the eclipse "Parvas" and "Manvantaras", each in its chapter. What remains of that, we mention now. We say that the Indians do not go regarding the "Lord of the Year" to what the people of the West go to in extracting it...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...from the Ascendant of the Year, and its conditions are known. But he is the owner of a turn of time, and the state of the owner of the Month is like it. They are measured on the turns of the lords of hours and days. If you intend to know the Lord of the Year, obtain the days of the date according to what is in the Zij "Khandakhadyaka", for it is the one used among their majority. Subtract from them 2201 and divide the remainder by 360. Multiply the result by three and always add three to the sum. Cast away weeks from the total. What remains is not more than a week; count it from Sunday. The day you end at, its lord is the Lord of the Year. What remains from the division are the past days of his management. As for the remaining ones, they are the completion of the past to three hundred and sixty. Whether you do what we mentioned or add to the mentioned days 319 instead of subtracting from them. If you intend the "Lord of the Month", subtract from the days of the date 71 and divide the remainder by 30. Add one to double the result. Cast away weeks from the sum and count the remainder from Sunday. You end at the day of the "Lord of the Month". What remains from the division is the past of his management, and its completion to thirty is the remaining of it. Whether you do that or add to the days of the date 19 instead of subtracting, then add two to double the output instead of one. There is no benefit in mentioning the "Lord of the Day" for it is obtained from casting away weeks from the days of the date, nor in mentioning the "Lord of the Hour" for it is obtained by dividing the rotation of the sphere by fifteen. Those of them who go to the "Crooked" (Seasonal Hours) divide what is between the degree of the sun to the degree of the ascendant in degrees of ascension by fifteen. In the book "Sarodhaya Mahadeva": Each of the thirds of the daytime and night has a lord. The lord of the first third of each of them is "Brahma", the lord of the second of them is "Vishnu", and the lord of the third of them is "Rudra". That is according to the system of the first three powers. The Indians have another custom, which is that they mention with the "Lord of the Year" one of the Nagas, I mean snakes, and they are names assigned for each planet. We have placed them in this table.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: The people attributed the wandering planets to the Sun because their matters are attached to it, and the fixed stars to the Moon because its Mansions are from their group. It is known among their astrologers and ours that the planets manage the lordship of the Zodiac Signs. So they also made lords for them from the spiritual beings; we include them in this table as in the book "Vishnu Dharma": [Table]

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: In this book also, the Lunar Mansions have lords in the form of the lords of the planets. We include them in this table: Table of Lords of Mansions [Table]

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: LXII. On the Sixty-Year "Samvatsara", Also Called "Shashtyabda". This Samvatsara, its interpretation is the years, and its meaning was the cycles of years based on the motion of Jupiter and the Sun, starting in it from its (Jupiter's) heliacal rising. It rotates in sixty years, and for that reason it was called "Shashtyabda", meaning sixty years. We have presented that the names of the Mansions are distributed over the names of the months; no month is devoid of having a namesake from the Mansions in its division. We placed that for facilitation in a table. When you know the Mansion in which Jupiter rises from under the rays and seek it in that table, you find the month dominating that year written to its right opposite it. Attribute the year to it and say it is the year of "Chaitra", for example, or the year of "Vaisakha" or others. Each one of them has judgments and rulings known in their books. As for knowing the Mansion of heliacal rising, "Varahamihira" said in the book "Samhita": Place the "Shakakala" and multiply it by eleven and the sum by four. Whether you do that or multiply Shakakala by forty-four. Add to the sum 8589. Divide the amount by 3750. What comes out is years, months, days, and what follows them. Add them to Shakakala and divide the sum by sixty. Great sixty-year Yugas come out, which are complete Shashtyabdas, and there is no need for them. Divide what remains by...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...five. Small complete five-year Yugas come out. What remains less is its name "Samvatsara", meaning the Year. Place it in two places. Multiply one of them by nine and add to what results half of a sixth (1/12) of the other place. Then take a quarter of what gathered; it will be complete Mansions and what follows them of part of the broken Mansion. Count them from "Dhanishta"; the Mansion you end at is the place of Jupiter's heliacal rising. Know from it the month of the year as preceded. These Great Yugas open with the rising of Jupiter in the beginning of the Mansion Dhanishta and the beginning of the month "Magha". The Small ones in every Great one of them have a system falling on a number of years, and it has a lord attributed to it. We have placed them in a table. Whenever you know the position of your year from the Great Yuga and find its number in the numbers of years at the tops of the table, you find opposite it below it the name of the year and the name of its lord. 1 2

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: Likewise, for all the sixty years there is a name individually, and for the Yugas there are names which are the names of their lords. We have placed them in a table. Finding the required from it is on the example of what preceded, opposite the number of the year from its name. As for the interpretations of the names and their judgments, they are long, and they are in the book "Samhita". 3 4 5

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: 1 2 3 4 5. This is the method recorded in their books. I have seen some of them subtract three from the date of "Vikramaditya" and divide the remainder by sixty, and count what remains from the beginning of the Great Yuga (Jovian cycle)...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...and that is nothing. Whether he does that or adds twelve to the date of "Shaka". A group from the regions of "Kannauj" fell to me who mentioned that the cycle of Samvatsara according to them is 1248 and that they are twelve, each one 104. His report implied subtracting 554 from "Shakakala" and entering with what remains into this table, to know in which "Samvatsara" he is and what passed of it: When I heard names of nations, trees, and mountains in it, I suspected them, especially since the premise of their need was deception and forgery like the dyed beard testifying against its owner of lying. I took precautions in questioning one by one, repeating the question, and changing the order. They did not differ in it. And Allah knows best!

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: LXIII. On What Concerns the Brahmin and What He Must Do Throughout His Life. The life of the Brahmin, after the passing of seven years of it, is divided into four sections. The beginning of the first section is the eighth year. Brahmins gather to him to alert him and inform him of the duties upon him and advise him to adhere to them and embrace them as long as he lives. Then they bind his waist with a girdle and invest him with a pair of "Yajnopavita", which is a thread twisted from nine strands, and a third single one made of cloth, taking from his left shoulder to his right side. He is given a rod to hold and a ring of grass called "Darbha" to wear on the ring finger of the right hand. This ring is called "Pavitra". The purpose in it is seeking good omen and blessing in his gifts from that hand. The strictness in it is less than the strictness in the matter of "Yajnopavita", for Yajnopavita is something he never separates from. If he puts it down so he eats or relieves himself without it, he becomes thereby a sinner whom nothing purifies except expiation by fasting or charity. He has entered into the first section until the twenty-fifth year of his years. I found that in "Vishnu Purana" until the forty-eighth year. What is obligatory upon him in it is to be ascetic, make the earth his bed, and devote himself to learning "Veda" and its interpretation, theology, and law from a teacher whom he serves throughout his night and day. He washes every day three times and establishes the fire sacrifice at the two ends of the day. He prostrates to his teacher after the sacrifice. He fasts a day and breaks fast a day, while abstaining from...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...meat entirely. His residence is in the teacher's house. He goes out from it for begging and alms from five houses only once every day at noon or evening. Whatever he finds of charity, he places before his teacher to choose from it what he wants. Then he permits him the rest, so he sustains himself with what remains of it. He carries to the fire its firewood from the two trees "Palasha" and "Darbha" for making the sacrifice. Fire is venerated among them and approached with lights, and likewise among other nations. They used to see the acceptance of the offering by the descent of fire upon it, and worship of idols, stars, cows, donkeys, or images did not dissuade them from it. For this reason Bashar bin Burd said: 'And Fire has been worshipped since Fire existed.' As for the second section, it is from the twenty-fifth year to the fiftieth. In Vishnu Purana instead of this fifty it is seventy. In it, the teacher permits him to marry. So he marries and establishes a household (Grihastha) and intends offspring, on condition that he does not have intercourse with his wife more than once a month following the woman's purification from menstruation. He is not allowed to marry a woman whose age has exceeded twelve. His livelihood is either from teaching Brahmins and "Kshatriyas", and what reaches him from it is by way of honor not by way of wage; or from a gift given to him because of what fire sacrifices he performs for others; or by asking from kings and nobles without persistence from him in request or dislike from the giver. There is always a Brahmin in the houses of these people establishing religious matters and good deeds in them, nicknamed "Purohita"; or from something he gathers from the earth or picks from trees. He is allowed to try his hand in trade with clothes and betel nut, and if he does not handle it himself and a "Vaisya" trades for him, it is better because trade is originally prohibited due to what enters it of fraud and lying. It was only permitted for necessity if it is unavoidable. The Brahmin is not obligated to kings what is obligated to others of taxes and duties. As for dealing in beasts, cows, dyes, and benefiting from usury, it is forbidden for him. Indigo dye among the dyes is impure; if it touches his body, washing is obligatory upon him. He continues to praise and read over the fire what is prescribed for it. As for the third section, it is from the fiftieth year to...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...the seventy-fifth. In "Vishnu Purana" instead of seventy-five it is ninety. In this section, he becomes ascetic (Vanaprastha), leaves the household, and hands it and the wife to his children if she does not accompany him to the desert. He continues outside habitation on the conduct he followed in the first section. He does not shelter under a roof, nor wear except what covers his private parts of tree bark, nor sleep except on the ground without bedding, nor feed except on fruits and plants and their roots. He grows his hair long and does not anoint himself. As for the fourth section, it is to the end of life (Sannyasa). He wears red clothing in it and takes a rod in his hand. He devotes himself to thought and stripping the heart of friendships and enmities, and rejecting desire, greed, and anger. He does not associate with anyone at all. If he intends a place of virtue seeking reward, he does not stay on his way in a village more than a day and in a town more than five days. If anyone gives him something, he does not leave a remainder of it for tomorrow. He has nothing but diligence on the conditions of the path leading to salvation and reaching "Moksha" in which there is no return to the world. As for what is obligatory upon him in all his life generally, it is acts of righteousness, giving charity and taking it—for what is given to Brahmins returns to the Fathers—and continuous reading and performing sacrifices, and maintaining a fire he kindles, offers to, serves, and preserves from extinguishing so he is burned with it after his death; its name is "Homa". And washing every day three times: at the "Sandhi" of rising which is dawn, at the Sandhi of setting which is twilight, and at noon between them. As for in the morning, it is because of the night's sleep and the relaxation of vents in it, so it is purification from occurring impurity and preparation for prayer. Prayer is glorification, praise, and prostration according to their custom on the two thumbs of the joined palms towards the sun, for it is the Qibla wherever it is except the South. Nothing of good deeds is done towards this direction, nor does one advance towards it except in every bad thing. As for the time of the sun's decline from noon, it is designated for earning reward, so he must be pure in it. Evening is the time of supper and prayer, and he is allowed to do them in it without washing.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: So the matter of the third washing is not like the first and second in emphasis. The washing obligatory upon him at night is only at times of eclipses for establishing their conditions and sacrifices. The Brahmin lunches in all his life twice a day at noon and evening. If he wants food, he begins by setting aside charity from it for a person or two, especially for the wild (ascetic) Brahmins who come at the time of Asr (afternoon) to beg. Neglecting feeding them is a great sin. Then for beasts, birds, and the fire. He glorifies over the remainder and eats it. What remains of it he places outside the house and does not approach it as it is not lawful for him. It is only for whoever happens to pass by of those in need of it, whether human, bird, dog, or other. The water vessel must be separate, otherwise it is broken, and likewise his eating utensils. I have seen Brahmins who permitted eating with their relatives in one bowl, while the rest of them denied that. He is required to dwell between the river "Sindh" towards the North and the river "Charmanvati" (Chambal) towards the South. He does not exceed them to the borders of the Turks and the borders of Karnata and the sea on the sides of the East and West. For it is mentioned that it is not lawful for him to stay in a land that does not grow the grass he wears as a ring on the ring finger, and in which black-haired gazelles do not graze. That is the description of what is beyond the mentioned borders. If he crosses them to what is beyond, he is a sinner and expiation is required of him. As for the lands where the entire floor of the house prepared for food is not plastered with mud, but a "Mandala" is made for each of the eaters by pouring water on a spot and plastering it with cow dung, the shape of the Brahmin's Mandala must be square. He who makes the Mandala claimed as a reason for it: That the place of eating becomes impure by eating; and that when finished, it is washed and plastered to be pure. If the impure place is not specified, all places are reckoned due to ambiguity. Five types of plants are forbidden to him by text: Onions, Garlic, Gourd, a root of a plant like carrots called "Ghrinjana", and another plant growing around their ponds called "Nali".

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: LXIV. On the Customs for Other than the Brahmin in His Life. As for the "Kshatriya", he reads the "Veda" and learns it but does not teach it. He offers to the fire and acts according to what is in the Puranas. If he is in the places we mentioned where a Mandala is made for eating, he makes it triangular. He governs people and fights for them, for he is created for that. He is invested with a single "Yajnopavita" of three strands and another single one of cotton. That is upon completing twelve years of his age. As for the "Vaisya", to him belongs agriculture, cultivation, tending livestock, and removing the needs of Brahmins. He is allowed to wear only one Yajnopavita made of two threads. As for the "Sudra", he is like a slave to the Brahmin, attending to his affairs and serving him. If he wants not to be without a Yajnopavita for asceticism, he wears the cotton one only. Every deed specific to the Brahmin of glorifications, reading Veda, and fire sacrifices is forbidden to him to the extent that if it is proven against him and the Vaisya that they read the Veda, the Brahmins raise them to the ruler so he cuts off their tongues. As for the remembrance of Allah and doing good and charity, he is not prevented from it. Whoever undertakes what is not for his class to undertake, like the Brahmin trading and the "Sudra" farming, is a sinner, even if the amount of his sin falls short of theft. They mentioned in their reports: That lifespans in the days of King "Rama" were long, determined, and known. Therefore, no child died in them before his father. It happened that a son of a Brahmin died while he (the father) was alive...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...so his father carried him to the King's door and said to him: This only began in your days due to corruption in the land and a vizier committing (sins) in your kingdom. Rama began investigating that until he was guided to a "Chandala" striving in worship and self-mortification. He rode to him and found him on the bank of the river "Ganges" having hung himself upside down. Rama strung his bow and struck his neck (or chest?) with the arrow, piercing it. He said: Here it is! I kill you for a good deed that is not yours to do. He returned, and the Brahmin's son placed at his door had come to life. Then other people below the Chandala who are not Indians are called "Mleccha", meaning impure ones, and they are those who kill, slaughter, and eat cow meat. All these are of the disparity of degrees in which some take others in mockery. Otherwise, "Basudeva" said regarding the seeker of salvation: The wise man equates the Brahmin and the Chandala, the friend and the enemy, the trustworthy and the traitor, indeed the snake and the weasel. If it is reason that equated, then it is ignorance that separated and differentiated. Basudeva said to Arjuna: If the cultivation of the world is the intended goal, and policy in it does not proceed except by fighting to suppress corruption, it is obligatory upon us, the assembly of the wise, to work and fight, not to complete a deficiency in us but for its obligation from the side of treatment and negation of ruin. Then the ignorant follow us in action like children follow adults without knowing the realities of purposes in actions. For their nature is averse to rational paths, and they are only used by force to work according to what their senses stir for them of desire and anger. The wise knower is contrary to them.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: LXV. On the Mention of Sacrifices. Most of "Veda" contains fire sacrifices and the description of each one of them. They differ in magnitude so that only great kings are capable of some of them, like "Asvamedha" performed with the animal (horse) released in the world grazing without hindrance, and soldiers follow it and drive it and proclaim over it: That it belongs to the King of the World, so let him who refuses that come forth to it. Brahmins are behind it establishing fire sacrifices at its dung. When it has roamed the regions of the world, it becomes food for the Brahmins and its owner. They differ also in duration so that only one whose life is long is capable of them, and that is nonexistent in this time. Therefore, many of them were suspended and few remained for use. Fire according to them is an eater of all things. Therefore, it becomes impure by the entry of impurities into it like water. Because of that, Indians are not lenient regarding both if they are with someone not of them due to their becoming impure by him. Whatever fire is fed of its share returns to the "Devas" because it comes out of their mouths. What the Brahmin feeds it is oil and various grains of wheat, barley, and rice he throws into it. He reads from the Veda what is prescribed for that if the sacrifice is for himself. He does not read anything over it if it is for another. It is mentioned in the book "Vishnu Dharma": That in the past of the "Daitya" race there was a strong brave man expanded in kingdom named "Hiranyakashipu". He had a daughter named "Diti" (?) who persisted in striving in worship and testing the soul with fasting and asceticism. She deserved reward...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...with a place in the high (heaven). "Mahadeva" married her. When he was alone with her—and it is the nature of "Devas" to prolong intimacy and delay ejaculation—Fire noticed the matter and became jealous fearing that a fire like them would be born from them. So he intended to disturb and spoil (the moment) for them. When Mahadeva saw him, his forehead sweated from intense rage until it flowed onto the earth. The earth drank it and conceived from it Mars, who is "Skanda" the owner of the army of Devas. "Rudra" the Destroyer took the sperm of Mahadeva and threw it; it scattered in the belly of the earth which is the thin swampy part. As for Fire, he became leprous and sank from excessive shame and disgrace to "Patala", the lower earth. When the Devas missed him, they turned to seeking him and searching for him. The frog guided them to him. When he saw them, he left his place and hid in the "Ashvattha" tree and cursed the frog to be lacking in croaking, hated by hearts. Then the parrot guided them to his place, so he cursed it with the inversion of the tongue so that its root is towards its tip. The Deva said to it: If your tongue is inverted, be speaking with human speech and eating good things. Fire fled from the Ashvattha tree to the "Sami" tree. The elephant pointed him out, so he cursed it also with the inversion of the tongue. The Deva said to it: If your tongue is inverted, be sharing with humans in their foods, understanding their speech. Then they stumbled upon Fire, but he hesitated to be with them while leprous. So they fixed him, removed his leprosy, and returned him to them honored. They made him an intermediary between them and people, taking their shares from them and delivering them to them.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: LXVI. On Pilgrimage and Visiting Venerated Places. Pilgrimage is not among the obligatory duties for them, but rather it is voluntary and a virtue. It is that the pilgrim intends one of the pure lands or one of the venerated idols or one of the purified rivers. He bathes in it, serves the idol, gives gifts to it, increases glorification and supplication, fasts, gives charity to the Brahmins, custodians, and others, shaves his head and beard, and departs. As for the venerated pure ponds, they are in the cold mountains around "Meru". What is in "Vayu Purana" and in "Matsya Purana" together of mentioning them: That at the foot of Meru is "Arhata" (?), a very great pond described with the light of the moon. The river "Jambu" exits from it, very pure, flowing over pure gold. At Mount "Sveta" is the pond "Uttaramansa"; around it are twelve ponds, each like a lake, from which the rivers "Sandhi" (?) and "Madvayi" (?) exit to "Kimpurusha". At Mount "Nila" is the pond "Piyoda" (?) possessing lotus. At Mount "Nishadha" is the pond "Vishnupada"; the valley "Sarasvati", which is "Sarsat", exits from it, and the river "Gandharva" also exits from it. In Mount "Kailasa" is the pond "Manda", great like a sea; the river "Mandakini" exits from it. Between the North and East of "Kailasa" is Mount "Chandraparvata"; at its foot is the pond "Acchoda"; the river Acchoda exits from it. Between the East and South of Kailasa...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...Mount "Lohita" [Lohit], and at its foot is a lake named after it, from which the river "Lohita Nada" [Brahmaputra] flows. South of Kailasa is Mount "Sarvapushadha" [?], at its foot is the lake "Manasa" [Manasarovar], from which the river "Sarayu" [Saryu] flows. West of Kailasa is Mount "Aruna" [?], perpetually covered in snow, impossible to ascend, and at its foot is the lake "Sailoda", from which the river Sailoda «1» flows. North of Kailasa is Mount "Gaura" [?], and at its foot is the lake "Bindusara" [Bindusarovar], meaning that whose sand is gold. Near it, King "Bhagiratha" practiced asceticism. That is because a king of theirs named "Sagara" had sixty thousand sons, all of whom were immoral and wicked. It happened that an animal of theirs went astray, so they sought it and continued galloping in search of it until the earth collapsed from the intensity of their galloping on its back. They found their animal in its interior standing before «2» a man looking down, lowering his gaze. When they approached him, he glanced at them, and they burned in their place and ended up in Hell due to their bad deeds. The collapsed place of the earth became a sea, which is the Great Ocean. Then from the descendants of this king was a king named Bhagiratha who heard the news of his ancestors and pitied them. He went to the mentioned lake whose bottom is ground gold and stayed there fasting his days, standing in worship his nights, until "Mahadev" asked him about his need. He said: I want the river "Ganges" which flows in Paradise, knowing that whoever its water flows over, his sins are forgiven. He answered his request. The celestial Milky Way was the course of Ganges, and it had become proud of itself and did not see anyone capable of it. "Mahadev" took it and placed it on his head. It could not move and became angry at that, surging and foaming. Mahadev held onto it «3» so it could not dive into him. Then he took a piece of it and gave it to "Bhagiratha" so he could make the middle branch of its seven «4» branches flow over the bones of his ancestors, and they were saved by that from punishment. Therefore, the burnt bones of their dead are thrown into it. The river Ganges was nicknamed with the name of this king who brought it.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: We have narrated from them that in the Dvipas (Islands/Continents) are rivers pure like the purity of Ganges. In every place described with virtue, the Indians build tanks intended for bathing. That became for them a craft in which they exaggerate, such that when our people see them, they marvel at them and are unable to describe them, let alone construct them. For they build them from very large stones, extremely well-fitted, fastened with thick iron clamps, as stairs like shelves. The step circles the sides of the tank with a thickness taller than the stature of a man. Then they make on the face between the two steps ascents like crenellations. So the first steps become like paths, and the crenellations are steps. If many people descended and others ascended, they would not meet, nor would a path be blocked for them due to the multitude of steps, and the one ascending in them can turn to other than the one the descender descends upon. Thus, the hardship of crowding is removed. In Multan, there is a tank in which they worship by bathing if they are not interfered with. In "Samhita" of "Varahamihira", there is a tank in Thanesar which the Indians seek from afar and bathe in its water. They claim that its cause is the visit of the waters of other honored tanks to it at the time of the eclipse, and that bathing in it for that reason substitutes for bathing in each one of them. Then he says, narrating: They say, were it not that the Head (Rahu) is the eclipser of the two luminaries, the tanks would not visit that tank. The fame of tanks for virtue is either by the occurrence of a great matter in them or a text mentioned in books and reports. I have mentioned speech narrated by "Shaunaka", transmitting it from Venus from "Brahm", that he was addressed with it. In that speech is the mention of King "Bali" and what will be done to him until "Narayan" sinks him into the lower earth. In that speech: "I only do that to him to remove what he desires of equality among people, and so they differ in condition, and the world becomes organized by that, and so they turn from worshipping him to worshipping Me and believing in Me." Just as the cooperation of civilized people does not occur except with difference so one of them needs the other, likewise Allah created the world different in natures, disparate in regions; one cold highlands «1» and another hot lowlands «2», one good in soil, water, and air, and another salty or putrid, stagnant in water, pestilential in air. Likewise...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...other differences in the abundance of blessings and their scarcity, and the frequency of pests and their lack, among what calls civilized people to choose places for building cities because of them. This is due to prevailing customs. But religious commands are stronger than them and more dominant over natures than customs and habits. Do you not see that the causes of these are sought and they are taken or rejected according to them, while the causes of those are left unsought, held onto by the majority through imitation? They do not argue in it with more than what the inhabitant of a miserable spot argues with if he was born in it and did not witness other than it, of love of the homeland and the difficulty of moving from the dwelling. Then if the preference of spots is from the side of a religious command, there occurs in those acting upon it what is not uprooted from their hearts forever. The Indians have places magnified from the side of religion, like the city of "Varanasi" [Benares]. Their ascetics seek it and stick to it like the sticking of those residing in Mecca to the Kaaba. They are eager that their deaths come «1» to them in it so their outcome after death is good. They say that the shedder of blood is held accountable for his sin, requited for his crime, unless he enters the city of Varanasi, where he attains pardon and forgiveness. They claim regarding its cause: That "Brahm" was possessing four heads in form, and that an evil occurred between him and "Shankar", who is "Mahadev", leading to a dispute between them in which he plucked one of those heads from him. The custom at that time was that the head of the slain be taken by the hand of the slayer and remain suspended from it for disgrace and sign. Likewise, it adhered «2», so the head of Brahm stuck to the hand of Mahadev. He used to roam with it in his destinations and activities, not separating from it in whatever lands he entered, until he reached Varanasi. The head fell from his hand when he entered it and separated from it. Among the likes of those lands is "Pushkara". Its cause: That Brahm was establishing a sacrifice to the fire in it, and a boar came out of it. Therefore, they made his idol in the form of a boar. Outside the town in three places of it, honored tanks were made which are places of worship. Among them is "Thanesar", called "Kurukshetra", meaning the land of "Kuru". He was a peasant, ascetic, righteous man who worked wonders by divine power. The land was attributed...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...to him and magnified for his sake. Then the deeds of "Basdiv" [Krishna] happened in it during the wars of "Bharata" and the destruction of the corrupters in it, so its status increased. Among them is the city of "Mathura", filled with Brahmins. Its magnification is due to the birth of Basdiv in it and his upbringing in "Nandagokula" near it. "Kashmir" is now sought. "Multan" was likewise before the destruction of the house of its idol.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
67 - On Charity and What is Obligatory in Property
Charity according to them is obligatory every day with what is possible. Wealth is not left until a year passes over it or a month passes, for that is referring to an unknown; man does not know if he will reach it. As for what he obtains from the side of crops or cattle, the obligatory in it is to begin for the ruler by paying the tax (Kharaj) which is due on the land or pasture, and the sixth as a wage for him for defending the subjects and protecting their wealth and harem. That exactly is obligatory on the common people (merchants/craftsmen), except that they lie about it and betray. Taxes are obligatory on trades for the like of it. All that we mentioned is dropped from the Brahmin, excluding others. Then regarding the yield after taking that out of the property, some of them see in it the ninth for charity, because he sees in a third of it saving so the heart is reassured by it, and in a third of it to be spent in trade to bear fruit by profit, and in the remaining third to give a third of it in charity and spend two-thirds in the house. The matter regarding what comes out of profit is on this rule. Some of them see dividing it into quarters: a quarter of it for expenditure, a quarter for adornment and establishing chivalry, a quarter for charity, and a quarter for saving if it is sufficient for expenditure for three years. If the quarter for saving exceeds this amount, he separates from it what does not fall short of expenditure for three years and gives the excess in charity. As for usury in money for money, it is forbidden. Its sin is according to the increase placed on the capital. There is no license in it except for the Shudra, on condition that the profit does not exceed one-fifteenth of the capital.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
68 - On the Permissible and Forbidden of Foods and Drinks
Killing is originally forbidden for them absolutely, as it is for the Christians and Manichaeans. But people crave meat and throw every command and prohibition regarding it behind their backs. So what we mentioned becomes specific to the Brahmins due to their specialization in religion and religion preventing them from following desires. Like the example in those above the bishops of Christians, of "Metropolitan", "Catholicos", and "Patriarch", excluding those below them of "Priest" and "Deacon", unless one of them became a monk in addition to his rank. Since the matter is on this, killing by strangulation and withholding breath was permitted in some animals excluding others. Carrion of the permissible animals was forbidden if they died a natural death. As for the permissible things, they are sheep, goats, gazelles, hares, the rhinoceros (Ganda), buffaloes, fish, water birds, and wild birds like sparrows, turtle doves, francolins, pigeons, peacocks, and what the soul does not loathe of what no prohibition was received about. The text on its prohibition is cows, horses, mules, donkeys, camels, elephants, domestic chickens, crows, parrots, and nightingales (Sharak), and the eggs of all of them absolutely, and wine except for the Shudra; for drinking it is permitted for him, but selling it is forbidden for him like selling meat. Some of them have said that cows were permissible before "Bharata" and among the sacrifices were those involving killing cows, except that it was forbidden after Bharata due to the weakness of people's natures to perform the duties, just as the "Veda", which was originally one, was made into four parts to make it easy for people. This is speech of little yield, for the prohibition of cows is not lightening...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...and license, but rather it is tightening and restriction. I heard others say that the Brahmins used to be harmed by eating cow meat because their lands are hot lowlands and the interiors of bodies in them are cold, the natural heat in them is lukewarm, and the digestive power is weak. They strengthen them by eating Betel leaves after food and chewing Areca nut. The Betel with its sharpness inflames the heat and dries the moisture of the lime on it, and the Areca nut strengthens the teeth and gums and astringes the stomach. Since it was so, they forbade it for its thickness and coldness. I think in that one of two matters: Either politics, for the cow is the animal that serves in travels by carrying loads and weights, and in agriculture by plowing and sowing, and in household management by milk and what comes out of it. Then benefit is derived from its dung, indeed in winter from its breath. So it was forbidden as Al-Hajjaj forbade it when the ruin of the Sawad (fertile lands of Iraq) was complained to him. Or, it was narrated to me that in some of their books: That all things are one thing, and in prohibition and permission equal. They only differ due to inability and ability. So the wolf is capable of smashing the sheep, so it is its food, and the sheep is incapable against it, so it became its prey. I found in their books what testified to the like of it, except that this is for the Knower with his knowledge if he attains in it a rank where the Brahmin and the "Chandala" are equal to him. If it is so, other things are also equal to him in refraining from them. So whether they were all lawful since he is dispensed «1» with regarding them, or were forbidden, he is not desirous of them. As for him who has a need in them due to the mastery of ignorance over him, some are lawful for him and some are forbidden to him, and the wall between them is set up.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
69 - On Marriages, Menstruation, Conditions of Embryos, and Puerperium
Marriage is something no nation is without, because it «1» is a preventer of the commingling deemed ugly in reason, and a cutter of the causes that excite anger in the animal until it incites to corruption. Whoever contemplates the pairing of animals and the restriction of each pair of them to a mate and the cutting off of the greeds of others from them, deems marriage necessary and contains fornication out of disdain for falling short of the rank of what is below him of animals. Every nation has customs in it, especially those among them who claimed a Sharia and divine commands for themselves. It is the affair of the Indians that marriage among them is at a young age; therefore the parents contract it for their children. The Brahmins establish the rites of sacrifices in it, and charity is spread among them and others, and instruments of joy appear. No dowry is named between them.
