Rather, there is in it for the woman a gift according to ambition and a present given in advance which is not permissible to take back unless the woman gives it willingly of herself. Nothing separates the spouses except death, as they have no divorce. A man may marry more than one up to four. What is above four is forbidden to him unless one of those under his hand dies, then he completes the number with another and does not exceed it. As for the woman, if her husband dies, she does not have the right to marry. She is between one of two matters: either to remain a widow all her life or to burn herself, and that is the better of her two states because she remains in torment for the duration of her life. Of their custom regarding the wives of their kings...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...is burning, whether they wish or refuse, as a precaution against a slip that might occur from them. They do not leave of them except the old women or those with children if the son guarantees the maintenance of the mother and her protection. The law in marriage according to them is that strangers are better than relatives. What is farther in lineage of relatives is better than what is near in it. As for what ran straight downwards, meaning the daughter of children and children of children, and upwards of mother and grandmother and their mothers, it is forbidden absolutely. As for what «1» deviated from straightness and branched to the two sides, of sister, sister's daughter, paternal aunt, maternal aunt, and their daughters, it is likewise in prohibition unless they are separated by generations of five consecutive wombs in birth; then the prohibition ceases with the persistence of dislike. Some of them view the number of women according to classes, so that the Brahmin has four, the Kshatriya three, the Vaishya two, and the Shudra one. It is permissible for each one of the people of the classes to marry in his class and what is below it, and it is not lawful for him to marry from a class above his class. The child is attributed to the class of the mother, not the father. If the wife of the Brahmin, for example, is a Brahmin, the child is likewise; and if she is a Shudra, he is a Shudra. But the Brahmins in our time, even if that is lawful for them, do not do it and do not exceed in marriage other than their class. As for menstruation, its maximum by visibility is sixteen days, and by verification it is the first four days. Approaching a woman in them is forbidden; indeed nearing her in the house is likewise, for she is then impure. If the four days expire and she bathes, she is pure and approaching her is lawful. If the blood does not stop from her, then that is not menstruation but rather material for embryos. It is obligatory on the Brahmin if he wants to approach women seeking a child to establish a sacrifice to the fire called "Garbhadhana". He only does not do it because he needs the presence of the woman in it, and shame prevents that. So it is delayed and combined with the one following it in the fourth month of pregnancy and called "Simantonnayana". If the woman delivers her load, a third sacrifice is established between the birth and breastfeeding called "Jatakarma". He is not named with a name except after the expiration of the days of puerperium. The sacrifice of the name is called "Namakarma". As long as the woman is in puerperium, she does not approach a vessel, and nothing is eaten in her house...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...nor does a Brahmin kindle a fire in it. Those days are for a Brahmin eight, for a Kshatriya twelve «1», for a Vaishya fifteen, and for a Shudra thirty. For those below them, it is uncounted; it has no limited boundary in customs. The maximum of breastfeeding is three years without obligation. The Aqiqah (sacrifice for newborn) is in the third, and ear-piercing in the seventh or eighth. People think regarding fornication that it is permissible among them, as the "Ispahbad of Kabul" stipulated in the days of its conquest and his Islam not to eat cow meat and not to commit sodomy. The matter with them is not as thought, but they are not severe in punishment for it. The affliction in it is from the side of their kings. For those who are in the houses of idols are for singing, dancing, and playing; no Brahmin or custodian is pleased with them for other than that. But their kings made them an adornment for the cities, a joy, and an expansion for the subjects. Their purpose in them is the treasury and the return of what comes out of it to the army from taxes and levies. Such was the action of 'Adud al-Dawla, and he added to it the protection of the subjects from the bachelors of the army.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
70 - On Claims (Lawsuits)
The judge demands from the claimant the document written against the defendant in the known script «1» suitable for its likes and the proof established in it. If there is none, then witnesses without a document. Their number is not less than four and upwards, unless the probity of the witness is established with the judge, so he allows it and decides the judgment by the testimony of that one, without abandoning spying in secret and inferring by signs in public and comparing some of what appears to him to some, and using tricks to deduce the truth as Iyas bin Mu'awiyah used to do. If the claimant is unable to establish proof, the oath becomes binding on the denier. It is permissible to turn it to the claimant and accept it against him, so he says to him: You swear to the validity of your claim so I may extract it for you. Oaths are of many types according to the magnitude of the claim. For a small thing, with the satisfaction of the opponent with the oath, he says before five people of the Brahmin scholars: If I am lying, he has of the reward of my deeds what equals eight times what he claims against me. Above this oath: That drinking the "Bish" (Poison/Aconite) known as Brahmin be offered to him, which is the worst of its types; for if he is truthful, drinking it does not harm him. Above this: That he be brought to a river of strong flow and deep bottom, or to a well of deep depth and abundant water, and he says to the water: You are of the pure angels, knowing the secret and the public, so kill me if I am lying...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...and protect me if I am truthful. Then five people surround him and throw him into it. If he is truthful, he does not drown in it and does not die. Above this: That the judge directs both disputants to the place of the most honored idol of that city or kingdom. The denier fasts at it that day. Then he wears new clothes on the morrow and stands there with his opponent. The custodians pour water on the idol and give it to him to drink. If he is lying, he vomits blood immediately. Above this: That the denier be placed in the pan of a balance and balanced with weights equal to him, then he exits from it and the balance is left as it is. He calls the Spirituals, Angels, and Celestial Persons to witness his truthfulness one after another, and writes all he says in a paper and ties it to his head. He is returned in his state to the pan. If he is truthful, he outweighs the first weight. Above this: That ghee and oil dissolved equally are taken and boiled in a pot. A rose is thrown into it for the sign of reaching (boiling point); its wilting and burning is that sign. When it reaches its limit «1», a piece of gold is thrown into that pot, and the denier is ordered to take it out with his hand. If he is truthful, he takes it out. Then the greatest of oaths: That a piece of iron be heated to a limit it almost melts, and placed with tongs on the palm of the denier, there being nothing between it and the skin except a broad leaf of plant leaves under which are a few scattered grains of rice in their husks. He is ordered to carry it seven steps then throw it to the ground.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
71 - On Punishments and Expiations
The example of the situation among them is similar to the situation of Christianity, for it is built on good and refraining from evil, of abandoning killing entirely, throwing shirts after the usurper of the shawl, enabling the slapper of the cheek of the other cheek, and praying for the enemy for good and blessings upon him. It is, by my life, a virtuous way, but the people of the world are not all philosophers. Rather, most of them are ignorant, astray; nothing straightens them except the sword and the whip. Since "Constantine" the Victorious became Christian, neither of them «1» rested from movement (sword and whip), for without them politics is not complete. Likewise the Indians. They mentioned that matters of governance and wars were in the past to the Brahmins, and in that was the corruption of the world from the perspective that they conducted politics according to the requirements of the books of the creed of rational conduct, and that was not consistent for them with those of mischief and viciousness. The matter almost incapacitated them from undertaking what was to them of the matter of religion, so they pleaded to their Lord regarding it, until "Brahm" singled them out for what was to them and assigned politics and fighting to "Kshatriya". Therefore, the livelihood of the Brahmins became from begging and solicitation. Punishments among people for sins occurred from the side of kings, not scholars. As for the matter of killing, if the killer is a Brahmin and the killed is from other classes, nothing is binding on him except expiation, and it is by fasting, prayer, and charity. If the killed is a Brahmin also, his matter is to the Hereafter, and it does not suffice him...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...expiation, because expiation wipes out sins, and nothing wipes out from the Brahmin the major sins. The greatest of them is killing a Brahmin, and its burden is called "Brahma Hatya". Then killing a cow, then drinking wine, then fornication, especially with who belongs to his father or his teacher. However, the rulers do not exact retribution (Qisas) from a "Brahmin" or "Kshatriya", but they confiscate his wealth and exile him from their kingdoms. As for those below the Brahmins and Kshatriyas, if some of them kill others, it is expiated by expiation, but the rulers execute retribution among them for example. As for theft, the punishment of the thief is according to its magnitude. It might necessitate mutilation by excess and moderation, and it might necessitate discipline and fining, and it might necessitate restricting to scandal and publicizing. If the amount is great, the rulers blind the Brahmin or cut him from opposite sides (hand and foot), and cut the Kshatriya and do not blind him, and kill others. The punishment of the adulteress is to be expelled from the husband's house and exiled. I used to hear that he who flees from the Indian slaves returning to their lands and religion, fasting is imposed on him for expiation, and he is soaked in cow dung, urine, and milk for numbered days until he ferments in them, and he exits from impurity and is fed what resembles what he is in, and likes of that. I asked the Brahmins about it, and they denied it and claimed that there is no expiation for him and no license in returning him to what he was in. And how, when the Brahmin if he eats in the house of a "Shudra" for days falls from his class and does not return to it!

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
72 - On Inheritances and the Rights of the Deceased in them
The principle among them in inheritances is the dropping of women from them except the daughter, for she has a quarter of what the son has by a text on that in the book of "Manu". If she is not married, she is spent on until the time of marriage, and her dowry (trousseau) is from her inheritance. Then spending on her is cut off at that time. As for the wife, if she does not burn herself and chooses life, her provision and clothing are on the heir as long as she remains. The debts of the deceased are on the heir; he pays them from what he inherited or from his own money, whether the deceased left something or did not leave. Likewise, the mentioned expenses are binding on him in any case. The principle regarding heirs, and they are males inevitably, is that the lower from the deceased is more confirmed in matter and more entitled to inheritance than the one above him. I mean that the son and his children are more entitled than the father and grandfathers. Then what is in one side of low and high, the closer to the deceased is more entitled than the farther from him. I mean that the son is more entitled than the son's son, and the father is more entitled than the grandfather. What deviated from lineal straightness like brothers is weaker and they do not inherit except upon the lack of the stronger. It is known from that that the daughter's son is more entitled than the sister's son, and the brother's son is more entitled than both. If they are a number in one genus like sons or brothers, the division among them is equal. Their hermaphrodite is in the group of males. If the deceased has no heir, the estate goes to the treasury of the ruler, unless the deceased is a Brahmin, for the ruler has no way to his estate, but it is for charity only. As for what is binding on the heir to establish of the rights of the deceased in the first year, it is sixteen banquets in which he feeds and gives charity from it on each of...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...the eleventh day and the fifteenth from the day of his death, and once in every month. The one in the sixth of months has an advantage over others in multitude and quality. And a day before the completion of the year, and it is for him and the ancestors. Then the conclusion of the year, and his rights have ended with its end. If the heir is a son, mourning and grief and avoiding women are obligatory on him throughout this year if he is a legitimate son and from a good planting. It must be known that food is forbidden to the heirs for one day from the beginning of this year. It is obligatory on them, along with what we mentioned of the sixteen charities, to prepare above the door of the house something like a shelf protruding from the wall open to the sky, placing on it every day a bowl of cooked food and a jug of water until the completion of ten days from the time of death, lest the spirit has not settled yet and wanders around the house in hunger or thirst. "Socrates" pointed to something close to it in the book "Phaedo" regarding the soul hovering around graves due to what remnants of bodily love might be in it, and in his saying: It has been said regarding the soul that it is its habit to gather from each of the members of the body something that joins and becomes its dwelling in this world and in the one after it when it separates from the body and dissolves from it by its death. Then on the tenth of these days, much food and cold water are given in charity in his name. After the eleventh day, every day food sufficient for one soul and a dirham with it is directed to the house of a "Brahmin", and that is continued throughout the days of the year and not cut off until its end.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
73 - On the Right of the Deceased in his Body and the Living in their Bodies
The bodies of the dead in the past first times used to be pushed to the sky by throwing them in the deserts exposed to it. The sick were taken out to them and to the mountains and left in them. If they died, they were as we said; and if they recovered, they returned by themselves to their homes. Then there came after that he who «1» undertook establishing the laws and ordered them to push them to the wind. So they turned to building houses for them, roofed with netted walls from which the wind blows on them, on the example of the condition in the Towers of Silence (Nawawis) of the Magians. They stayed on that for a time until "Narayan" prescribed for them pushing them to the fire. So since that time they burn them, and nothing remains of them of filth or rot or smell but vanishes quickly and is hardly remembered. The Slavs in our time burn the dead. It is imagined from the side of the Greeks that they were among them between burning and burial. "Socrates" said in the book "Phaedo" when "Crito" asked him in what manner to bury him, so he said: However you wish if you can catch me and I do not flee from you. Then he said to those around him: Guarantee me to Crito the opposite of the guarantee he gave for me to the judges, for he guaranteed that I would stay, and you guarantee that I will not stay after death, but go, so it becomes easy for Crito when he sees my body being burned or buried, so he does not panic and say: That Socrates is being taken out or burned or buried. And you, O Crito, be reassured in burying...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...my body, and do that as you love, especially according to the laws. "Galen" said in his commentary on the Covenants of "Hippocrates": That it is famous of the matter of "Asclepius «1»" that he fell to the angels in a column of fire, as is said of "Dionysus" and "Heracles" and others who were concerned with benefiting people and strove. It is said that Allah did that to them so «2» the dead earthly part of them perishes by fire, then He attracts after that their part which does not accept death and lifts their souls to the sky. This is an indication to burning, and it seems it was only for the great ones. Likewise, the Indians say that in man is a point by which man is man, and it is the one that is liberated upon the dissolution of the mixtures by burning and their scattering. They saw in this return that some of it is by the ray of the sun to which the spirit clings and ascends, and some of it is by the flame of fire and its lifting it. As some of them used to pray that Allah makes his path to Him on a straight line because it is the shortest of distances, and to the height there is only fire or ray. The Ghuzz Turks went to what resembles it regarding the drowned; they place his carcass on a bed on the bank and hang a rope from its leg and throw its end in the water so his spirit ascends by it for resurrection. Then the saying of "Basdiv" strengthened the belief of the Indians in that regarding the sign of the liberated from the bond: That his death is in "Uttarayana" in the white half of the month in what is from a lighted lamp, meaning between Conjunction and Opposition in one of the two seasons of winter and spring. To this "Mani" went in his saying: That the people of creeds shame us that we prostrate to the sun and moon and set them up like an idol, because they did not know their reality and that they are our passage and the door of our exit to the world of our being, as Jesus testified to that, he claimed. They said: And the Buddha ordered sending the corpses of the dead in flowing water; therefore the Shamaniyya his companions throw them in rivers. As for the Indians, they see of the right of the corpse of the deceased on the heirs that it be washed, perfumed, shrouded, then burned with what is possible of sandalwood or wood. Some of his burnt bones are carried to the river "Ganges" and thrown...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...into it to flow over them as it flowed over the burnt bones of the sons of "Sagara" and saved them from Hell and obtained them in Paradise. The rest of his ashes are thrown in some flowing valleys. The place of his burning is plastered with a structure like a milestone over it. Of children, he whose age falls short of three is not burned. Then he who undertakes that washes with his clothes for two days because of the impurity of the deceased. Whoever is unable to burn inclines with it to throwing in the desert or in flowing water. As for the right of the living in his body, no one inclines in it to burning except the widow who prefers following her husband, or the one who tired of his life and became weary of his body due to an incurable disease and permanent disability or old age and weakness. Then a virtuous one does not do it with that; rather a "Vaishya" or "Shudra" prefers it in hopeful virtuous times seeking a state better than what he is in upon return. That is not permissible by text for a Brahmin or "Kshatriya". For this reason, he who kills himself among them kills it at the times of eclipse or hires someone to drown him in the river "Ganges" and undertakes holding him until he dies. At the confluence of the rivers "Jumna" and Ganges is a great tree known as Prayaga of the genus of trees called "Bar" (Banyan). Its property is that two types of branches emerge from its branches: one to the top as for other trees, and the other to the bottom in the form of roots without leaves. If it enters the ground, it becomes for the branch like a pillar. That was prepared for it due to the excessive spreading of its branches. At this mentioned tree, those people kill themselves by climbing it and throwing themselves into the water of Ganges. Yahya al-Nahwi narrated that a people in the Jahiliyyah (Ignorance) of the Greeks, I name them he claimed devil worshippers, used to strike their limbs with their swords and throw themselves into fires and did not suffer pain by them. Just as we narrated about the Indians, so "Socrates" said equally: It is not appropriate for anyone to kill himself before the gods cause «1» for him a compulsion and coercion like that which attends us now. He also said: That we, the assembly of people, are like those in a prison, and that it is not appropriate that we flee «2» nor that we release ourselves from it, for the gods care for us because we, the assembly of people, are servants to them.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
74 - On Fasting and its Types
Fasting, all of it, according to them is voluntary and supererogatory; none of it is obligatory. Fasting is abstaining from food for some duration. Then it differs according to the amount of the duration and according to the form of the act. As for the middle matter by which the condition of fasting is obtained, it is to designate the day fasted and keep in mind the name of whom he draws near to by it and fasts for his sake, of Allah or one of the angels or others. Then this doer proceeds and has his meal on the day before the day of fasting at noon, cleans the teeth by picking and miswak (tooth-stick), and intends the fast of the morrow. He refrains from that time from food. When the day of fasting breaks, he uses the miswak again, washes, establishes the obligations of his day, takes water in his hand and throws it in his directions, manifests the name of whom he fasts for with his tongue, and remains in his state until «1» the morrow of the day of fasting. When the sun rises, he has the choice in breaking the fast if he wills it at that time, and if he wills he delays it to noon. This type is called "Upavasa", and it is Fasting, because eating if it is from noon to noon is called "Ekanakta" and is not called fasting. From it is another type called "Kricchra", which is: To eat on a certain day at noon, and on the second day at the time of darkness (evening), and not eat on the third day except what is given to him unasked, then fast the fourth day. From it is a type called "Paraka", which is: To make his meal at the time of noon three...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...consecutive days. Then he shifts it to the time of darkness (evening) for three consecutive days. Then he fasts three consecutive days without breaking fast at all. From it is a type called "Chandrayana", which is: To fast the day of the Full Moon, and take on the day following it of food the amount of a morsel filling the mouth, and double it on the day after it, and make it on the third day three times it, until reaching the day of the Conjunction with this increase. So he fasts it, then retreats from the amount his food reached by decreasing morsel by morsel «1» until it vanishes upon reaching the Full Moon. From it is a type called "Masavasa" (Masopavasa?), which is: To fast continuously the days of a month consecutively, not breaking fast in them at all. Then they detail the reward of this fasting in the months upon the return after death. They say: If he continues the fast of the days of "Chaitra", he attains wealth and delight of the eye with noble children. If he continues "Vaishakha", he heads his tribe and becomes great in his army. If he continues "Jyeshtha", he is favored by women. If he continues "Ashadha", he attains ease. If he continues "Sravana «2»", he attains knowledge. If he continues "Bhadrapada", he attains health, courage, wealth, and cattle. If he continues "Ashvina", he remains victorious over his enemies. If he continues "Kartika", he becomes majestic in eyes and attains his will. If he continues "Margashirsha", he attains birth in the best and most fertile kingdom. If he continues "Pausha", he attains high lineage. If he continues "Magha", he obtains uncounted wealth. If he continues "Phalguna", he returns beloved. Whoever continues all the months and does not break fast in the year except twelve times, stays in Paradise ten thousand «3» years and returns from it to a family of honor, high status, and lineage. In the book "Vishnu Dharma": That "Maitreyi", wife of "Yajnavalkya", asked her husband about what a person does so his children are saved from calamities and bodily ailments. He answered her that whoever began with "Dvitiya" (the second day) in the month of "Pausha", which is the second of each of its two halves, and fasted four consecutive days...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...washing in the first of them with water, in the second with sesame, in the third with sweet flag (Vacha), and in the fourth with mixed compound perfume, and giving charity in each of them, and glorifying with the names of the angels, and doing the like of that in every month until the completion of the year, no calamity or pest will afflict his children in the return, and he attains his desire as "Dilipa", "Dushyanta", and "Yayati" attained their desires when they did it.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
75 - On Determining the Days of Fasting
It must be known absolutely that the eighth and eleventh day of the white half of every month is a fast, except in the intercalary month, for it is suspended, inauspicious. The eleventh day is specific to "Basdiv" [Vasudeva/Krishna] because when he ruled in the city of "Mathura" and its people before him used to celebrate a day in the name of "Indra" in every month, he induced them to transfer it to the eleventh to be in his name. They did so, and Indra became angry and sent upon them rains like deluges to destroy them and their cattle with them. So "Basdiv" lifted a mountain with his hand and protected them with it, until the rains flowed around them not upon them, and his image was repelled (became ugly/unnatural?). So they marked that in a mountain near "Mathura". Therefore, this day is fasted with utmost cleanliness and its night is spent awake in the manner of obligation, even if it is not obligatory. In the book "Vishnu Dharma": That if the Moon is in the mansion of "Rohini", which is the fourth of its mansions, on the eighth day of the black half, it is a fasting day called "Jayanti". Charity in it is an expiation for all sins. It is known that this condition does not apply to all months, but is specific to "Bhadrapada" in which Basdiv was born on this day of it while the Moon was in Rohini. Due to "Adhimasa" and the delaying and advancing of years, the two conditions of the Moon's mansion and the day of the month do not coincide except once every few years. It was said in the mentioned book also: That if the Moon is in the mansion of "Punarvasu «1»", which is the seventh of the mansions, on the eleventh day of the white half...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...of the month, it is a fast called "Attataja" (Vijaya?). Acts of righteousness in it enable obtaining wills as "Sagara", "Kakutstha", and "Dhandhumara" were enabled by them and attained kingship when they did them. The sixth day of "Chaitra" is a fast in the name of the Sun. In "Ashadha", if the Moon is in the mansion of "Anuradha", which is the seventeenth of the mansions, it is a fast for Basdiv called "Devasayani", meaning that "Deva" is sleeping, because it is the first of the four months which he slept. Some of them add to the condition the being of the day the eleventh of the month. It is known that that does not happen every year. Whoever is of the sect of "Basdiv" avoids in them meat, fish, sweets, and approaching women, and makes his eating once every day, and makes the earth his bed without a mattress or elevation from it on a bed. It has been said regarding these four months that they are the night of the angels, excepted from its beginning a month for twilight and from its end a month for dawn. But the sun is then close to the beginning of Cancer, which is the noon of the angels, so I do not know how it connects to its two Sandhis «1». The day of the Full Moon of "Sravana" is a fast in the name of "Somnath". In "Ashvina", if the Moon is in Cancer and the Sun in Virgo, it is a fast. The eighth day of this month is a fast for Bhagavati, and its breaking is with the rising of the Moon. The fifth day of "Bhadrapada" is a fast [in] the name of the Sun called "Shat" (Shashti?). In it they anoint its rays and what enters from the windows with types of perfume and place on it herbs and flowers. In this month, if the Moon is in the mansion of "Rohini", it is the fast of the birth of Basdiv. Some of them add to the condition the being of the day the eighth of the black half. We have said that that does not last consecutively but happens [occasionally]. In "Kartika", if the Moon is in "Revati", the last of the mansions, it is the fast of the awakening of Basdiv from his sleep, called "Devotthani", meaning the rising of Deva. Some of them add to its condition being the eleventh of the white half. In it they smear themselves with cow dung and break fast with its milk, urine, and dung mixed. This day is the first of five days they call "Bhishma «2» Pancha...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...ratri". They fast them for Basdiv. In the second of them, they feed the Brahmins then break fast after them. In the sixth of "Pausha" is a fast in the name of the Sun. In the third of "Magha" is a fast for women excluding men, called "Gauri-tritiya", being a complete day and night. When they wake up, they donate the young camel.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
76 - On Festivals and Joys
"Yatra «1»" is the running in travel with blessing. For this reason, the festival was named "Yatra «1»". Most festivals are for women and children. The second day of "Chaitra" is a festival for the people of "Kashmir" called "Agdus" (Agodu?). Its cause is the victory of its king "Muttai" (Lalitaditya Muktapida?) over the Turks. According to them, he used to rule the whole world. This is their habit regarding most of their kings. Then they approximate his date as we mentioned, so their lying appears. Even if it is possible that an Indian takes over as a Greek, Roman, Babylonian, and Persian took over, but most of the reports close to us are as established with us. This mentioned one was the king of the land of India in its entirety, for they know no other than it nor other than its people. The eleventh day of the month is called "Hindoli Chaitra". They gather in it at "Devahara Basdiv" (Temple of Vasudeva) and swing his idol as was done with him in the swing when he was a boy. Likewise, they do in their houses all day and rejoice. The Full Moon of this month is called "Bahand" (Vasant?). It is a festival for women in which they adorn themselves and propose gifts to their husbands. The twenty-second day of "Chaitra" is called "Chaitra-ashtami". It is a festival and joy in the name of "Bhagavati". In it one bathes and gives charity. The third day of "Vaishakha" is a festival for women called "Gauri-tritiya", in the name of "Gauri" daughter of Mount "Himavant", who is the wife of "Mahadev". They bathe, adorn themselves, prostrate to her idol, light lamps...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...at it, offer perfume, do not eat anything, and play with the swing. Then they give charity on its morrow and eat. On the tenth of "Vaishakha", whoever of the Brahmins their kings summoned go out to the deserts and light great fires for sacrifices for five days until the Full Moon. Their lighting of them is in sixteen places, every four of them separately. A "Brahmin" undertakes the sacrifice in them to be four according to the number of "Veda". Then they return on the sixteenth day. In this month is the Vernal Equinox called "Vasanta". They extract it by their calculation, celebrate it, and host the Brahmins. The first day of "Jyeshtha", which is the day of Conjunction, they celebrate and throw the first fruits of crops into the water by way of blessing. Its Full Moon is a festival for women called "Rupa-pancha" (Rupa-panchami?). The days of the month of "Ashadha" are all for charity. It is called "Ahari". In it vessels are renewed. On the Full Moon of "Sravana", banquets are held for the Brahmins. On the eighth day of "Ashvina" while the Moon is in the mansion of "Mula", the nineteenth of the mansions, is the beginning of sucking sugar cane. It is a festival in the name of "Mahanavami", sister of "Basdiv". They offer the first of everything of sugar cane and others to her idol called "Bhagavati «1»", increase charities at it, and kill kids (young goats). He who owns nothing stands at it and does not sit, and perhaps kills whom he meets. On the fifteenth while the Moon is in "Revati", the last of the mansions, is the festival of "Puhai" (Purnima?). They wrestle in it and play with animals. It is in the name of "Basdiv" when his maternal uncle "Kamsa" summoned him for wrestling. On the sixteenth is a festival in which charity is given to the Brahmins. On the twenty-third is the festival of "Ashoka", and it is also called "Ahoi". The Moon in it is in the mansion of "Punarvasu", the seventh. It is for joy and wrestling. In the month of "Bhadrapada", if the Moon settles in "Magha", the tenth of the mansions, they celebrate it and call it "Pitripaksha «2»", meaning the half of the month belonging to the Fathers (Ancestors), because the Moon's settling in this mansion is near the Conjunction. So they give charity in the name of the Fathers for fifteen...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...days. On the third day of Bhadrapada is the festival of "Haritali" (Hartalika?) for women. It is their custom to proceed a few days before and plant from every seed in baskets, then place them on this day when they have sprouted. They cast rose and perfume on them and play all night. When it is morning, they bring them to the tanks, wash them, bathe, and give charity. The sixth day of Bhadrapada is called "Kaphashthi" (?) in which feeding is done. The eighth day, when the light of the Moon is half in its body, is called "Dhruva-griha" (?). They bathe in it and eat sprouted grains so their children remain safe. Women celebrate it due to pregnancy and seeking a child. The eleventh day of Bhadrapada is called "Parvati". It is the name of a thread the custodian makes from what is gifted to him. He dyes a place of it with saffron and leaves another. He estimates it according to the stature of the idol of "Basdiv", then casts it on his neck so it hangs down to his foot. It is a magnified festival. The sixteenth day, which is the first of the Black Half, is the first of seven days called "Karara" (?). They adorn the boys in them and perfume them, so they play with types of animals. When it is the seventh, the men adorn themselves and celebrate it. In what remains of the month, they return to adorning the boys «1» «1» in the late parts of the day, give charity to the Brahmins, and do good. If the Moon is in the mansion of "Rohini", the fourth, they call it "Gunala-hid" (?) and celebrate it for three days, showing joy by playing, rejoicing at the birth of Basdiv. "Jivasharman" narrated that the people of "Kashmir" celebrate the twenty-sixth and twenty-seventh day of this month due to pieces of wood called "Gana" (?) which the water of the river "Biyatta" carries in these two days to the middle of the Capital called "Adhishtana". They claim that "Mahadev" sends them in it. Among its properties, it is claimed that whoever reaches for it and wants to take it cannot grasp it because it moves away from him and distances itself. Those whom I witnessed of the people of Kashmir opposed him regarding the place and time and claimed that that happens in a tank called "Kudabashahar «2»" to the left of the source of the mentioned river, and that that is in...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...the middle of "Vaishakha". This is closer because Vaishakha is the time of the increase of water. In the matter is a resemblance to the wood of "Jurjan" which emerges at the time of the extension of water in its spring. "Jivasharman «1»" also mentioned that in the borders of "Swat" in the mountains of the region of "Kiri" is a valley which is the meeting of fifty-three rivers there, called "Traranjai" (?). Its water whitens in these two days, so they attribute that to the bathing of "Mahadev" in it. The first day of "Kartika", which is the day of Conjunction in the sign of Libra, is called "Diwali «2»". They bathe in it, adorn themselves, exchange gifts of Betel leaves and Areca nut, ride to the Devaharas (Temples) for charity, and play rejoicing until noon. In its night, they increase the lighting of lamps in every place until the air is illuminated. Its cause is that "Lakshmi", wife of "Basdiv", releases "Bali son of Virochana «3»", the King imprisoned in the seventh earth, every year on this day and brings him out to the world. So it is called "Bali-rajya", meaning the Emirate of Bali. They claim that he was in "Krita Yuga", the time of good, so we rejoice because our day resembles that time. In this month, if the Full Moon passes, they hold banquets and adorn the women throughout the days of its Black Half. The third day of "Margashirsha" is called "Guvana-batrij" (?). It is a festival for women in the name of "Gauri". Also, they gather in the houses of the wealthy among them and collect silver idols of Gauri on a chair, perfume them, play all night, and give charity in the morning. The day of Full Moon in it is also a festival for women. As for the month of "Pausha", they increase in most of its days "Puhal" (?), which is a sweet food they make. The eighth day of its White Half is called "Ashtaka". They gather the Brahmins for foods made from "Bast" (?), which is Orach (Sarmaq), and treat them kindly. The eighth day of its Black Half is called "Sakartam" (Sakatam?). They eat turnips in it. The third day of "Magha" is called "Mah «4» «4»...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...tritiya" (Magha-tritiya?). It is a festival for women in the name of "Gauri". Also, they gather in the houses of the great ones at the idol of Gauri and place at it types of fine clothes, good perfume, and clean cooking. In every gathering of theirs, one hundred and eight vessels of water in number are placed full, until when their waters cool, they bathe with them four times in the quarters of this night. Then they give charity in the morning and hold feasts and banquets. The bathing of women with cold water is general for the days of this month. At its end, which is the «1» twenty-ninth day, when three minutes of a day remain of the night, and that is an hour and a fifth of an hour, the masses enter the water and immerse themselves in it seven times. The day of Full Moon of this month is called "Camaha" (?). Fires are lit in it on high places. The twenty-third day of it is called "Mansartak" (?) and is also called "Mahatan" (?). They hold a banquet in it with meats and large black pulse (Mash). The eighth day of "Phalguna" is called "Purartak" (?). They make in it for the Brahmins from flour and ghee types of foods. In its Full Moon is a festival for women called "Udad" (?) and is also called "Dhola" (Holi?). They light fires in it in a place lower than the places of Camaha and throw them outside the village. In the night following it, which is the sixteenth and is called "Shivaratri", they serve "Mahadev" all night and keep vigil and do not sleep, and gift perfume and herbs to him. The twenty-third day is called "Puyattan" (?). They eat rice with ghee and sugar in it. The Hindus of Multan have a festival called "Samba-pur-yatra". They celebrate it for the Sun and prostrate to it. Its knowledge is that "Ahargana Khandakhadyaka" is taken and 98,040 is subtracted from it. The remainder is divided by 365, and what comes out is discarded. If «2» nothing remains from the division, it is the time of this festival. If something remains, it is the past days after it, and its complement to 365 is the remaining to the future (festival).

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
77 - On the Magnified Days and the Auspicious and Inauspicious Times Designated for Earning Reward
Days differ in magnification due to attributes added to them, like Sunday, for it is magnified among the Indians due to the Sun and due to the beginning of the week in it, like Friday in Islam. Among the magnified days are "Amavasya" and "Purnima", meaning the day of Conjunction and Opposition. Their cause is that they are two limits for the light of the Moon in extinction and fullness. They believe regarding this increase and decrease that the Brahmins perpetuate sacrifices to the fire for reward. So the shares of the angels from what is fed by throwing into it gather at the Moon from the Conjunction to the Opposition. Then distributing it to the angels and apportioning it begins from the Opposition until I reach the Conjunction; no remnant remains of it. We have also said that they are the two halves of the day of the Fathers and their night. So charity in them always is for the Fathers always. Among them are four days magnified because, they claimed, the entries of the four Yugas in the "Chaturyuga" which we are in were in them. They are the third day of "Vaishakha" called "Akshaya Tritiya", in which they claimed "Krita Yuga" entered. The ninth day of "Kartika", in which "Treta Yuga" entered. The fifteenth day of "Magha", in which "Dvapara" entered. The thirteenth day of "Ashvina", in which "Kali Yuga" entered. As I think, they are festivals by the names of the Yugas established for charities or establishing some customs like the memorials «1» of the Christians. As for the entry of the Yugas being in them in reality, no. As for...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...Krita Yuga, its matter is apparent because it is the beginning of the cycles of the Sun and Moon; nothing of their conditions is broken because it is the beginning of Chaturyuga. So it is the first of the month of "Chaitra" and the time of the Vernal Equinox together. Likewise, the rest of the Yugas, each one according to the opinion of its author. Because according to "Brahmagupta", the civil days of Chaturyuga are 1,577,916,450, the solar months in it are 51,840,000, the months of "Adhimasa" 1,593,300, the days of the Moon 1,602,999,000, and the days of "Unaratra" 25,082,550. These are the things by which analysis and synthesis run in dates. The orbit of the matter of the Yugas according to him is on tenths, and each one of these numbers has a correct tenth. So the condition of the beginnings of the Yugas is the condition of the beginning of Chaturyuga. As for according to "Paulisa", the civil days of Chaturyuga are 1,577,917,800, the solar months in it 51,840,000, the months of Adhimasa 1,593,336, the days of the Moon 1,603,000,010, and the days of "Unaratra" 25,082,280. The orbit of the matter of the Yugas according to him is on quarters, and each one of these numbers has a correct quarter. So the beginnings of the Yugas like the beginning of "Chaturyuga" do not depart from the first of "Chaitra" and from the Vernal Equinox. They only differ in the week (day). So there is no face then for what they mention unless they take it by interpretation. The times in which reward is earned are called "Punyakala". "Balabhadra" said in his commentary on Khandakhadyaka: If a Yogi man, who is the ascetic who intellects the Creator and prefers good and refrains from evil, persisted in his conduct for thousands of years, his reward would not catch up to the reward of one who gave charity in Punyakala and established its conditions of bathing, anointing, prayer, and glorifications. Inevitably, most of the preceding festivals are of this genus, for they are for charities and banquets. Were they not hopeful, joy and rejoicing would not be approved in them. Then of Punyakala are what are auspicious along with that, and of them what are inauspicious. Among the auspicious are the transitions of the planets from Sign to Sign, especially the transition of the Sun. These times are called "Sankranti". Their choicest are the two Equinoxes and the two Solstices. The best of them is the Vernal Equinox, called "Bikhuv" (Vishuva) and "Bishu «1»"...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...due to the exchange of the two letters and their alternation. Because these times pass with an instant of time, and making a sacrifice "Shanti" to the fire with oil and grains is needed in them, they made them possessors of width (duration) with a beginning for them when the eastern edge of its (Sun's) body touches the first of the Sign, and a middle when its center meets it, which is the time of transition by calculation, and an end when its western edge touches it. So from the beginning of this time to its end in the Sun became close to two hours. To know the positions of the times of the transitions of the Sun into the Signs from the week, there are methods. Among them is what "Simha" dictated, which is to subtract from "Shakakala" 847, multiply the remainder by 180, and divide the sum by 143. Days and what follows them of their minutes and seconds come out. It is the Origin. Whatever Sign the time of the Sun's transition into it is wanted in that year, what is opposite it is taken and added to the Origin, each chapter to its chapter. What is seven or more is cast from the integers, and the remainder is counted from the beginning of Sunday; so it ends at the time of "Sankranti".

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
Solar years differ in the week by one day and the fraction following the year of the Sun. Their sum genericized is the number which is multiplied by to find for each year its remainder. That which is divided by is the denominator of the fraction. So then the fraction following the year of the Sun according to this work is 37 of 143. The requirement of the magnitude of the year is 365 15 31 28 6. After it remains 102 of 143. I do not know whose opinion it is. For if we divide the days of "Chaturyuga" by its years according to "Brahmagupta", the year of the Sun comes out 365 15 30 22 30. So the Gunakara, the multiplier, is 4027, and "Bhagahara", the divisor, is 3200. It is for the like of that according to "Paulisa" 365 15 31 30. So the Gunakara is 1007 and Bhagahara 800. According to "Aryabhata" 365 15 31 15. So Gunakara is 725 and Bhagahara 572. What "Utpala bin Sahavi" (Bhattotpala?) dictated of that is built on the opinion of Paulisa, which is to subtract from "Shakakala" 918, multiply the remainder by 1007, add to the sum 79, divide the total by 800, and cast what comes out of the integers by sevens. So the Origin remains. The additions to it for every Sign according to what preceded are placed «1» in the table:
[Table]

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: "Varahamihira" claimed in "Pancha Siddhantika" that "Shadashitimukha" is parallel to Sankranti in virtue and reward which cannot be counted in multitude. It is the settling of the Sun in the eighteenth degree of the Sign of Gemini, the fourteenth of the Sign of Virgo, the twenty-sixth of the Sign of Sagittarius, and the twenty-second of the Sign of Pisces. The reward at the transition of the Sun to...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...the Fixed Signs is four times the rest of the reward. For each one of these times, the beginning of the time and its end are calculated from the radius of the Sun in the manner of the minutes of immersion and clearance in the eclipse. That is known in the Zijes. We do not present of their works except what we find strange or know that it did not ring in the ears of our companions who do not know of their works other than what is in their Sindhind. Among those times are the two times of the solar and lunar eclipse. In them, they claimed, all the waters of the earth become pure like the purity of the water of "Ganges". Their magnification of them reaches such that many of them kill themselves choosing death in the virtuous time. Only "Vaishya" and "Shudra" do that. As for "Brahmin" and "Kshatriya", that is forbidden to them and they do not do it. And the times of "Parva", meaning those in which eclipse is possible, even if it does not occur, they are comparable to the eclipse in virtue. And the times of the Yogas are like eclipses, and they have a separate chapter. When it happens within the civil day that the Moon is in the last of its mansions and moves to the one following it and completes it and moves in it to a third so that it is in that day in three consecutive mansions, they call it "Tryahasparsha" and also "Tri-harkasha" (?). It is inauspicious; they take it as an evil omen, and it is among the whole of "Punyakala". Likewise is the condition in the civil day that includes a complete lunar day, its beginning on the last of the lunar day before it and its end on the beginning of the one after it. It is called "Treyahkatata" (?). It is inauspicious, but chosen for earning reward. When a day is completed of "Unaratra", which are the days of Decrease, it is inauspicious and counted among the whole of Punyakala. That occurs according to "Brahmagupta" from the civil days in 62 and 50,663, from the solar days in 62 and 182, and from the lunar days in 63 and a fraction like the fraction of the civil, and the denominator for all of them is 55,739. According to "Paulisa", the fraction of the civil and lunar is 63,379, the fraction of the solar is 274, and the denominator for all of them is 69,673. As for "Adhimasa", the time in which its month is completed and its fraction is removed is inauspicious and not Punyakala. That is because it occurs according to Brahmagupta from the civil days in 990 and 3,663 of 10,622, from the solar days in 976 and 464 of 5,311, and from the lunar days in 1006, and the fraction and its denominator are like those for the solar.

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: Among the times are those to which inauspiciousness is attributed and are not marked with anything of the matter of reward, like the time of earthquakes. For the Indians strike the pots of their houses on the ground in it and break them, acting optimistically (or pessimistically) and to repel evil omen «1». And like what is mentioned in the book "Samhita" of times of crashing, falling (of stars), redness, burning of the earth by thunderbolts, appearance of comets, occurrence of what is outside nature and custom of wild beasts and predators entering villages, of rain coming out of its season, trees fruiting contrary to their time, the transfer of the properties of the sixths of the year from some to some, and the rest of what resembles that. In the book "Sravadhava" «2» attributed to "Mahadev": Indeed the Burnt Days, meaning the inauspicious, for this is their expression for that: are the second day of each of the white and black halves of the months of "Chaitra" and "Pausha". The fourth day of each of the two halves in the months of "Jyeshtha" and "Phalguna". The sixth of the two halves of the months of "Sravana" and "Vaishakha". The eighth of the two halves of the months of "Ashadha" and "Ashvina". The tenth of the two halves of the months of "Margashirsha" and "Bhadrapada". The twelfth of the two halves of "Kartika".

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
78 - On Mentioning the Karanas
We have mentioned the lunar days called "Tithi" and that each one of them is smaller in magnitude than the civil (rising) one, for the lunar month by them is thirty and by the civil ones is weightier slightly than twenty-nine and a half. Just as they were called days, likewise the first half of each one was called a day for it and the last a night. Each one has a name, and their total is "Karana". Of those names are what come once and do not return, and they are around the Conjunction. Their number is four, and they are called "Fixed" from the perspective that they are not in the month except once and from the perspective that their positions do not differ by day and night. Of them are what rotate and come in the month eight times. They are called "Moving" because of their rotation and because each one of them comes in the day and in the night together. Their number is seven. The last of them, the seventh, is the inauspicious one (Vishti/Bhadra) by which boys are frightened and by whose name children turn gray. We have investigated their matter in other than this book. No arithmetic book of the Indians is devoid of mentioning them. If you want to know them, precede with knowing the lunar days and the position of the assumed time in them. That is to subtract the corrected Sun from the corrected Moon. The distance between them remains. If it is less than six Signs, you are in the White Half, and if it is more, you are in the Black. Then genericize it into minutes and divide them by 720. So "Tithi" comes out, which are the complete lunar days. What remains, multiply it by sixty and divide what reached by the adjusted Bhukti (daily motion). So "Ghati" and what follows it past of the broken day come out. This is according to what is in their Zijes. It is obligatory in the distance between the two corrected ones to divide also by the adjusted Bhukti, except that that is impossible in what is much of days. Therefore, it was divided by...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
...the difference between the two motions of the two luminaries for a day, on [the basis] that that of the Moon is thirteen degrees and that of the Sun is one degree. It is preferred in the likes of these laws, and especially the Indian ones, to use the mean motion. So subtract the mean Sun from the mean Moon and divide the remainder by 732, which is the difference between their two mean Bhuktis. The days and Ghatis come out by it. The name of Bhukti is from their language; it is "Bhukti". If it is by the corrected motion, it is "Bhukti Sphuta". If it is by the mean, it is "Bhukti Madhyama". The adjusted Bhukti is "Bhukti Antara", meaning the difference between the two Bhuktis. The lunar days in the month have names I have deposited in the table. If you know the lunar day you are in, you find at its number the name of the day and opposite it the Karana you are in. If the past of the broken day is less than half of it, the Karana is the daily one. If the past is more than half of it, it is the nightly one. This is the table: «1»
