text: 1 2. And knowing it by calculation is to subtract the corrected position of the Sun from the corrected position of the Moon, convert the remainder into minutes, and divide them by three hundred and sixty. Complete 'Karanas' come out. Multiply the remainder by sixty and divide it by the modified daily motion ('Bhukti'). What has passed of the [current] incomplete Karana comes out...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...and each one of it is half a 'Ghati'. Then return to the complete Karanas. If they are two or less, you are in the second of them; add one to it and count the sum from 'Chatushpada'. If it is fifty-nine, you are in 'Sakuni'. If it is less than fifty-nine and more than two, add one to it and cast away weeks (divide by seven). Count the remainder from the beginning of the cycle of the moving ones, which is 'Bava'. You end at the name of the broken Karana you are in. If you want me to remind you of its matter which you might have forgotten, know that Al-Kindi and his likes stumbled upon it without detail, and did not verify the subject of those using it. They attributed it sometimes to the Indians and sometimes to the people of 'Babylon' [Babylon, Iraq], distorted from its laws and misspelled. Then they applied an analogy to it that is better organized than the subject itself in origin, so it became something else. That is, they started from the Conjunction (New Moon) by half a day, half a day. They made the first twelve hours for the Sun, burnt and inauspicious, then the like for Venus, then for Mercury, and so on according to the order of the spheres. Whenever the turn returned to the Sun, they called its twelve hours 'hours of Vishti' (Visti), which is 'Bhadra'. But the Indians do not measure its times by civil days but by lunar days, and they do not start with this burnt one from the Conjunction. According to Al-Kindi's analogy, they start after the Conjunction with Jupiter, so the turns of the Sun are not burnt. If he started in the Indian subject after the Conjunction with the Sun, the hours of 'Bhadra' would belong to Mercury. Therefore, let this be separate and that be separate. Because 'Bhadra' occurs eight times in the month and the directions in the horizon are eight, we place in a table what they said about it, which astrologers are not free from the likes of, regarding the forms of the planets and what rises in the thirds of the Signs: 1

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: LXXIX. On the Mention of the Yogas. These are times the Indians consider very inauspicious, and they refrain from actions during them. They are many; we will mention them. However, the agreed-upon ones among them are two. One is the existence of the two luminaries together on two declination circles... meaning every two circles whose declinations are in one direction are equal; this is called 'Vyatipata'. And their existence together on two equal circles, meaning every two circles whose declinations are in two different directions are equal; this is called 'Vaidhrita'. The sign of the first is the sum of the corrected positions of the two luminaries from the beginning of Aries being exactly six signs. The sign of the second is this sum being exactly twelve signs. If they are corrected for a specific time and their corrected positions added, if it is like one of the two signs, it is the time of one of them. If the sum falls short of the amount of the sign or exceeds it, the time of equality is extracted by the difference between this sum and the limit set for it, and by the sum of the daily motions of the two luminaries representing the modified daily motion, similar to the operation of the time of Conjunction and Opposition in the Zijes (Astronomical Tables). If the distance of the time from noon or midnight—whichever the correction was based on—is known, its time is called the 'Mean', because if the Moon adhered to the ecliptic as the Sun adheres to it, this time would be the required one. But it has latitude from it, so at this time it is not on the declination circle of the Sun or the circle equal to it by vision. Therefore, the positions of the two luminaries and the Node are extracted for the Mean time, and the declination of the Sun and Moon is calculated for it. If they are equal, it is...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...the required time. Otherwise, look at the declination of the Moon. If its latitude was added to the declination of its degree in its calculation, subtract the latitude of the Moon from the declination of the Sun. If its latitude was subtracted from the declination of its degree, add its latitude to the declination of the Sun. Then find the arc of the result in the units of declination, and preserve this arc. It is the one used in the Zij 'Karanatilaka'. Then look at the Moon for the Mean time. If it is in the odd quadrants of the ecliptic, which are the vernal and autumnal, and its declination is less than the Sun's declination, then the time of equality of the two declinations, which is the required, is after the Mean, meaning future. If its declination is more than hers, then the time is before the Mean, meaning past. In the even quadrants, the matter is the opposite. Then 'Paulisa' adds the declinations of the two luminaries in 'Vyatipata' if their directions differ, and in 'Vaidhrita' if they agree. And he takes the difference between the declinations of the two luminaries in 'Vyatipata' if their directions agree, and in 'Vaidhrita' if they differ. This becomes the First Preserved, and it is for the Mean time. Then he places minutes of days 'Masha' (Matra?) provided it is less than a quarter of a day. He extracts for it from the daily motions of the luminaries and the Node their motions, and from them their positions according to its state from the Mean time in past and future. He calculates the Second Preserved from them. He identifies the state of past and future in it and compares it to the Mean time. If the time of equality of the two declinations is past or future in both, the difference between the two Preserved values is the divisor. If it is past in one and future in the other, the sum of the two Preserved values is the divisor. Then he multiplies the minutes of days placed in the First Preserved and divides the sum by the divisor. The minutes of distance from the Mean time come out, and it was established whether they are past or future. According to that, the time of equality of the two declinations becomes known. As for in the Zij 'Karanatilaka', he returns to the preserved arc of declination. If the corrected position of the Moon is less than three signs, it is it. If it is more up to six signs, he subtracts it from six signs. If it is...

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: ...more up to nine, he adds six signs to it. If it is more than nine, he subtracts it from twelve signs. The position of the Second Moon is obtained. Compare it to the position of the Moon at the time of correction. If the position of the Second Moon is less than it, the time of equality of the two declinations is future. If it is more than it, it is past. Then multiply the difference between the two Moons by the daily motion of the Sun and divide the sum by the daily motion of the Moon. Add what comes out to the position of the Sun at the time of correction if the Second Moon is more than the First, and subtract it from the Sun if the Second Moon is less. The position of the Sun at the time of equality of the two declinations is obtained. To know it (the time), divide the difference between the two Moons by the daily motion of the Moon; minutes of days come out, which are for the distance. Extract by them the positions of the two luminaries, the Node, and the two declinations. If they are equal, it is the required. Otherwise, repeat the operation and iterate until they are equal and the time is correct. Then extract the magnitude of the two luminaries, and cast away half their sum; half of the two magnitudes remains. Multiply by sixty and divide the amount by the modified daily motion; minutes of the falling (duration) come out. Place the time that was corrected in three places. Subtract the minutes of falling from the first and add to the last. The first is the time of the beginning of 'Vyatipata' or 'Vaidhrita', whichever the work was for. The second is the time of its middle, and the third is the time of its expiration. We have exhaustively investigated the proofs of these operations in a book we named 'The Imagination of the Two Eclipses' (Khayal al-Kusufayn) and verified them in the Zij we made for Syavabala (?) the Kashmiri and named it the Arabic 'Khandakhadyaka'. As for 'Bhattila', he considers their whole day inauspicious. As for 'Varahamihira', he considers inauspicious their duration which calculation brings out, and likens it to the wound of a gazelle whose arrow was poisoned; for its harm does not exceed what is around it, so if the poisoned spot is cut, the harm ceases. They have multiplied the number of 'Vyatipata' by the Mansions according to what 'Paulisa' narrated from 'Parashara', and its reference is to what he mentioned, for the species did not increase by it, but its particular individuals multiplied. Bhattila the Brahmin said in his Zij: There are eight times here having standards; if the sum of the corrected positions of the two luminaries equals them, they occur. The first is 'Gandanta', and its standard is four signs (120 degrees). (The second?) and its standard is four signs and thirteen degrees and a third. The third is 'Lata', which is the absolute Vyatipata, and its standard is six signs. The fourth is 'Chapas', and its standard is six signs, six degrees, and two-thirds of a degree.

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: and the fifth is 'Barha', and perhaps it is said 'Barha Vyatipata', and its standard is seven signs, sixteen degrees, and two-thirds of a degree. The sixth is 'Kaladanda', and its standard is eight signs, thirteen degrees, and a third. The seventh is 'Vyakshata', and its standard is nine signs, twenty-three degrees, and a third. The eighth is 'Vaidhrita', and its standard is twelve signs. These are famous but do not refer to a law like the return of the third and eighth of them. Because they are so, no duration in minutes of falling was obtained for them, but rather unknown estimations. The duration of each of Vyakshata and Gandanta, according to what Varahamihira mentioned, is one 'Muhurta', and the duration of each of Kaladanda and Barha is two Muhurtas. Then they also lengthened and detailed without benefit, and we have recounted them in that book. It is mentioned in the Zij 'Karanatilaka': Twenty-seven Yogas. Their calculation is to add the corrected position of the Sun to the corrected position of the Moon, make the sum all minutes, and divide by eight hundred. Complete Yogas come out. Multiply the remainder by sixty and divide the sum by the sum of the daily motions of the two luminaries. Minutes of days and what follows them come out, passed from the broken Yoga. As for their names and conditions, I wrote them from 'Sripala', and they are in this table: 1 2

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: LXXX. On the Mention of Their Introductory Principles in Judicial Astrology and Indicating Their Origins Therein. Our companions in these lands have not known the methods of the Indians in judicial astrology, nay, they have never looked at a book of theirs regarding it. Therefore, they think they agree with them and narrate stories about them of which we found nothing among them. Just as we pointed previously to a portion of everything, likewise we point in this chapter to what would be informative and facilitate studying with them. For if we intended sufficiency in that, the matter would be long, while we intend the summaries, not the branches. Let it be known first that their reliance in most judgments is on what resembles omens and physiognomy, and reversing the obligation of inferring beings from the seconds of the stars which are the events of the atmosphere. As for the planets being seven, there is no disagreement between us and them in it. They call the wandering planets 'Graha'. Among them are benefics absolutely, which are three: Jupiter, Venus, and the Moon, and are called 'Saumya Graha'. And three malefics absolutely, called 'Krura Graha', which are Saturn, Mars, and the Sun. The Head (Node), even if not a planet, is mentioned with the malefics. And one whose states change, so it is added to who is with it, benefic or malefic, and that is Mercury; if it is alone by itself, it is a benefic. We have placed the conditions of the planets in a table: 1 2 3 4 1 2 3 1

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: The purpose of what is in the table of order in magnitude and strength is that perhaps equality in indication and equivalence in powers and number of witnessing happens between two planets; then, the one among them who has precedence in this table is put forward, and it is said he is the greatest of them or the strongest. As for the months of pregnant women, it is the completion of the table. They assign the eighth month to the Ascendant of the falling of the sperm (conception). They claim that the fetus in it takes the subtleties of foods. If it completes them then is born, it lives; and if it is born before completing them, it dies due to deficiency. The ninth month belongs to the Moon and the tenth to the Sun. They do not exceed it in staying (gestation). If it happens, they claim there is an affliction in it from the wind. They look into the time of the falling of the sperm, known by reports not by extraction by calculation, at the conditions of the planets and their powers, and judge the months of their turns according to them. The matter of friendship and enmity among them is very strong, like the strength of the lordship of the House. Perhaps it transforms in time from the original nature. An example for it and its years will come later. There is no disagreement between us and them regarding the Signs being twelve and what planets follow them in Lordship. We have placed in this table what pertains to the complete Signs regarding conditions: 1 1 1 2

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: Exaltation in their language is 'Ucchastha', and its degree is 'Paramoccha'. Fall is 'Nicastha', and its degree is 'Paramanica'. As for 'Mulatrikona', it is a strength for the planet, which is what is resorted to in the joy of the planet in one of its two houses. They do not attribute the Triplicities to the elements and natures as is our custom, but they attribute them to the directions in general, and their detail is in the table. They call the cardinal Sign 'Chara Rasi', meaning the moving Sign; the fixed 'Sthira Rasi', meaning the stationary; and the bicorporeal (mutable) 'Dvisvabhava', meaning both together. We have placed in the table the conditions of the Houses as we placed for the Signs. They express in it the half that is above the earth as 'Chatra', meaning the umbrella, and the one below the earth as 'Nau', meaning the ship. And for each of the half ascending to the Midheaven and the half descending to the peg of the earth (Imum Coeli) as 'Dhanus', meaning the bow. They call the angles (cardinal houses) 'Kendra', what follows them (succedent) 'Panaphara', and the cadent 'Apoklima': 1

book_title: Verification of What is Said About India, Accepted by Reason or Rejected
text: These are the principles upon which the axis of judicial astrology truly revolves, I mean the planets, the Signs, and the Houses. He who is capable of extracting their indications deserves the label of graduated and advanced in his craft. Following them is the division of Signs into parts. The first of them is the 'Nim-bahras' (Half-Signs), called 'Hora' by the name of the hour, because the rising of half a Sign is in close to an hour. The first half of every male Sign belongs to the malefic of the two luminaries, I mean the Sun, due to masculinity; and the last to the benefic of them, due to femininity, which is the Moon. That is reversed in the female Signs. Then the thirds, called 'Drekkana' (Decans). There is no benefit in mentioning them because they are exactly what are called among us 'Darijanat'. Then the 'Nuh-bahras' (Ninths), called 'Navamsha'. Because they are of two types in the books of introductions among us, we mention what the Indians are upon to know the inciter upon them. It is to make from the beginning of the Sign to the minute whose Navamsha is desired into total minutes and divide by two hundred. Complete ninths come out, counted from the cardinal Sign which is in the triplicity of that Sign consecutively for every ninth a Sign. The one the turn of the fraction ends at is the owner of the required Navamsha. The first ninth of every cardinal Sign, the fifth of every fixed, and the ninth of every bicorporeal is called 'Vargottama', meaning the greatest of shares. Then the Twelfths, called 'Dvadasamsa'. Knowing it for the assumed place of the Sign is to make from its beginning to it into total minutes and divide the sum by one hundred and fifty. Complete half-sixths (twelfths) come out, counted from that Sign consecutively for every one a Sign. The one the fraction ends at, its lord is the lord of the twelfth of that place. After that are the Degrees, called 'Trimsamsa', meaning the thirty degrees, standing as the Terms (Hudud) among us. Their system is that Mars has five degrees from the beginning of every male Sign, then Saturn the like of it, Jupiter eight, Mercury seven, and Venus five. As for female Signs, the mentioned order is reversed in them, I mean...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: Venus has five degrees from the beginning of the Sign, then Mercury has seven, Jupiter eight, Saturn five, and Mars five. These are the principles they refer to. The condition of every Sign regarding the Aspect (Drishti) is the condition of the Ascendant that «1» rises above the horizon «1». Its law is that the Sign does not look at the two [signs] on its sides (2nd and 12th). Every two Signs between whose beginnings is a quarter of the sphere, or its third, or its half, correspond (aspect) each other. If there is a sixth of it between them, the aspect is only in the sequence of the Signs. If there is the sum of its quarter and its sixth between them, the aspect is only contrary to the sequence of the Signs. The aspect has ranks: That which is between a Sign and its fourth «2» or between it and its eleventh is a quarter aspect. That which is between it and its fifth or ninth is half an aspect. That which is between it and its sixth or tenth is three-quarters of an aspect. That which is between it and its seventh is a full aspect. They do not mention the aspect regarding two planets present in one Sign. As for the transformation of friendship and enmity, it is among their principles that if a planet happens to be in the tenth, eleventh, twelfth, the Sign itself, second, third, or fourth [from another planet], it moves from its state with it to a better one. If it was among its enemies, it becomes intermediate (neutral); if it was among the intermediate, it becomes a friend; and if it was among friends, it becomes a closer friend. As for in the other Signs, it moves from its state with it to a worse one. If it was a friend, it becomes intermediate; if intermediate, it becomes an enemy; and if an enemy, it becomes a bitter enemy. This is an accidental state in the moment, folded over the original one. Since this is established, we mention the four strengths that belong to a planet. The first of them is the Positional, called "Sthana-bala". Its attainment for a planet is by its being in its exaltation, its house (Mul-trikona), the house of its friend, or the "Navabhaga" (Navamsa) of its house, or its exaltation, or its "Mulatrikona", meaning its joy in «3» the line of benefics. The Sun and Moon are distinguished in it by being in the benefic Signs, just as the wandering planets are distinguished in it by being in the malefic Signs. The Moon specifically in the first third of its month helps every planet it looks at to possess this...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...strength. It is obtained for the Ascendant if it is a bipedal Sign. As for the second strength, it is called "Dig-bala", meaning the Directional, and also "Dik-bala". It is obtained for the planet by being in the Angle (Kendra) in which it is strong. Some of the people add to that the two houses adjacent to the Angle. It is obtained for the Ascendant by day if it is bipedal, and by night if it is quadrupedal; and at the two times of "Sandhi" (twilight) for the rest of the Signs. This is what pertains to Nativities. As for in Questions (Horary Astrology), they claim that this strength is obtained for the tenth [house] if it is quadrupedal, for the seventh if it is Scorpio or Cancer, and for the fourth if it is Aquarius or Cancer. As for the third strength, it is the Motional (or Victorious) called "Chesta-bala". It is obtained for the planet by retrograding and by emerging from invisibility (combustion) up to a limit of four Signs of visibility, and its declination to the North, except for Venus, for the South is for it like the North for others. The two luminaries are distinguished in it by being in the ascending half approaching the Summer Solstice, and the Moon specifically by being with the planets other than the Sun, so it prepares for it from them. This strength is obtained for the Ascendant by its lord being in it, if we look at the aspect of Jupiter and Mercury to it, and its freedom from the aspect of malefics and their presence in it except its lord; for the presence of a malefic in it weakens the aspect of Jupiter and Mercury to it until their utility «1» in this strength is nullified. As for the fourth strength, it is "Kala-bala", meaning the Temporal. It is obtained for diurnal planets by day and nocturnal ones by night, and for Mercury in its Sandhi (twilight)—and some of them claim that it has this strength perpetually because it is attributed to the day and night together. It is also obtained for benefics in the white half of the month (Waxing) and for malefics in the black (Waning). It belongs to the Ascendant always. Some of them add to the citation: because it is one of the four times of years, months, days, and hours. These are the strengths extracted for the planets and the Ascendant. Preference belongs to the one whose number of them is greater. If two are equal in the number of "Bala", the one who has «2» precedence in magnitude is prioritized. It is what is named in the table "Naisargika-bala", which is the order in...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...magnitude or strength. The mean years that are extracted for the planets are of three types. Two of them are based on the distance from the Exaltation. We have placed the magnitudes of the first and second types in the table. "Shadaya" and "Bisharkah Qaqa" (?) [act as] the degree of exaltation. As for the first, it is extracted if the mentioned strengths of the Sun exceed the strengths of each of the Moon and the Ascendant. As for the second, it is if the strengths «2» of the Moon exceed the strengths of each of the Sun and the Ascendant. The third type is called "Amshaya" (Amsayu); it is extracted when the strengths of the Ascendant exceed their strengths. As for extracting the years of the first type for every planet, if it is not at the degree of its exaltation, its distance from it is taken if it is more than six signs, and the completion of this distance to twelve signs if it is less than six signs. Then it is multiplied by its years placed in the table. So, months gather from signs, days from degrees, and minutes of days from minutes. They are raised to what they are raised to: every sixty minutes a day, every thirty days a month, and every twelve months a year. Its extraction for the Ascendant is that for every sign of the distance of its degree from the beginning of Aries, a year is taken, for every two and a half degrees a month, for every five minutes a day «4», and for every five seconds a minute of a day. As for extracting the years of the second type for the planets, it is that its distance from the degree of exaltation is taken with the condition that preceded, and multiplied by its years which are in the table, and done with what gathered as preceded. The Ascendant is taken from the distance of its degree from the beginning of Aries: for every "Navabhaga" (Navamsa) a year, and the months and what follows them according to that calculation. Then what resulted of years is cast twelve by twelve, and what remains not exceeding twelve is the years of the Ascendant. As for «5» extracting the years of the third type for the planets and the Ascendant together, it is like extracting the years of the Ascendant in the second type—I mean that it is taken from its distance from the beginning of Aries...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...for every "Navabhaga" a year; by multiplying «1» the whole distance by one hundred and eight. So months gather from signs, days from degrees, and minutes from minutes if raised to what they are raised to. If «2» the years are cast twelve «3» by twelve «3», the required years remain. The name "Ayurdaya" encompasses all these years. Before the equation, they are called "Madhyamaya", and after it "Sphutaya", meaning corrected. As for the years of the Ascendant in all types, they are corrected and do not need equation by the two types of reduction: one according to the place in the Ether «5» (Zodiac) and the other according to the position from the Horizon. The third type is distinguished by the equation of increase in one manner, which is that if the planet is in its greatest portion (Exaltation?), or in its house, or the "Drekkana" of its house, or the Drekkana of its exaltation, or the Navabhaga of its house, or the Navabhaga of its exaltation, or in most of that, its years become double the mean. If it is retrograde or in most of that, its years become double the mean. If it is retrograde or in its exaltation or both, the years become three times the mean. As for the equation of reduction in the first manner, the years of the planet being in its fall (debilitation) return to their two-thirds if they were of the first or second type, and to their half if they were of the third type. Its being in the house of its enemy does not impugn its years. The years of the planet hidden by the rays of the Sun (combust) from preference «6» return to half in the three types, except Venus and Saturn, for their combustion does not decrease anything from their cause. As for the equation of reduction in the second manner, we have established in the table what drops from the years of malefics and benefics by their being in the houses that are above the earth. If two planets or more gather in a house, [one looks] to the greatest and strongest of them in rank, so the reduction is attached to its years and the remaining are left as...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...they are. When two increases from two sides gather for one planet in the third type, one restricts to one of them, which is the greater. Likewise if two reductions gather for it. If an increase and a reduction gather for it, present one of them and follow with the other «1», for it does not differ. So the years become equated, and their sum is the life span of the owner of the nativity. It remains now to explain their method in turns (periods/Dasha). The life span is divided over these years. The beginning is from birth with the years of the two luminaries. The prioritized of them is the one with more strength and effect; if they are equal, then the one with more luck in its position, then the other follows. Following them is either the Ascendant or the planet being in the Angles (Kendras) with the abundance of strengths and portions. If several planets gather in the Angles, prioritize them according to their strengths and shares «2». Following them are the planets being in what follows the Angles (Panapara), then in the Cadent houses (Apoklima), on the example of what preceded, until the position of the years of every planet in the total life span is known. It (the planet) does not become independent with its years except for what «3» befalls it from «3» the partners, and they are the planets aspecting it. For they share with it in governance and participate in the division of years. As for the one being with it in one sign, its participation is by half; the one in its fifth and ninth by a third; the one in its fourth and eighth by a quarter; and the one in its seventh by a seventh. If several planets gather in one place, each one shares the fraction which the place necessitated. The method of extracting the years of partnership is to place for the owner of the years a one for the numerator and the like of it for the denominator because he takes over the whole. Then place for every partner the fraction of its denominator. Multiply every denominator of them by all the numerators and its quotient except itself and its numerator. So all fractions are obtained from a single denominator. Discard the equal denominators. Then multiply every numerator by the total years and divide what «4» is reached by the sum of the numerators. The years of "Kalamanuka" (?) «5»...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...planet come out. As for their arrangement after prioritizing «1», the philosophical ones «1» correspond with it, singular in governance. So on the example of what preceded of prioritizing who is in the Angles, the stronger then the stronger, then the one who is in what follows them, then the one who is in the Cadent houses. Their method in extracting the life span is known from what we mentioned. The quality of the state of division is known from the positions of the planets in the Origin and in the Time. Let us follow it regarding the matter of nativities with what others do not busy themselves with. That is that they look for the father at the time of birth, was he present? They infer his absence by the Moon not aspecting the Ascendant, or the sign of the Moon being confined between the signs of Venus and Mercury, or Saturn being in the Ascendant or Mars in the seventh. They look whether the newborn is legitimate. If the two luminaries gather in a sign and with them is a malefic, or the Moon and Jupiter fall from aspecting the Ascendant, or Jupiter falls from aspecting the gathered luminaries, he is illegitimate. They look into the matter of the lamp at the sign of the Sun. If it is movable (Cardinal), the lamp was moving, transferred from one place to another. If fixed, then fixed. If it was double-bodied (Mutable), it was moving once and resting another. They look at the ratio of the degrees of the Ascendant to thirty; according to it is the burnt part of the wick. If the Moon is full, the lamp was full of oil; then it is in it according to the amount of light in the body of the Moon. They infer the door of the house by the strongest planet in the Angles, for its direction is to its direction, or the direction of the sign of the Ascendant if the Angles are empty. They look at the planet in the house «2». If it is the Sun, the house is dilapidated; the Moon, sound; Mars, burnt; Mercury, arched; Jupiter, strong; and Saturn, old. Then if Jupiter is in its exaltation in the tenth, the house has two legs (pillars) or three. If its testimony is strong in Sagittarius, it has three; and in the other double-bodied signs, it has two legs. They look for the bed/couch and its legs (the third house) and its squares «3» and its length from the twelfth to the third. The corruption of the leg or the side is known from the malefics according to the malefic. If it is Mars, from burning...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...and if it is the Sun, from breaking; and Saturn, from age. The number of women present is according to the number of planets in the sign of the Ascendant and the sign of the Moon. Their descriptions are according to their (the planets') forms. Those of them being above the earth indicate those going out of the house, and those under the earth indicate those entering it. Then they look into the coming «1» of the soul (Past Life) from the lord of the "Drekkana" of the stronger of the luminaries. If it is Jupiter, his coming was from "Devaloka"; Venus or the Moon, from "Pitriloka"; Mars or the Sun, from "Tiryagloka" (Animal world - text says Burjak Loka?); Saturn and Mercury, from "Naraka Loka" (Hell - text says Park Loka?). Likewise, the look into the going of his soul after death (Future Life) is from the stronger of the lord of the Drekkana of the sixth and the eighth on the example of what preceded. If Jupiter is in his exaltation in the sixth or the eighth or one of the Angles, or the Ascendant is Pisces and Jupiter is in his exaltation in it, and the figures of the time of death agree with the figures of the time of birth, the soul is liberated and does not return. I only narrated this so that the contrast of the methods of our people and the methods of the Indians in astrological judgments is known. As for their methods in atmospheric and worldly events, despite their length, they are very weak. Just as we restricted ourselves regarding the matter of nativities to mentioning life spans, likewise we restrict ourselves regarding this art to the type of comets from the saying of the one among them thought to have superior attainment, so what is beyond it may be measured by it. We say that the name of the Head of the Dragon (Node) is "Rahu" and the name of its Tail is "Ketu". The Indians rarely mention the Tail; they only use the Head alone. All tailed stars (comets) occurring in the atmosphere are also called "Ketu" generally. "Varahamihira" said: The Head has thirty-three sons called "Tamas-kilaka". They are types of comets, whether they extend (have a tail) or do not extend. The judgment on them...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: ...is according to their shapes, colors, sizes, and positions. The worst of them is the one formed in the image of a crow, the one formed in the image of a beheaded man, and the one in the image of a sword, dagger, bow, and arrow. They are always around the luminaries, agitating the waters until they become turbid, stirring the atmosphere until it reddens, and shaking it until its storms uproot great trees and strike the legs and knees of people with pebbles. They shift the natures of time until the seasons of the year move from their places. So whenever misfortunes and evils multiply, such as earthquakes, crashes, inflammation of heat, redness of the sky, frequency of the noise of wild beasts and the screaming of birds, know that that is from the sons of the Head. If those conditions appear with an eclipse or the emergence of a comet, be certain of what you perceived, and do not occupy yourself in inferring by other than the sons of the Head. Point in the place of evil to their direction from the body of the Sun in the eight directions. "Varahamihira" said in the book "Samhita": I did not speak on comets except after exhausting what is in the books of "Garga", "Parashara", "Asita", "Devala", and what is in other books despite their multitude. Recognizing their calculation is impossible unless knowledge precedes the time of their appearance and disappearance, because they are not one type but many. Among them are the high ones distant from the earth which appear between the stars of the lunar mansions and are called «1» "Divya". Among them are the intermediate in distance which are between the heaven and the earth and are called "Antariksha". Among them are those close to the earth which fall on it and on mountains, houses, and trees. Perhaps a light is seen falling on the earth and it is thought to be fire; if it is not fire, it is "Ketu Rupa", meaning «2» in the form of a comet. As for the animals which if they fly in the air are like sparks or fires remaining in the houses of "Pishacha" (devils) and demons, or other shinings of jewels and others, they are not of the genus of comets. Therefore, knowledge of their quiddity must precede judging upon them, for the judgment is according to them. That which is in the air falls on banners, weapons, houses, trees...

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
...and on beasts and elephants. That which is from a Lord is seen between «1» the stars of the lunar mansions. If what appears is not from one of these two nor from the mentioned imaginings, it is a terrestrial "Ketu". He said: The scholars differed on their number. Some of them said it is one hundred and one, and some of them said it is a thousand. "Narada" the Sage said: It is one, but it differs by the multitude of forms; it sheds one and wears another. He said regarding the duration of their influence: It is months like the number of days of their appearance «2». If it exceeds a month and a half, subtract from it forty-five days; the remainder is the months of its influence. If it exceeds two months, make the years of its influence according to the number of the months of its appearance. The number of comets does not exceed «3» a thousand. He presented what we deposited in this table to facilitate contemplation, even if the cells of the table are not filled due to the deficiency «4» of what is in the book regarding the sections, either the original or the copy that fell to us. His intent in what he mentioned was verifying the ancients in the two numbers he narrated from them in it, so he strove until he completed the thousand:
[Table Columns 1-7 likely containing data about comets]

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text:
He divided comets into three sections: high at the stars, flowing at the earth, and intermediate in the air. He also mentioned from the high and intermediate section what is in our table, each one separately. He mentioned that the intermediate, if its light connects to the instruments of kings such as banners, parasols, fans, and fly-whisks, indicates the destruction of the rulers. If it connects to a house, tree, or mountain, it indicates the corruption of the kingdom. If it connects to the furniture of the house, its people perish. If it connects to the sweepings of the house, its owner perishes. He said: If a meteor swoops down obstructing the tail of the comet, safety ceases, and rains and trees attributed to "Mahadev" are corrupted—and there is no benefit in enumerating them because they are unfamiliar in name and body to us—and conditions are disturbed in the kingdom of "Gaur" [Gauda/Bengal], "Sata" (Sita?), "Huna" [Huns], and "China" [China]. He said: Look at the direction of the comet's tail, whether it hangs down, stands up, or inclines, and to the Mansion (Nakshatra) whose tip it touches. Judge corruption there and the attack of armies on its people «1», swallowing them as the peacock swallows snakes. Exclude from them what is indicative of good. Then contemplate in the remaining ones the Mansion in which their tails appear or which they occupy or reach. Judge corruption in the kings of the regions which the Mansions indicate and the rest of the things which are attributed «2» to them «3», and which the people of the Torah describe with our description of the Kaaba (Orientation/Qibla?). He mentioned in it regarding the meteor (falling star): That it is one of the rewarded ones whose duration in the high has expired, so he descended to the world «4». These are the two tables:
[Tables]

book_title: Tahqiq ma li-l-Hind min Maqulah Maqbulah fi al-'Aql aw Mardhulah
text: This is their method regarding comets and judging upon them. Few of them occupy themselves with verification like the occupation of the naturalists among the Greeks in researching them and the quiddity of celestial effects, for they are not free in them from the speech of the establishers of their creed. It was mentioned in "Matsya Purana" that rains are four and mountains are four, and their origin is water. And that the earth is set up on four elephants in the four directions, lifting water with their trunks to purify the crops, spraying them as rains in summer and snows in winter. And that smoke is the servant of rain; it rises to it and adorns the cloud with blackness. Because of the four elephants, it was said in the book of Elephant Medicine (Hastyayurveda) that among their males is what people advance as a trick so it is taken as an evil omen; it is a blaze in the herd (distinctive?), called "Manqana" (?). Among them is what presents one tusk, then there are among them those with three and four tusks, and they are of the offspring of the bearers of the earth. They are not interfered with, and if they fall into a trap, they are released. It was mentioned in "Vayu Purana": That wind and ray lift water from the sea to the Sun. If the dripping were from it, the rain would be hot, but it pushes it to the Moon so it drips from it and the world is revived by it. It was said regarding atmospheric events that thunder is the voice of "Airavata", which is the mount of "Indra" the Chief among elephants, when it drinks from the pond "Manasa" and becomes rutting and roars. And that the rainbow is the bow of this Chief, just as our commoners attribute it to Rustam «1». We see in what we have narrated sufficiency for him who wants to interact with the Indians and address them in demands with the reality of what they are upon. Let us cut the speech which has become boring by its length and breadth. We ask Allah for forgiveness in the narrations except for the truth, and we ask Him for support to hold fast to what pleases Him, and we ask Him for guidance to recognize falsehood to avoid it. Indeed, good is from Him, and He is Compassionate to His servants. Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and His blessings be upon the Prophet Muhammad and all his family.
